description:
Fantastic! The food, service, atmosphere - all were incredible. 

The $34 pre-fixe menu is so worth it. So much delicious food. It's meant to be shared so my friend and I made sure we ordered different plates so we could share. The seasonal fish was halibut and it was so delicious! Whatever the green sauce on the flank steak is was amazing and it was cooked to medium rare perfection. They also bring out a bread basket here with free refills (though we couldn't finish our one with all the yummy food we had)

Our waiter was phenomenal. He was so nice, helpful with the menu and explaining how sharing the plates are. He was great conversation, too! The staff was personable and we loved hearing the history of the restaurant. Longstanding and the menu hasn't changed much. 

I got to there a little early to meet a friend while I was in town. They asked me if a table in the front room was fine, I said sure, not knowing there was a patio. When my friend arrived a moment later she inquired about a patio table and the staff was so nice and accommodating! They checked if they had space and moved us back there no questions asked. The patio was gorgeous! I love the lights they have going on and it's heated, which was a plus.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Stopped in on a Tuesday evening with a friend and was disappointed with the experience. While the restaurant was not busy the service was slow (waiter walked by 4 times before we shouted at them that we were ready to order even though our menus were closed) and the food took much longer than expected. I ended up getting the lamb which was fine but the portions are small so we ended up heading somewhere else afterwards as we were still hungry. Took some more time to hunt down the waiter for a check.

Given the other positive reviews I'm  assuming the service isn't always like this so YMMV - but I will say that for what you pay and given the other restaurants in the area do yourself a favor and look at some other options before going here
author: Al D.

description:
Isa was pretty underwhelming for me and my family. Now, I can understand why it was pretty easy to get a dinner reservation during peak dinner hours on a Saturday.

I felt a big part of what I brought down my experience here was that our waiter talked too much and sold the food to be better than it actually was. It sucks to talk a big game and fall flat from the expectations you give people. The biggest plus for Isa is that it is convenient (no lines, waits, easy to make a reservation) and the prices are good.

That said, the decor and experience of eating here felt cheap, dark and uninspiring. My family ordered the top recommendation by our waiter: steak, pork chop, fish of the day, appetizers and the foie gras. 

Maybe it's because I'm now used to quality, dry aged meats, the steak and pork chop at Isa tasted dry, less naturally flavored, and over salted. The fish of the day was halibut, which was actually pretty moist except that its flavor was pretty bland without much dimension. Appetizers and desserts were both ok but were nothing interesting to write home about. The foie gras seems to be why people come here to eat and is actually highly recommended by the waiter. I wasn't planning to be blown away by it because it is hard to mess it up. That said, the foie gras that we had tasted older and somewhat off from ones I've had at other restaurants. I can't put my finger on exactly what but something about it was off.

For those of you who have a sweet tooth, you might enjoy the prix fix dessert selections. 3 out of the 4 options for us that night was cheese. Personally, I love cheese. My favorite was a soft triple cream Brie that was served with honey, grapes and walnuts. Nothing special, but it was tasty. The other cheeses were way too salted and heavy to end with. I felt their selection for dessert was a quite off. I don't remember much about the actual "sweet dessert." Their other dessert menu, not included on the fix menu, is probably the way to go.


Overall, my experience here was mediocre in terms of food and experience. Service is also slow and not well coordinated. Our appetizers were all served at different times and they served our entrees when our table was still working through appetizers, without much room. I don't think I'll be returning in the future, not even for the foie gras. That being said, if you're looking for a good deal (their prix fix is pretty cheap for SF, at around $30pp) and is a quick place to grab dinner when other sought-after choices are packed with people, Isa would be a decent option. However, if you're a pretty decent chef at home or have eaten at a lot of SF restaurants, you might not be that into or impressed by Isa.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Ambiance
Isa is a very lively restaurant right in the Marina/Cow Hollow region.  Definitely a place to chat while having food and drinks.  The space can accommodate some decent size groups.  However, it feels a little bit tight given it is in SF.  I'd be a regular visitor if I lived in San Francisco permanently.  

Food
We came during restaurant week in 2017 and the pre-fixed meal is delicious.

-$1 oysters: Good deal for $1.  We started with this before our pre-fixed meal.  
-Foie gras: Pear, toast and Foie Gras. Very good combo.  Foie gras is really tasty.
-Potato leak soup:  Somewhat creamy and tasty with the bread. 
-Butter lettuce: Some pepper and Italian type dressing with candied walnuts. The dish has blue cheese on top.
-Tuna: Sashimi style tuna with some jalapeño and sesame seed. 
-Carpaccio: The salmon didn't taste too fresh. The rest was decent. 
-Duck breast:  Very well done.  There is a nice sear on the outside.
-Steak: Impressive job done by the cook.  Super tasty sauce on the bottom and horse radish on top. 
-Creme brûlée:  Typical usual tasty desert.  
-Ice cream: Almond flavored and reminds me of the Chinese almond cookies. 

Service
The customer service was very good for us.  The food came spaced out so we can enjoy all the food.
author: Simon N.

description:
3.75/5
Honestly one of the better restaurant week experiences I've had (though honestly they usually aren't great). Food was solid all around and $40 was a pretty reasonable price. Made a reservation for a Sunday night for an early-ish dinner. We were seated right away and service was very friendly throughout the night.

My friend and I ordered the following items:
1) Potato & Leak Soup w/ cream/truffle oil/chives: Friends 1st course from RW. Decent soup. Light and smooth though a bit heavy handed on the truffle oil which I didn't feel was very necessary in the first place. (3.25/5)

2) Arugula Salad: My 1st Course for RW. A simple semi classic salad. Light vinegary dressing w/ some fresh fruits and some extra crunch from the fennel + a bit of nutty cheese. Can't go wrong. (3.5/5)

3) Loch Duart Salmon Carpaccio: My 2nd Course for RW: Another very classic dish. The main "unique" angle of this dish was the egg which honestly didn't stand out much. Salmon quality was decent (though personally wish it was a bit colder/firmer). Could've used some other flavor to make it standout but it's fine all around (3.5/5)

4) Duck breast: My 3rd course for RW. One of the better dishes off the RW menu in my opinion. There isn't a flavor that blew my mind but it was good. Duck breast was very moist and tender (though would've liked a bit more sear on the fat) with just the right amount of fat. I wasn't a huge fan of the golden beets/spinach combination. The beets were soft and had a sweet earthy flavor but the chunks were too large. The spinach also didn't hold up to the other flavors and textures. The tangy goat cheese went well with the beets though. The huckleberry sauce went well with the duck. (3.75/5)

5) Truffle Risotto: Friend's 3rd course. Had a bite. Not much to say. It's about as basic of a risotto as you can get from a semi-nice place. Pretty creamy and some mushroom flavor though. Not bad but there's better options (like the duck) (3.25/5)

6) Foie Gras & Fruit Pairing: A $25 side option and the best item of the night. A very sizeable, solid piece of foie gras. Perfect sear, very fatty, and paired w/ some delicious pears and toasted almost custard-like bread. (4.75/5)

7) Bucherondin De Chevre paired w/ a star-anise honey & walnuts: A lovely way to end the dinner. A semi-pungent goat cheese w/ a light amount of honey and some walnuts for crunch. Honey could have used a bit more of the anise flavor but then again it's all about that cheese (4.5/5)

Overall, I left very happy with my meal. I do feel like my friend's options were a bit more underwhelming so I can't say how consistent this place is but they definitely have some good options that are worth the price. Would love to come back (especially for dollar oysters).
author: Vivian C.

description:
HAPPY HOUR EVERY DAY BEFORE 7PM? Count me in, damn. 
Went to this restaurant with some coworkers, and it was overall a great experience! We had such a kind waiter who was willing to explain everything, and deal with 10 different orders without flinching. 
We ended up ordering from the house menu, and I got Mussels as an appetizer and their Flat Iron Steak for an entree. I will say, that their Flat Iron Steak may not have been marinated for long enough - only because I could still smell and taste some rawness. Aside from that, I was downing glasses of wine in between because come on - happy hour especially in the Marina? 
I would definitely come back to hang out with a friend or two; they have a nice bar ambiance.
author: Julia T.

description:
1,900+ reviews I don't think there's much input I can add that hasn't been said already.

Overall - great service and a delicious meal at this small French cuisine restaurant in the Marina District. We sat in the back patio which I strongly suggest. Seating inside the restaurant is fine, but to get the full experience, book yourself a back patio reservation and be merry.

They've got a great selection of wine, and entree portion size is plenty big. Our table had the duck breast and flat iron steak, both were out-of-this-world delicious.

Atmosphere in the back patio can be both group setting/birthday party shenanigans as well as romantic/intimate like your 4th date with that special someone you met online and trying to impress because you think it's finally time to make a move.  Our reservation was party of four - two married couples looking for an excuse to throw back as many glasses of wine as possible, and stuff our face with delicious meat.

Judging by all the Marina douchebag debacle one expect to encounter in any given night of the week, Isa stood out to me as one of the finer establishments in this neighborhood.
author: Dave K.

description:
If you are looking for a romantic and intimate french spot this place is your go-to! They have a great happy hour with $5 wine and cocktail specials before 7PM. They have a reasonable $34/pp prix fix menu and on Thursdays they have $15 Foie Gras Special. 

They converted their back patio area into a romantic dining area with lights strung everywhere you would think it was Christmas already. 

I personally love Foie Gras and its hard to find restaurants in the city that does not serve you something out of a can. They have the real deal, "Grade A Foie Gras" and i immediately fell in love with it. I will never settle for anything out of a can ever again. Paired with some pears with some kind of fruit reduction and a custard brioche. (5/5) 

Potato Wrapped Sea Bass was also a favorite. Served w/ capers, Fesno peppers, parsley, tomato confit, brown butter & lemon. Perfectly moist and the potato worked well to balance out the strong flavors. Without it i think it would have been too salty (4.5/5) 

Maple leaf farm duck breast - with braised red cabbage, potato gratiné & huckleberry sauce. The duck breast was cooked medium rare just how i like it and the dish was not overly sweet (4.5/5)

Overall, it was a very good experience. Our server gave great recommendations and had amazing energy that lifted everyone's spirits.
author: Anh T.

description:
Now this place is a small gem in the rough. Didn't even know they had a romantic low lit patio in the back with nicely decorated lights. It's a romantic place to take your date/gf and to have some really good French food. 

When I got to the table the waiter immediately informed me of the specials and what's a go to plate. He recommended the "Grade A foie gras" and the duck dish. 

I must admit the foie gras was really good and extremely buttery and rich. This is one of the best that I've ever had and wouldn't mind coming back for it. 

I ordered the potato wrapped sea bass which was so buttery with flavors and the light seared crunch of the thin potatoes that was wrapped around it made it a dream dish to eat. 
You definitely will have to try this dish if it's still in the menu. You'll be happy that you did. 

The last thing that was ordered was the maple leaf farm duck breast which was very succulent and moist. It wasn't dry at all and the seared crust of it was just too delicious. The richness of the flavor from this duck breast will definitely fulfill your appetite.

This place also has a good selection of wine and I believe their happy hours include some of the good wine that they provide. 

Parking is a little bit hard to find so be prepared to come 30mins to an hour early.
author: Lakeen W.

description:
The best French Restaurant I have ever been to. Came to celebrate my birthday in May. Always wanted to write something about this lovely place and the fantastic food. 

Environment 4.5/5
The bar is at the front area along with kitchen, when waking through the lane, a main area for meal. Very lovely and well decorated. Not so shinny, but warm and delicate. 

Service 5/5
My servicer Dean, who is the most professional servicer I have ever met. Always be energetic and wears a smile on his face. He explained everything including dinner menu, special menu, wine menu and promotions to us in detail, willing to further explain my doubt for the menu. 
However, the host who took us to the seat did not do well in his job. No smile and very rude, when we found my chair is not convenient for me, I told him I want to change the seat, he informed that upper level has been booked and I could not sit at that way. So I kept sitting for the uncomfortable table until I found they changed seat for other tables. I asked my servicer Dean for help and he immediately did the change for me. At the end of my meal, the upper level only sat three tables including mine, so the host lied me before. This is the only one bad memory for that day.

Food 5/5
Grilled local calamari 5/5
The whole plate played a good job in mixing every flavor together. The calamari is not dry or chewy. The flageolet beans and arugula are the most delicious one I have ever had. I am not a fan of beans. But they did a good job! Highly recommend!

Steamed Prince Edward Island mussels 5/5
The sauce under is perfect, can not waste any drop of it. Use bread to save every drop is a wise decision. The mussels are fresh and juicy!

Grade A Foie Gras 4.5/5
OMG! This is wonderful, you can found them melt in you mouth, but the center of it is cold, so little affect the perfect flavor!

Truffle risotto 5/5
The mushroom inside amplify the flavor, do not miss this, like a magic made by the food!

Seasonal Fish4/5
The out layer is crispy! But inner is a little bit dry. The orange under it is a highlight! Very fresh and natural!

Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak 3/5
The potato chunks on the side can still be remembered by me till now! Best flavor, but the steak is not a good part for today, nothing special, not juicy.

Grapefruit granite 3.5/5
Shaved ice with natural fruits juice. Very natural 

Semifreddo all amaretto 3/5
Not milky, melt when gave to me. 

Wine 4.5/5
Great to try!

Overall, I will give five star. They did good job in my meals. Everything is perfect for first course dishes. Good memory for my birthday!
author: Mengrou L.

description:
Cool place - we stopped here for a drink on the way to dinner because of their happy house specials. These specials consist of 7 cocktail options and 3 separate wines, all $5 each from 5-7pm. 

We came at 6pm and this place was dead unfortunately; stayed for 1 drink and then left for dinner. People started slowing coming in closer to 7 so that might say something about this place. 

I can't speak to the food but the cheap drinks are nice during happy hour. Other than that, nothing too spectacular about this place.
author: Bethany M.

description:
I would hate to give this place such a bad review because the first 2 times I came here was a great experience, but after yesterday's dining experience, that great experience turned into a nightmare.

The 1 star rating is for our 2nd server Dean, who did his best to make this a wonderful dining experience after all the mishaps we had to go through and for the Manager who fairly adjusted our bill due to our bad experience. 

I will be enumerating every single event that went wrong. We came for SFRW Party of 4:

1. Reservations at 8:30pm, got seated at 9:10pm
2. First course was served, 3 potato leak soup. (missing salad)
3. Oysters came, still no salad. We asked for more bread
4. Bread came, so we had to check what's going on with our salad.
5. Server rudely got close to my friends face and stated " What did I just tell you, I TOLD YOU WE WILL BRING IT OUT ONCE THE KITCHEN IS DONE WITH IT" (so uncalled for)
6. I asked for a new server. Dean took over and he is seriously the only positive thing that happened during dinner. Flat iron steak was brought out by another server (not Dean and not the first one) We told him that the steak is still cold, and he said "WHAT DO YOU WANT ME TO DO ABOUT IT" 
7. Flat iron steak was taken and brought back to our table clearly was just microwaved.
8. Dessert took 20 mins to come out

I am still in shock that these servers exist nowadays. Very unprofessional and poorly trained. I will not be going back nor will recommend any of my friends to come back here. I hope this serves as a lesson for them to improve their service more.
author: Gwen M.

description:
Yay! Finally got to check this place out for SFRW. This was one of the few places that offered four courses for the price of $40. Happy hour was also from 3-7pm I believe, which consists of $1 oyster and $5 soju or wine. Just FYI you need to buy at least half a dozen oysters to order. 

I wasn't able to make an online reservation but called and got reservations made. We came in around 5:45pm so we were one of the firsts being served.

1st course: 
-potato soup: 3/5 it was decent. Not too overwhelming and had a lighter consistency than I expected. 

2nd course: 
-mussel: also not something that was super tasteful but it was decent. I'm used to this being more tomatoey but this was ok too. Tip: just dip your bread all over the sauce on the bottom. 3.5/5
-salmon: sashimi salmon over bread was pretty good too. I maybe would prefer a smoked salmon but overall this was light and delicious. 4/5
-yellowfin tuna: yum!! This was good. Love how the avocado was on the bottom and tuna was on the top. Perfect blend. 4/5

3rd course: 
-scallops: ohh this was soo yummy! I definitely felt a little firework happening in my mouth, in a good way. The mashed potatoes that came along with also complimented well with the scallops. 5/5
-duck: ok this was a game changer too.. the first bite, it was decent but as you kept chewing, the flavor kept changing and intensified. I ate the bottom of it first and then hit the crunchy part and it was sooo good. The salad that came with it had bacon, cranberries, and duck pieces in it. This one was a win too. 5/5 
-angus steak: ok probably should've listened to people on this.. definitely underwhelming and was just decent. The potato that came with it was good and crunchy though. 3/5 

Drinks: 
Please get the number 7! It's so good. Blended with ginger, blackberries, and lemon. Our initial waiter made it and it was perfect. The second waiter gave us the second round but it wasn't as good, so consistency was a bit off on this. We were able to flag this first water and he remade it for us. Great customer service. 5/5

Fourth course: 
-creme brûlée: ahhh not too sweet and not too bland. Definitely recommend this over the other dessert 5/5 
-goat cheese: ok to be fair, I don't even like goat cheese but yeah it was a no go. 1/5.

Overall had a good time. The service was nice and they checked up on us occasionally, which was nice. Some dishes are better than the other so just know that. At the end, we got entered in a raffle and they gave us a red envelope to bring back the next time unopened. If I get that raffle prize, I will definitely be back for more, haha.
author: Sherluna V.

description:
Woah, I don't even know where to start. Everything was perfect, the food, service, and location. A party of 7 arrived earlier than our reservation time and we were seated immediately in the back -- loved the tent setting w/ white Christmas lights. 

For appetizers we shared the Maine lobster broth, Oysters, and, Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio, Must try everything!!

For my entree, I ordered the Sea bass wrapped w/ potato. IMO this dish is over hyped, my fish was pretty dry but it had great flavor. Lucky me, my fiance shared his steak with me. 

Lastly, I couldn't stop eating the bread. Gluten free (not that I care) and it was so soft!
author: Annie Y.

description:
We went for happy hour so I can't really review the food. 

The ambience is nice and it's generally quiet. Service is good and it's a clean restaurant. 

They've got a $5 drink special for happy hour which is great. Although, if you like wine, they only have 2 options for that. If you like mixed drinks they have more options for you. 

Great spot to stop for a drink and then check out other spots.
author: Matt M.

description:
A real San Francisco gem. I went to Isa last Saturday and it was such an amazing experience. From the food to the ambience, Isa is not a place to miss.
We started off with the tuna tartar. The tuna was incredibly fresh, I haven't had tuna so fresh like this before. The tuna sat on guacamole which was delicious.
The goat cheese bruschetta was to die for. If you're a fan of goat cheese, good luck because you're going to be ruined for life. Nothing else will ever compare. I still dream about the goat cheese.
The shrimp pasta sauce was really tasty, but my favorite dish of all was the sea bass. It was incredibly soft and flavorful. The capers and bell peppers complemented the seabass perfectly. 
Also the halibut with oranges and beet root was really tasty-- the perfect balance of sweet and savory flavors, I could eat the sauce all day!

I have never had paella before but if there's somewhere to have it, here's the spot. The calamari was soft and scrumptious. The rice had a great spicy kick, loved it!

I would recommend Isa to anyone in the SF area. It's truly an experience. I'll be back for more!
author: Sana S.

description: I was delighted with our meal at Isa. The wait staff was very friendly and accommodating. We are both vegetarians and the server was very helpful in suggesting several options. We shared the Brussels Sprouts, Arugula salad, Leek and Potato Soup and Truffle Spaghetti. All items were delicious, and I had no complaints whatsoever. The hot bread was perfectly crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. We were delighted to experience the sweet, cozy window seat for 2. Bonus, they were very sweet to my chihuahua (who remained in her bag), instead of being jerks about it, like other nearby restaurants were. We will definitely be back. Check it out! A++ on food, service and ambiance.
author: Susan T.

description:
I first got to enjoy Isa when SF Restaurant Week was still called Dine About Town (obviously a much better name, right?). That was over 7 years ago and 7 years later, this place still holds up and is just like how I remembered it. Back when the sale of foie gras was banned in California, Isa was doing secret dining clubs where people could buy fruit, and enjoy foie gras on the side for free. They stick to what they know - quality French meals served at an affordable price. They don't try to do what's on trend (hence their longevity). Although the Marina area is a pain to get to, Isa was just a $20 Uber ride from the peninsula. I recently planned a 10-person birthday dinner here for a friend and it was so hassle-free, unlike other SF spots. The real star of our last meal was the great service given by Dean who helped us enjoy our long, coursed out meal. Dean warned us not to fill up on their baguette bread, but when those suckers come out warm, no one at our table could help but enjoy it. Everyone at your table can order their own prix fixe meal, but plates are served as they are ready and they encourage family-style sharing. One person at the table should always opt for the scallops. I think the table favorite dessert was their classic creme brulee. Reading some of the reviews from this last SF Restaurant week regarding the service, most praised Dean and had issues with other servers. I can believe it, during our meal one of the waiters dropped some salad in my hair, but I shrugged it off. I would suggest coming back here outside of SF restaurant week, they have a regular prix fixe meal that's even cheaper than the SF Restaurant Week pricing. And of course, ask for Dean, he'll take care of you!

Pro-tip: Payment is limited to two credit cards per table. They don't serve hard alcohol, but do have an array of beers and wines. Their soju cocktails are only $5 each before 7pm.
author: Ghia G.

description: We come here often and only just realized that I hadn't posted the 5 star review that it deserves. Awesome place- great food, great service , great ambiance. On top of that good priced and kid friendly.. What more can you ask for in the city!!
author: P G.

description: Isa is the best!!! So glad I got to try this awesome restaurant during restaurant week! A four course meal for $40 - what a deal! I got the arugula salad, yellowfin tuna, the duck, and grapefruit graphite... every thing was so delicious! The service is excellent and it's located in a great location. I will definitely be back for more!!
author: Jenny E.

description:
Landmark restaurant been there many years. 

French style/fresh ingredients with some classic interpretations like potato/leekm, foie gras, butter/cream saucesm salads with contrasting flavors etc... Constantly changing menu. 

Seafood: prawns are imported from Mexico, they taste sweet vs. the farm raised shrimp from India/Thailand. 

Meat: all organically and locally sourced. 

High quality ingredients. Regular stop for birthdays and for food which isn't too heavy and makes use of local higher quality sourced ingredients.
author: Doug C.

description:
My first time trying ISA was an ABSOLUTE DISAPPOINTMENT. 

Decided to dine here for San Francisco Restaurant Week. My girls and I had reservations at 830 pm. However, we were not seated until 9-910pm. We had plenty of time to look over the menu as we were waiting. Ordered right when we were seated. It was a four course meal. 

First course: We ordered three potato and leek soup and a arugula salad. Also, ordered a dozen oysters. The soup arrived first with bread and butter. The three soups were almost finished and we decided to ask our waiter for the status of the salad. Waiter's response was, "we will bring it out when the kitchen is done with it." One of our second course dish came out and I asked our waiter about the salad that never came. To my surprise, he came inches away from my face and said, "I TOLD YOU, WE WILL BRING IT OUT WHEN THE KITCHEN IS DONE WITH IT." At this point, I'm in total shock. I have never ever in my life had a waiter get in my face like that. I sat there in disbelief and did not say a word. Luckily, my best friend who was sitting in front of me questioned the waiter about his rudeness. We had asked the manager of the restaurant for a new waiter. That kind of behavior and customer service is unacceptable. 

Second course: I recommend the mussels and the goat cheese. Both were really good and had a lot of flavor. We also tried to salmon carpaccio and yellowfin tuna. Not as good as it sounds. Also, as our waiter was serving our dishes, he knocked down a glass of wine on my best friend across from me. The entire restaurant went quiet as we all watch her wipe off all the wine that was on her face, neck, and shirt! The waiter was really apologetic and he seemed to be very sincere and genuine with his apology. It was truly an accident, and we didn't want to make him feel worst than he probably already feels about spilling the wine. We said it was totally okay and that he didn't have to keep apologizing. 

Third course: Seared scallops with bacon and mashed potatoes was a hit. Super good! I would also recommend the truffle risotto. We also ordered the seasonal fish with spinach. Fish was really bland, but the spinach was cooked to perfection. Lastly, the angus flat iron steak came. My friend took a bite from the steak and it was cold. Not warm but COLD. It was probably sitting in the kitchen for awhile before it was served to us. We mentioned it to a waiter and the waiter responded with, "so what do you want me to do about it?" ARE YOU KIDDING ME!?!? Is this a new thing where steak is served cold?? The was absolutely the last straw for everyone at our table. Waiter took the plate back in to the kitchen and brought it back a few moments later. The pieces of steak that were moved when my friend tried to eat it was at the same placement when the waiter had brought it back to the kitchen. We figured they just microwaved it and brought it back. We barely ate the steak and asked for the check while we wait for the dessert. 

Fourth course: While waiting for our dessert, our bill came. Waiter came back and wanted to know why we didn't want dessert. They must've misunderstood us, because we had asked for the check while we wait for the dessert. Due to the confusion, we probably had to wait another 15-20 minutes for some darn ice cream and crème brulee. 

This has got to be the worst customer service I've ever had at a restaurant. If I could give this place a zero star I would. So, this one star is for the waiter Dean. Dean tried everything possible to accommodate us.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
Oh man. Isa was the winner of Restaurant Week SF 2018 hands down.

I can guarantee you that I'll be back for the regular dining service. They just execute all of the dishes so well and provide an awesome dining experience if you factor in the service and the ambiance.

Props to Chi (served near the front window/wall on the left side) for being an amazing server. Your prob the best we've had in recent memory.

Had:
1. Arugula & Goat Cheese Salad
2. Mussels
3. Ahi w/avocado
4. Duck
5. Creme Brulee
6. Grapefruit ice/sorbet 

All very good.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Came here for SF Restaurant Week! They had an amazing deal - four courses for $40! The first course gives you a choice of a soup or 2 salad options (recommend the butter lettuce salad), second course had 4 options (recommend salmon carpaccio and the mussels!), for the third course I really liked the duck and risotto, and the fourth course had 5 dessert options (creme brûlée!). 

The service was great! Dean was our server and he was beyond friendly and very helpful. It did take a little bit of time for some things to come out, but they are very busy for restaurant week.

The only dish that I wouldn't recommend is the flat iron steak - we ordered medium rare but it was medium well, which was disappointing.

Portion sizes were great for the $40 meal and definitely a great deal for all of the food! They also have happy hour until 7pm with $5 cocktails! 

Highly recommend coming for restaurant week!
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
I'm not too sure where to start but I was a bit disappointing in trying this place out. I came here for a friends birthday so we had a HUGE group and coordinating with the events person we were suppose to get a prefix menu but we ended up not getting that but the regular menu. Because we had about 18 people in our party, and we were told each person should choose two things to share I decided to divide up the sharing with 4 people.  For starters we had the clams, prawns, and shared a tuna tartare. Our starters took FOREVER to come out. I mean we got to the restaurant around 8 and we all only had a few starters for the other people and didn't full eat till about 10. And our entrees we ordered the scallops, sea bass, spaghetti, and risotto.

The clams were ok,  pretty flavorful and we ordered two orders of it as we got really hungry. I wouldn't say its different from any other restaurant, but they cooked it well enough and we finished the plate. 
The prawns were a bit over cooked, but we each only had one to eat so I want to say that because we waited for almost 2 hours for food we got so hungry we ate anything that came our way. As for the tuna I only tried a bit of it since the other group ordered it, and it was Ok, nothing that WOW'ed me. 

The scallops were cooked perfectly and went well with the brussels sprouts. The risotto was cook good as well and I think we liked the two dishes the best. The sea bass however, we were told was a popular dish and we were not impressed. The sea bass was over cooked and I could not taste any flavor, and I eat fish often. The spaghetti was ok as well, it was something I can technically cook at home, it wasn't unique in anyway. 

All in all the food was not the best to what I've seen in previous reviews. It was a it disappointing in how unorganized the staff was when we ordered our food. One waiter just threw the plate of food on the table and just assumed we ordered it and  the wait was EXTREMELY long. Very disappointing, and there was another party next to us that arrived later than we did which looked like they gotten all their food before use which was a bit frustrating. We arrive by 8pm to the restaurant and did not leave till midnight. And the food was not made out to be shared, unless your ok with a bit of each plate. I only gave it two stars as our main waiter was super nice and friendly and hes been with the restaurant for about 9 years otherwise I would give it a one star for everything else food and other waitress. I probably wont be coming back as this experience was not the greatest.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
OMG probably one of the best meals I've had in years. Oysters, mussels, corn chowder, and Ahi just for starters.  The butterfish in parchment with truffles and white wine just knocked us over. Melted like butter for lack of words!  They have a nice two seater bench with window which would be a perfect date night place.  It's small so make a reservation to be safe. 

I brought a business client here with me from Indiana and he has not stopped about how great the experience was.

Ioved it here so much I came back with three business guests from Singapore .   All left so happy.
author: Tony B.

description:
Love this place, especially for date night.
There's two sides of the restaurant, the cool & chic bar top area with intimate seating & dimmed down low lights- and then there's the bistro, fun- yet romantic, string lights area in the back. 
Both are great and depending on your mood, you can choose the seating! 
We came here a few times for dinner & luckily we made it to their HH, which is 5$ wines (yess) and cocktails! 
We had their: 
Steamed mussels: PERFECT. Delicious, buttery, salty, and fresh. Loved the sauce and two toasted bread that I can dip it in. 
Truffle risotto: a bit salty but robust flavors. Lots of mushrooms if you're looking for a vege option 
Flat iron steak: steak was cooked perfectly to medium rare, juicy & tender. I was hoping for a bit more in quantity but that's the hunger talking. 
I didn't care for the lentils that it came with, I feel like this should be replaced with some type of grilled vege or a salad? I loved the fingerling potatoes, tho. 
Overall, love this restaurant. Luckily we didn't have to wait for a table for 2 on a Friday night, which was a bit ominous - but our food tasted great. A bit Pricey but so is most things in SF.
author: Maria C.

description: This is a great place. The bread is hot and delicious. The butter lettuce salad was simple and clean and just what I wanted. The seared scallops were awesome and the happy hour from 5:30-7:00 had prices of $5 on wine and cocktails. The cheapest I've found. Service was phenomenal. It looks small fro the front but there's a huge back room. Go here!
author: Lauren H.

description: Came here with a party of ten. Often times with a party that size the server gets overwhelmed. Not ours! He was awesome! Name it, no problem. All the food was delicious (I couldn't stop picking from my husbands plate). First time at Isa and surely not the last!
author: Elle B.

description:
3.5 / 5 

Went for SF Restaurant Week was incredibly hyped up because all my friends had good things to say about the restaurant but I felt like it was only mediocre. 

Got the leek soup which was really good and had really strong truffle flavour. Then got the mussels but the sauce wasn't as flavorful as hoped and it was only lukewarm. The scallops only came in 3s and also though soft had no texture. The best duck did not have crispy skin as my roommate had said so the quality is definitely inconsistent. However the dessert made up for it! Loved the creme brûlée and the coffee ice cream! 

We got the $27 foie gras was too oily in my opinion.
author: Lesley Y.

description: Amazing food and service! Staff was knowledge about gluten-free menu items and they were incredible!
author: Akiko I.

description:
I was staying in the Marina District, and was so delighted I found this charming restaurant. The atmosphere in the front of the restaurant was very relaxed. Dark, and cozy. A hard thing to find in the bustling neighborhood. There was a very lively heated patio in the back that was quite large and inviting, but I preferred the front dining area.

The food was delicious! So good, we went back 3 times while visiting.  So fresh, with plenty of local choices. A well balanced mix of flavors and beautifully presented. I loved the scallops. The local oysters were buttery and Devine. Tuna tartar amazing... oh and the local blue cheese on the desert menu- get it to accompany a salad. It's amazing!

The staff and owner were so engaging and welcoming. Taking time to check in and make sure we were happy. We enjoyed it so much, we ate there a number of times. We started to feel like 
family! 

I can't say enough how I enjoyed the experience, food, and atmosphere. I highly recommend. Thank you Isa!
author: Melle F.

description: I really love this place, the food, the atmosphere, every single aspect of this place is perfect to my associates and my self, the service is one of the best, definitely recommend this place....
author: Jose V.

description:
This restaurant is fairly small, so make sure you make reservations. I came during Restaurant week, and the food was delicious! We ordered the Salmon Capacio and Mussels for appetizer. Me and my fiance were expecting a small portion of mussels, but nope, it was huge! I would say, there were enough mussels to think that it was an entree! For main course, we got the scallops and steak. The steak was okay, nothing too much that made it stand out. But the scallops were perfectly cooked and seasoned! For dessert, we got the Grapefruit Granite and the Creme Brûlée. I really liked the Grapefruit Granite because it was like a palette cleanser!

All of these items for $40/per person during Restaurant Week. Not bad!

Also, parking can be a bit difficult here, so best to maybe Uber or Lyft. We got super lucky and our small rental car was able to take the parking spot right in front of the restaurant! (HEH!)
author: Michelle S.

description:
I had an amazing experience here with 3 other friends. Our host/server/life coach extraordinaire (whose name we didn't get because we lingered too long) was 90% of the reason why we had such an amazing time. From wine recommendations to helping us bundle our food into the prix fixe deal and therefore securing us desserts we had absolutely no room for, he really saved the day. Plus, the total came out to a very reasonable amount. Thank you kind gentleman.

It was also a Tuesday and the restaurant was fairly empty, which helped it feel extra special.

Now on to the food. What was memorable to me was the salmon, goat cheese, risotto, and skirt steak. Steak was just nice, but the risotto and smoked salmon especially were fantastic. I wasn't blown away by the ahi tuna, potato wrapped bass, or any of the desserts we had. Their goat cheese dessert sounded like it would be special but there wasn't enough sweetness to balance out the goat. The grapefruit granite was nice to cleanse the palette but very mediocre and tasted like a non sweet icee. They did forget one of our entrees but we didn't mind since we over ordered - although I get how that could've been really annoying for a large group. 

I would definitely come back here!
author: Robin Y.

description: What a gem! From customer experience, to ambiance, to absolutely delicious cuisine, Isa is fabulous. Our waiter Dean has been there for 12 years and said the same chef has perfected his dishes after being there for 14 years. We were here on a busy Saturday night and service was perfect--super attentive at the beginning of the meal and then less frequent throughout so that we didn't feel rushed. We sat outside under the covered heated patio, which was great. Normally I am cold wherever I am, but I didn't feel chilly. We got the crab salad, mussels, duck, and lamb, which was perfect for two people, but we also topped off the evening with the goat cheese and an espresso. Fabulous meal, we'll certainly come back during the week for their pre-fix menu (Sunday-Thursday).
author: Ashley P.

description:
I was really excited to come here for the prix fixe as well as the drink special. I guess the dampener started with parking - it's really hard in this area :( You can park at the nearby Wells Fargo for $13, which puts the evening to an meh experience.

The space itself is not the greatest but may have charm for some folk. It took a while to get seated despite a reservation, but it wasn't too bad.

To save time, basically we got 2 drinks (I forget what they are now; one had a number in it, the other was the Mojito) - they're not bad but not particularly good either. We also got 2 prix fixe: the salmon (pretty good!), the soup (this was really bad; watered down so much), the halibut (nice sear, but overcooked), the flat iron (I enjoyed this, though it's more of a homecooked taste than professional), and for dessert we had the "almond ice cream" (this was sweet but I liked it), and the goat cheese with bread (random choice; having bread at the end of a meal felt really out-of-place).

Overall, I still had fun trying a new place with a prix fixe but I would try something else next time.
author: Greg G.

description:
I visited Isa last night with several friends and although the food was enjoyable overall, this review is specifically about the abhorrent service my party received not only from our waiter, but predominantly from the manager. 

To make a long story short, our entrees arrived 40 minutes apart from one another. When we asked our waiter why that happened, instead of providing an explanation, he exclaimed "that's how it is here." Not satisfied with his answer, we requested to speak with a manager. Rather than apologize and explain to us why this transpired, the manager decided it would be better to take a condescending tone and inform us "that's how it's been for the last 12 years, you can't read the menu? check Yelp." When we attempted to continue the conversation, he turned around and walked away as if he couldn't be bothered with this. He circled back around a couple times to throw a few more choice comments our way. Clearly, he was not interested in the satisfaction of his guests, and preferred to find ways to demean his unhappy customers instead. 

Eventually, our bill came, and our kind waiter took the liberty of filling out the tip amount by hand. They neglected the fact that 3/6 of our entrees had to be sent back because they were cold, and that items were sent to our table that we hadn't ordered. Rather than deal with this nonsense from the manager and avoid an altercation, we decided to pay the bill in full and walk out. Much to our dismay, the manager chose to count our payment in front of us and throw in some more passive aggressive lines. Cute. That's exactly what I want to hear when I go to dinner.

Six people who dine out regularly get treated like absolute shit by a manager at a seemingly well established restaurant and this is considered normal? Despite the decency of the food, think twice before wasting your money here. No food is worth being treated in such a manner over.
author: Boris B.

description:
Con - 2/3 appetizers good but uninspired

Pro - proteins (halibut, chicken and steak) very well cooked and presented 
- sun - thurs prixfixe prices 
- desserts were good
- butter lettuce salad presentation and freshness
- excellent and friendly service

Overall - 4.5
author: Mike S.

description:
This place is so awesome with a group. All the plates were designed for sharing, so with more people you get to try more food. They accepted our day-of reservation for 8 people for dinner on a Saturday night. We actually ended up with 9 people but they were able to accommodate us in the back, even though we were a little squished. 

Between four (hungry) people on our side of the table we had the:
Dungeness Crab Salad
Yellowfin Tuna
Maine Lobster Broth
Calamari
Steamed Prince Edward Island Mussels
Seared Scallops
Potato Wrapped Seabass
Truffle Risotto
Maple Farm Leaf Duck Breast

All were amazing. Would really recommend the risotto and duck breast! Fair warning: another person in our party ordered only the risotto for himself but unfortunately it took an hour to come. We didn't notice the wait because we had so many dishes come out in between. 

Will be back!
author: Irene L.

description:
The Prix Fix three course specials at $29.95 and the $5.00 Happy Hour drinks are worth checking out. 

In Cow Hollow this rustic space incorporates a bar and covered outside patio. My friends and I tried three Prix Fix courses, which we all shared. At $5.00 each their Happy Hour Greyhound was an unexpected mix of Soju and Grapefruit while their House Isa Red (wine) Blend was fruity and smooth.

Our Prix Fix choices include an appetizer, main course and a desert. We were especially attracted to the Grilled Local Calamari. Delicately prepared and on a bed of flagoelent beans these full upper and lower bodies were excellent! 

Another favorite appetizer was the Steamed Prince Edward Island Mussels. With two thick pieces of thick grilled garlic bread these delicate steamed gems arrived in a savory tomato confit with white wine and shallots, mmm mmm.

Our entrees included: 
1-The Seasonal Fish. With gold beats this fluffy and flakey white fish dish was a thoughtful mix of texture and flavor that really pleased all of our pallets. 

2-The Truffle Risotto with baby shiitake, Hon shimiji mushrooms and cheese was very heavy and a bit rich for me. Between the three of us we still took half of it home. 

3-The Grilled Golden Gate Natural Angus Flat Iron Steak arrived in an excellent butter and red wine sauce with yummy roasted potatoes and zucchini. To us, this beef dish was difficult to eat. Although the flavors were wonderful all three of us easily tired of chewing this somewhat tough selection of beef. We did did not take home its remainder.

Deserts:
1-The Semifreddo all'Amaretto with three little cookies a branch of fresh mint and its overall creamy texture and almond flavor was delightful.

2-The Bucherondin Cheese drizzled with honey some fresh baguette and candied walnuts was the icing on the cake of a memorable dining experience. I have included seven photos for your scrutiny.
author: Caesar A.

description: Great service, very attentive staff and the food--delicious from the duck breast to the scallops.  Will definitely be back!
author: Roxanne F.

description:
Dined here last night for SFRW (I have been previously in the past) and it was genuinely the worst dining experience I've ever had.

We (party of 4) had reservations for 8:30 pm, but was not seated until ~9:10 pm. If you see my other reviews, I understand it's SFRW and a lot of restaurants run a bit behind due to being busier than usual. Again, this was no problem for me. What had occurred following being seated is why I would never come back.

3 out of 4 of our first course was served (soup), along with bread and butter. We finished our soups and a waiter came to grab all the empty bowls and one of our second courses, along with our dozen oysters, were served before we asked our waiter about our friend's first course (arugula salad). I will now describe the waiter's EXACT action and quote him verbatim: he bends over within inches of one of my friends face and says very rudely, "What did I tell you?!! I told you we bring it out once the kitchen is done with it!!!" Our whole table was so shocked that we all just sat there for a few moments quietly before one our friend spoke up on our behalf.

Angry, we asked the manager for another server, Dean, who ended up being the saving grace of our night. Dean bumps into our table and accidentally spills a glass of wine all over my friend's shirt and face, but was GENUINELY apologetic about it, so no one was really upset about it. What was upsetting was that when we received the final bill, AT THE VERY LEAST they could have comped that ONE glass of wine.

Also, our very last third course served was the steak. I was the first one to try a piece and when I bit into a small piece, the steak was COLD. Not cool, but actually COLD. I flagged down a server and told him that the steak was cold and no lie, I'm going to quote verbatim again. He says, "What do you want me to do about it?" I was AGAIN so shocked that I actually had to stuttered out "to cook it?"

At this point, we all are so upset that we asked for our check so that we can leave ASAP. The bill comes and one of our friend was so upset that she went to find the manager to have some of the items comped, ESPECIALLY the glass of wine that was spilled all over our friend.
author: Annie N.

description:
To end Restaurant Week, I made reservations for two at Isa. Unfortunately, I was only able to get a table at 5:15pm on a Sunday night, which was a bit early. The plus side is that they have happy hour until 7pm, so we got dollar oysters and $5 soju/wines to start off. Drinks are not too strong, but tasty and oysters were standard. The restaurant enters a dim-lit dining area as you're taken through the back. It's a covered outdoor backyard with strings of lights and heated lamps. There's plants hanging all around to give a cozy and romantic ambiance with an outdoor feel. I was head over heels with their décor of the restaurant. To add, we were treated with a warm and chirpy welcome from the server telling us that they have been waiting 15 years for our arrival. What a silly guy.

Although complimentary bread was offered, we were also warned to not stuff ourselves since we had a lot of food coming our way. The 4-course restaurant week started off with a Smooth Potato Leek Soup and Arugula Salad. Both were decent, but the salad lacked some flavor. Second course was the Yellowfin Tuna and Organic Loch Duart Salmon Carpaccio. As a huge fan of raw fish, I loved both of these dishes. The only problem was that I was not too hungry coming in for dinner, so we were both pretty stuffed by this point.

The main course was the Maple Leaf Farm Duck Breast and Grilled Golden Gate Natural Flat Iron Steak. Both of them came with a side of greens: steak with zucchini and potatoes/duck with spinach and beets. Both dishes were very solid and tasty, but I think I was way too stuffed to enjoy any more of it. Thankfully we decided to boxed these up and move onto our dessert. We finished with the Vanilla Bean Crème Brulee and Buche Au Lait De Crevre Aged Goat Cheese. The date loved the goat cheese while I indulged myself in the crème brulee. Very smooth, sweet and a very crystallized top layer --yum!

What I loved most was the variety of choices for each course. Although the food was not out of this world, it was still pleasurable. Top it off with wonderful ambiance and even better service, I truly enjoyed myself at this place. That alone will keep me excited about my return to Isa.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Year 3 the charm!

Finally, I've had the great experience of trying Isa during restaurant week! The last two years were fully booked, so when the participating restaurants were announced again this year, my friend and I immediately jumped on the opportunity.

When we walked in, it seemed very quiet and intimate, but our hostess led us out back to the covered porch where it was much more lively. Our server Jon informed us that restaurant week was actually served more family style so he highly recommended ordering different dishes so we could try everything - thank you for the honesty sir!

We started with the potato leek soup and the butter lettuce salad. The potato leek soup was delicious. The truffle oil on top helped give it that earthy flavor which was then spiked by the delicious bacon pieces in the soup. As for the butter lettuce salad, I thought it was a little too deconstructed. Leaves were coated in balsamic vinaigrette but were just stacked atop a few candied walnuts and crumbles of blue cheese and a few slivers of pear. But when when you gathered all the ingredients together, the bite was really good. Nutty, creamy, sweet, with a little bite.

Second came the salmon carpaccio and yellowfin tuna. The carpaccio was dressed in creme fraiche with capers, lemon, cucumbers and little bits of egg. Flavors were excellent, but fish was sliced somewhat unevenly. As for the yellowfin tuna, it had a more Asian flair. It was dressed in light soy sauce with a touch of sriracha which definitely gave it a slightly spicy undertone - delicious in my opinion.

Next came the main entrees. The seared scallops were TO. DIE. FOR. They had a beautiful golden crust for the sear and perfectly buttery in texture. My only complaint was that there were only 3 for a main entree. The majority of the plate was composed of vegetables, served in a variety of ways. The risotto was equally delicious, but a bit too rich for my taste buds. Very creamy and very hearty for those who enjoy that type of plate though. And they also don't skimp on the mushrooms!

For dessert, we opted for the vanilla bean creme brulee and semifreddo. The creme brulee came as expected. I personally thought the sugar crust was too thick, but my friend thought it was done perfectly. In my opinion, it should break like glass, very light revealing that smooth, not fully set custard underneath. As for the semifreddo, it did not skimp on the amaretto flavor - but I love almond, so I found this dessert very delicious. It wasn't too sweet, but it was refreshing (because it was cold) and a nice way to wrap up the meal.

All in all. 4 courses for $40 is a great value. Add in the share factor and being able to taste 8 different dishes made it an even better experience. The only thing was that I felt service was a bit rushed - perhaps because they were trying to turn over as many tables as possible to accommodate restaurant week. Multiple times, plates were almost taken away before we finished such that the next course could come out.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
The definition of a S*** SHOW!

My girls and I decided to dine here for SFRW. 

We made rsvps at 8:30pm and wasn't seated until 9pm. During that  time, my girls checked in a few times to get an update on our table since multiple parties who arrived after us were seated. We got responses such as the table was still eating dessert and they were taking longer than expected.. They were determined to seat us at a specific table instead of a table that was already available. 

1st course we ordered 3 leek soups and 1 arugula salad. All food came out except for my salad... The girls were pretty much done with their soup and finished the bread. We asked for more bread and the status of the salad. In response, the waiter said "we will bring it out once the kitchen is done with it." Time passes by and still no salad BUT we get one of our second courses... We waived down the waiter and this time around he says and gets in my friend's face, "I TOLD YOU WE WILL BRING IT OUT ONCE THE KITCHEN IS DONE WITH IT." At this point this is when I lose it questioning him of his rudeness and the reason for it.. The waiter replied "I TOLD YOU..." instead of apologizing. 

After all this chaos (mind you, its only about to be the 2nd course), we decided we should ask for a new waiter so it wouldn't be so awkward and negative throughout dinner... We asked for the manager, she apologized and gave us a new waiter.

Moving on we received the next dishes and as the new waiter drops off the food he knocks down my full glass of red wine and I am completely showered in it. I was completely drenched with wine all over my face and shirt. Luckily I was wearing gray and nothing I really cared about. The whole restaurant is in complete silence looking at our table, while the other party next to us offers me their napkin (how embarrassing, right?!). We weren't mad at the server because it was a complete accident and he was totally sincere and apologetic. After the incident, random servers came by instead and I'm guessing this is b/c our server was embarrassed for spilling wine all over me. Moving on we received our steak which came out cold.. We told one of the other servers and he asked us "So what do you want me to do about it?" LOL. TBH at this point I'm not sure why we stayed though out the dinner. The steak was returned on the same plate and was basically microwaved since food placement was the same on the plate.

We asked for the bill while we waited for the dessert and told them we just want to be out of here after we eat our dessert. Somehow they misunderstood us when it was clearly stated we were still waiting for dessert. We wanted to be able to leave right away once we finished dessert. Instead the bill was dropped off and they cleaned our table asking why we didn't want dessert... We checked the bill and not even one thing was comp'd after the whole experience. Only our wine was offered to be comp'd after my friend decided to speak to the manager... She offered her phone number & to personally serve us the next time but what does personally serving us change anything? First of all I won't even be back, second, no comps were offered until one of us complained.. 

OVERALL, FOOD WAS JUST OKAY AND NOTHING TO RAVE ABOUT. I RATHER GO ELSEWHERE WITH BETTER FOOD, BETTER SERVICE AND NOT BE SHOWERED IN RED WINE. 

One star only b/c Dean was totally apologetic and tried to accommodate us after accidentally spilling wine all over me. If it was't for him this place would get a ZERO. I do not recommend this place.
author: Cat F.

description:
Scored a reservation to celebrate a friend's birthday during Restaurant Week! 

There were four of us, so with the variety of selections for the Prix Fixe menu, we each chose something and shared it. Family style dining is usually the way to go when I go out with friends, but I do have to say, because the portions are on the small side, I would suggest ordering what you like and go for it.

First course: Arugula salad-mostly greens and slivers of apple, but I didn't get any persimmon, wished there was more dressing 

Second course: 
Salmon carpaccio-delicate flavors 
Steamed mussels-the sauce was delicious, especially dipping the bread in it and soaking it up
Yellowfin tuna-very nicely done, with avocado on the bottom

Third course:
Seared scallops-winner! Buttery taste and perfectly cooked
Flat iron steak-didn't try it since I was fasting red meat, but it looked good
Portobello mushroom with quinoa and vegetables-this was a good sized portion, all the flavors pulled together well and a healthy option for vegetarians 

Fourth course:
Grapefruit granite-looked refreshing
Vanilla bean creme brûlée-my favorite dessert! 

They came out with a birthday candle in the creme brûlée and sang Happy Birthday!

Overall: 
Food was very good
Ambiance: romantic fairy lights on the back patio Happy Hour drinks and $1 oysters-great deal
Seating is close together, but we got a corner spot, so it was not as noisy
Service: excellent and very attentive, the team worked together well

It was a very enjoyable and festive way to celebrate and catch up with good friends! I would definitely come back again.  (Btw, they gave us a red envelope and said when we come back to open it and see what gift is inside...nice touch!)
author: Linh L.

description: The food was really great. Everything we ordered was delicious. (Ahi tuna tartare, asparagus, seared scallops, potato-wrapped fish.) But the only reason I'm not giving it a 5/5 star review is cause the restaurant itself was old and kind of janky. (Had a very "cheap-motel-by-the-beach-with-plastic-flowers-vibe" about it.) Now, this is purely based on preference so ignore my review if you don't care about this kind of stuff.
author: Kelly O.

description:
Came here today for sf restaurant week. We reserved seats ahead of time for opening time, and it was still pretty empty so it was probably possible to get seated if you went early without reservations. It started to get packed and busy around 6:30. 

The service and restaurant was very nice, we got seated in the back at the patio. It was so beautiful with all the decoration lights and such. It seems to be a place for dates and such but hey it's sf restaurant week just bring a friend or family. Definitely would recommend to try and I probably will come back again for next years sf restaurant week.

So we ordered:

Course 1:

Potato and leek soup (which was rich and cream)
Arugula salad ( nothing too special)
Tomales Bay Pt Reyes oyster ( it was pretty good but wish the spicy orange mignonette was a more spicy and sweet)

Course 2:

Yellowfin tuna ( was so delicious, great mixture with the Sriracha and avocado to give it such great flavor)
Steamed Prince Edward Island Mussels ( they were so small and soft, love it taste and sauce)

Course 3:

Seared Scallops ( they were so fire aka delicious, it was made so nicely, and cooked perfectly that it not too cooked, had a bit rawness softness that made it melt in your mouth)
Grilled Golden Gate Natural Angus Flat Iron Steak ( we had it made medium rare and it was so good, so chewy and delicious loaded with flavors)

Course 4 (dessert):
Semifreddo all' amaretto ( such a delicious dessert, I believe it was ice cream but it was so good, so much almond and Carmel flavor)
Vanilla bean creme brûlée ( love the creme and how hard they made the sugar that it doesn't crack so easily when you tap the sugar part)

Overall a great experience and great food! For those coming for sf restaurant week definitely recommend coming for that amazing $40 deal before it's over!
author: Christopher G.

description:
After Isa changed business owners I have not been back, but before the end of the new year, my family and I decided to try it. 

We ordered everything... from the salad with persimmons, to the lobster tail soup, goat cheese dish, foie Gras  (thank God it's back!), lamb dish, steak, scallops, risotto.... even dessert!!!!!! Creme brulee and the flourless chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream.

Did I get your mouth watering yet? You HAVE to try it. I'd say it's French fusion. The atmosphere was very festive, we were seated in the indoor patio area with heaters everywhere. I thought we were going to freeze but it was cozy and warm. 

Servers were very attentative and I didn't have to continuously ask for more water or anything. 

Parking was no issue, there were two opened meter spots ( free parking after 6 ). There's also a parking garage nearby!

Come by and try, recommended! Mmmm, yummmmmy!
author: Eugenia W.

description:
We finally got the time to come check out Isa's food.  The timing was good as it fell on Restaurant Week.  Upon arrival, the hostess immediately led us through a narrow passage to the back of the restaurant.  We walked by the kitchen and were shown to our table under a tent.  It was supposed to be the garden area.  The setting was not what we had expected but it was fine.

Our waiter was charming and persuaded me to start off with a cocktail called "Number Seven."  It was a mixture of soju, blackberries, ginger and champagne.  Unfortunately, the drink was a miss for me.  Apart from the sweetness, there just wasn't enough of everything aforementioned.

We ordered a few things for dinner.  For our starter, the oysters on the half shell were accompanied by an orange mignonette.  The tangy sauce had a kick.  I could not say I was a fan of the taste but it got our palates ready for sure.  I had the Butter Lettuce Salad with pears, walnuts, watercress and blue cheese.  The plating looked rather messy and could have used more cheese or dressing to enhance the flavor.  My wife's Arugula Salad had apples, oranges, fennel and parmesan in a lemon vinaigrette.  It was really refreshing.

Onward to more substance, the Steamed Mussels served in a white wine garlic broth were very flavorful.  I also couldn't get enough of the Baked Goat Cheese.  It was just lovely together with the basil pesto and pine nuts.  The next course for my wife was Seared Scallops in truffle sauce.   They were perfectly cooked and the medley of orzo, favas, corn, and tomatoes was a nice accent.  My Angus Flat Iron Steak was slightly over for me but the Bordelaise sauce was nice.

No matter how full you are, a meal is not complete without dessert.  We each picked a different one.  The Grapefruit Granite was very simple and light.  However, the Semifreddo all'amaretto was creamy and decadent.  I liked it so much there was nothing left on my plate except the mint leaves.

Their timing on food was pretty good.  Although the restaurant was packed, they did not rush things through.  We were able to take our time and enjoy each course.  The atmosphere was average.  It got a little noisy at times.  Furthermore, I wish they had more restrooms.  Patrons were waiting right in the major thoroughfare.  Overall, we had a very pleasant experience at Isa and would love to return to try the other items with an Amaretto dessert encore.
author: Allen C.

description:
I came here on Sunday night for a group of 5 people for SF Restaurant week. To put my review in perspective, I normally do not order 3+ courses meals at restaurants and not an expert on European food. And I have never been to Isa before this. 

When we came in around 7:45 pm, there were multiple groups waiting in line, good thing we made a reservation. We were seated immediately in the back area. There were a lot of big groups in the back. It was much noisier than I expected for a non-Asian restaurant. It was a big deal through. Although it can be romantics place for two, with the crowd and the noise level, maybe not that night. Because of so many large groups in the back, the space was cramp. 

Service: 3.5/5
Service was slow that night. Our waiter came over to introduce himself 10-15 minutes after we got seated (Which is a longer than normal). Because of Restaurant week, there is only one set of menu, which is way more convenient for the restaurant to prepare the food. I felt like we spent a lot of time waiting for next course to come out. I guess it's good that they give you plenty of time to finish each course. But it made dinner felt like it was super long (around 2.5 hrs). 

Price 4/5
It's $40 dollar for 4 courses meal, which is really reasonable. It also gives you at least 3 options for each course, around 6 for the main course. And Oysters are only $1 each (you must get set of 6 though). 

Food 4/5
Between the 5 of us, we tried these options dishes: 

Oysters 3/5 
My friends said that it's just mediocre oysters. They definitely had better Oysters. But what can you say, they are only a dollar each. You can find that at many places now. However, the sauce was good. 

Bacon Potato Leek Soup: 5/5
It was really good. I'm not a big leek person but you can't really taste the leek. It is creamy and the Bacon definitely makes it better. (None of us got Salad lol!) 

Salmon (Forgot the full name): 4/5 
It was good, I definitely liked it. 

Yellowtail Tuna 3.5/5
I really like Tartrate. The combination of raw fish and avocado is amazing. However, it is not the big tartrate I have ever had though. It was a bit spicy for me (but I have very low tolerance for spicy food). The portion of avocado is very small, I was a bit disappointed. 


Flat Iron Steak: 3/5 
Steak is steak. No the best, not the worse. Afterward, one of my friends wished he got duck breast instead. 

Scallop 3.5/5
I personally ordered this. It was a very small portion. I only had 3 scallops (I thought it comes with 4, but whatever). It also comes with mashed potato and butter squash cubes. Probably wouldn't have gotten this if I were to order individually. 

Mushroom Risotto 4/5
It was good, the only downside is that it's vegetarian.

Creme Brulee 
It was as expected. It wasn't extraordinary. 

Semifreddo 
My friends liked it. We thought it was a melted ice cream at first (lol). It was very different. 

At the end of the night, I was bloated. I don't normally eat a lot, so it might not be a lot of food for guys. I did a survey around the table, we probably would not have ordered any of those separately. But it was a great experience to try different courses in a new restaurant.
author: Ashley H.

description: The food is delicious and the service is great. Love the $5 Happy Hour cocktails and the prefix menu has great selections. Isa is a gem!
author: Luisa C.

description:
I dined here a while ago.
The servers were friendly and attentive, and the restaurant had a fun and cute ambiance. We sat in the back room where it's outdoorsy but still an indoor(?)
I just remember that it was really loud in the restaurant that it was kind of hard to have a conversation.
The food was just average too. Not bad, but nothing really to write home about.
I'd give this place 3.5 stars if there was half a star rate.
author: Hyemin J.

description: What a hidden gem that's maybe not so hidden. A seemingly nondescript storefront that has a beautiful lit back room that transports you to another place. The food was exceptional. The portions were perfect for sharing and the price was reasonable. The waiter was jovial and really took good care of us. We'll be back!
author: Kim B.

description:
Came to Isa for their SF restaurant week deal - $40 dinner for a three course meal. Overall a great deal and satisfying meal. 

To start, we were seated in the back patio which was very nicely decorated with hanging lights. Provides a cute, casual ambience that's nice for birthdays, hangouts, dates, etc. 

Having arrived around 5:45, we made it in time for their happy hour deal! $5 soju cocktails and select wines as well as $1 oysters, which I definitely recommend taking advantage of (because why not?)

For our meal, we had the yellowfin tuna, arugula salad, mussels, duck breast, steak, and semifreddo dessert. The duck breast definitely stood out as the star of the dish with its crispy skin, tender meat and subtle huckleberry sauce. The semifreddo had a strong amaretto kick to it, so take that as you will. Otherwise, the other dishes were good but nothing special. 

Definitely worth the money during restaurant week so can't speak to their regular prices, but come by for their happy hour if anything!
author: Jay P.

description: Such a great place to go with friends, we shared 6 entrees between 4 of us, plus dessert and drinks and it was perfect. All the food was delicious and the service was friendly and enthusiastic. Will definitely be back for more truffle risotto
author: Abby J.

description:
*SF Restaurant Week 2017 Review*

It was such a struggle to make reservations here because they have such a narrow window of open hours, but with a 4 course dinner for $40, who could resist? My friend and I eventually settled on a reservation for Tuesday night at 6pm because it was the only night with normal dinner availability. Even though we arrived 30 minutes after opening, the restaurant was already packed and it stayed that way for the entire 2 hours we were there. 

We decided to order different items per course because there was so many options for each, so we started off with a potato leek soup and butter lettuce salad. The flavors in the soup all balanced out very well, and I especially liked the bits of bacon in it; the blue cheese in the salad was quite overpowering and masked even the acidic vinaigrette, and I thought it was a little weird that they gave us entire leaves instead of cutting them into smaller pieces. Next we had the tuna and mussels appetizers. The clear winner here was the mussels: they were sweet and juicy and not overly salty (although a tad on the small side) while the tuna itself didn't have much flavor and I felt that the avocado didn't particularly complement it. 

For our main course, we had the flat iron steak and the duck breast, both cooked medium rare per their suggestion. Both meats were so tender and flavorful! The butter on the steak was a nice touch but it would've been fine on its own, and the thinly sliced zucchini went well with it. I've never had medium rare duck before this, but I was thoroughly impressed by this dish - the golden beets were light and refreshing and the sauce even had whole cranberries! For dessert we both had the crème brûlée, which was absolutely amazing. We both ended up scraping all the crusted sugar off the edges of the ramekin - no shame - because it was that good.

This restaurant is perfect for date night as it's super cozy and quiet enough to hold a conversation at a normal volume. Our table was kind of awkward as we were seated in a corner sitting next to each other and facing out the window, and it seemed to be difficult for servers to bring/clear our plates, but at least the food made up for this. Servers were also very attentive and polite, and I thought it was really cool how every customer gets a mystery reward to redeem at a later time - great incentive to get people to come back. Their regular menu is a little above my usual price point, but if you're willing to splurge, you will definitely get a quality meal here!
author: KC W.

description: Food was pretty good but service was pretty horrendous. We only got one out of our three appetizers, had to remind the waiter after about an hour for the other two. Then entrees didn't come out until a half hour after that. It was strange because the restaurant was pretty empty so unsure what was going on.
author: Shabnam E.

description: Came here on my own on a trip for work. Staff were delightful and the food is truly excellent. Lots of options for all palettes and dietary concerns.
author: Toby E.

description: We came during the restaurant week. Excellent customer services and food quality. We sat at the back of the restaurant. It's cozy but a bit cold.
author: J L.

description:
Food was delicious. We ordered the foie grais, dungeoness crab salad, scallop, truffle risotto, and lamb. All were fantastic. For dessert, we got the flourless chocolate cake and creme brulee, which were average but a nice way to end a meal. 

Ambience and decor provided a nice setting for dining. Staff felt kind of pushy on what and how to order but it's okay, everything else made up for it. Will be back.
author: Jones J.

description:
This restaurants cozy front room is tiny and loud - most seats are in the tented back patio, which is also loud, plus cold and unfinished feeling.  The menu is very appealing, with a lot of options for gluten free diners--a plus.  Servers are friendly, if overwhelmed.

  I will say the quality of the food in terms of freshness and flavors was very, very good.  The problem was the preparations.  I ordered duck breast rare and received a portion that was medium- to well-done (not a trace of pink).  The server was so overwhelmed I could see that sending it back would create a major delay, so I kept the dish and, to be fair, the flavors were very good.  But there's no excuse for getting the temperature so wrong. 

My husband's paella came out looking great, with plump prawns and mussels in a pretty saffron-y bed of rice.  Seafood was fresh and tasty and the rice was seasoned nicely with a bit of smoked paprika.  Alas, the rice itself had the texture of mushy porridge -- overcooking the culprit once again.

So, how to rate this place?  Menu is great, setting is meh, flavors are terrific, kitchen's technical abilities seriously lacking.  Add to that either parking hassles or Uber fare up to the Marina, and for me, it's just not worth another visit.
author: Laura W.

description:
My wife and I came here for our birthday and was well worth the drive to the city.

1) atmosphere was nice a quiet enough to converse.

2) Our server was awesome!! Was not rushed and was helpful with the menu. 

3) Food was really good starting with the oysters. Super clean and not gritty.  

Foil grais was probably the best I had. 
Butter lettuce crab was amazing and portions were huge 

Lamb was properly cooked with no gamey taste.

Paella seafood was good but thought the rice was over cooked.
author: Jino l.

description: Amazingly kind service and delicious food! Love the ambiance and all! Very nice for groups and for a date. Sit in the back --it is the most charming with the twinkle lights. The lamb was great!!!
author: Rachel ..

description: Every experience here is simply magical. I always think that it can't be as good as i remember it being, and every time i am wrong. The scallops melt in your mouth, the truffle risotto is so creamy and delicious, and the semifreddo amaretto is unlike anything else i've ever had. That being said, everything on the menu is ridiculously good, and the staff are very friendly and knowledgeable.
author: Zelah B.

description: What a fabulous restaurant for our 30th birthday dinner! The service and food were both outstanding. We spilled a little wine on our scarf, and the waiter immediately came with "Wine Out" to get the stain out. It was a memorable experience!
author: Ferrell M.

description: Great neighborhood spot that reminds me of Europe! Fresh, quality ingredients and friendly staff greeting and serving customers with such care. It's a good place to go when you want to enjoy the atmosphere, food and wine. (The back patio is my favorite!) They don't rush you and let you take your time, similar to Europe.
author: D C.

description:
The $29.95 3-course Prix Fixe (available Sundays-Thursdays) might be the best bang of the buck for a casual-romantic hole in the wall meal in town.

It was completely uncrowded on Tuesday night.
