The restaurant was also kind enough to give us vouchers for a free drink for the next time we come in, so we will definitely be back! One of my new favorite restaurants :)
author: Kay A.

description: While the food was great, the server was overly pushy and made us order way more food than we could consume. We were in a rush, but he kept going on and on about how we must order at least 2 dishes per person, and how we must order the specialty ones - which obviously are more expensive. But like I said, the food was good.
author: Natz W.

description:
BF and I came here for SF restaurant week and enjoyed it. Everything was well-cooked and the place was packed. They advertise themselves as serving everything "family style"/tapas, so order diff things from your companions and for a four course meal with TONS of options for $40, I was sold.

I had the potato leek soup which was ALRIGHT. Not so hot on it, needed more flavour-- but tasted OK with the bread. My boyfriend got the arugula salad which we both liked. The fruit accompanied the salad well and there was a generous portion of shaved Parmesan on top. For the next course, I got the yellowfish tuna tartare which is a really spicy knockoff of Alan Wong's ahi stack. Really good, but reminded me of another (better executed) dish. But since j can't have that all the time, this will do in a pinch. It's REALLY good. My boyfriend got the mussels which were TINY with not a lot of broth, but were perfectly cooked. Wish they used bigger mussels though. I got the truffle risotto for my entree and my boyfriend got  the steak. We liked both a lot, though the truffle risotto should be called a mushroom risotto as the flavour overwhelms it. There are a lot of bits of truffles throughout the risotto though, which I REAAAAALLY liked. I can't really comment on my BF's steak as I only had a bite, but the veggies were cooked wel and deliciously seasoned. Yum :)

Our dessert was the creme brûlée which came out in small ramekins, but was delighted to see that they use vanilla bean (speckles galore!) and that each brûlée had an amazing caramelised crust.

All in all, super busy restaurant with attentive service that could have only been improved by serving higher quality ingredients and perhaps the service would have been more attentive had the restaurant not been PACKED. For the sheer volume and turnout, they did pretty well though! I'll probably come here again for another date night and they mentioned that they have a $23 prix fixe dinner sometimes!
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
Grilled local calamari $12 - not battered; different, tasty
Roasted rack of lamb $24 - delicious
Maple leaf farm duck breast $22 - perfect
Flourless chocolate cake, vanilla bean gelato $7 - worth it

I would sit outside again; I really liked the atmosphere here. 
Also, excellent service, but I would order more quickly because the kitchen is small and gets backed up.
author: Kimi K.

description:
Food and restaurant: 4 stars
Service: 2.5-3

I made a reservation for 7:15pm, arrived a tad bit late, but was greeted with a smile and seated immediately.

I ordered the Dungeness crab salad for appetizer, which was really good. Just the right amount of salt and pepper sprinkled on the lettuce. Then for entree I got the Truffle risotto. MMM, buttery mushroom rice, my favorite! And my friend got the short rib special.

The restaurant is nice and intimate but noise level can get high.

Service here was meh... our waiter was sweet but looked like he was totally over being a waiter. Our host came by to check on us and asked if we wanted any dessert, I said no, just the check. She paused, mugged me for all of 2 seconds and asked why. Uhhh, okay? Sorry babe, but I got places to be.

Otherwise, everything went well. I'd definitely come back for the environment and the food.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Very tasty and affordable! Must try their sea bass and mushrooms!!!
author: Weiqi M.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town/Restaurant week and I felt it was a decent choice! The service was really great -the waiter was patient in taking our order and giving recommendations. The 4 course menu had enough options so we could try a lot of different things.There was also more than enough to eat in terms of portions of each course.  The dishes were good enough so that I was generally satisfied.

1st: We tried the endive salad and the arugula salad, both were fairly simple. The endive salad came with beets and blue cheese in a vinaigrette. The arugula salad had a more savory flavor with the fennel. I think I preferred the second.  

2nd: We tried the yellow-fin tuna and the salmon carpaccio. The tuna was spicy and tasty and reminded me of a Hawaiian poke. The salmon was delicate and sauce was creamy.  Both dishes were fresh and represent the highlight the meal. 

3rd: We had the duck and the iron flat steak. Both of these were a bit disappointing to me. The blue cheese sauce atop the steak was a bit too assertive, and I wasn't a huge fan of the cut of flank steak. The greens in the meat sauce were decent. As for the duck,  I would have liked a crisp on the duck. I thought both were cooked medium rare perfectly.

4th: Semifreddo and the creme brulee.  The vanilla brulee was sweet and creamy and the caramelization gave it that nice crunch. The semifreddo had a more subtle sweetness and a nutty flavor.  The cookies that accompanied it were not good.  I thought the brulee was the superior choice.  

Overall I enjoyed the experience. A combination of nice ambience and great service redeemed somewhat average to slightly above average eating. Worth checking out.
author: Huy V.

description: Small intimate spot in the Marina. On Saturday there's happy hour until 7, drinks $5, good value. For the meals,  arugula salad to start and seared scallops and flatiron steak as entrees, family style. Food was good but not memorable.  Overall dining experience, ambience, service and food gets passing grade. I'd come again.
author: Gordon H.

description: I love this place! The ambience on the patio is casual yet chic, perfect for a romantic date night. The quality of the food is top notch yet the prices are affordable. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Anne K.

description:
At the recommendation of my sister's, my boyfriend and I came here to celebrate our 2-year anniversary. We wanted something a bit on the low-key end and not too expensive. It was Dine About Town week, and we made a reservation for 2 on a weeknight.

Before 7pm, the HH menu is great. $5 glasses of wine. We sat at the bar, and the bartender was friendly enough, but moved pretty slowly. As we enjoyed our wine at the bar, we played a game on one of the tablets. Since we were there celebrating our anniversary, it was only appropriate to play a game re how well we know each other. It was a lot of fun, and the hostess let us bring the tablet to your table to continue playing.

When we were seated, a friendly waiter came to greet us. My boyfriend started with the arugula salad, and I started with the leek soup. I then had the truffle risotto and he had the duck -- both were so delicious! For dessert, we had the amaretto and the grapefruit granite.

Overall, everything was delicious and we had a wonderful experience here. Would definitely recommend and come again! Just noticed that they have a fixed price menu regularly, so it's definitely affordable and a great option for delicious French cuisine.
author: Siv L.

description:
We went to Isa during SF Restaurant Week and thoroughly enjoyed the meal. We had a 4 course prix fixe and between the two of us, got a pretty wide selection of food. My favorites were the salmon carpaccio, baked goat cheese, and the steak. Everything else was pretty good. The lone disappointment was the soup. Didn't really taste potato-y or leek-y and was really thin. Not the hearty soup I was expecting. 

Other notable aspects: 

Bread comes with unlimited refills and is delicious! Save some to dip in steak juices or soup or salad or butter. Just eat the bread. 

Service is great and kind of seems communal, meaning you get waited on by more than one person and not necessarily a dedicated server. 

$5 soju cocktails and beer/wine deals during happy hour which lasts until 7:00 pm. They have a fun cocktail list and you can have a couple without getting hammered which is nice and affordable. 

I would definitely come back and had a great time on their back patio.
author: Jamie S.

description: Great meal. Everything is paired to split between people and share. We got the crab salad, corn soup, lobster bisque which has real lobster in it, scallop and duck breast entree. Everything tasted great and I especially loved the duck breast. It paired with a hash brown and purple cabbage with some figs. The scallop dish was evenly glazed and just swallowed smooth. The crab salad was also quite delicious too.
author: Steven L.

description:
I was really expecting an awesome dinner given the raving reviews on Yelp. However, my dinner during SF Restaurant Week was not as awesome as I had hoped.

Granted, the service was excellent (thanks Domingo!) and the waiters were always refilling our waters, however, the food was rather mediocre. For the 1st course, my potato leek soup was pretty bland and my BF's arugula salad was nothing special (seemed like we could've thrown it together ourselves). I did enjoy my salmon carpaccio for my 2nd course while my BF's mussels were... eh. For the main course, I got the truffle risotto (which my BF and I agreed is probably the best dish from our dinner) while my BF got the flat iron steak. The steak was nothing spectacular - the only flavor I tasted was the blue cheese sauce that was drizzled on top. As for dessert, the grapefruit granite was nothing more than grapefruit-flavored shaved ice. The semifreddo was a bit better.

Another thing to note like many other reviewers had mentioned is the fact that they seem to really rush you along your dinner. There didn't seem to be room for a breather whatsoever. I wished they would slow the pace down a bit so diners could really enjoy their meals and conversations with one another.

The ambiance was cozy and they had a nice backyard patio - perhaps I'd come here for happy hour instead of paying full price for a mediocre, rushed dinner. I somewhat wished I chose a different restaurant to eat at for restaurant week, but hey, I can finally cross this place off my list. Perhaps the food would taste different had it not been restaurant week? You would think that during restaurant week, restaurants are supposed to showcase what their food is all about. If what I tasted is what defines Isa as a restaurant, then I'm very disappointed. Maybe I'll come back for dinner and give them a second chance. Just maybe.

Also, I don't really understand why it's considered a French restaurant when I didn't see a lot of French elements in their dishes. It's definitely not traditional French, that's for sure.
author: Victoria V.

description:
Came here for the 5th time to see what they had to offer for the January 2013 Dine About Town. One thing you need to know about this place is that you should reserve at least 15 minutes to look for parking - this area is the worst, especially from 5pm - 7pm. In addition, you should ALWAYS always request to be seated at the patio (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zVaqERmqkftmBrzhQMOxMw/l.jpg), it really makes the experience of dining at Isa, even if you have to wait. Oh, and they only serve Dine About Town menu during this time - good one Isa, good one: they only have to mass produce a couple of items the whole day. 

Here is a complete Dine About Town menu: 
First and Second Course - http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fEgrLwAGuEShES0NLuQjgA/l.jpg
Third and Fourth Course - http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1_SGLSMnLqMzWzldwn68FA/l.jpg

We ordered two of each course from the menu:

1. First Course:
- Maine Lobster Broth with prawn, tomato, celery & tarragon  (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BieHD4bPiN0bEc7Ioi3-DQ/l.jpg)
- Potato and Leak Soup with parsley, chives & cream (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ELmKZKp2D-Ghbr8HuiBaAw/l.jpg)

2. Second Course:
- Dungeness Crab Salad with avocado, apple, grapefruit & tarragon (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fASlHgi0somxUkcbnAKsDw/l.jpg)
- Arugula Salad with fuji apples, mandarins, fennel, lemon vinaigrette & goat cheese (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/MhDRHXSxf0vPQHxH9LHDhA/l.jpg)

3. Third Course:
- Seared Scallop with mashed potatoes, brussel sprouts, bacon & truffle sauce (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vKYoblmbu9L_TSrOclYpoQ/l.jpg)
- Braised Short Ribs, not on the menu (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/tlo8D_lJ4RtGmxG3jCOPuQ/l.jpg)

4. Fourth Course:
- Semifreddo all'almaretto (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vKfnCsU2N_FS5UFeJF-V2Q/l.jpg)
- Grapefruit Granite (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/_xC5kfm-SRfKf_9H7pdb6g/l.jpg)

I would definitely recommend the Maine Lobster Broth, Dungeness Crab Salad, Seared Scallop with a glass of vouvray, and the Grapefruit Granite to refresh the palettes.
author: Ximeng W.

description:
DINE ABOUT TOWN SF 2011

It's the most wonderful time of the year! I was really sad that I had been very busy and might miss it this time around... but on the last day... I was invited to DINE ABOUT TOWN and we went to ISA (funny become in tagalog ISA means 1 hee hee)

silly connections aside i have the highest praises for this place. this little restaurant serves up a delicious menu and everything we tried that night was delicious!

1st course:
to start i had the DUNGENESS CRAB SALAD which was fresh, light and tasted like San Francisco in the Spring. too cheesy? okay moving on.

she had the steamed PRINCE EDWARD inland MUSSELS with garlic & white wine- 

i may be allergic to crustaceans but i just can't help myself sometimes :)

2nd course:
she's always been a fan of scallops. that's one of the reasons why we picked this place. she had the SCALLOPS with GARLIC MASH POTATOES, GRILLED ASPARAGUS & TRUFFLE SAUCE. -scallop was cooked well, seared on the outside and juicy inside. the mash potatoes in the middle was warm and garlic(y) just the way i like them. delicious! 

i had the DUCK BREAST with BACON! i'll admit it was the bacon that caught my eye but it was the duck breast that won me over. (don't tell the bacon i said that) the duck breast unlike the gamey pecking duck that i know and love was tender and melted in my mouth. i was happily surprised. and of course, there was bacon like the cherry on top of sundaes.

3rd course:
SEMIFREDDO OL' AMARETTO & VANILLA BEAN CREME BRULEE -i don't have much of a sweet tooth, i was good by the end of the 2nd course. The amaretto was delicious but the creme brulee was just okay. 

Thank you DINE ABOUT TOWN-
Until next time,

Cheers!
author: Jerico P.

description:
When I saw that Isa was participating in Dine About Town SF, I had to make a reservation ASAP!  Usually, their menu is over my price range, so knowing that I get three courses for $34.95 was something I had to act on quickly.  Plus, I really liked the menu they had available.  There were many choices for each course.

My friend and I ordered the salmon carpaccio, arugula salad, duck breast, scallops, grapefruit granite, and the vanilla bean creme brulee.  And everything was spot on delicious!  There's no other way to describe it.  I will mention that the spinach that came with the duck had bacon in it.  Spinach and bacon.. what an awesome combination!

What I thought was cool is the shared menu.. I read a couple of reviews of those who didn't know what that meant.. Basically, it's family style.  Having to share each course sets the pace... For me, it makes you slow down and really focus on the flavors.  Maybe I'm breaking it down too much, but it's how I felt about it.

Read more in my blog: http://sexydishes.blogspot.com/2011/06/dine-about-town-part-1.html
author: Vira P.

description:
If you are taking someone special to dinner, make reservations and request for the back patio area for dining! It's spacious and cute with its courtyard ambiance.  If you want a more intimate and dark atmosphere, then request for indoor dining.

Ordered:

-Dungeness crab salad with avocado, apple, grapefruit & tarragon: perfect to share for 2

-Roasted rack of lamb with sautèed eggplant, zucchini, red peppers, nicoise olives & lamb jus: so DELICIOUS! Perfectly cooked lamb with some juicy red to my liking.  I am a carnivore, what can I say!

-Maple leaf farm duck breast with baby spinach, pinenuts, currants, bacon & sherry vin sauce: A definite hit and such a generous amount given to even possibly share.

Service was on the dot.  I have no complaints.  The bread guy refilled our baguettes with quickness to the point where I had to tell him to stop refilling my share.  I enjoyed my time here and would come back here again!  

Great alternative for french food if you don't want to spend $$$$ at a fine dining restaurant!
author: Kathy D.

description:
The service and food was amazing.  I really appreciate great service.  

They had a full house, but the service never skipped a beat.  Our wine glasses and bread basket never went empty.  The maître d was attentive and asked us how we were doing.

I had two children with me and they were wiling to accommodate a special entree for them.  However, my kids were too young to enjoy a fancy palate.  In any case,  the service was phenomenal.

The food was amazing.  I would recommend the crab salad and mussels to start.  Great Entree choices are the braised short ribs and duck breast.  As for dessert, the creme brûlée and the blue cheese platter was my favorite.  One suggestion is to add some crackers and an extra slice of of blue cheese to the plate.  The plate just seemed very bare and lonesome.  Other than that, a great experience and I will be back to try other items.
author: Food C.

description:
Dine About Town Menu! :) Third visit at Isa!

You come to Isa partly for the food and partly for the impeccable service. The waiter staff is very knowledgeable in the menu and is always there by your side for whenever you need ANYTHING. The bread basket was never empty and the water glass will always be at least half full. They have kind, friendly, and efficient. If I had my own restaurant, I would want to steal this waitstaff at Isa! 

On to the food...

1. Lobster Broth - I really enjoyed this broth as it was very fresh and clean. It wasn't fattening and buttery as I would've imagined it to be. The prawns were a good addition to the dish. 

2. Mussels - This dish was decent, but definitely not the most flavorful mussels I've had. Some of them actually had that fishy stench, but not a whole lot. The broth was good with bread though.

3. Crab Salad - Generous portion! There were four little salad cups with generous servings of dungeness crab meat. This was very refreshing and delicious!

4. Risotto - This was kind of a disappointment. It was rather watery and the amount of cheese made it too rich. In addition, I think that it could have used more flavor from the mushrooms. 

5. Duck Breast - The meat was so tender that it didn't even taste like duck! I really enjoyed this dish and wished I had ordered this instead. 

6. Steak - People at my table raved about the tenderness of the steak and the sauce. I didn't get to try it, but it sure looked yummy!

7. Scallops - Not a big portion for those of you who are hungry. 

8. Creme Brulee - The consistency of the creme brulee was pretty good. It had the nice bitterness and caramelization from the sugar and sweetness of the custard. It would have been nice served with some fresh berries!

9. Semifreddo - Very almondy for those who like that. It tasted somewhere between a cake and ice cream. Can't really pinpoint it, but don't think I liked it very much...

Overall, the food and service here is great. Would definitely come back! :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
Isa is a solid group dining spot in the Marina.  My wife and I recently went there on a double date, and we all enjoyed it.

The setup is interesting.  The restaurant appears to be small and narrow up front, but the back is quite expansive.  In fact, I've only ever sat in the back, which appears to be a backyard patio converted for indoor use.  There looks to be a retractable roof of sorts, but I think they keep it covered year-round.  Heating lamps make the area very cozy.  I actually enjoyed the unique experience of being semi-outdoors much more than dining indoors as is the case with almost every restaurant.

The food here is served tapas style, so we ordered a bunch of small plates to be shared.  We went on a Sunday, which gave us the opportunity to order from a special, discounted prix fixe menu ($29.95 for 2 courses + dessert) .   However, we opted to "ball out" by select several dishes from the regular menu.  We did manage to take advantage of one prix fixe set given the number of items.   The waiter was very helpful in pointing this out for us.

As I mentioned, we tried a bunch of small plates including:

- The Yellowfin Tuna, which had spice/flavor that I really enjoyed
- The Endive Frisee Salad, which was just decent in my opinion
- The Arugula Salad, which was excellent and the better of the two salads we tried
- The Prawns, which were large in both size and flavor
- The Rack of Lamb, which was excellent (there were only 3 pieces, so we added a 4th piece pro rata)
- The spaghetti, which was just OK
-  The Potato Wrapped Seabass, which we were told was the most famous dish and lived up to its name
-  and, finally the Mussels, which all but confirmed to me that I have a shellfish allergy albeit limited to mollusks (the rest of the table enjoyed the dish for what it's worth)

The desserts we ordered were both fantastic:  Creme Brulee and the Semifredd Amaretto.

I'm definitely coming back.
author: Sebastian N.

description:
I will say... I was impressed. Came here for a special event to enjoy some wonderful food with Lorrie M. and if it wasn't for her, I would have never found out about this place. It was a group of us that went to enjoy some specials they were offering that night. Needless to say, the food there was absolutely wonderful.

My gf and I also took advantage of their Prix Fixe and ordered the salmon carpaccio as our first course, the steak as our 2nd, and the grapefruit granita as our 3rd. Coupled with the brioche specials, it was absolutely magnificent.

Towards the end, my gf decided to order more of the special brioche as well as the creme brulee. I can not describe in words how wonderful my meal was. I would undeniably say the best I've had in years. Granted in the end, the bill absolutely reflected that.. lol.. OOPS.

but was it worth it? OH YES.
author: Trung N.

description:
Wow, a completely different experience our second time back. As I noted before, the restaurant contacted me, saddened at the first experience, and invited us back for another try. The manager/owner greeted us at door, thanked us for coming back, and seated us in a completely different area of the restaurant that I didn't even know existed, a gorgeous tented spot in the back (good for big groups, too!). I was a little concerned that it would be strained having voiced our previous negative experience, but she was gracious and did not discuss it at all.

We received two glasses of champagne upon seating, and promptly placed our order. I noticed on the menu this time that it stated the dishes came out as ready in a more family style presentation, and the manager emphasized this as well when handing us our menus. Setting this expectation up front made all of the difference, as we ordered things we knew we'd both like and didn't feel like we had to wait for the other person's food. She had mentioned previously that it would be on the house and we didn't want to take advantage of this with ordering lots of drinks, but our server encouraged us to enjoy a drink with our dinner, so we ordered two different chardonnays, and both tasted great.

I started with the smoked salmon, and my boyfriend had the crab salad. Both were delicious, but I liked mine better.  I had ordered it last time as well, and both times it was so fresh and the seasoning/toppings were perfect accompaniments. For my main, I ordered the scallops and my date the teriyaki beef. Again, both were tasty and perfectly prepared, and the sides were very complimentary.

We were full and tried to decline desserts, but our server insisted on trying the creme brulee and brought us out two dessert drinks with it. We somehow managed to scarf down the dessert as well :) We left a tip for both of our times there, as this more than made up for the last. Thank you Isa for inviting us again; we will be back soon!
author: Sarah B.

description:
We went to Isa as we got a recommendation from two different friends but were rather disappointed. 

The atmosphere was really nice especially in the back but the food was really not good. The grilled calamari was served with white beans and very intense olives which just didn't work very well together. The fish of the day was ok but came again with these olives. Also the spinach and the mussels can be prepared in a much more delicious way. 

I wouldn't recommend this restaurant.
author: BettyLou H.

description:
Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese
+
Grilled Local Calamari
+
Maple Leaf Farm Duck Breast 
=
Delicious!!!
author: Elena P.

description:
First Impression: Who do these people think they are? We are a table of four, we have a groupon and people ordering from pre-fixe. Why is this a problem?! The waiter simply said "not allowed" rolled his eyes, huffed away. We asked for the manager, she basically made every excuse in the book. We asked her unprofessionally dressed self (Jeans and a plaid shirt? Really?) if we should just leave or split our table. She started retracting all her statements. I've seen "one groupon per table." I've seen "groupon excludes certain items" but to say that if one person uses a groupon, nobody else at the table can order what they want? Especially when my friend is a regular? Considering the prices, Customer Service Fail. 

That being said, they let us order, switched our waiter to the fabulous Luis. Luis saved this experience for me. He was busy but kind, attentive, professional (unlike the previously mentioned staff...) and just a ton of fun. 

We ordered 11 dishes, 6 glasses of wine. Don't even begin to tell me that they were losing money. 

The food? OMG IT WAS SO GOOD! The menu was fantastic everything was orgasmic. (see pictures for what we had) Being 11 dishes, I'm not going to describe them all, but the highlights for me were: Tuna Tartare, Foie gras, and halibut.   

Since I have tried most things on the menu now, I'm looking forward to what sort of new dishes are to come later in the fall/winter!
author: Susan C.

description:
My family considers Isa a 'family celebration' restaurant where we go for our birthdays, anniversaries, even thanksgiving and new years. It is quite good for the reasonable price. Indoor seating is limited, outdoor patio is covered and heated properly. Ambience is good. Its california-french fusion food is true to the taste of its founders a caucasian+asian family. Changing owners did not dilute the great taste of Isa, and many great waiters are retained. This is a good reasonably upscale dining place, good for dates, celebrations, a place to pop champagne and enjoy a good meal. 

Salad here are good: arugula salad is light and very much argula oriented with a bit of cheese, not too much distracting dressings, baby lettuce is crispy! Halibut is my dad's favorite fall back, but sometimes it appears to be grilled for two long - a bit of inconsistency over the years. Tuna tartare has always been good. This is somewhat a tapa like place, with medium small size plates meant to be shared across the table. The family style attracts quite a few trendy modern Asian families, the seafood appeals to my Japanese visitors too
author: Dilys S.

description: Awesome li'l joint to say the least - French cooking that tastes amazing and is actually [gulp] healthy.  One of the folks in our party has Celiac disease, so the gluten free aspect of this place was important, for health reasons.  There are only a few items on the menu with an asterisk indicating they contain gluten - so watch out for that - and also the fact that they offer bread (since it is a French restaurant, well duh...).  However, note to all the Celiacs (silly yaks?) out there: You can see when you walk by the kitchen that all the bread is cut in a separate area, well-segregated from the rest of the goings-on.  So it's nice that Isa takes this seriously.  Every dish we ordered was a '10' in terms of flavor, aroma, texture...you name it.  Cool ambiance especially in the back room.
author: Fred M.

description:
Perfect place to enjoy a delicious dinner with friends in an upscale, yet relaxed venue. 

I came here with a group of 6 friends and tried their prix fixe menu. The dishes seemed to be intentionally shareable, so we just tried as many as possible. 

We started with their mussels which were good. I definitely appreciated that the bread at our table was replenished quite frequently, that way ensuring that no drop of juice and sauce was wasted. Both the crab salad and the goat cheese with tomato & basil were good, bright, and refreshing dishes. The salmon carpaccio to my disappointment was underseasoned. 

Moving on to the main courses, we tried the steak which was cooked and seasoned to perfection. Similarly well executed was the baked chicken with its delectable crispy skin. The funghi risotto was spot on. The seared scallops with asparagus and the halibut were the two weaker main dishes 

I definitely want to come back as soon as possible. I really enjoyed their friendly service, their tasty food, and the buzzing atmosphere of the restaurant in the outdoor patio.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Came here in a party of four for their Dine about Town menu. We decided to do family style to try as many of the second and third courses as possible. They also say that they design those dishes to be shared which made the experience all the more enjoyable.

What we tried:

Lobster Bisque - Absolutely delicious, and not skimpy on the protein either.

Potato Leek Soup - Nice creamy texture. Good flavor too.

Salmon Carpaccio - Generous amounts of salmon served with sides of crostini

Yellowfin Tuna Tartare - Fresh raw fish and avocado is always a winning combination in my book.

Steamed Mussels - Served with grilled bread. We kept getting more bread to soak up all the leftover sauce which was simply amazing.  

Baked Goat Cheese - I wasn't a huge fan of this dish, probably because I'm not that into cheese. Two members of our party really liked it though.

Seared Scallops - Probably my favorite entree. Beautifully seared scallops with bacon mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts. Can't go wrong.

Petrale Sole - Not a huge fan of this dish. Fish had a nice crisp on the outside but it was a little too overcooked for my liking. Beets were pretty tasty though and I'm not generally a fan of beets.

Truffle Mushroom Risotto - Pretty good, didn't think it was that special though. 

Flank Steak - Tender and had a good flavor from the sauce.

Grapefruit Granite - Didn't think I would like this but I was pleasantly surprised. Grapefruit flavor was prominent and refreshing.

Semifreddo Amaretto - Not too heavy and not overly sweet. Dessert is my least favorite course though, so I didn't care too much about it.

Vanilla Bean Creme Brulee - Pretty good I guess...again, not a huge fan of dessert.

I'm normally not a huge fan of fine/upscale dining due to the smaller more "refined" portion sizes. But Isa showed me that it's possible to create refined dishes while actually filling people up. I actually felt that this meal was well worth the $45 we each paid after tip and tax.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Isa served up bland unimaginative food and lackluster service during our most recent visit for SF Restaurant Week. 

We were seated promptly. However, that was the highlight of the attentive service we received. At 6:30 on a Sunday night, the restaurant was about 2/3 full. There were several staff milling around, yet we still had to actively hail down someone to take our order after a 10-minute wait. 

The dishes are meant to be served family style and will arrive as soon as it's ready per Isa staff. Great concept, but the order of how our food came out was plain odd. We got the potato leek soup (Avoid! It's a bland potato mix with bits of parsley. The leek flavor was nowhere to be found.), followed by the salmon carpaccio, then the mushroom truffle risotto, before the yellowtail salad finally made it's way to our table. It does not make sense, and it's a huge no-no, to serve a cold appetizer AFTER a hot entree. We grabbed a server to make the complaint, but all we got was a shrug and "Well, we can reheat the risotto for you." So much for attentive and competent service. 

The food itself was forgetful at best. The creme bulee dessert was probably the best thing on the prie fixe menu. The flat iron steak was flavorable but on the small side, especially when paired with mounds of zucchini and string beans. 

We also ordered the foie gras at $24/serving. It was a disappointing experience. The foie gras tasted greasy from the excessive oil used to sear it. And, it wasn't good quality foie gras either. I had better seared ones at Naked Lunch and they are priced lower too!
author: Jessica K.

description: The food here is great (particularly the semifreddo dessert, yum), and the prix fixe menu is a good value for SF standards, but the service could be better. The first time I went here the issue was that the service was slow - food took forever to come out. This time around I really didn't like our waitress. I was with a group of 8, and multiple times she stopped by and asked us if we wanted drinks - no, we didn't, and that didn't change throughout the night - to the point where it felt like it was too pushy. Also, not all of us got dessert and she took multiple opportunities to point out that NOT EVERYONE has a dessert. Ok, we get it, lady - not everyone ordered prix fixe, we didn't get drinks, and you want more tip money. With so many restaurants in SF I wouldn't consider coming back here if I have to be served by waitresses like this.
author: Madonna N.

description:
Came here the other night for Dine about Town. When I first walked in, through the narrow hallway, I thought this was going to be a very small restaurant. Our hostess kept walking through the hallway and lead us out into the gorgeous back patio. The patio is enclosed so you are sheltered from the cold, but Isa has it decorated giving off the impression you are outside. They line the walls and ceiling with small lights giving it a very romantic vibe. If possible, ask to sit outside. Ok, on to the food. 

I was not very impressed by the soup (both the lobster broth and potato and leek soup) or the dessert. I ordered the leek soup and the first couple spoonfuls were just too oily. I had a taste of my boyfriend's lobster broth and it was nothing impressive. However, the oysters and braised ribs were delicious. The ribs just fell off the bone and they were very generous with the amount of meat they served.  For a 4 course meal, I thought $37.95 was very well worth it. However, I don't know if this is a place I would visit again.
author: Cindy A.

description: Warm friendly service and fantastic gluten free French food. We really enjoyed our dinner here and will be back. The only drawback was the noise level due to two large parties.
author: Kaitlyn H.

description: Just had another great dinner here.  This is a go-to place for me to take friends and family from out of town.  The menu always has something to please everyone. Tonight, we walked in with no reservation but were seated right away. I had the seafood paella and the duck breast (came with cheesy potatoes, yum), which never disappoints.  The table next to us had the special, which was a short rib dish that looked delicious and hearty.  The bartender/server guy tonight was very informative, friendly, and enthusiastic. Ambiance was quiet despite the close tables and small space in the front half of the restaurant.
author: Kari L.

description:
made a reservation for 2 on a sunday night.  It was packed and we couldn't get seated for about 15 minutes past our reservation time.  it's a cramped space.  I sort of wish there was more space between tables because I could hear the conversation next to me very easily.  

we did the prix-fix 4 course dinner.  it was 40 per person, discounted b/c of the SF restaurant week promotion.  

first course - potato leek soup & the arugula salad.  the soup was delicious but i thought the salad was underwhelming. 

second course- salmon and mussels.  i recommend the mussels.  the wine sauce they cook it in is great and can double as a dip for the bread should you grow tired of butter.  

3rd course- short ribs & scallops.  scallops were some of the best i've had, but the short ribs were a bit salty.  

dessert - creme brûlee & amaretto - i'm not a huge fan of creme brûlée in general but the amaretto was great.  there was a cookie garnish on the side that didn't really go with it all that well but the amaretto itself was delightful.  highly recommend.
author: Mason T.

description:
Good food, good portion sizes, and good service! We were here for Dine About Town... we arrived early to our reservation (which was pretty late on a Friday evening) and they ended up seating us a bit early. 

They recommend doing the dishes family style, since the food doesn't come out all at once because of the limited kitchen size. The four of us tried to order as many different things as we could so that we could try everything and we tried 4 different dishes for each course, except for soup dessert :)

Some favorites:
- Lobster Bisque
- Tuna Tartare
- Mussels: Good portion size and the sauce was so good! The waiter totally encouraged us when we were dipping extra bread in the sauce. 
- Salmon Carpaccio 
- Scallops - Not a huge portion but was delicious with mashed potatoes, brussel sprouts, and bacon
- Truffle Mushroom Risotto
- Vanilla Bean Creme Brulee

The only dish that I didn't really like was the goat cheese appetizer, but I'm not a fan of goat cheese in general so I wasn't expecting to enjoy it much. Other than that, everything we tried was really good!

This seems like a good place to come and talk while you enjoy your food. Since the kitchen is pretty small and food may take a bit longer to come out, you'll have plenty of time to chat with your dining companions... unfortunately, one of the tables near us was ridiculously loud and rowdy so it was really hard for us to talk and hear each other, but that's probably my only complaint about this place. Service was really friendly and generous with bread... we were really hungry when we got seated since it was a late dinner.
author: Sophie Y.

description: Went here for a Valentine's Day celebration and the food portions are huge to share and delicious too.  Service was spot on and they didn't rush us at all.  It's a great place for dinner and cocktails.  Definitely coming back.
author: Kathy C.

description: Fantastic place to dine.  We had a bunch of seafood tapas and they were all unique, tasty with very clean flavor. Use of fresh herbs made the dishes unique and with subtle flavor.  Crab salad was extremely good.  Calamari was very tender and grilled perfectly.  Mussels were good but a bit more juice might be desirable. The paella had an abundant of seafood and all very well cooked. If there is one criticism, the paella did not come with socarrat (toasty crust of rice). A must try place. Parking was pretty challenging though.
author: Anne K.

description:
This came recommended from local friends and also from Yelpers. We needed a good spot in the Marina for a date.

Place wasn't super busy. We sat in a cute space in the back which is "SF outdoors" - zipped up and not really outside but it has the ability to be if it's nice out.

It was a tapas-esque dinner so we shared all the dishes and a bottle of wine. First we had the butter lettuce salad, curious what "butter" lettuce meant. It was pretty basic ... felt like iceberg lettuce with some candied walnuts, pear and blue cheese. Then we had the hamachi special. That was amazing! The fish quality was delicious. The we went all meat on our entrees. We shared the steak and the rack of lamb. All of it was delicious. 

It was a nice dinner but I was a bit overwhelmed by our waiter. He was passionate and over the top about everything. It was nice at first but as the evening went on he was overzealous about everything and it was a bit too much to handle. I wish he was a bit calmer. It was all good and I felt he was trying to convince us of it all over and over again.

It was mostly yummy but pricey and so I hold them to a higher standard. Since the salad was meh and service was a bit too intense I took off a couple stars. I would recommend it though, just get seated with a calmer waiter and avoid the salad we had. I recommend everything else!
author: Dalia M.

description:
Went to this place with my boyfriend on a Sunday night since a friend of his recommended it. I was surprised to find out that they weren't very busy the night we went, which is also very fortunate since we did not make a reservation prior to going. The restaurant is larger than it seems and has a beautiful, sheltered and heated patio at the back. The waiters are warm and courteous, and the food was delicious!

We ordered the Salmon Carpaccio and the Maine Lobster Broth for our appetizers. My boyfriend absolutely raved about the Lobster Broth and said that he would come to Isa for that alone, while I enjoyed the Salmon Carpaccio as well. The salmon had a hint of lemon, was very fresh, and the textures were amazing. We would order both again. Unfortunately, they were out of the Dungeness Crab Salad when we went, but we are definitely going to try that next time.

For our main course, I ordered the Truffle Risotto while my boyfriend ordered the Flat Iron Steak. The Truffle Risotto was amazing. The texture of the risotto was just right, and the mushrooms were delectable. It reminded me very much of Lupa Trattoria's Fettuccine Tartufate, which is just about my absolute favorite pasta dish that I've had in all my 25 years of life (but that's a review for another time). The Flat Iron Steak was also very delicious, and reminded me of the steak frites from Le Relais de l'Entrecôte in Paris since the moutarde verte that they topped the steak with is very similar to the ones from Le Relais. You can also choose other side dishes to come with the steak, but I highly recommend sticking to the moutarde verte. You can't go wrong! 

For dessert I ordered the Flourless Chocolate Cake. This is probably my one disappointment, but only because I was expecting a very dense chocolate cake like the ones they serve at The House (which is mindblowingly amazing). I could tell that the cake was straight out of the oven though as it was piping hot and incredibly fresh. It was a more spongy cake than I would have liked, but it was served with a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream and I enjoyed myself despite my expectations.

Overall, this restaurant just shot up to one of my top 5 places to eat in San Francisco, and I have lived here for 4 years now. Great for dates, and good to bring a family and friends as well! In fact, I am thinking of dragging a few people here for my birthday this year. Can't wait to come back!
author: Clarisse V.

description:
I made reservations about 2 weeks in advance for my birthday dinner for a party of 4. When we arrived, the greeter sat us immediately at a lovely table in the outdoor patio space in the back. I loved the decorated patio with outdoor heaters near each table to accommodate for any weather. 

It was the perfect ambience  for a double date. It was a little noisy so sometimes had a difficult time hearing each other from across the table, but it wasn't distracting. When it was a little chilly, the employees adjusted the space heaters to accommodate our preferences and somehow knew exactly when we were getting too warm to turn it down. 

The waiter was a dear. He explained to us all of the specials of the day, gave us recommendations and when he didn't have a definite answer about certain wines, he went out of his way to ask the cooks or another employee to ensure that he provided the best recommendations. 

The food was absolutely delicious. We ordered the fish special, crab and lobster soup, scallops, and truffle risotto. Everything tasted amazing but I think the truffle risotto was our favorite. 

My friends secretly told the waiter that it was my birthday and he surprised me with the best creme brulee I had ever tasted and sang happy birthday :) 

Everyone was so accommodating and eager to help. They didn't complain or act weird when I asked for a bandaid for a blister...or when I told them that I had dropped my lipstick...the greeter helped me look around the restaurant for it, checked the lost and found AND even gave me a call the next day to let me know that they still haven't found it but will keep an eye out. 

I think that deserves 5 stars in of itself for being so helpful and caring. 

I will definitely be back again!
author: Christine N.

description:
3.5 Stars.  This is mostly because of my friend's meal as mine was a lot better.  We both came here for Dine About Town last night.  Was seated promptly in the patio area next to a heated lamp.  Our "main" server (and I say that as he stated they are all our wait staff) was very charming and informative.  Here's the breakdown:

1st course
We both ordered the lobster bisque.  It was delicious.  Try it with the bread.  I ran into another friend there too who stated the leek soup was not as good.

2nd course
I had the mussels.  The mussels itself were ok. The sauce though I really enjoyed.  Especially with the bread it came with.  My friend and I were lapping it up.  She ordered the crab salad that was refreshing.  I was expecting more flavors but I guess it couldn't be as rich as the sauce I had with the mussels.

3rd course (where we diverged)
My friend received her Grilled golden gate natural angus Flat iron steak with zucchini, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce first.  It was...disappointing.  The steak was way too salty.  That stood out too much for its own good.  And weirdly enough, the bordelaise sauce made the rest of the steak almost taste like duck.  It was a very uncomfortable course.  It was a very small cut of steak to begin with and she could only stomach eating less than half of it. Yikes! 

I had the Maple leaf farm Duck breast with baby spinach, pinenuts, currants, bacon & sherry vin sauce which was a much better course.  The duck was also a bit salty but not as much as the steak.  The spinach and currents were a good compliment.  It also came with a type of potato hash/pancake thing that did not work with the dish.

4rd course
My Semifreddo all'amaretto was delicious but i LOVE amaretto.  My friend's Vanilla bean creme brulee was...underwhelming.  It was just a bit bland.

On to service, I had to ask for more water and remind them of our bread request twice.  I also requested a cup of coffee to have with my dessert.  They never brought it.  After our desserts were done I told the same waiter to cancel my coffee request then he stated "Oh yea! I'm sorry I forgot about that." So yea...

Either case, for $37.95 for a four course meal, it was a good deal.  I don't know if I would eat here otherwise.  And in all, my actual meal choices were fairly successful.  Just don't get the steak if you come for DAT.
author: Kim D.

description:
I have been there for a few times, and every time I enjoyed the great food, top notch service, and the cozy open air seating.
Isa  is definitely one of my favorite restaurant in the city!
author: Ayin P.

description:
Great meal this time around. I don't know why I only gave 3 stars last time, maybe I was just feeling cheap. We ordered the duck, short ribs, lamb and the goat cheese, all of which were great.

The goat cheese is one of the few non-meat dishes I would stab someone in the eye for if it were ever taken off the menu.
author: Huey N.

description:
Came here last night for my cousin's birthday. This is not your typical French Restaurant. You get your orders fast and you don't have to wait for like a hour for your food to come out. The waiter also mention that all the food is cooked to order. Our whole party ordered through the 3 course Prix Fix Menu for $29.95 per person only available Sunday thru Thursday. The waiter said these dishes are created like Tapas so we could share. I was shocked at the portions, its quite generous for tapas.

For my 1st course I ordered the Smooth Potato Leek Soup with parsley, chives & cream. This has a very frothy, and I also tasted Truffle Oil. It tasted the best when you dip bread into the soup.

For my 2nd course I ordered the Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with zucchini, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce. I absolutely love this dish and I loved the sauce. The steak was delish; however, next time I might order it medium rare. The fingerling potatoes were cooked to perfection also had a nice little sear on it to as crunch when you bite in.

For my desert I originally ordered the Semifreddo all' amaretto but since I was so full from the appetizer and entree I decided to change it to the Grapefruit granite which is more like a icy sorbet. The Grapefruit granite was not the best tasting for me but that's because I've never been a fan of grapefruit. every bite was flavorful I tasted sweet, sour and bitter at the same time. I had a taste of the Semifreddo all' amaretto with is a gelato with Macaroons and I prefer this desert more. 

Since it was my cousins birthday they gave her a complimentary Vanilla bean crème brulée. We all got a taste, and I think it was quite good, very light textured and delish.

Basically,

Food - I give 5 star for all the flavors, my pallet was having a great time.
Service - our waiter was super friendly and catered to our needs; however, I was missing a steak knife, but no biggy I made it work with my butter knife.
Ambiance and Decor -  very intimate, and perfect lighting not too bright not too dark.
Overall Experience - I loved it, I liked how its not the typical french restaurant where you wait for a very long time before your food is ready. Definitely will come back.
author: Susan K.

description:
8pm reservation for a party of six. We were on-time but restaurant had slow eaters. So we had to wait 15min to get seated. But it was worth it, their dine-about-town was superb! 36.95 for four course and served in family style. With so many of us, we got try out quite a bit of courses. We sat in the back patio/tent with plenty of heated lamps to keep us toasty. We had a friendly and funny server as well.

We gobbled everything down with a bottle of Chardonnay. Here's goes:

1st:
Lobster Bisque
Smooth Potato Leek Soup

2nd:
Tomales bay Pt Reyes oysters 
Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio
Arugula salad 
Steamed Prince Edward island mussels
Dungeness crab salad 
Yellowfin tuna

Main:
Pan roasted rocky Jr. Range chicken
Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak 
(special) slow cooked Ribs
Pan Seared Scallops
Filet of Sole
Maple leaf farm duck breast

Dessert:
Ice Cream with Amaretto 
Grapefruit ice
Creme Brulee

Will be back for sure!!
author: Vee V.

description:
Seabass wrapped in potato..the seabass wasn't even cooked all the way, and was slightly cold in the middle, but can still eat it. It was super small and cost a lot!

The medium-rare lamb was good, the veggies was ok, though the eggplant was a bit bland and olives were super salty. The lamb came like lollipops basically 3 only..how sad..the portions are so small..

yes, i understand its family style, but unless u have a bunch of $$$ growing out of no where, yes brace yourself for small ass portions and mediocre taste in food.

the oysters were $1, special..and THAT was on the best so far..i mean the lamb was good,  tender and juicy, but eh...

service was good, we load up on bread, and got water filled quickly..it got packed around 7:30pm..came little before 7pm, but eh..I had better FRENCH food..REAL French food that is..
author: Minerva L.

description:
Enjoyed their Dine About Town menu.  We went for dinner on Tuesday night and it wasn't very crowded and we got seated right away.  

My favorites from dinner were: 
-yellowfin tuna tartare was fresh and delicious.  
-risotto was cooked perfectly and I liked the incorporation of mushroom
-the short ribs were good, I really liked the sides that came with it too

Their soup was pretty disappointing - the chowder was very watery, wouldn't really consider it a chowder.  But I figure it shouldn't really be held against them since they give you a 4-course dinner instead of the standard 3.  

One of my more impressive Dine About Town experiences.  I'd definitely come back for that tartare.
author: Gloria N.

description:
I really enjoyed my time here at this restaurant. Service was excellent and that BREAD.  So soft, so crunchy, so perfect OHMYGAWD.

I came here for dinner and sat outside on a warm evening (rare). I ordered off of the fixed menu and tried the following:

Steamed Prince Edward island mussels - ok. Not terrible but not anything special. They were very mini itty bitty mussels.

Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio - really good. but how can you mess up smoked salmon on toasted bread anyway?

Truffle risotto - was just ok. There was a lot of hype for this dish on yelp but I didn't find it anything special. And yes, I'm a fan of truffled anything but this dish just wasnt worth the calories for me.

Pan Roasted Rocky Jr. Range chicken - the piece I had was amazingly tender and crispy and I usually don't get fried chicken because it tends to be dry. However, the part of the chicken my boyfriend had was dry so I guess it's a hit or miss.

Semifreddo all' amaretto - my boyfriend and I did not like this one at all. I am a huge dessert fan and really wished that there were more options that were actually appealing. This dessert really just tasted like bad old cream that had been sitting out.

Despite the food being just ok, I still really enjoyed my dinner, the ambiance, the service, and would be willing to try other items on the menu to give the food another shot and maybe I'll have to tried their soju cocktails :)
author: Sandy T.

description:
Atmosphere: 5 stars
Food: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars

We read about the prix fixe menu [3 courses for $28] and were sold. 

ATMOSPHERE
The back patio area is the best seating. The wood floors and walls, the dim lighting, the heat lamps are all amazing. It's more spacious than the inside restaurant, but still warm with the heat lamps. Perfect for large parties as well. 

FOOD:  served FAMILY STYLE
The prix fixe menu was fantastic. We had a party of 3 but since this place serves everything family style, we got 2 prix fixe orders, and an extra order of seared scallops. 

SCALLOPS
Seared scallops with asparagus, potato puree & truffle jus de poulet. This was an expensive dish, but absolutely amazing. The scallops were cooked to perfection, melting in your mouth, and seasoned nicely. The potatoes were lightly salted and paired perfectly. 

SALMON CARPACCIO
Organic Loch Duart Salmon carpaccio with lemon, crème fraiche, cucumber, egg, capers & crostini. This is a delicious appetizer. So light, but still flavorful, i wanted to eat the whole thing by myself. 

CORN, LEEK, POTATO SOUP
Smooth summer white corn, leek & potato soup with sautèed corn, parsley & chives. This wasn't my favorite dish. We used the bread and dipped it in the soup instead. It was nice, warm, and unique, but we didn't eat much of it. 

HALIBUT
Northern Halibuta la plancha with olive oil, parsley, nicoise olives, zucchini, artichoke & tomato confit. By far my favorite entree. The halibut fell apart as soon as my fork touched it. It was soft, flaky, and absolutely amazing with the mandarin oranges.

FLAT IRON STEAK
Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with zucchini, potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce. Very tender steak. I was really full by the time we got to the steak, so the fact that the meat is not that big, and cut up for us into smaller pieces, was a huge plus!

GRAPEFRUIT GRANITE
Delicioussssss. It's just shaved ice with grapefruit flavoring. Can't really justify the price, but since it's part of the prix fixe, and so refreshing, i was quite happy. 

SEMIFREDDO ALL' AMARETTO
Vanilla bean ice cream, amaretto, and biscotti. We loved this dessert as well. The light vanilla with the perfect touch of ameretto was amazing. Perfect finish.

CAPPUCCINO / CAFE
I think they serve Cafe Roma. I thought it wasn't as smooth as Illy or Lavazza, but it did the job. 

WINE: 
Stephen Vincent 2007 Crimson
We got a bottle and it was such a good price. I normally expect wines to be $50-60 for a bottle, but this was about $35. Pleasantly surprised and happy since their wine list was quite impressive.
author: Debby L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Isa for dinner last night. First of all, our waiter (Dean) was incredibly helpful with giving a rundown of the entire menu.
We started with the oysters and yellowfin tuna. The oysters were incredibly fresh and served with a spicy orange mignonette. If you are into oysters, these are a must! The mignonette is the perfect balance of sweet and spicy with the salty oyster. The yellowfin tuna was also a great dish, which was served much like a tuna tartare with a little spice. The yellowfin was simple, yet beautifully done. 
For our main course, I got the flatiron steak and my boyfriend got the scallops. Both dishes were great! The steak was cooked to perfection and incredibly juicy. 
Lastly, for dessert we ordered the creme brûlée. Oh.my.lanta! It was delicious. I even considered ordering a second creme brûlée despite the fact that I was ridiculously full.

Overall, Isa is a great go-to date spot with fantastic food!
author: Krista G.

description:
Tomales bay Pt Reyes oysters (6) on the half shell with spicy orange mignonette ($12): Very fresh, but lacked on the meat part. Loved the sauce in the center of the plate. Overall, oyster craving was satisfied. 
http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nMwQB2zY2Fmwiio4ojOkQg/l.jpg

Steamed Prince Edward island mussels with garlic, white wine, parsley & grilled bread ($13): Sooo GOOD! The mussels were cooked right, the sauce was really good and I couldn't help but drink it by spoonfuls cause the white wine sauce was so good. 
http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vUljtbZxy3hEEytWUHczXQ/l.jpg

Hudson valley grade A foie gras with poached pears, huckleberrys & custard brioche ($22): Foie gras was made to perfection and the custard brioche was good too. I just wasn't a fan of the sauce that the foie gras with sitting on. It was just too sweet for me.  
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hNCCP9T2qk-IwspPYtqhZQ/l.jpg

Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with haricots verts, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce ($21): mMmmm very tender! They gave a nice amount of green beans and potatoes. Overall, awesome dish. 
http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/YHVrhNcW_11_ej7v5dmLAQ/l.jpg

Maple leaf farm duck breast with red beet, arugula, goat cheese, & huckleberry sauce ($22): This was the dish I ordered. Duck medium rare and it was phenomenal. Very tender, the red beets, arugula and goat cheese was really paired well with the huckleberry sauce and duck. 
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BNkRf8Hmfp9bicNa40amsg/l.jpg

Grapefruit granite ($6): I wasn't a fan of this dish, just way to sour. If you like grapefuit, this would be a good dish for you.
http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/mFeat1uRZDxJo1MoXyoEpw/l.jpg

Vanilla bean crème brulée ($6): One of the best creme brulees that I had. My friend even finished his creme brulee and stole more from our bowl!! BF was sad I cracked the sugar coating before he did. The layer of sugar was thick enough to not be soggy and thick enough for the portion of the creme in the bowl. LOVED IT!
http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AbiSf60jOnZhBS0UUxHEmA/l.jpg

Semifreddo all' amaretto ($6): Very rich, but very good. 
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6tFirbs1mzB7A1HESKq9wQ/l.jpg

White wine that came free with the mean (for dine about town Sunday-Thurs ONLY) was good. It had a hint of pear to it. Wish i got the name.....Red wine on the other hand wasn't to my liking.

I listed the prices of each individual dish; however, I paid the $34.95 Dine About Town price with the additional $22 for the foie gras.

Service was phenomenal! From the reservations to the last min change of number of people to the end of dinner.  Waiter was also a good salesman, got my friend to order a glass of wine to pair with his foie gras, that cost him $9 for a small glass! HAHA
author: Erica T.

description: While I had a very nice time/meal at Isa the dishes were hit and miss... Crab salad = It was good but could use a little more crab and a little less tarragon.  Calamari = sounded really good but this dish did not work at all, an odd combo of ingredients with too many textures. Salmon tartare = bland. Flat iron steak = very good. Asparagus = great! With so many option in the area I probably won't be back but at the same time it was fine and don't regret going there.
author: James N.

description: Have been here twice. Each time we loved it. Wonderful service and amazing food. We shared each.course and was extremely happy with everything we had.
author: Jay R.

description:
My family and I came here for restaurant week about a month ago, reading the high reviews and seeing the great menu they were offering, we made the trek to inner San Francisco to try it.

It is located in a great neighborhood which is definitely worth another visit. Arriving at Isa, it was packed. Our server brought us to our table and I was excited.

Since it was our first time, our server who was very friendly, described their food as family style, making us expect large portions. However when the food arrived it was a lot smaller that I had expected. Basically you could share, but it looked like it was meant for one person.

The appetizers were OK, but nothing really special.

The entrees were not spectacular. We made the mistake of ordering the spaghetti with truffles. It was basically a small dish of spaghetti with red sauce topped with a lot of salty cheese. It then had some tiny black pieces of "truffles". We didn't think that they used actual truffle in the dish.

The desserts were OK. We liked the grapefruit granita and the amaretto.

I don't think this place is worth the trek across the bay, but if you are in the area, it might be worth a look.

3/5!
author: Perry N.

description:
Am I missing something? I came here last night on a double date and the food was only "okay." What I thought was going to be an amazing night with us rolling outta there so full and satisfied, was more like we all left half full. 

3 out of the 4 of us opted for the pre-fixe menu. 

The starters were:
-Salmon carpaccio: Advertised as the same salmon used at the French Laundry, but I liked the package smoked salmon from Trader Joe's better
-Baked cheese: Was pretty tasty, but doesn't come with anything to put the cheese on. We used the free bread.
-Arugula salad: Don't remember it.

Entrees:
-Chicken: Our 2 guys got this and it was the best dish of the night! Flavorful mashed potatoes and crispy skin on the chicken. Big portion too.
-Flat iron steak: Blue cheese butter all over the top. I prefer it on the side so I can control the portion. Too much blue cheese for the portion of steak. The veggies were also not very pretty to look at.
-Seabass: The 1 think we ordered that wasn't on the pre-fixe. It was tasty, but I thought it was a little rubbery. 

Dessert:
-Semifreddo: Eh. Too sweet for my taste.
-Honey goat cheese: Fiancee was not happy with his dessert. The portion of cheese was too big for the amount of honey and bread given.

Our server was a really nice little man that's worked there for 8 years. He was great, but dear lord, he gave the longest intro at a restaurant I've ever sat through. Our water glasses were kept full sometimes, and I couldn't find a busboy for water refill the others.
author: L M.

description:
Did I enjoy it more than The French Laundry?  Yes I did.

In fact, it was one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco -- right up there with State Bird Provisions and we didn't even have to fight with Ryan Gossling for a table.  

The food was phenomenal, the wine selection was broad and reasonable, and three of us split about 13 dishes without hitting a single bad one.  We sat on the back patio and the ambiance was perfect for a relaxing evening.  Our waiter, Jonathan, was flawless in his service (knowledgeable, attentive and personable), as was the rest of the team.  

Really, an excellent meal.
author: Charles Y.

description:
I came here not knowing what to expect. The atmosphere is very romantic and classy a nice date spot. 

My friend and I started off with the yellow fin tuna it had a nice blend with spinach , avocado, and tuna. It was so delicious!! Then we also tried the glazed calamari it was so good! Cooked to perfection and it was not tough at all. We shared the potato skin wrapped sea bass. It was surprisingly good, the textures played nicely together. It was nicely seasoned it had the right amount of savoriness. I enjoyed the entire meal.

I wish I had tried the desserts they all looked really good. Will be back Here again to try more food! :)
author: Stella J.

description: One of my favorite finer dining restaurants in the city! The staff is generally friendly and attentive, the food is great, and the price for the quality and portions is right. My favorites are the arugala salad and sea bass, and my BF judges duck breast dishes at other restaurants against theirs because he likes it so much (tip: ask for extra sauce). If you go early for dinner, you can also enjoy their $5 happy hour drinks. We usually like to try new places, but keep finding ourselves returning here because we like it so much!
author: Cara R.

description:
I've been to this restaurant twice - once during Dine About Town, and once for a regular Saturday night dinner (two weeks ago). Both experiences have been great - the staff and management are so helpful, attentive, and personable without being intrusive. 

The second time around was a little funny since Danny Glover (Lethal Weapon) was walking out as we were ordering. All the males on our side of the restaurant looked around in shock/excitement while the women sat back and looked confused (myself included)...very entertaining.

My favorite part of both of my meals there was undoubtedly the scallop dish. Ohhhh, the scallops. Beautiful and buttery, smooth and tender, juicy and flavorful. Plus they're bathed in bacon and truffle sauce. Next to brussel sprouts. On mashed potatoes. Too much good stuff.
author: Cristal M.

description: This place was awesome! I brought my family (8 people) from Seattle and the services and food could not have been better. Three courses for $30 -- you don't find that very often in the city. I had the scallops and they were unreal! The goat cheese starter with pesto and pine nuts was fantastic as well. I have to say the braised short rib was the table's favorite. I will definitely be back -- friendly service, nice ambience and delicious food!
author: Whitney W.

description:
More like 3.5 stars but rounding up since they were really nice). We had reservations, we were seated right away in the covered patio area. We ordered:

-Negroni (Blood Orange Bitters, OJ & Campari, $8.50,  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/isa-san-francisco?select=4jXZ_2c7HKoALTgQYhlJqQ#wWTyQ6gAMV9WKwu8Dp94Ug): A solid drink.
-Steamed Prince Edward Island Mussels w/Garlic, White Wine, Parsley, Grilled Bread, ($13, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/isa-san-francisco?select=4jXZ_2c7HKoALTgQYhlJqQ#Z0SVf2ZUHq_dmaB3uAH1Yg): Really good, and they gave you a pretty big bowl of mussels. They were very fresh, and everyone loved the sauce they were served with. Recommended!
-Truffle Risotto w/Baby Shiitake, Hon Shimiji Mushroom, Reggiano ($19, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/isa-san-francisco?select=4jXZ_2c7HKoALTgQYhlJqQ#hKpsgOytef2VwUS2w_aGwg): Pretty good, but I'm not a huge fan of risotto so wouldn't get this dish again. However, if you enjoy risotto and truffle, this is a good dish to sample.
-Semifreddo all' Amaretto ($6, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/isa-san-francisco?select=4jXZ_2c7HKoALTgQYhlJqQ#arjjWV1byNhQbiwvKV1T9g): Pretty good, but not amazing. I wouldn't order this again.

The dishes we had weren't amazing for the most part, but they were all solid dishes that were cooked well, and with fresh ingredients. The service was attentive, but parking in the Marina district was still challenging on a Sunday night. I would recommend trying Isa once, especially if you sign up for their mailing list since you get invited to special events and also coupons for freebies like half a dozen oysters.
author: Amy D.

description:
This is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the city. You want to know why? Two very simple reasons - amazing food AND great service. I love when I run across this beautiful combo. And the rustic, woodsy-cottage ambiance certainly doesn't hurt. I've been here almost 6 times in the past year, with the girl friends, the bf and the parents... For birthdays, dates, girls night out, etc. And it has been perfect for every occasion. 

Here are the dishes I've tried: 

Foie Gras (5 stars)
To die for! Seriously, it's beyond amazing. The waitress also recommended a shot of dessert wine to go with it. Absolutely delish. 

Mussels (4 stars) 
I don't usually like mussels. In fact, I tend to steer clear of them. However, one of my friends ordered this and unfortunately, I couldn't stop picking into her food. It was just that good. 

Truffle Risotto (5 stars) 
Now we're talking. We're back to my territory. I don't mean to sound snobbish but I'm sort of a risotto connoisseur. If a restaurant lists risotto on their menu, you can pretty much assume that's what I'm ordering. So my reviews for risottos are excruciatingly critical. This was perfect in every way, however - cheesy without being over-the-top, buttery, and filled with a variety of different mushrooms, adding to the perfect flavor. 

Vanilla Bean Creme Brulee (5 stars) 
Couldn't have asked for a better way to end the meal. Absolutely great. 

Oh and since Isa is also a wine bar, they have a great wine menu as well. I personally paired everything with a Pinot Noir. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
I cannot tell you enough how perfectly fantastic our meal was at Isa. Every single thing was absolutely fantastic. From the ambiance to the service to the food was five star. It was honestly THE ABSOLUTE BEST MEAL I've had in a very long time. You wouldn't expect from the outside but it is so on point. We started with the point Reyes oysters. 

We each had a half a dozen oysters each to start. They were perfect. No cocktail sauce but the slightly spicy, sweet sauce that came with it was a very nice change. Than we did the risotto, scallops and veal shortbreads. They do small plates for a entrees (kinda like tapas). I really liked it because we got to try more than two dishes. Every single dish was so so good. All three were perfectly balanced and impeccable. We loved everything so much we were using our bread to soak up all of the sauces on every dish because it really was that fantastic.

On top of the amazing food, I also can't say enough about the service. All of the wait staff was more than attentive. I was very impressed. 

I honestly can't wait to go back to Isa. It was the perfect date night spot or any special occasion but also very good for any meal. Please please try Isa! You will not forget it!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Been here a couple of times now and my most recent visit was for Valentines Day 2015.

There was a 4 course Prix-Fix Menu for $49/person if you choose the early seating from 5 PM-5:30 PM. or $79/person with a free glass of champagne.

We went there at 5:30 PM to have a early dinner because I personally don't like to wait and why not move my reservation half hour early to have &60 right?

We got there and was seated immediately and was offered the happy hour menu. We had a total of 4 drink and added the Foie Gras to our dinner. The bill was under $200 with tax and tip! For the price we paid and the quality of the food, it was well worth it. 

The food is served family style - meaning they bring out the food whenever its ready. The food did come out a little too fast because they didn't even clear our plates from the previous course and the next course was already waiting to be served. The tables are also very small and their plates are really big. You cannot even put 3 plates on the table at once... This made me feel very cramped.

Frist:
The Oysters we had as a starter were very fresh and the kitchen did a pretty good job cleaning them except for one where I bit into a shell.

Second:
The Salmon Carpaccio would of been a little colder when served.
The yellow fin tuna tartare was not spicy at all.. even thought they used sriracha

The fruit pair Foie Gras was delicious but like I always say, the Foie Gras portion could of been bigger. ($24 supplement)

Third:
Angus Flat Iron Steak: No comment, I don't eat beef
Maple Leaf Duck Breast was a little over cooked to my liking but the meat was still soft and Juicy.

Forth: (took about 15 mins to come out after they collected out third course dishes)
Flourless Chocolate Cake - typical flourless chocolate cake, nothing to WOW about
Semifreddo all' amaretto- eh... nothing to WOW about either.

Overall experience was good, and I have a nice meal and the atmosphere was pretty quite, probably because I was seated in the front of the restaurant this time whereas all the other times I sat in the back and it gets loud.
author: Jan H.

description:
This is exactly what a restaurant should be like. 

I have celiac so I need to eat gluten free. My husband and I went to Isa because it claimed to have gf options. Basically- the entire menu is gluten free with the exception of two things that come with bread. 

We went here for my birthday and we were extremely impressed. The service was above and beyond what was expected as was the food. The food was so fresh and well seasoned. Everything was also meant to be shared family style so my husband and I ordered two appetizers, two entrees and one dessert and left stuffed (but it was so worth it.) We ordered the duck and the potato wrapped snapper. Both were incredible. 

Best restaurant I've been to in the entire city. We went to Gary Danko's a week prior to this visit and it's better than Gary Danko and much more reasonable on the price.
author: Cassie B.

description:
I'm about 2 weeks backed up on a lot of my reviews, but I figure you have to start somewhere with the queue. Doesn't start any better with this gem of a restaurant in the Chestnut/Marina area. I would describe this food as a French restaurant with some Asian sensibilities mixed in. I was on my way to meet my group of friends including Nina V. (San Diego Yelper!), arrived by the 30 bus and was already late as I made the dash up Steiner street. I looked up at the sign and saw Isa, but for some idiotic reason I ran into the restaurant at 3340. I spent about 5 minutes arguing with the server about there being a table of 11 before I realized, I was in the wrong restaurant! FML

Humped it up the street to the REAL Isa and there they were waiting for me. Friends with fizz faces. As in they were already getting there drink on at the bar. The setting was dark in the front and a very intimate feel perfect for meeting people and getting some happy hour drinks. But if you reserve a table for dinner you will most likely be ushered to the back where there is a back room enclosed garden with a good  number of tables under a sunroof.

I don't necessarily recommend this, but I next to 2 other friends and we ordered a sampling of dishes only for the three of us.

We started off with Arugala Salad, Hudson valley grade A foie gras with Mango and beets instead of the Pears and Huckleberry. For main course dishes we tried the Seared Scallops, Truffle Risotto, Rocky Roasted Chicken, Maple Leaf Farm Duck Breast. I must have really fatty taste because I really enjoyed the foie gras and the combination with mango and beats was strangely satisfying. The piece of foie gras was also the size of a piece of filet mignon! If you are looking to get your foie gras fixe before it becomes outlawed in California 1 July 2012, then this is definitely the place to try it. Second favorite dish was the Truffle Risotto, because it just setup shop in your mouth with so much buttery'ness. The duck breast was also cooked very well, on the moist and rare side, how I prefer it. The food overall was very good!

The server for our table was extremely courteous and helpful in deciding between dishes. However, it was a nightmare at the end of the meal trying to determine how much each person owed, especially when my separate group of three ordered the most food. One waiter explained that they would only accept a split check with 3 cards. That just seemed ridiculous, so we asked another waiter and he overruled our waiter and made things happen. The meal came out to be $50/per our group of 3. This was seems like quite a lot, but in perspective for how much food we ordered, seems reasonable.

Overall, I really enjoyed the experience and would not hesitate to take a date or my parents for a special birthday occasion. Good hearty food, and good service.
author: Michael C.

description:
Last night my dear friend and I had dinner at the restaurant. Amir at the bar was very accommodating throughout the evening and he was accompanied by hostess that was average. We made a reservation for 6 PM and Amir allowed us to have a few drinks at the bar prior to going to the table.  The hostess was dressed pretty casual and we had asked for many things multiple times to get from her (ice, water, etc.) 

The experience during the middle of our dinner was what was so disturbing!  We were eating our entrees and the hostess asked that we move two tables down???  The table was a very small table near the window that was on a booth and you couldn't even see the person  across the table because it's an oval table. I highly recommend you purchase a round table and work on the accommodations near the window. Not suited for two people that want to talk. 

Amir was very accommodating and offered us a dessert and an after dinner drink. Please work with the hostess on her presentation and serving skills
author: Freida O.

description: Consistently good food cranked out. Hubs and I love the lamb chops. So juicy and tender. Butter lettuce salad is delish! I would stay away from the sea bass - it's wrapped w/ potato and tends to come out really dry.
author: Julie L.
