description: Food is pretty good but service can be horrendous. If that doesn't bother you then consider this closer to a four star review. For the money you pay to go here you should expect quality service but it seems that they are occasionally under staffed. I was served a duck breast that wasn't warm but the fish was good enough that I ate t regardless (also waited an hour for it so didn't feel like waiting longer to eat). Other than that, pretty good food and small but nice wine selection. You can find a good wine for any dish, that's for sure.
author: Faiz H.

description:
Came here for DAT because the menu looked interesting. It was nice that the dishes were made to share; this way I can try more of there dishes ^_^Y 

Overall the food was good. My friend with the picky palate thought it was ok. The food had flavor but not to overbearing. The cocktails on the other hand weren't impressive. I would get wine instead to accompany the food. The cocktails seemed interesting so why not try it while I'm here! 

The service was great and the atmosphere was nice! If you don't like noisy places, don't come here because this place is popping! I would come again to try their other dishes. And maybe more of the neighborhood too =]
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
I came here for DAT a few weeks ago with my boyfriend and it was great. 
-Nice outdoor patio
-Generous portions
-faves of the DAT menu: goat cheese app and the pasta
-Nice attentive service
I would come back here!
author: Daniela J.

description:
We recently had a birthday dinner celebration for one of our friend's here and it was a PERFECT restaurant for a large party.

There are two things that capture the essence of Isa:
1. Family style
2. Bread

Let me explain. The whole concept of Isa is French food served family style. We had a group of 6 and each of us were able to try at least fifteen things on the menu because we all shared every single dish. Of course, there was 1 dish that we all agreed was "meh", which was the crab salad. However...the rest of the dishes were A+ phenomenal. This is where the word "Bread" comes in.

The bread was great. If I had to guess it was Acme bread, and boy was there a lot of it. The best part was that every time we got more bread, it came out piping hot. The bread itself was 3-4 star worthy, but what made me realize that Isa was so amazing was that out of the fifteen or so dishes we ordered, I dipped the bread into the remaining juices/sauce/crumbs of each dish and they elevated the bread to a delicious, almost addicting hors d'oeuvre. That's what made me put Isa on a pedestal. It could take an ordinary piece of bread and turn it into an extraordinary delectable bite.

This example only serves to highlight the extraordinary flavors characteristic of every appetizer, entree, and dessert we ordered. Our favorites:

1. Potato crusted sea bass
2. Yellowfin Tuna
3. Rack of Lamb
4. Grapefruit Granite

I can't wait to come back here. I would highly recommend coming with a group of friends, but otherwise enjoy indulging :)
author: Brian L.

description:
#Service#
First of all, the service is poor. We had to wait half an hour for a table even though the reservation was already made. So be prepared for the wait or get there a bit earlier than your reservation.

#Menu#
The most popular dishes there are potato wrapped sea bass, seared scallops and amaretto semifreddo.

#Tips#
Their 3 course dinner menu is very good value. There is no portion difference between the a la carte and the 3 course menu, but the 3 course prefix only costs $29.95.
They also have a monthly complementary foie gras menu. Be sure to get on their mailing list to get the details.
author: Weijia L.

description:
Food = 4
Service = 2

Visited for my mom's bday. No notice on prix fixe Dine about Town. Strike one. I slated Isa specifically so my daughter would have choices. So much for that. 

Waiter wouldn't answer questions directly. It was like he was programmed. "This is yummy". No effort to accommodate my daughter. Disappeared half way through dinner never to be seen again. 

Courses, right? Prix fixe. If you're gonna shaft me, at least make it feel good!  No concept of one course, let 'em eat it before serving the next. Weird and disconcerting. 

As for the food, it was very tasty. No real clunkers. It could have tasted even better if the courses were served properly and we could have enjoyed. Oh well. 

All in all, not going back. I'm always one to favor food over service but this was a simply a clumsy, disappointing experience in a neighborhood I'd rather avoid if possible anyway!
author: Andrew J.

description:
Came here with my girlfriends for Dine About Town - and the food was delectable. We were about twenty minutes late for our reservation (although we called to let them know we were running late). The host was very amicable although he did let us know that we only had about an hour and a half because they had another seating (slight minus points because the front of the restaurant was half empty -- he could have spared us the guilt trip).

Nonetheless we were ushered into the back area where there was a whole 'nother world of intimately squished tables 'neath a tented patio amongst outdoor heaters and a fun, festive environment. The back area was full of Dine About Towners and our waiter handed us the menu options of the day.

For my options, I chose:

1. Pt Reyes Oysters on the half shell  (fresh. oh so fresh. Had that slight brininess of fresh ocean. Went down real smooth.)

2. Lobster Broth with Tiger Prawn. (very tasty indeed)

3. Seared Scallops with mashed potatoes, bacon, brussel sprouts and truffle sauce. The scallops were perfectly cooked. The bacon added that depth of flavor and the brussel sprouts (have I told you that's my new favorite "sepcial" vegetable?)

4. Grapefruit Granite. Mmm. After such a decadent dinner, this was the perfect way to bring it to a close. It was refreshing, tart and tasted so fresh.
author: Nicha K.

description:
When we finally got our food two hours after ordering, the Duck Breast was green on the inside.  I had one bite and decided the texture was as if the duck had been frozen in plastic for a while, then thawed out and cooked.  I took one bite (even though it was green), and couldn't finish the rest.  When you're paying $25 for duck breast, you'd at least hope it looks like real duck.  

The Truffle Risotto was okay, but they didn't put very much mushroom; it was mostly cheese and cream.  

The salmon carpaccio didn't seem very fresh either, but at least it was edible.   

It would be one thing if it wasn't so expensive, but when you're paying over $100 for a meal for two, you hope your food is warm and your poultry isn't green on the inside.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I have lived in the bay area for 8+ years now, and had never before taken advantage of Restaurant Week. This year, I tried two restaurants - most recently, Isa. I went by myself, and had an 8:30pm reservation. I arrived about 30mins early, and asked if I could be seated early. They let me sit at the bar, which wasn't a great spot, but it was very convenient as it was near the kitchen.
For the $40 prix fixe menu during Restaurant Week, they gave a pretty good selection of menu items to choose from. I went with the potato-leek soup, mussels, duck breast, and creme brulee. 
First course was the soup, cup-size. The few pieces of bacon that were in the soup, really did set the tone for the flavor. It was a solid start, comforting and warm, with a smooth texture.
Second course = mussels. I've seen reviews where people were unhappy with the size of the mussels. I would say if this is the normal size of the dish, then I probably would not order it off the regular menu. But I got 6-7 good spoonfuls of mussel, after removing them from the shells from the onset. And as a prix fixe dish, I think that was adequate enough for me.
Main entree was duck, I think it was prepared medium rare. It was served with a huckleberry sauce, which made it more diffcult to tell how rare it was. In any case, I thoroughly enjoyed this dish. The meat was delectable and easy to cut, and I am a big fan of beets so the beet salad was a nice accompaniment. 
For dessert, I wavered between the semifreddo and the creme brulee. My server recommended the brulee, so that's what I went with. The sugar top layer was pretty good, probably the best part of the dish. But overall it was a solid dessert, although next time I'd likely go for the semifreddo.
For $40, plus a drink plus tip, this was a very good deal. The overall portion sizes were perfect for me, it filled me up without causing the need for a doggy bag. Next time I come I will likely bring friends or eat at a table rather than the bar, which lacked a bit of ambience although probably sped up the pace of my dining experience.
author: Steven Q.

description:
Came here for "Dine About Town" 2015 with a group of my girl friends! 

It was a 4-course prix fix dinner for $40 and I think it was well worth the pricetag, especially compared to the other list of restaurants around this caliber. We also went during happy hour (I think Everyday from 5:30-7, $5 any cocktail on their HH list!) so we started off with some drinks and were brought some delicious bread and butter to the table. 

I got: 

-Arugula Salad: It was well dressed and a light start to the dinner, but i didn't find it too special. I also enjoyed it because I generally like arugula, but for those who are particular to it might not like it as much since it does get a bit peppery and bitter

-Yellowfin Tuna Tartare: I thought this was great! It had great big chunks of raw tuna, and I could tell the fish was fresh. It was topped on avocado and had some seaweed surrounding it. It was well dressed (I liked the sriracha addition as it gave the dish a nice kick!) and I loved the seaweed salad around it. Overall, great dish but again, nothing spectacularly different from other tartare dishes you would find elsewhere (it actually reminded me more of poke)

-Braised Short Rib: This dish was accompanied by mashed potatoes, broccolini, and a carrot. I really enjoyed this dish and felt that the sauce around it made the whole dish taste very comforting and delicious. The broccolinis were cooked to my liking, and I also enjoyed the mashed potatoes but some of my other fellow friends thought the mashed potatoes could use a bit more seasoning (I do agree the mashed potatoes were a bit bland, but I felt the sauce on the dish made it more flavorful and I personally would prefer underseasoned than overseasoned). The short rib was spectacular in that it was soft, moist, and fell apart. 

-Creme Brulee: It was good, but again, not a dish that was unique or "different". The caramelized sugar on top was kind of thick, which I enjoyed but others might find it too crunchy/overwhelming. What I did like about it is that it wasn't as sweet as other creme brulee desserts I've had at other restaurants, but still rich. I also really liked the fact that they used real vanilla beans (you could see the vanilla bean specks all settled at the bottom of the dish) 

The waiters told us that the dishes were "family style" and meant to be shared and kept insisting on us to try each other's dishes (dishes came out as they were prepared so for the entree, some of the girls' dishes came out about 10-15 minutes faster than the other half of the girls) but the dishes aren't huge that you HAVE to share, but big enough to fill you up!

Overall Verdict: The food was well executed, hearty, and tasty, but none of the dishes were really unique or interesting. For the price and the quantity/quality of food though, it was definitely worth it. Therefore, I'll probably be back some time in the future, but probably not anytime soon given that there are so many other restaurants in SF that offer more of a food palate experience that I still need to explore!
author: Judy B.

description: Holy cow this place is delicious! I ordered delivery and it was just so good. Even to the French bread with butter that was just above room temperature. Fantastic. So happy to have discovered this place. Kudos to the chefs. I ordered the sea bass wrapped in potato and highly recommend.
author: Sarah T.

description:
I came here the other week for dine about town and was impressed by not only the food, but the service. I remember calling the restaurant letting them know I was running late and the hostess' response was simply "Don't worry, we still have a party of 40 who's not ready to leave." As I arrived to the restaurant, I thought...How the hell can they fit 40 people in this restaurant. As the hostess takes us to our seat (outside in the patio), I understood. I loved the outside patio. It was so spacious and open. 

Everything I had was exceptional. I had the Yellowfin Tuna with avocado and sriracha, which melted in my mouth and had just the right amount of heat. I also had the potato leek soup and the shortribs which fell right off the bone. I was impressed with everything I tried and the portions are considerably larger since they're known as a french restaurant. 

Looking back I really enjoyed my dining experience at Isa and I definitely would go back. I liked that my server was very attentive. It's just that at times, he was too attentive. I did like that he was very prompt in refilling my water. But is there such a thing as being too prompt? Anyway, you can't go wrong with their food and I am probably just being nit-picky about this one experience. :)
author: Herb A.

description:
I like this place a lot! 

Reasons why:
- Affordable prices. Prixe menu for $35 from Sunday to Thursday. $5 for a glass of wine before 7pm too!
- Delicious food. Everything is good!
- Great service. Wait staff are super friendly and fun. 
- Wonderful atmosphere. You can sit inside where the ambiance is cozy and intimate or if you want something more lively and fun, sit out in the patio.

This time I went for Dine About Town, which is a three course menu for $35 accompanied by a glass of wine. What's not to love about free wine!?? 

Everything was good and we had so many dishes, so for the sake of being brief here are my recommendations:
+ mussels
+ crab salad
+ salmon carpaccio 
+ halibut 
+ duck
+ creme brulee
+ gelato 

Okay, I think I may have listed the entire menu. Lol.
author: Donna W.

description:
Things that make me feel decidedly "French":

1) Striped shirts.
2) Berets.
3) Baguettes.
4) France.
5) Isa.

Isa isn't my style of dining, because it's slow (the waiter will take some time to explain to you why they take their time preparing the food, so you should share all the dishes), it's expensive for what you get and taste, and it's too rich for my stomach to handle (for example, the potato-wrapped sea bass could be so much tastier if it wasn't so salty, because the fish was very delicate and tender, and potato was a nice complement).  The heated outdoor back patio is very cute and since we arrived early, it was pretty empty.

I much prefer rustic French food, which Isa is not.  But at least for an hour, I did feel like I was transported to a land of high calories and slow times.
author: Tori S.

description:
The service is amazing and the ambiance is cute. The food, however, is just mediocre, decent at most. My favorite part of the meal was actually the bread basket and the bottle of Villa Botanica Cab Syrah blend. 

Tried the scallop, crab salad, and grilled calamari and they were all just okay. Maybe we didn't order the right things, but I just wasn't that impressed :/
author: Becky W.

description:
We came on a Saturday night. The place was packed and we were lucky enough to have a reservation. If you come without one, good luck to you. We were intrigued by their Dine about town menu and they were only serving from that menu the day we went. They mentioned they had the best DAT menu out there and I thought that to be a very bold claim but they have the skills to back the claim up. We were seated out in the back in a tent canopy type thing and it was really cute and heat lamps helped keep us warm. Our server was friendly and gave us no problems opening up the wine bottle we brought (corkage fee $20). 

Their DAT menu features 4 courses. For most of the menu they serve the food family style, so essentially if you go with a date, you both get 8 courses and that's a fantastic deal. For starters we got the lobster broth with shrimp. The broth was fantastic and flavorful that went well when you soaked the amazing warm bread they bring you. The shrimp was overcooked a bit but the broth made you forget all about that. The next course was a salmon carppaccio that came with crostinis. Very fresh fish and the sauce on it made me enjoy the capers on it, I hate capers normally. They also offer $1 oysters so we got half a dozen to split. Very tasty with the house made vinegar but they run small. Next course was mussels with toasted olive oil bread and the clams were fresh and the broth was amazing to soak up the bread. So many broths which are all amazing on their own but you take it to a whole other level by soaking bread in them. So good. The next course was a truffle risotto with mushrooms. THE BEST RISOTTO I HAVE EVER HAD! No joke. I thought the best was made by Gordon Ramsey when I went to his LA restaurant, but no this flavor was way better. Granted Ramsey had better cooked risotto but the the flavor at Isa is unmatched so you didn't notice if some rice was undercooked/overcooked here or there. That's when you know you have something special, even if it isn't cooked perfectly, the flavor alone makes up for it. It was that good. I will go back to just order bowls of the stuff. The other entree was seared scallops with Brussels sprouts and bacon. Scallops were cooked perfectly, the sprouts were good even though I generally hate them but with bacon and mashed potatoes you can't really go wrong. One of the best scallops I've had in a while.

For dessert we ordered some amaretto frozen custard with cookies and it was really fricken good. So creamy and flavorful and it was still light. Very nice. The next dessert was goat cheese with honey and walnut and bread. Some people don't think cheese can be dessert, well I don't want to be your friend then. Heck yes, it's dessert and my girl can only eat so much cheese in one sitting so I pretty much had the whole thing to myself. I'm lactose intollerant but honey badger don't care. Cheese all up in my mouth and belly. It was so amazing! Overall this restaurant does have the best DAT menu in SF and they know it. The service was great, even when the bread wasn't gone they would immediately fill it up with new bread. They were on point and the food was to die for. Very romantic restaurant if you an sit outdoor in the patio area. My girl said "the food game is strong with this restaurant." I have to agree strongly. If I could choose one restaurant to eat at once a week for the rest of my life. I might come here. Best DAT meal and experience I've ever had. Beats out DAT last year and beats out any of Oakland's and Los Angeles' restaurant weeks I've been to, including Gordon Ramsey. So amazing.
author: Jeromy G.

description: While the food might be delicious, I'll never know. Myself & 7 other guests attempted to dine at Isa on a Monday evening and were greeted with the rudest waiter/host. Condescending and nasty, he managed to offend every person with us in less than 5 minutes of being in the restaurant. Needless to say we won't be returning and will be cautioning our friends to do the same!
author: Kara Y.

description:
What a good experience! I came here for Dine about Town like many others. I also went to Fringale (not so good...), but Isa is definitely the winner in my Dine about Town experience. 

Let's just start with service. I had an 8:15pm reservation on a Sunday night, came in 30 minutes early, and they seated us 10 later. It was busy but I think with the awesome service they had, people rarely had to wait during their dining experience. There was seating in the front and back of the house, I prefer the back b/c it feels more cozy, warm and less busy than the front. 

Appetizers: Dungeness Crab Salad and Salmon Carpaccio (they were out of mussels... boo). My favorite was the crab salad. It was the perfect first course. Light, refreshing and not over powered with vinaigrette. There were slices of apple, avocado, and grapefruit. Though I wish there was more grapefruit, I still enjoyed it overall. The salmon carpaccio was the bf's fav. I though it was good. It tasted fresh, and not over whelming with the sauce. 

Entrees: Duck breast and flat iron steak. We ordered medium rare... and they seriously mean it! At some restaurants I order medium rare to get it pink in the middle, but nope, this joint does it precisely to the description! Look at my pictures, they were perfect! Our favorite was definitely the duck. The steak wasn't anything special, I wish we tried the risotto or the scallops but the bf didn't want to pass up steak -.-'' 

Dessert: Semifredo amaretto and vanilla bean creme brulee. The semifredo came with amaretto ice cream and cookies. This was definitely very delicious but quite sweet. After eating a few bites of this and trying the creme brulee, we couldn't taste the sugar in the creme brulee, haha. The creme brulee was very good, I appreciated the thick layer of sugar on top with vanilla bean at the bottom. 

Service: OMG this is my favorite part. My top five places for best service, no joke! I actually enjoyed overtipping them. Our server didn't bother us much, came by to ask if we needed more wine or the occasional "how's everything?" What really set the record was their actions, our bread basket was never empty! They didn't even ask if we wanted more bread, just refilled it :D Our water was never near empty, always refilled when less than 50%. Plates were cleared immediately. After our entrees were finished, they removed the place mats to reveal a clean table for dessert. Seriouly, BEST SERVICE EVER! 

I am definitely coming back, even if it's not Dine about Town. Oh and we had a free glass of wine, sweeeht!
author: Jen L.

description:
A group of us came here 2 days before the foie gras ban. The foie was excellent! =) We each got our own. I miss you already foie! ='( Overall, the experience was amazing! Our waiter was very friendly and funny. We ordered 

4 foies(A+!), 
the truffle risotto (A), 
sea bass (decent decent, A-), 
Scallops (a little small so A-), 
and mussels (don't remember this one too well A-?). 

They changed their menu recently so now they encourage friends to order a bunch of small plates and share everything. 
The only semi annoyance i have is that they should consider adding a few more bathrooms soon =P
author: Annie Z.

description:
Went here for Dine about Town back in June and after looking through the menus of dozens of restaurants I settled on Isa since they offered a four course prix fixe instead of only three - awesome! I assumed this would mean smaller portions but not the case at all. 

The portions are large, and they do tell you they are meant to be shared. I went with two other gals and we all shared the following dishes: 

Corn soup - Yum. 
Ahi Tuna Tartare - AMAZING. love avocado with tuna. 
Mussels - I'm not a huge mussels fan, but the other ladies loved them.
Goat cheese - Huge portion and very delicious flavor.
Spare ribs - Melt in your mouth, a LOT of food for a four course meal. Even better warmed up the next day. The Broccolini needed salt but that was my only complaint of the entire meal. 
Scallops - So delicious. I've never had scallops with Orzo but the combo was great.
Semi Freddo - Great ending to the meal. Very tasty.
Creme Brulee - Yes - typical deliciousness you'd expect. 

The bang for your buck at this place was outstanding for Dine About Town, and I did notice they have a cheap Prix Fixe menu Sunday - Thursday so I will definitely be back!
author: Dana J.

description:
We booked Isa for a pre-show dinner and we'll definitely be going back. 

We ordered the popular choices based on the waiter's recommendations and we can see why they are so popular!

We shared the tuna (best thing I've tasted in a LONG time), duck (beautifully cooked), goats cheese (a perfect accompaniment for the duck). The only let down was the crab salad which was so so, nothing to write home about. We finished up with espressos and a creme brulee (which was incredible).

There was a hiccup with our order as 'the kitchen didn't get our ticket'. That was a little stressful as we didn't have long to eat but the waiter was all over it and it was remedied very quickly. 

Happy hour on drinks before 7pm is worth an early meal!
author: Belinda W.

description:
Nice, nice, nice place!

Food is great! Drinks are delicious ( I loved the "Number seven") and service is very good as well.
The ambience is very nice. You can get a seat inside, which is a very classy but very common, or you can be at the patio, which is surprisingly cool and laid back. 

The servers are all very nice and prompt, except that in my first visit to this place, our waiter interrupted us so many times, that we started to laugh at some point. He would just not leave us alone! ahahah It was funny at least.  But not a big deal, the place is definitelly a great spot!
author: Paula C.

description:
We had dinner there 1/20/17-- It's SF Restaurant week. They have an interesting menu for
this event. $40 for 4 courses. Nice selection of items- Most of our choices were "OK" none were great. They also have $5 wines- very limited choice- until 7P
We arrived at opening time and were greeted in a friendly manner and seated at the table of our choice. We made our choices and asked for an"extra" that was on the menu- fois gras-
After eating 2 courses I cancelled the fois gras order- "sad"- it was one of the reasons that we went there. Service was friendly and prompt-in fact too prompt- we felt rushed at every course.
It seemed apparent to me/us that they were anxious to keep turning the tables-my math said that they could get 3 turns/night at the pace they rushed us 
There is some value and the dinner was ok but I almost forgot that they seemed to put stale
truffle oil on many dishes-
No returns for us
author: David C.

description:
This place has really good cocktails for $5 before 7. My favorite was the "mojito" and the "number seven." We had a group of 5 and the waiter recommended we order half pre fixe and half regular entrees. First of, the bread was amazing ( I know is just bread) but it was warm and toasty on the sides. We ordered three apetizer but the best one was the goat cheese with basil. 
Overall, the food was really good, the risotto was excellent, the sea bass was wrapped with potatoes and it was also delicious! I wasn't too impressed with the desserts so I was glad we only got two pre fixe menus. I would definitely go back when I'm back in SF.
author: Andrea A.

description:
Second time here and left as impressed as the first time if not a little more. This time I got to dine in the back patio which I found was a nice change of setting. Well lit & felt like a great summer night.

Service was superb as always, attentive but enough privacy. This time around I ordered a few dishes I've had before (because I enjoyed them soo much the first time) and a few new ones. Can't forget about the foie gras either as this was my main objective. 

Foie gras with rhubarb, strawberry & custard brioche - first time eating foie gras and per server recommendation. wasn't quite a fan of the strawberry pairing in this dish. I think I would've enjoyed the peach pairing more. (3.5/5)

Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio - (5/5) delicious as the first time! loved the pairing of fresh salmon sashimi with creme fraiche and the capers. 

Steamed mussels - (3.5/5) regretted not getting the scallops. basic dish but was good, great white wine sauce and good proportions

Seasonal fish with artichokes, olives, zucchini in tomato confit - (4.5/5) great dish, fish was buttery and I loved the addition of artichokes. the olives were a little too much for me and threw off the light flavors in this dish.

Truffle risotto - was looking forward to this dish the most because I LOVE RISOTTO. the truffle was way too overwhelming in terms of flavor, as with the added shiitake mushrooms that made the entire dish very heavy to the taste. I would not get this dish again (2/5) 

Semifreddo all'ameretto - topped everything off right. fluffy, delicious light almond flavor
author: Tina N.

description:
Came for happy hour- $5 glasses of wine, drinks & apps.

Stayed for dinner & opted for the pre-fixed menu.  Appetizers were delicious, especially the goat cheese.  For the main course we chose the local fish, halibut, and it was way too salty!  I think the dish would have been much more enjoyable if the salt had been reduced.  My husband ordered the steak. The steak had a good flavor, but very, very rich. It almost tasted like the chef poured clarified butter on top. Amaretto dessert was delicious.  Creme brûlée could have used a bit more rich, creamy, vanilla flavor. That's what makes creme brûlée, creme brûlée.

Overall, 3.5 stars.  I'd go back for the happy hour & maybe a few appetizers.
author: Kate G.

description:
Eight years ago I criticized Isa for settling into an uninspired groove a few years after a high concept critics-pleasing opening. Eight years later I'm back for Dine About Town and and they're on the same groove, only every last detail is two steps better, proves a point about finding your groove and sticking with it. Isa s now a can't fail, always a good time, delicious, go-to restaurant for dates, family, non-fancy special occasions.

The tent out back is the place to go day or night, hot or cold, rain or shine. On an unusually hot SF summer day after the Union Street Fair the breeze and shade in here was cooler than anywhere else indoors or out.

Every last patron had the dine-about-town menu, that included $1 oysters all night, very decent $5 wines, and a list of French-American comfort food with Asian touches. Salmon carpaccio was stellar (prepared with traditional salmon or caviar accompaniments: egg cubes, capers, toasted bread rounds, etc), as were the mussels (with a surprise guest of roasted jalapenos). I never would have ordered a butter leaf salad on my own but that was the stand-out of the night, an education in how you're supposed to treat lettuce leaves. This is not an accident, making a good salad is harder than you think. The short rib was  a perfect melt in your mouth crowd pleaser.The only ho-hum was my scallop dish. It was cooked just right but the concept didn't work for me, a bed of corn kernels and orzo didn't really dance together.

Not the standout, but the girl you come home to, is the humble grapefruit granite dessert, which has been on the menu since the beginning and the food critics first raved about, which is why I ever came here in the first place. A dairy-free frozen ice that's _supposed_ to have noticeable ice crystals in it, it's now got a more pronounced does of fresh mint, a perfect ending to the night, I could have this five times a week and never grow tired. The creme brulee was solid too. 

Final score, of 8 dishes 7 were minor hits, nothing so amazing that you stand up and rip your shirt off because it's another planet, but each had a hint of inspiration about it, not bad for a Sunday night, chef's day off. Like I said, solid.

Two more notes. First, the portion size is inconsistent. Perhaps by design, but some dishes in the same category are 2-3X more filling than others. Mussels and salmon carpaccio are both appetizers for about the same price, mussels could be a small meal on their own, but salmon (though generous carpaccio-wise) is a tiny snack.

Second, a special shout-out to our waiter, Dean. He really made our night. He's been working here 7 1/2 years now, and has such an enthusiasm, happiness, and genuine spirit, you can't help but smile and be happy with him. We asked why he was so happy and he said it made him happy to work here. Damn. He was like a unicorn waiting your table.
author: Gil S.

description:
I came here for Dine About Town week this past Thursday and I was so happy we chose ISA! For $36.95 we got 4 courses: soup, salad, main course, and dessert. 

Ambiance: Impeccable! A perfect environment to go have a nice, intimate meal with your girlfriend or special someone. Although it looks small on the outside, there is ample seating inside, a full bar, and a beautiful outdoor patio sort of seating area. The seating area outside is full of lamp heaters, so unlike other places where you are only warm if you are right next to one of the heaters, the whole seating area was warm and cozy! The patio was lit with beautiful lights and just instantly made you feel at home and comfortable. 

Service: Again, impeccable! Our server was kind and explained all the different menu items to us, especially because many of them had french words in the titles. Our food came out at perfect intervals, with one exception. My sister got her main course atleast 10 minutes before I got mine, which wasn't a big deal since we shared everything anyways. The only thing that came very late was my mojito that I ordered right when I got inside ($5 cocktails before 7pm, yes please!). The mojito came after the bread and the salad course, so it took quite a bit of time. Besides that, our waiter was charming and sweet! 

Food: 
Soup: Smooth Potato and Leek Soup with parsley, chives & cream --This was a nice soup to get started with. I've never had potato and leek soup, so it was different. I wish it was a little more flavorful (read: more salty or even spicy) but it was nice to dip the bread in. 
Salad: Arugula salad with fuji apples, persimmon, fennel, lemon vinaigrette & parmesan --This was delicious! I loved the flavors of the vinagrette with the fruits and arugula is my favorite, so I devoured this salad!
Main Course: 
1. Truffle risotto with baby shiitake, hon shimiji mushroom & reggiano --I loved the baby shiitake mushrooms in this dish, added so much texture and flavor! The risotto was a little bland for my taste. Not sure if this is because the flavors from the salad were so powerful, but the risotto needed more seasoning and again, salt or spices. Something to give it direction perhaps? Not a bad dish, just not something I would order again. 
2.  Spaghetti with himalayan truffles, tomatoes, basil & parmesan cheese -- Very simple spaghetti dish. I guess you can't make spaghetti that amazing since it is a pretty simple dish, but the marinara sauce was definitely more flavorful than the risotto or soup dishes that I had previously, so I enjoyed that! 
Dessert:  Vanilla bean crème brulée -- MMM still dreaming about this dessert. The top was crisp and golden brown, and below was the creamiest, mousse type vanilla pudding. I was in love. Although I was so so full after the risotto, my creme brulee disappeared in minutes. 

Verdict: I would say the food was 3.5 stars, probably because although this was the most vegetarian friendly and appetizing looking menu for me, the dishes did not have as much promise. The risotto needed more flavor and the spaghetti was very simple. So I'd say it's party because it's a French restaurant, so their specialty isn't making delicious vegetarian dishes but rather more meat based ones. But regardless, the other courses were great and left us completely satisfied! Service + ambiance made it a solid 4 star experience. 

Tips: 
+parking is hard in the marina--the garage we found was $2 an hour, change only but really turned out to be about $4 in hour (ugh). 
+get drinks before 7! Glasses of wine & cocktails are only $5--what a steal! 
+yummy free bread and butter to start with! :)
author: Anu P.

description:
Another Dine About Town review. Had a reservation for a party of 4 at 7:45 on a Saturday night. Requested the patio for seating, but they had large parties that night and were unable to accommodate this request. I appreciate that they called me to notify me about it.

I recommend reserving about 45 minutes to find parking, because it took us way too long to find a spot. It took almost an hour.

Seating-wise, we were seated at a tall 4-person table and every time I tried to move or get off the chair to use the restroom, I hit the candle holder on the wall. The restaurant was incredibly noisy, so it was difficult to have a nice meal. 

I ordered the lobster broth as my starter, the salmon carpaccio as my second dish, the duck as my entree, and creme brulee for dessert. I also tried the steak, mussels, and dungeness crab salad. 

Everyone said the lobster broth tasted like the sea. The prawn inside was pretty good, but I didn't think the broth itself was spectacular. I did not like the crostinis that came with the salmon carpaccio. The duck was pretty good, not as gamey as I thought it'd be. Creme brulee was well, creme brulee..it's hard to mess up.

The dungeness crab salad was quite refreshing. The dressing was kind of unnecessary though. The mussels were almost raw (yuck, I only like mussels from Marica). The steak had a strange taste (actually, both duck and steak, but moreso the steak). It seems they used a blowtorch to cook it or finish it. No one really enjoyed the steak.

Service was friendly and very informative, as well as funny. Our server was explaining how DAT works to all the tables he went to with a friendly attitude. The busboys were quick with clearing things off the table and bringing dishes to us.

Overall, I must say I'm disappointed by the taste of the food. I was expecting to be blown out of the water and I was not. Perhaps I should have tried Luce instead. ):
author: M C.

description:
I was thoroughly impressed with the service, the food and love their back patio seating at Isa. My first dining experience here was a couple of years ago and since then, I've been back a few times. Each time, Isa did not disappoint.

They recommend  that you eat family style, and quite honestly, I love this because you get to try a little bit of everything. 

I have some tried and true favorites such as the dungeness crab salad, steamed Prince Edward Island mussels, and seared scallops. I've tasted many other items on their menu and all are good but the aforementioned are dishes I always look forward to and sometimes daydream about.

Isa quickly moved up the ranks on my list of favorite restaurants.
author: Cyndi G.

description:
We came here for Dine About Town 2014. Unlike the other Dine About Town restaurants, which had three courses, this one had four. But don't be fooled by the numbers! Remember, it's quality over quantity!

Our first course was smooth potato and leek soup and main lobster broth with prawns were both disappointments. Both looked like soapy water and plastic bowls, and looked unappetizing. The lobster broth tasted like REALLY watered down imitation lobster.

For our second course, we got dungeness crab salad and yellowfin tuna. The dungeness crab salad included large leaves of greens that made it extremely hard to eat, slices of grapefruit in the salad were overpowering, and the crab was tasteless. The yellowfin tuna was average - nothing special, but a touch of soy sauce would have been nice.

Our third course was seared scallops and braised short ribs. These entrees came in big plates for sharing. The seared scallops was underwhelming. The scallops sat on top of brussels sprouts, bacon, and mashed potatoes. It felt like something you could make at home like a prepackaged meal from a supermarket. The braised short ribs weren't bad though. The meat was tender and pretty flavorful.

Lastly, for desserts, we had the semifreddo all' amaretto and a vanilla bean creme brulee. The semifreddo all' amaretto tasted weird like chemicals and was pretty unappetizing. The creme brulee was just average.

We sat in the back patio of the restaurant where the tables were fairly close to one another. You could easily eavesdrop on other conversations if you wanted to. Service was great though - one of the waiters was very adamant about making sure our water glasses were filled to the brim.

Overall, the place was below average. We definitely won't be coming back, especially for their regular menu. The dishes were too simple and not worth the money.
author: NoonNarin N.

description:
Great food, great ambience. Well, I feel like the first time I went there was better, though.

Mussels - good. Then again.. I feel like every decent restaurant around here that serve mussels in garlic broth always tastes exactly the same.

Seared foie gras - I swear this was amazing the first time I came here, 3 years ago. They paired it with some rhubarb and brioche, which was just fantastic. This time.. they had the brioche, but had it paired with some other sweet thing. It wasn't as good, and I also feel like the quality of the foie just wasn't as great. I just felt overwhelmingly heavy and disgusting after finishing this plate.

Prawns - okay, nothing to write home about.

Duck breast - Must get! Probably the best thing here.


Hmm... the food the last time around just wasn't as good, but I remember it being absolutely amazing 3 years ago. I'll have to stop by once more and figure out which part of my memory is the correct one.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Note to ALL: all menu items are "SMALL DISHES" meant to be shared.  So instead of ordering one entree/pp, we ended up splitting 6 different dishes and ended up spending 2x as much as I had intended.  Ultimately still a fantastic meal but it will cost you big bucks.  Also, stock up on bread b/c you're going to want to mop up a lot of these plates.

1st tier of awesome: the foie gras with strawberries, rhubarb & brioche, the veal sweetbreads, and the mushrooms.  Normally not a big fan of foie gras in the few times that I've had it but this shit blew my mind partly b/c the sauce is divine.  They basically made a homemade jam that goes so well w/ the fatty liver.  #1 plate to mop up w/ bread.  The sweetbreads, which I found out are usually either thymus or pancreas (delicious!), were also special.  And the local mushrooms were the best mushrooms I've ever had - there were a variety of maybe 4-5 different types all simply sauteed w/ garlic but made me want to steal their garden.

2nd tier of awesome: potato wrapped seabass, oysters with spicy orange mignonette, and the flat iron steak.  These were all good but not on the same level as the ones above.  Stupid Yelp for highlighting the steak - don't get me wrong, it's perfectly well done but it is nothing special when you look at the rest of the dishes.  

Time to starve for all of next week.
author: Derrick C.

description: We came here for a birthday celebration and fell in love with it. The restaurant is quite small, but they have extra space set up in the back which is so charming and romantic. Casual ambiance. I didn't think that it would be a good place for kids, but have seen others brought their kids.  Service was great and food was phenomenal. We ordered a Prix Fix menu plus some extra items. We really enjoyed our dinner here and would definitely come back in the future.
author: NT T.

description:
5 star appetizers 
- Yellowfin tuna (NOM!)
- Salmon carpaccio also very good

5 star wine prices.
- $25-35 for some bottles?! WOW, and $5 for a glass everyday 5-7pm

3 star service.
- Whatever, they're French...

3 star entrees.
- Steak too chewy.
- Ono special, not tender enough.

I'd come back for drinks and apps.
author: Jess C.

description: In town from Texas, and just had dinner here. Loved this place! The food was excellent, the service was efficient, and the staff very accommodating.
author: Erin T.

description:
4/5 it's been said.

i think this place is pretty solid. the back area is great, and the service is spot on and genuinely friendly. as with the other reviews, the food is great, can't go wrong.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Apparently I was there on a bad night, since all the other reviews, and the hype from a friend say it's actually excellent. So I'll write my review to give warning of what may happen if you go on an off night.

My theory is that the restaurant was understaffed, and the person in the kitchen either didn't know what they were doing, or didn't care. 

I know for a fact that the restaurant was understaffed, because there was only one server for the whole front restaurant, who was also the bartender. And this was on a busy night. Isa's been doing Dine About Town for years now, they should be able to foresee proper staff usage, even if it is a Wednesday. I understand the concept of ordering all at once and bringing food out as it comes ready. But when you're a group of two, and my soup is well on its way to room temp by the time his salad comes out, it just makes for awkward times. It really should not take over two hours for 2 people to eat from a prix fixe menu.

As for my theory about the kitchen, the execution frankly sucked. My duck was well done on one edge, and medium rare on the other, with chewy tendons attached, and no knife besides the one for the butter available. I had to borrow my date's steak knife. He also had the same doneness problems with his flank steak, only the range was from medium-well to rare (raw). All the flavor combinations were great, but those were from things prepared in advance, not made to order.

So though everyone else says Isa is awesome, I highly doubt that I will return.
author: Amanda S.

description: Oh how I loathe San Francisco, but for odd reason the monster keeps dragging me here. I came to Isa to experience their Dine About the Town menu and it was a wonderful experience. Great food, outstanding service, and comfortable decor. On the menu you get to choose a variety of items for your 3 course meal. I encourage you to mix it up with your date that way you can try all the dishes. For the appetizer I had the salmon which was very fresh, a perfectly cooked duck for the main course, and crème brûlée for dessert. Two complementary glasses of wine was also given to us, but what won me over in the end was the bread. They keep bringing it and asking us if we wanted more. Now that is quality service. I would definitely come back to try their official menu items.
author: Owie N.

description:
So glad we tried this place! Dinner was delicious and service was great. They have so many items to choose from on the menu. There is something for everyone here. They bring you fresh and warm bread throughout dinner too. 

Nice to come out to this part of SF. We had a chance to meet the owner and his family. Really sweet people. Looking forward to visiting Isa again:)
author: Zainab B.

description:
Service good. Food delicious and perfect. seating and eating comfortable with no pressure. Love their perfect duck breast and mussels.
Warm bread in the beginning is really nice too (don't really like cold breads at other restaurants). And when bills came, it was much cheaper than other French restaurants with average taste of food. Strongly recommended.  Love their private dinner invitation too and their french dessert.  My French friends said food was great and traditional French.  The only un-French part was staff too friendly and service too good :P
However, waiting for seating in after 7pm on the weekend will be long.  I went twice: 7:30 reservation but got seated at 8:30pm.  (but they gave us everyone free champagne).  2nd time 8pm but got seated at 8:45pm.  This time I booked 6pm and expect to wait long but surprisingly went directly seated without waiting at all.  So, book early time to avoid waiting.
author: Julie W.

description:
UGH.  WHAT HORRIBLE SERVICE!

Wifey picked up a 30% off coupon on savored.com and we decided to come check this place out.  she absolutely loves french food...so why not give it a try?  yeah...probably some of the worst service i have ever had.

let's start off with the food which was mediocre at best...we went all out since we did have this coupon although we have been on a health-conscious diet as of late.

1)  Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio with lemon, crème fraiche, cucumber, egg, capers & crostini.  not bad...the salmon appeared to be semi fresh but the crostini almost broke a tooth.  

2)  Steamed Prince Edward island mussels with garlic, white wine, parsley & grilled bread.  the dish was overall just ok...nothing to call home about...not exactly the wow factor or memorable. 

3)  Spaghetti with himalayan truffles, tomatoes, basil & parmesan cheese.  surprisingly the best dish of the night...my only complaint was that the past was not cooked al dente...it was a little on the softer side.  the sauce was delicious and the truffles really highlighted the dish.

4)  Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with haricots verts, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce.  the best part of the dish?  the haricots verts.  if the green beans are the highlight of your entree...then something is seriously wrong.  the steak was cooked medium rare but just didn't have any flavor even after dousing it in the to sauce.  i've had better steak at diners.

5)  Creamy mascarpone with fresh fruit & huckleberry trifle.  worst dessert i've ever had.  period.  

ok. so let's step back a moment with the service.  we were the first at the restaurant since our reservation was at 5:30pm.  there was no greeting, no hello, no hi, how are you.  all we got was, "your name?  sit over there."  this was the not so charming, tall, long, gray haired guy with facial hair waiter that we suffered through for the next 1.5 hours.  he didn't describe any of the food that most french restaurants are known for...he was actually quite strange...he would walk in circles around the restaurant but never ask any of his guests how everything was or if they needed anything.  there were multiple times that he would walk up to our table, abruptly stop, stare at us, and walk away.  thankfully, he got busy with the tables outside (which he was extremely attentive to)...and the hostess came over to help us with at least half of our meal.  

but then the hostess blew it...wifey and i always make it a point to eat half of our entrees and save the rest for another time.  yanno...something called portion control?  so we ask for a box...we have no problem boxing our food but the hostess said she would box it up for us.  as she was walking away, she turned around and came back asking if we were hungry or not.  what???  so i said, well, we did order a lot of food for 2 people.  and then she made it a point to say that the chef always questions her if she brings back the food to the kitchen to box up.  um...that's not my problem?

i'm sorry but i do not ever plan to be a part of the obesity problem in our country.  in my head i was thinking, can you just give me a box so we can move on with our lives?  ugh.

NEVER EVER AGAIN.  there are far better places for upscale french cuisine than isa in the city.  and i plan to bring my business there instead.
author: Jen W.

description:
I loved every single tapa I tried here! This place is unbelievable, everything melted in my mouth. I tried the oysters, tuna tartar, shrimp, sea bass, hanger steak, lamb, risotto, and mushrooms. Hard to say I had a favorite because I enjoyed it all, but I could say the calamari was unique here (not fried) which I loved. Everything was high quality, flavorful, cooked perfectly. The bass melted like butter in my mouth! Did I mention our server was amazing, super nice guy.

I would love to come back.
author: Azizi A.

description:
This place was much cuter from what I remembered before.  Still like the patio seating with string lights, very cute, but not crazy about the green lights.  Randomly asked the waiter for foie and they have it! They served a generous slab of seared foie gras.  We tried both versions: strawberry rhubarb and the pear.  Strawberry sauce was way too heavy for my liking, but they didnt' smother it over the foie so that was fine.  The foie itself was very good.  Other things we had:
Crab salad - lots of crab, light and fresh
Sea bass wrapped in potato - this was amazing!! The potato shell was crispy, sea bass was sooo juicy.. mmm so good
Truffle risotto - this was good, tasted like they used truffle oil and maybe specks of truffle.  For some reason I expected slices of truffle, so I was disappointed, but it tasted good.  It also came after the amazing sea bass so it's hard to top.
Felt like the waiter was a bit rushed, running around, but didn't forget our orders or anything so it was fine.
author: Lina J.

description:
Came here to DAT, and that was the entire menu they offered, which is understandably so since their kitchen is small.  The food was good, but I'm not sure if I'd repeat, which sets a restaurant from a three star to a four star for me.

Crab salad - okay. Missing some acid like some chefs would say.
PEI Mussels - yummy, nice juicy and plump pieces. Good flavor, but how do you mess this up?
Foie Gras - good, but I would have preferred it without the red sauce. Kinda detracted from the piece.
Mushroom Risotto - very delicious and filling. I didn't appreciate how it just looked like they slopped it onto the plate. If you get this I recommend having someone else get a protein dish so you can share
Strip Steak - cooked well, flavorful and yummy
Creme Brulee - tastes like a brulee should
Semifreddo almond something - good the first few bites, then it's too almondy for me

I'm curious about their regular menu, but I'm thinking there are other french restaurant's I'd like to try first.  However, not sure if Isa is French, as the above dishes are actually "french."
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Now I'm usually a classy guy who likes to sip on Two-Buck-Chuck for fine dining in my South Bay mansion, so I know a good wine when I taste one.  And this one Spanish red at Isa was exceptional.  And even better, the glass was FREE with the Dine-About-Town deal for Sun-Thurs!   To add to that, the Number Seven ($5 before 7PM) was a delicious soju cocktail of champagne and refreshing blackberries.

Our group was seated in the spacious, covered courtyard out back; the darker, quainter inside is better for dates and a couple of "just friends."  Our server was amazing ("We will bring you more hot bread whenever you want."  Must.  Stop.  Eating.  Bread.) and more than made up for the snooty host and bartender.

Credit the chef for having a wide variety of 4-5 choices for each Dine-About-Town course rather than the usual boring soup or salad as the first course, for example.  Almost all of dishes on the regular menu were available, so there were options for every taste.

-- The Salmon Carpaccio was amazingly fresh.  The slices were served at just the right temperature - not too hot, not too cold.  The capers and crème fraiche were a light complement, as to not overpower the salmon.

-- The Angus Flat Iron Steak was cooked perfectly tender and pre-sliced - fancy!  The green beans were firm and crunchy.  The long fingerling potatoes were delicious and almost upstaged the steak for the main course.

-- The Foie Gras (+$22) was a huge slab and definitely a good bang for your buck.  I didn't like the poached pears and huckleberry sauce, as I think I prefer salty to sweet.  (I'm more of a fan of flavorful pate than foie gras.)  The accompanying custard brioche was good.

-- The Semifreddo All' Amaretto was delightful with a light sweetness and Amaretto flavor.  I'm really glad that there was this option rather than the usual desserts.

All the plates were SPECTACULAR, which is a rarity with the $35 Dine-About-Town.  Isa has definitely redeemed these prix fixe deals for me and my high class belly.
author: Kevin W.

description: My friends and I were hanging out in the Marina area and one of my friends recommended Isa because of a previous positive experience. Since it was Sunday they had thei prefix meals 3 course for $29 bucks, not a bad deal and the portions were not tiny either. I love the flat iron steak and the mussels, for dessert we got the grapefruit and the blue cheese dish. Service was perfect, our server Dave was very polite and courteous, never had to ask for more of anything because he brought it to us. Overall it was a fantastic dining experience with good friends and good food. Highly recommend if you are in the area, and especially on a Sun-Thurs for their prefix menu.
author: Matthew L.

description: I came here with my sister and cousin for dinner on New Year's Eve and we were given the 4 course meal special for $49! It was very delicious and worth it! Service was attentive too. For my starter, I got lobster broth, my appetizer was clams, main entree was steak with potatoes and green beans, and for my dessert I got vanilla bean gelato. I was very pleased with my meal. I finished everything! I don't remember the specific name of what I ordered or what everything was, all I know is that my tummy was happy. I would have given this place 4 stars but unfortunately my cousin got food poisoning from here. So Isa, you only get 3 stars!
author: Tiffany T.

description: Oh, Isa. Your food is so good, your restaurant is so beautiful, and your staff is so kind. But if you want to experience all of that, you have to have a lot of patience. We stood in a crowded foyer with other groups who had reservations but were waiting 15+ minutes to be seated. We waited quite a bit between dishes. And then we waited even more for our check. Perhaps it was the Restaurant Week rush that left the Isa staff so harried and disorganized. We hope that's what it was, because the food was fantastic and it seemed like the wait staff really believed in the food. And they were right: the scallops were perfection, the risotto was heaven, and everything in-between was well-presented, well-made, and delicious. We left satiated but a bit frustrated. I think we will wait a bit more and come back when it's not Restaurant Week.
author: Convict T.

description:
I came here with two friends when it was Dine in SF week.

This place was also highly recommended from a friend that had also went here for Dine in SF. I was definitely not disappointed.

Portions are very generous! For a very classy, expensive restaurant, one would normally assume small portions. Not Isa. I was very very happy with this. We all left stuffed!

We ordered almost everything on the menu and just shared it. The duck was my favorite. It has got to be the best duck I've ever had in my life - and I'm Asian. We eat lots of duck. The duck was just so well cooked that it melted in my mouth. For someone that eats quite a bit of duck, I can safely say that it doesn't normally melt.

The scallops, however, seemed a little plain. It was good - just not amazing, which was what I expected from a restaurant of this caliber.

Overall, for the price I paid, the portions I got, and the fine ambiance, this is 5 stars in my book. I would definitely come back, especially if they have deals like this again.

Thinking back to this makes me drool too much so I'll end the review here.
author: Anh T.

description:
Farewell Foie Gras! 

This place is so cute!  My friend had her wedding reception here and even the food for a group of 50+ was delish!  

I came here for my foie gras send off dinner and I left quite satisfied. We had the foie gras with strawberry and rhubarb compote and a custard brioche.  I did hear that the pear one was better, but I still enjoyed the strawberry one.  The seared foie was so delicious on the brioche and smothered in the sauce.  We did a wine pairing but our server recommended a different one then what was on the menu and it was a great pairing.  

I went on a Sunday so we ordered one prix fixe menu and picked off the menu.  We  ordered the angus flat iron steak, Loch Duart salmon carpaccio, and potato wrapped seabass.  Unfortunately there was a mistake somewhere and we didn't get our seabass.  =(  The bf was very disappointed, but our server Jonathan was very nice and apologetic.  Since the kitchen was closed, he could only send us  dessert.  He sent out the chocolate cake and a slice of Point Reyes blue cheese.  The cake was okay.  I'm not a fan of blue cheese, but the cheese was very creamy and rich; I'm sure I would have loved it if I liked blue cheese. The grapefruit granite was so refreshing and perfect! 

I'll definitely be back since all the food is pretty good and I really want to try that seabass!  Thanks for the great service Jonathan!
author: Nikki L.

description:
4 stars for the overall meal, but 5 stars for the salmon carpaccio and the duck breast. The salmon was light and refreshing and SO FRESH. The duck breast was probably the best duck I've ever had in my life and changed my mind about not liking duck meat.

Came with a party of 3 for their SF Chefs Restaurant Week prix fixe menu last night, and in looking at the prices, this is a place that won't break the bank if you come on a non-RW night. The dishes are meant to share and are served from lightest to heaviest, so we all got a taste of everything. There were some items on the regular menu that were not on the prix fixe that I'd like to try if I were to come back, but I would definitely order the salmon carpaccio every time. SO GOOD.
author: Kathy L.

description: The food and service here is great.  The best foie gras I've ever had was from here so I'm very sad that CA no longer allows the sale of it. Their servers are super friendly and constantly check on us and never left my water glass empty. This place is great for a cute date or get together with friends.
author: SanDee W.

description:
Wow, what a wonderful experience- food, service and atmosphere. 
We were there on a first date and everything was perfect. We ordered oysters (they were ok), sea bass (my fav! So much flavor), pan seared chicken (yummy and so tender) and arugula salad (delicious lite dressing). 
Highly recommend this place. Sit out back on the deck!
author: Leslie E.

description: I was pleasantly surprised at how decent the "Isa Zinfindel" was which is the HH red wine for $5 a glass. I am always skeptical of a " mystery wine". Very very juicy and Jammie and cherries quite good, actually as wine on HH is usually not good at all. The scallops with asparagus was something I cud imitate at home so not outstanding. Just simple sauté with what tasted like basalmic reduction. I can make better Brussel sprouts as there was no carmelization of the garlic and I guess scallions as they were still a bit raw but I guess that was done on purpose. I don't like overlooked veggies either but it's hard to over sauté or roast Brussel sprouts.The space itself is quite appealing, romantic with cool lighting reminds me of stars in the night and I loved the back outdoors area under the dome of what have you. The wine is great. They pressure u to order tons of food  tapas style for sharing when u r already full.
author: First L.

description: This is a long overdue review.  I've been to Isa quite a few times and each time, the food does not disappoint.  This place is always packed and lively.  Even with the crowd, the service is quick and good.  One of my favorite dish here is the duck confit - it is so tender and full of flavor - just thinking about it is making me hungry  Other dishes that I've tried here include the braised pork, scallop, and steak - all are wonderful as well, although not quite as good as the duck dish. This is definitely one of my favorite restaurant in the city - highly recommended
author: Trang N.

description:
I came here for my NYE dinner. They had a pre fixe for $50, comes with four courses, and they were of great quality. The restaurant is just adorable. Very romantic, with booths and high tables for larger groups. The only thing is that the tables are slightly too closed together, so it's hard for the person to get in and get out from the booth seat.

My date and I each ordered a soup, an appetizer, an entree, and a dessert. I got the main lobster broth to start, it's very flavorful. Since it's a broth, the texture is not extremely creamy like a bisque. It's of a small tasting portion, so you won't be full from it. 

We split an order of salmon carpaccio and the baked goat cheese. Salmon carpaccio was delicious and fresh. It came with four pieces of bread to eat it like an open sandwich. The goat cheese was just odd. It lacks texture because it was baked, it tasted like a doughless pizza, since it was cheesy, with crushed tomato and pesto. I guess that was why they added pinenuts to it, just to add some layers to the mushy texture. 

We shared our entrees too: seared scallops with brussel sprouts and seared duck breasts. They were both well-prepared. I chose the seared scallops to be on a safe side, since I loved both scallops and brussel sprouts. They were not the best I've tried, but they're not of bad quality. The scallops were soft, melted in my mouth, and were very flavorful. The sprouts were well seasoned with bacon bits, I just have a preference on having my brussel sprouts fried in duck fat or something to get a crunchy texture. The duck breasts were just right in terms of how it wasn't overly cooked, it kept its moisture and tenderness. The sauce was a bit too heavy for me at that time though. 

I ordered the vanilla creme brulee for dessert. The torching was done almost perfectly, my creme brulee had a nice, even tan. The harden caramelized sugar is like the best part, it contains its original sweetness yet it's evened out by the burnt taste. However, I forced myself to finish the rest of my dessert, since I wasn't a big fan of vanilla for it made my dessert too sweet, yet I loved creme brulee. But for normal people, this is just right!

Parking can be a pain around this area. It's very hard to find street parking, and the parking lot we parked at was with expensive meters. But this place is worthwhile!
author: Connie C.

description:
If you order well, this is a five star experience, as some of the dishes are true knockouts.  To our group's collective surprise, neither the server's recommendations nor the Yelp Review Highlights were able to predict the winning dishes on the night we came, about a week ago. Well, here's what you want:
- The rack of lamb!  This might be the best lamb I've ever had.  (And a couple others in the group had similar sentiments.) They season it just right so that it almost has a hint of butter flavor and none of that funk that makes some people avoid lamb.  Probably a touch fattier than your typical cut, which might explain it... do it.
- The flatiron - wonderful, again perfectly seasoned and cooked medium rare.
- To our surprise, the risotto, which I think had truffle mushrooms on it.
- The tuna tartare, which again to our surprise was better than the salmon carpaccio.  Do that too!
- The free bread.  Maybe it was the butter they served with it, not sure... but it was awesome.
- The Goat Cheese appetizer.  I didn't have this one, but it was one couple's fav.

Now there were tons of other dishes recommended by either Yelpers or the staff, but no one in our group loved these: the dungeness crab salad, the crab broth, the salmon carpaccio, the mussels, the duck breast (surprising right? that looked awesome!) and the lamb tenderloin (which was a special).  And a couple others I forgot to note.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I think I just died and went to food heaven.

Isa is a great place!

I had a reservation for 6 on Friday night (7:45p) and requested for the outdoor seating. The hostess was very accommodating and saved us a great round table by the heater for 8:00p. Our server was also excellent. He was attentive, gave suggestions, and was pleasant.

Our group ordered:

Starters -
Yellowfin Tuna Tartar - The table was pleased definitely fresh & tasty
Dungeness Crab Salad - Yum!

Mains -
Scallops - The scallops could of used a slight crisp but it was yummy nonetheless. The brussel sprouts were slighty salty for our preference.

Flat iron steak - The meat was cooked perfectly & the sauce was amazing!

Sea bass - TDF! It's ingenious to wrap the potato skin around the fish. It was so flavorful. 

Chicken - TDF! The chicken was juicy and succulent. Even the skin was delicious. We loved the sauce so much we asked for more bread to soak up the yummy goodness. The mash potatoes were just... :-)

Duck -  TDF! Melts in your mouth. We had one 'non-duck' believer but even he said he wanted more. The salad was delicious. 

Spaghetti - I rarely eat pasta since I prefer my proteins and vegetables but this pasta was perfection.

We also had about 6 drinks. The tab came out to $45 per person...$270 total, not bad.

Will def be back!
author: Crystal K.

description:
Wow.

We had our holiday dinner here tonight (party of 55).  Sameera, the owner, was responsive and helpful.  She was also there that night.  If you ever need to organize a huge group dinner, you will not find a better person to work with than Sameera. I would easily recommend Isa to anyone, for anything from date night to taking out your parents to group celebrations.  The food is very good for the price.  This is my third time here and I will be returning.

Everything went without a hitch.  Sometimes, when you have a large party, the quality of the food or service will suffer.  This did not happen.  There were plenty of waiters and the kitchen kept the food coming.  We took a welcome break after the entrees then plowed on to dessert.  The timing was perfect, the food was hot, and there was plenty to go around.

Since we had a huge group, we were seated in the back patio and Isa had to go with their shared menu for groups.  This basically consisted of six courses (see below, and keep in mind that the food came out to all 55 people at once), and everyone got to dig in.  Your dollar will go far here.  About the back patio -- it was a December night in SF, and even at 45-50 degrees outside, the patio was perfectly warm.

First

Baked Laura chenel goat cheese with pesto, tomato concassée & pine nuts
-- Good; I ate this with the fresh bread served at the table.  It needed a vessel.  I couldn't have eaten just a giant piece of cheese.  

Butter lettuce salad with apples, candied walnuts, watercress & roaring forties blue cheese
-- Delicious.  I've had this type of salad before and sometimes the dressing is overpowering, but at Isa it was just right.
 
Second

Seared scallops with brussel sprouts, bacon, mashed potatoes & truffle sauce
-- It was weird, they ended up serving this entree last.  The scallop was overcooked (probably because they were cooking these for 55 people) but I didn't mind.  The flavors were really good for this dish.  The brussel sprouts could be a tad less mushy, especially since mashed potatoes were already on the plate.  

Spaghetti with himalayan truffles, tomatoes, basil & parmesan cheese
-- This was a really simple dish with clean flavors.  A lot of people liked this and cleaned it up.

Grilled Golden Gate natural angus flat iron steak with haricots verts, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce
-- This was okay.  The best part of it was the potatoes, which were really flavorful and crispy.  The meat was a little underseasoned.
 
Third

Crème brûlée
-- Standard fare.  It's hard to mess up creme brulee.  That said, it was a solid one.
author: Erika C.

description:
Went there last year.
The foie gras is not available any more, too late... sigh.
However, I love other course.
Recommend:
Dungeness crab salad
Flat Iron Steak,
Truffle Risotto
Semifreddo al Amaretto.
The service is great. Love the layout of the restaurant, not splendid but very cute.
For 2 girls, 130$ in total. Worth it!
author: Sissi L.

description:
I love this cute, casual, yet fine dine and wine restaurant. Parking SUCKS here, so come early and prepare to drive around at least 15 minutes if you want street parking.

I suggest making reservations and when you do, request patio seating! It seems to be the main dining room but it's outside under a tent and decorated so whimsically. The indoor dining area seems really tiny and cramped and more like a happy hour/bar seating type area.

I came with two of my girlfriends and we were seated in a great table on the patio, right next to a heater :D (yay!). It was my birthday too, so the hostess or perhaps manager gave me a complimentary glass of champagne. Delicious! 

They do family style here, which is so unexpected of French fare. The waiter will suggest you order two plates per person, one appetizer and one entree. In my opinion, I feel that may be much, and I was right, we were STUFFED. I'm not complaining though because each dish we had was incredibly good and plentiful. But you could probably get away with ordering one or two less appetizers. 

For appetizers, we ordered the mussels which came in a tasty, brothy soup (YUM), salmon carpaccio (def. get this!), and hudson grade A foie gras (for SURE  must have!). The foie gras was huge and soft so that it traditionally melts in your mouth.  

For entrees, we got their apparently famous potato wrapped sea bass, which was very unique and good, the maple leaf farm duck breast (must get! So tender and flavorful, love the complementary flavors), and the angus flatiron steak (ALSO must get) which was cooked PERFECTLY.

Did i already say that each of these dishes were huge and definitely enough for sharing?? 

I would highly recommend this place for groups...it's a great restaurant with quality food for decent prices. I can't wait to come back.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Aw, man! Felt like Chapeau (http://www.yelp.com/biz/chapeau-san-francisco#hrid:tmsWW51_NAn7ZNOvCTzsnQ) all over again: 1.) a highly rated restaurant, 2.) during Dine About Town, 3.) that I was excited about.

Turns out: that recipe does not work.

First course
+I opted for the Maine lobster broth with tiger prawns, tomato, celery, and tarragon.
Tasty? Meh.
+The bestie opted for the smooth corn soup with parsley, chives, and cream.
Tasty? Well, tastier than the lobster water, yes.

Second course
+I opted for the yellowfin tuna with spicy Sriracha, toasted sesame, slices of seaweed, avocado, and soy.
Tasty? Yeah, it was pretty good. 
+She got the steamed Prince Edward Island mussels with garlic, white wine, parsley, and grilled bread.
Tasty? Um, no. Not at all. Have I become a mussels snob? No, no. Can't be.

Third course
+I opted for the truffle risotto with baby shiitake, hon shimeji mushrooms, and Parmigiano reggiano.
Tasty? More like salty. Holy macaroni, it was salty. 
+She got the grilled flat iron steak cooked medium rare with zucchini, roasted potatoes, moutarde verte, and Bordelaise sauce (which was basically just the meat drippings).
Tasty? It was just OK. The "green mustard" (moutarde verte) was good.

Dessert course
+We shared the vanilla bean creme brulee and the semifreddo all'amaretto. The creme brulee was solid, but the semifreddo (with its sugary-sugar-sweet cookies) was kinda horrible.

Service was great; unfortunately, that's not why I chose to dine here. Sad face.
author: Adena B.

description: Meh. But for $49 per person, 5 course meal, not a bad deal. The workers are friendly and awesome. I love them all. Don't trust their wine "connoisseur." He has no idea or maybe there's just no wine that's available that's good?
author: Nit A.

description:
A friend and I came here for dinner for Dine About Town, and we're glad we chose this restaurant out of the impressive list. For ~$40 each, we were served a delicious four course meal, with an appetizer, two entrees, and a dessert. We also added on half a dozen oysters, which were $1 each. Definitely a lot to take on for two ladies, but we loved food too much.

For the appetizer, we ordered the potato leek soup and arugula salad. Both were good-- I particularly liked the arugula salad, as the sweet sour citrus paired well with the bitter arugula. Next were the yellowfin tuna and steamed Prince Edward island mussels. The yellowfin tuna was AMAZING! It was served raw, but was so soft that it practically melted in your mouth. The avocado complimented the tuna extremely well for a sweet and rich taste. Definitely my favorite dish of the night! The mussels were also very tasty, more so for the broth. We enjoyed dipping our bread to finish off the broth. The oysters were also brought in around this time, and served with a simple sauce and dash of lemon, they were also delicious .The oysters were smaller than the usual oysters around the area-- the waiter explained to us they were Little Skookum oysters from Seattle. Yum! Now, we were already starting to get a bit full, but we had two courses left. Third course included the truffle risotto and maple leaf farm duck breast. The truffle risotto was thick and rich, and the duck breast was soft and flavored with huckleberry sauce. These two dishes were more savory and filling, and we had to pack both home as we were stuffed! However, no matter how full we are, there's always room for dessert. My friend and I joked how we have two stomachs: one for dinner and one for dessert. Our dessert stomachs were empty and ready for deliciousness. We ordered the vanilla bean creme brulee and Buche Au Lait De Chevre (aged goat cheese with honey and walnuts.) The creme brulee was delicious (when is it not?) but nothing different from any other restaurant. The entree with goat cheese was unique though in my opinion: a slice of bread lathered with rich goat cheese and sprinkled with honeyed walnuts. I'm not usually a huge fan of cheese, but I have to admit this was awesome. 

All in all, we had a wonderful experience at Isa. Service was impeccable; our wait was friendly and visited our table often to refill water and our basket of bread, answer questions, and ask about our experience. The ambiance was intimate and relaxing, perfect for a dinner date or an evening unwinding after a long day. Definitely will come here again!
author: Christine L.

description: Went here for restaurant week and had they had a four course offering. I personally tried the potato soup, tuna, mussels, goat cheese, duck, scallops. Duck is my favorite meat and you can never go wrong with it, this place did not disappoint. It was cut into multiple small thin pieces and the skin was a little crunchy, just the way I liked it. The scallops were a bit on the small side, and there wasn't that much. It was also kind of salty...so that was a bit disappointing. However, I would go back here just because of how good the service was. We came in with 8 people and they respected our reservation within 5 minutes and gave us complimentary dessert wine. The waiter also let us know about every dish as if he were really proud to serve it and it made us really excited to try the food.
author: Victor D.

description: This was a real treat to finish out my spa day I had.  The braisen short ribs was succulent!  Talkin bout meat fallin off tha bone!  I'm not going to even discuss the potatoes.  Just drop in and see for yourself!  It's all that and worth every penny.
author: Queen B.

description:
Take your girlfriend here on a date, and I promise you you'll earn extra brownie points for this! The ambiance of the back patio seating, which includes soft white Christmas lights entangled in the structure, dim candlelights, cozy tables/chairs, just oozes romanticism and Parisian. 

Came here for DAT and ordered:
1. Salmon Carpaccio - Salmon was extremely fresh, and was nice & thick. 
2. Duck Breast -- Meat was medium rare, and very tender, but the bacon and sauce was a bit too salty.
