I informed the owner that the way she handled the situation is unacceptable, and instead of trying to salvage the situation to ensure customer satisfaction, she made it worse by trying to exonerate herself and her shoddily run business.

Sorry, lady, this is not India, there are safety standards to uphold here in the US.
author: D. S.

description:
Delicious food and a very lovely experience. We managed to sneak in a last minute Friday night reservation in, and enjoyed it thoroughly. The roasted chicken dish was unreal (oh the crunch and crust on the chicken!) and mashed potatoes fluffy and gorgeous. The duck breast was a touch dry and tough, which is the only reason this didn't get a 5 star rating. Their calamari (grilled whole!) is an all-star on the menu, as are the haricot vert and grilled asparagus. They also have a great selection of reasonably priced wine.

A wonderful and romantic date spot that isn't trendy or too loud in the Marina!
author: Gigi B.

description:
This place is awesome!

My partner wanted to be spontaneous and dine out on a Tues night after work. 

I didnt have a difficult time getting a reservation which was a relief. 

We started with 2 appetizers that was plenty enough to be an entree! We ordered the Grilled local calamari and Prawns. They were delicious! The flavors were great!

I had Seared scallops and my partner got Halibut. They were both good. The Halibut is just flavored too lightly for my taste but my partner enjoyed it.

I ended the night with their oh so heavenly Flourless chocolate cake with Gelato! ... take note that I said "I" and not "WE" because i "forgot" to share! hahaha!

I definitely would recommend this place to everyone! 2 thumbs up! :)

Oh and our server was great. He was pleasant and very knowledgeable :)
author: RED C.

description:
We came here on our last night in San Fran for the Dine about Town menu. of course before we ordered our dinner we ordered drinks first. my bf got a glass of malbec while i got the number seven cocktail. it was delicious!! not to sweet but you could really taste the blackberries and a touch of ginger.

For our first course, i ordered the baked goat cheese and my bf got the butter lettuce salad. i didnt try any of his but he said it was really good and cleaned his plate off so must have been delicious. i noticed that a lot of the other tables were getting salads for their first course too. my dish... well how can baked goat cheese with a tomato sauce and pine nuts not be good??... i spread it on the bread they bring to the table... i think i went through like two baskets.... sooo goodddd....

For our main dish, i ordered the scallops and my bf got the pan roasted chicken. they were very generous with the amount of scallops on my dish. i think it came with at least 5. i just know i wasnt able to finish them all but they were so tender that i just cut it with my fork. they came with brussel sprouts... a new favorite of mine and mashed potatoes. loved both of the side dishes. brussel sprouts were cooked just right and the mashed potatoes were creamy and smooth. my bf's dish was also a hit. the chicken skin was crispy on the outside and the meat was tender, juicy, and flavorful.

For our dessert we both ordered creme brulee. its hard to screw up creme brulee.. i mean i even like it at the sushi buffet restaurants... having said that we both enjoyed our desserts. however i do especially love it when they put real vanilla beans in it and you can really taste the vanilla. it was somewhat there in this dish but it left me wanting more vanilla.
author: Lesley H.

description:
This place is awesome. 

Get the yellowtail, the duck, and for christ's sake if they have the braised short ribs special get that.

The waiter with the moustache who looks like Petyr Baelish (littlefinger) from game of thrones is great.

Prices are fair for how good everything is.

If you can try to sit in the back.
author: Ryan K.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on a date night, after an SHN broadway musical. The food was great. We probably won't be back often because this is a fancy date night location (i.e. expensive), but it has a great romantic, sophisticated feel to it.

I will definitely keep this on my list of special occassion dining locations.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Came here for dine about town with my boyfriend and his mom. This place does dine about town the right way. They have 20 different choices on the menu. They didn't skimp out on you like most dine about town restaurant do!

Lobster soup amazing, fish amazing, pasta amazing.

I'm planning on coming back to check out other dishes on their menu.

Oh PS.... they have an outside area that can sometimes be covered if cold but super cool!
author: Jess O.

description:
Love this place! Came here for DAT and it was probably the best DAT dinner I've had. I hate how most restaurants don't feature their best items when they should because I am not down for just salads, soups and bullshit.

Isa had the best 3 course menu compared to other restaurants, so we decided to give this place a try. Service was great and the food was awesome. Decided to add Foie Gras to dinner for additional $25 and it was worth it.

1st: 
Oysters w/ orange migonette- pop in yo mouth refreshing
Salmon Carpaccio - good but kinda bland, needed extra citrus

2nd:
Seared Scallops - yummm
Duck - delishhh. perfectly cooked & seasoned. SO GOOD!

3rd:
Almond Amaretto - it was ok. a little on the icy side
Vanilla Bean Creme Brulee - good but not the best.

Overall, i would definitely come here again!
author: Rosalynn D.

description:
Absolutely delicious food, I recommend the mussels, steak and duck especially.  I went for a friends birthday in the beginning of June and then the very next week to get my last taste of foie gras before it is outlawed. The service is a little slow as you can tell from some of the other reviews, but in general the staff is pleasant, if a little dry.  On the plus side, they aren't fake or gratuitously friendly which I find more of a turn off.  

The point of Isa is the food.  It is also crucial to note that the dishes will come out AS THEY ARE FINISHED in the kitchen.  Also, the dishes are of VARYING PROPORTIONS.  The (small) salad will come out before the (tons of) mussels.  The fish will come out before the duck.  Go with people who you are comfortable sharing with to ensure you all have a fantastic dining experience.
author: Nikki A.

description:
Came here with friends for a ladies night out.  They have friendly staff and wonderful food.

We started off with a seafood extravaganza!  Oysters on a half shell, PEI mussels, and tuna tartare!

We 3 had the juicy steak that was served with potatoes and zucchini.  It was cooked perfectly to a medium-rare (more on the rare side) as requested!
author: JJAMZ C.

description: Tuna tartare was good. Calamari was grilled and good.  Sochu is the new vodka, is their motto. Sea bass was ok- lamb was ok. Side of mushrooms was excellent.
author: Amit D.

description:
I've been here 3 times. Service was good twice and awkward the third time (Waiter was just... odd). 

Food--
Not good: the grilled calamari. Very not good.
Good: yellowfin tuna tartare, roasted rack of lamb, and maple leaf farm duck breast.
Very good: braised pork ribs. their butter :)

I'd come back a 4th time to try their mushroom risotto and have their braised pork ribs.. and of course, some butter. yumms.

note: portions are kind of small, given the price of this place. 3 plates should be okay for 2 people though.
author: Chau T.

description:
2.5 stars for mediocre food + sub-par customer service

I came with a party of 7 for dinner on a Saturday night.  I was excited to eat here because one of my friends highly recommended this place.  However, the service really ruined our dining experience here and I'm not sure the food was memorable enough to convince me to give them another try.

Our waiter was not responsive and quite condescending.  From his behavior, it was clear that he didn't like the fact that we didn't follow his recommendation of ordering 2 dishes per person and didn't like the fact that we didn't order any wine with our meals. Due to my severe lactose intolerance, I asked if it was possible to get my dish without butter.  He wasn't very accommodating or understanding of my condition.  Instead, he just suggested that I get another dish.  

I had heard so much hype about their potato wrapped seabass from yelpers and online food critics that I was really looking forward to the dish!  The potato wrapped seabass ($20) didn't  live up to my expectations. The seabass was overcooked and dry. The only great thing about this dish was the crispy pieces of potatoes on top of the fish. It's a unique idea of a dish but failed in execution. We also ordered the maple leaf farm duck breast ($19). The duck breast was tender and juicy but lacked flavor. 

As we were leaving, someone from our group decided that the owner needed to know about the terrible customer service we received.  I appreciate that the owner apologized and tried to see what they could do to compensate us for our bad experience.  I hope they will truly listen to their customers and work to improve their customers' dining experience here...as well as work to improve their food!  

It was also impossible to catch a cab by this restaurant on a weeknight.!
author: Angela F.

description: Fair food, certainly wouldn't rave about it, truffle risotto quite bland, corn soup could have been creamier, also dislike that they tried to overcharge us with prix fixe price when my dishes cost less: I'm sure this is routinely done,beware.
author: Sue F.

description: Great service and food. Highly recommend their lamb! They charge $8 for an extra lamb chop in case people want to share. The only thing is everything comes small but super delicious.
author: Christy Z.

description:
Friday night + an awesome dinner = A happy & satisfied customer

I don't think I would have ate at Isa if they didn't participate in the Dine About Town program.  I'm REALLY happy that they did because I had the perfect dinner experience last night.

Parking sucks around here especially on a Friday night so if you find yourself circling around the block, try the parking structure on Pierce Street.  It's only one block away and has meters so make sure to bring coins or pay via your smartphone.

We arrived at the restaurant exactly at our reservation time and were seated almost immediately.  They gave us the table for 2 in front that gave us a view of the street and isolated us from the main dining area where it was much louder.  A perfect table to have a conversation without having to raise your voice, repeat yourself, and hope you heard the other person correctly.  It's also a great seat to have people on the street pass by and look at your dishes and say "oh, that looks good..."*drool*

Since there were two of us, we played it smart and we each ordered something different for each course.  Here comes the break down:

First course:
Tomales Bay Point Reyes Oysters:  A plate of 6 oysters that are super fresh.  Nice way to start off the meal.  The oysters are on the smaller side so I was craving for more.  
Loch Duart Salmon Carpaccio:  Very generous slices of salmon that went well with the ingredients.  The crostini was a good way of contrasting the soft texture of the salmon.
After the first course, I was definitely a fan.

Second course:
Seared Scallops:  Oh man, these scallops were cooked to perfection!  They were fresh and tender, giving you that happy feeling as you ate each one.  The garlic and truffle sauce went well with the scallops.  Make sure to take the scallop and slide it across the plate to taste the sauce. Yum.
Truffle Risotto:  One word:  Delicious.  Two types of mushrooms with reggiano cheese.  This dish was not too rich and cooked the way I like it.
After the second course, I was in love with the food.

Third course:
Two types of vanilla desserts:  Gelato and creme brulee.  The vanilla flavor was evident in each dessert. The desserts were a good way to end the meal.

The food was great!  The staff was friendly, attentive, and brought out each dish at a steady pace so that you're not waiting saying "where's my food?"  I have no complaints at all about this restaurant.  

Five Yelp stars all the way.

I'll definitely come back and try their non-DAT menu.  I'd love to try their regular menu dishes.
author: Suzi K.

description:
I was a little frustrated to find that their menu was different than what they'd posted online. I'm the type that researches my dining options diligently, and thus, the menus too. I pretty much know what I want before I ever step foot in a restaurant.

I was here with a date and they sat us in a semi-secluded table by the window. Due to the layout of that part of the restaurant, we had to sit side-by-side. It was a good thing I liked my date! (Though I suppose even if I didn't, sitting side-by-side would mean I wouldn't have to look at him very much...)

I was very impressed with Isa. The atmosphere was perfect for a date. Quaint, intimate, dim lighting (= flattering lighting), and not too loud. I had absolutely no complaints about any of the food either, which is rare.

We started with the MAINE LOBSTER BROTH (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=jG56L5FMQmMU6kZfwS6pNQ). My oh my, that was delicious. It had the exact same rich lobster-y flavour as a bisque, without the heaviness. Next was the FOIE GRAS with apples, huckleberry, and custard brioche (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=kW2AjUC3cp3j1FtdqvJY8Q). (My date had never tried it before so I HAD to order it for us. I could never date someone who was against the force-feeding of ducks to fatten up their livers for me to eat). The foie gras was perfectly cooked and melted in my mouth. The huckleberries provided a nice acidity to cut the fattyness of the foie. I also loved the fact that they put the brioche on the side instead of under the foie so that it wasn't soaked with fat.

For the entrees, I had the duck breast with beets, chevre, arugula and huckleberry sauce (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=B8ovbnJn86OLbfdr36jqqA). The DUCK BREAST was cooked to a perfect medium-rare. The chevre also went really well with the arugula. My date ordered the RACK OF LAMB with sautéed eggplant, zucchini, red peppers, and lamb jus (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=jSSJrDKf5J92eKlG2irFkQ). That was delicious too. The meat was cooked well. The sautéed vegetables were so good that I ate most of them off his plate (I also need to date someone who'll share their food with me). We got a side of potato puree too (fancy term for mashed potatoes). They were also tasty and very creamy, but nothing spectacular.

For dessert we just split a CREME BRULEE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=2J8Tee15TzN8UbSulA7vkA). Again, very good but pretty standard stuff.

It was a good date. But whether it was because of the food or the company, I'm not really sure. Maybe the two enhanced each other, or maybe the food was so good I didn't notice how little chemistry we might've had. I'd definitely come back to Isa, maybe on a weeknight to check out their prix fix menu.
author: Steph L.

description: The place is very cute! The food is GREAT for Marina food. The service is odd! I recommend not taking wine advice and going for the Paela! YUM.
author: Candi M.

description:
AWESOME
more than 5 stars for the food, service, and the ambiance! 
every single dish we ordered was a hit. Very fresh ingredients that were amazingly cooked and drafted. The super star was the potato skin wrapped sea bass. this is their signature dish and I highly recommend it

 we had the pleasure to be serviced by a wonderful man Domingo.  We did not have any reservation, so we sat at the bar. The service was so prompt and perfectly timed. plus the smile and the joyful attitude of Domingo made it even better. thanks so much.

if I had one small suggestion it would be some gluten free crackers or bread if possible.
author: Khaoula B.

description:
This restaurant is growing on me quickly.  So quickly, it might be come one of my favorites around the Marina.  

So apparently, I'd been here before DAT.  Last year, a business partner hooked me up with some tickets for Pinot Days since his neighbor was somehow involved in the marketing or wineries.  Anyway, I found a picture of that menu and remembered how delectable everything was.

This time, we were doing DAT with a party of 7!  One thing that told us right away that this would be a great experience was that Isa was ONLY doing a DAT menu.  That's how committed they were.

Between the 7 of us, we ordered sole, steak, duck, scallops, goat cheese, a crab salad, salmon, gelato, semifreddo, granite, and cake.  Honestly, I still can't believe we got away with that quality of food for that inexpensively.  We basically shared everything family/tapas style and everything was either good or fantastic.  My favorites were the flank steak, the goat cheese, and the duck.  All of the desserts were good too, but we were too full to finish them.

Definitely a solid 4-star place, and the service was great.  I love how they have a front room and back room.  I've eaten in the back room twice now and it's so cozy.  Some things worth mentioning - anyone who knows, knows that parking around there is a BITCH so use the parking garages or cab it.  There are also (2) small unisex bathrooms so make sure you know where they are.
author: Dylan T.

description:
My husband and I have come here a few times for special occasions, and we really like this place.  

We've tried:
- mussels (delicious!)
- scallops (our favorite thing on the menu!)
- potato wrapped seabass (tasty, but inconsistent)
- truffle risotto (to die for!)
- flat iron steak (not a fan)

All in all, we are always satisfied with the food.  The only thing we really didn't like was the flat iron steak, which in general isn't our favorite cut to begin with.  

Bottom line:  The staff is friendly and we'll definitely return!
author: Jade F.

description: I was going to give if a 4 star but I couldn't find anything I was unhappy with. Mussels were delicious, sauce was perfect, prawns were amazing sweet and good, service was really nice, they work as a team! lobster soup was also perfect with chunks of meat. Duck was cooked to perfection with sweet bacon bits. Arugula salad with orange and apple bites was a good touch. Lamb shank was also good but my least favorite (seafood dishes were the best). Dessert, cream brulee and chocolate cake, topped with a authentic warm reminder from our server that they have daily special meals and wishes for us to come back. This place is really awesome.
author: Tiff W.

description:
After reading all the raging yelp review I felt like I had to try this place out. It seemed perfect since SF restaurant week was going on. We made reservations, put on our fancy pants and headed downtown for a romantic date night.  Be warned, this review is solely based on the restaurant week fixed menu. They offered a four course with a good selection. First we had potato leek soup and Endive frisée salad. Not impressed. The soup was bland and the salad had a weird mixture of flavors. A bit too vinegary and bitter for my taste. Second course, we had salmon gaspachio and mussels. Better, the salmon was fatty and melts in your mouth. Mussels were nice and salty with a bit of acidity. Third course, we got seared scallop and iron flat stake. The scallop was perfectly cooked, tender, and had great taste. The steak was medium rare and it came with a bitter cheese sauce. The third course disappointed me a bit, it was way too heavy. You can definitely taste the butter in all the dishes they served here and that fat was building up in my tastebuds. I had to order a couple slices of lemon wedges because I couldn't handle the heaviness  of the meal.  Lastly, we had the grapefruit granite and amaretto. The grapefruit granite was nothing special, just shaved ice with grapefruit syrup over it. The amaretto was a lot better. It was creamy and you could taste bits of almond in every bite. Although it did have ice crystals forming in the ice cream. 

Overall, it was a good French experience for the price. But I would not come back here based on the tasting of the meals I had. I was expecting a lot more out of this place and unfortunately I was disappointed. The flavors weren't out there and nothing really screamed DELICIOUS. It was just OK with good service and a fancy atmosphere.
author: Winne L.

description:
My bf and I always explorer many different French restaurants in the bay area, and Isa is one of our favorites! We went there twice, one for our anniversary and one for the valentine's day dinner last weekend. 

I wanted to give them all 5 stars but took 1 off for the first time we went; the owner's wife was pregnant and gave us some attitude when we already reserved a table, still made us wait for like 35 to 40min. (note: we had reservation at 6pm so the restaurant is basically empty)!!!

However, we have to admit that their foods are super good! Especially for their hot fresh foie gras and duck breast!! We order them EVERY TIME we go for sure! Then we also ordered their lamb chops, fresh oysters, and cream brule.

Isa, we love your foods! Please improve your services though!
author: Sammy C.

description:
I came here to try the Dine About Town, which was pretty good.  
I tried the Lobster Broth, which was a bit watery for me and there wasn't any lobster pieces that I was expecting.  However, the prawns in it was nice.  My dinner mate ordered the Leek Soup just for fun (to see how special Isa could make it), and it wasn't anything special.  We both had the Crab Salad, which was really good paired with the different fruit mixed in with the crab.
For the main course we had the Duck Breast and the Spaghetti with Truffles.  Decent size amount for both.  The duck was a bit too raw for me, but it was very tender.
For dessert we had the Semifreddo and the Creme Brulee.  Loved the Semifreddo, with the nuts mixed in and pairing it with cookies.  The waiter said it was a gelato, but it didn't really seem like it.  
Great service from the waiters.  And at $5 during happy hour, the cocktails are great, especially the Number Seven.
author: Karen L.

description:
Fantastic! 
I made a reservation on Opentable to eat here Saturday night and was very excited. We had to wait 15 minutes past our reservation since this place was completely packed but I'd say the short wait was worth it.
I had the Jr Rocky roasted chicken with au jus and mashed potatoes. This was delicious, I literally almost licked my plate! The bread before our meal was also really good.
Service here was good, our waters and bread basket was filled constantly. 
Dishes here are served as they are ready but my bf's rack of lamb came out just a few minutes before mine!
Would love to return and eat in the heated patio next time.
author: Miss H K.

description:
I came here for DAT and it was perhaps one of the best DAT meals I've had.... EVER! We tried all of the appetizer options, the scallops, steak, and duck entrees, and the grapefruit granite and chocolate flourless cake. All of the dishes were delicious and the service was friendly.

The only downside was that the zucchini was a tad overcooked (the side that accompanied the steak). And the service while friendly, could sometimes be a bit overzealous about removing plates and dishes.

I can't believe I haven't been here before. I've been walking past this place for years, yet somehow never tried it. I think it's one of the few places worth a trek into the Marina.
author: Dani D.

description:
Came with my team from work for a roll-off dinner and the food was phenomenal. Wine was good as well; all Reasonably priced for a place like this. Favorite dishes were the duck, lamb, shrimp appetizer (ordered another it was so good), red tuna. Side of corn and mushrooms were both really good. I'm not a liver person but the foie gras was probably on the better side that I've had (probably because it didn't taste too much like liver). It's sweet and a little different. Creme brûlée and the gluten free chocolate cake were my favorite desserts (especially the cake). I wasn't too crazy about the sea bass (prefer more flavor) or the mussels. 

Service was great - super friendly and they let us stay pretty late. Definitely hope to come again!
author: Josh S.

description:
I really like this place! I came with a group a friends for Dine About Town (of course) and we had such an amazing dinner - the only bad part was the waitress/host person kept trying to steer our choices toward more diverse ones - hey, if we ALL want to eat steak, there's no point in shoving a salad down our throats, hmmmm?

Never mind.

But seriously the ambiance was so lovely. You sit out on the patio but it's nice and warm and welcoming because it's enclosed in a tent and there's rows of sort of rustic picnic looking tables with tiny lanterns strung all over the place. It's haphazardly beautiful and a perfect date night place, if you were so inclined.

The food was on the whole very good. With the limited options, I think the soups were kind of on the oilier side (lobster broth and potato leek soup, I believe), but everything that followed was top notch. Since we were doing Dine About Town, we all tried a little of each others' food - the steak, the duck, the dungeness crab salad (ohmygoodness, YUM), the seriously never-ending bread basket, and the piece de resistance - the CREME BRULEE. Must must must get the creme brulee.

I loved this place and I'd definitely come back. It's got a great vibe and good, delicious food that puts a smile on your face :)
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Just had a pre-Christmas dinner party with family last night.  What a wonderful time we had!!  

Dean was our server and was pleasant, hospitable, patient & friendly.  He set our expectations early, then exceeded them.  He made our visit a delightful one.  The other members of the staff were friendly as well, participating in conversation with our group.  

What we had?
Goat cheese - wow
Prawns - perfect
Scallops - they melt in your mouth
Sea bass - delicious!!
Rack of lamb - tender & delicious
Risotto - my favorite dish!


Great place for an intimate dinner or an evening with a group of family or friends.  Food is delicious, service is wonderful, ambiance is perfect.  We will most definitely be returning.
author: G. C.

description:
Four years later I am back.  In San Francisco to visit my favorite engineers and dine at this excellent and most unpretentious restaurant.  

It was Restaurant Week (lucky break) and I was famished, having spent the day at Fort Mason chatting with outstanding artists at the summer ACC Crafts Show. (If you appreciate fine craftsmanship, watch for it next August).

Needless to say, I was happy we had reservations. The tables were full. Five of us ordered from the fixed price menu. Favorite dishes were the heirloom tomato salad, a slice of roasted duck, and one perfectly luscious lamb chop.  

It was a wonderful way to close out a perfect SF day;  lovely company and fabulous food. This place is a local gem--yes, those are heat lamps dotting the patio! At all the tables near ours, people looked as if they were enjoying their evening. (Expect it to be crowded and noisy).
author: Lynn S.

description:
Great drinks in the bar but the food was just so-so.
I must admit I was disappointed. After such a great experience in the bar while waiting for the table, I was geared up for an amazing dinner. The food was a bit bland and definitely missed the mark.
author: Jen F.

description:
There is happy hour here! $5 for a pretty good selection of cocktails, red wines, sparkling wines, and beers.

I came here for Dine About Town with a party of 8. During this promotion, there is only the Dine About Town menu, so don't think you can get some paella til February! 

I started off with a couple glasses of wines--pinot (which the server said is their most popular) and a cab.  For $5/glass... keep 'em coming!

For the first course, I ordered the lobster soup. It was a clear soup (not creamy), and was made so you can just enjoy the taste of lobster. With that said, it doesn't come off at first as anything special. If anything, one might not appreciate the soup to its full extent. But you can tell it takes some time to thoroughly cook the lobster taste out.

I chose the dungenness crab salad for my second course, which comes with tomatoes, apples, and grapefruit. This was such a good pick, not only because it's crab season, but because I don't think they added dressing onto this dish. All the juices were from the crab and fruits--different combinations of sweet flavors.

Our table ordered the risotto, scallops, duck, and beef. Risotto was delicious, with the truffle oil and mushrooms. The only reservation about this dish is that it's simple. I make this similar dish once in a while. It's not difficult to make, and I'm not sure if it's worth it. If you order the scallops, it comes with 1.5 large ones. Beef brisket (?) comes with mashed potatoes and veggies (which were good). Duck platter comes with duck that's fairly rare. 

For dessert, I ordered the semifreddo. Yum! I've only had this one other time at Candybar, and I don't it was similar. This one is nutty and comes with three amaretto cookies.

Overall, the food was decent. Happy hour was worth it. But what really blew this place away was the service. The server was such a sweet man. He was helpful and attentive to everyone at the table. I felt so welcomed here and informed about the menu and the restaurant that I would love to come again.
author: Adorable T.

description:
We ended up at Isa after heading to our favorite Bistro AIX where the wait was over 20min so we thought we'd try something new....however we were underwhelmed by the overall food experience.  

Eats:
Lil gem lettuce salad w blue chz
Potato wrapped sea bass: was overlooked and dry
Chicken
Dessert- goat cheese- was hard and dried out
author: Samantha A.

description:
4.5 stars

Have you ever been to a restaurant that served the one epic dish that took you away? You attempt to describe this dish to others but inevitably stutter to find the right words and end up resorting to a general description: "That dish was great!"

The Hudson Valley Grade A foie gras with apples, huckleberry, port and custard brioche could never be depicted with words.  Because once the aroma dissipates, once the taste leaves your mouth and the essence no longer lingers in your heart, only resonance is left.  But it has left a feeling of blissfulness in my memory.  The creative combination of fruit and foie gras was gastronomical.  Soft on the tongue and lightly sweetened, the custard brioche complemented the fruitfulness and saltiness of the dish quite well.  The display of huckleberry over foie gras surrounded by 4 apple balls and a pool of berry juice and port wine gave the dish a very artful appeal.  If cooking is art, then the Hudson Valley foie gras would be Chef Luke Sung's magnum opus.

The other dishes were splendid as well.  Though the seared scallops were a bit char-coaled for my taste, the brussel sprouts that accompanied it were surprisingly appetizing.  The short ribs were falling off the bone delicious!  It had just the right amount of fat to get me coming back for more.  Nevertheless, my sweet tooth was not fulfilled because the creme brulee and flourless chocolate cake did not end the meal with a bang.

The atmosphere was not too pretentious for a restaurant of this caliber so don't be intimidated, EAT here!! And remember, you MUST and I emphasize MUST try the foie gras that words can not simply describe.
author: Nancy L.

description: The 2 of us ordered truffle risotto, lobster broth, sea bass wrapped in bacon, flank steak.  It was too much food.  We ended up taking most of the steak to go since it came out last.  The truffle risotto was a little disappointing.  I guess I had high expectations for it since everyone on here raved about it.  The lobster broth was pretty good and had real lobster chunks in it.  The sea bass was amazing, cooked and seasoned just right.  The steak was mediocre.  It didn't have much flavor.
author: Mindy K.

description:
My wife and I celebrated our one year wedding anniversary at Isa. 

We felt that the food, service and atmosphere were all wonderful. Thank you for a memorable evening!
author: Roman S.

description:
I know, I'm cruel. Call it schadenfreude. Call it evil. But whatever it is, it's tasty homicide: foie gras. I love it. 

So when I heard that San Francisco passed a measure banning this practice, I knew I had to give this murderous dish one last go. There was no question that I had to go back to the first place that turned me into a Dexter of water fowl. 

I blame Isa, because they have always been consistent in their delivery. I dare to say they might have single handedly given reason to pass the measure for how well they are able to turn disgust into lust. 

To salt the wound in the face of the NIMBY city council, Isa decided it was an awesome idea to offer a "Say Farewell  to Foie Gras" dinner, featuring two different preparations; one with their classic pear, and the other mango. Picking the pear brought me back to the first time I shamefully turned the cheek to animal cruelty.

The risotto and the duck main courses went well with the (very, very) generously poured glasses of suggested wine, but came only secondary to the foie gras in its delivery. The seared scallops was by far one of the most impressive: They got the texture and tenderness perfect, allowing each piece to be cut like someone decided to crossbreed sea bass with prime rib.

Our server was impeccable and professional, always keeping an eye on our tiny booth in the corner. His wine suggestions were spot on.

I have always had a consistent, amazing, dining experience coming here; so it is no wonder I have allowed them to spam me with any promotions they have because I'll always be coming back.
author: Alfred Y.

description: For an out of this world experience, definitely order the truffle risotto! The place does get a little pricey and the portions are pretty small, but the ambiance and quality of the food is excellent. Be sure to get there before 7 PM for $5 drinks!
author: D K.

description: Great service, excellent food and nice presentation.  The truffle risotto was simply delicious.
author: Charlie C.

description:
4.5 Stars

I came here with my significant other for the "Down About Town" special. Keep in mind that this was a reservation and not a walk in. Our attire was semi formal but I saw people dressed casually there.

Right when we walked in (it was around 8:00 pm), we were immediately greeted by someone and was offered a booth that made my partner and I face each other indoors, side by side, or across from each other "outside" in this pseudo outside plaza that was dim but very romantic. We decided to take the pseudo plaza since the images on yelp looked great, and it was! Very pleased with the ambience that the area created.

We both ordered the pre fixe which was a 3 course meal. I got the leek soup first and it was good tasting but could have used a pinch of salt more. I added it in myself and it turned out to be delicious. My entrée was the steak that had a mustard kind of sauce on it. I ordered it medium rare and my goodness, it melted in my mouth. Very delicious and I highly recommend it. As for deserts, I just gave my deserts to my girl since I'm not too fond of sweetness. Overall, food quality was close to excellent and it all came out relatively quick! 

The best part of my night though was interacting with our waiter who was this middle age (getting towards his senior years) man from Cambodia (he told us). He complimented how my partner looked that night and even told us about his life story and how he ended up working there. It's very fascinating and you guys should rejoice if you get him as a waiter. He's really goofy but adorable, and quite loud but in a good way. We revealed to him that we were students at Cal and he just yelled out "Go Bears!", revealing to us he actually graduated from there! Small world indeed. He wanted to give us wine but my wallet at the time had a little hole in it so I didn't want to spend too much. The amazing part though was that towards the end of the night, he gave us 2 glasses of wine on the house and said we were a cute couple and that a romantic date must be coupled with some wine. Absolutely stellar service and I would definitely come back here again.
author: Chris K.

description:
Husband and I came here for the first time for the "Dine About Town" pre-fixe menu on Sun evening.  The choices on the menu were so great, we had such a hard time choosing because they all sounded so good.  We finally narrowed down to the Tamales Bay Oysters and mussels in garlic wine sauce.  As for the main, we chose the scallops and flat iron steak.  Everything was excellent!  They even gave us free wine which was an added bonus.  The table next to us ordered the duck and we were kicking ourselves for not choosing it, it looked fantastic.  

Our server, Justin was very pleasant and made us feel comfortable.  The entire staff were great, they kept coming to clear the plates to provide new ones, brought more bread and filled our water glasses before we even asked, the manager etc.  The ambiance was cozy, intimate yet could be dressy to casual.  There was absolutely nothing that we could complain about.  We were so impressed with this place, that my husband commented that it is one of his favorite restaurants.  We try different restaurants and critique - we are foodies!  Just love trying new places, especially if they are rated 4.0-stars and over. We definitely give this place a high mark and plan to return.
author: Diane S.

description:
FOIE GRAS? FO NAH!

Man it gave me such a bad stomachahce after dinner! I believe I had food poisoning! NEVER AGAIN ISA!

Went there a few years back and it was ok. Decided to give it another try since it was my friend's bday. Btw, this review is for a few months ago...before foie gras was banned.

FOOD: 
- Not that great..we had a party of ten and only two actually liked their food.
- My bf's plate didn't come until everyone was almost done with their food...Server gave him a free shot of something and apologized. Still, my bf was dying of hunger!
- Foie gras was small. I was still hungry leaving the restaurant.

PRICE:
- a little pricey..it is in the marina so what do you expect?

SERVICE:
- Our server looks like he was high on his job. He often forgot what we needed. He comes to our table very happy and made lots of jokes. But still....he seems high.

AMBIANCE:
- Small bar in front. We had to kill someone for seats because it is so small and pack by the bar. They have happy hour specials.
author: Tammy F.

description:
Terrible dining experience. About 15-30 minutes would pass between each course, and the courses were served haphazardly (eg my food arrives and 15 minutes later my date's food arrives -- this happened with 2 courses). We were there for over 2 hours, spending most of the time waiting for our food. 

And regarding the food: it wasn't good. As a note to the service, when you serve steak, don't give butter knives to cut it with then disappear for 20 minutes, especially when it is as rubbery as it was tonight.

This place is clearly overrated.

I will never return.
author: Captain B.

description:
ISA is one of my favorite any night of the week "go-to" restaurants.  The flavors are impeccable, the ingredients incredibly fresh, and the ambiance is set for the perfect casual get together - regardless the size of your party. 

The must haves - foie gras, goat cheese, and flat iron steak.  
The scallops are delicious, but the portion size is relatively small given the cost of the dish.   The truffle risotto is spectacular some days, and has been hit or miss others. 
For a simple dish that's simple and tasteful, we also order the chicken. 
Desserts - I tend to pass at ISA - I have a huge sweet tooth, and unfortunately this is one area where I hope the restaurant makes some adjustments.  We typically grab a treat around the corner at Susie cakes on the evenings we come to visit ISA. 

ISA will leave you with a smile.  The food is well prepared, and the perfect blend of French American cuisine.  It's not your typical heavy French meal, you will feel satisfied, and not overwhelmed.  I have brought many friends to this place, and will continue to do so.  ISA has kept a high standard of quality and taste since I've been dining here for the past few years.

One note - the dishes are served family style. If you want to order individual entrees, you will have to let your server know to bring the dishes out at the same time.
author: Pooja S.

description:
Isa is definitely one of my favorite french restaurants.  My BF and I have tried multiple items on the menu and we were never disappointed.  The potato wrapped sea bass is a must and the pasta is always cooked to perfection.  The free bread is awesome- always warm, crunch and soft on the inside.

Great date place!
author: Lynn S.

description:
Service: energetic, great as expected for a fancy restaurant

Ambiance: casual, yet romantic backyard, beautiful ambiance inside, lively feel

Food:
-Mapble leaf farm duck breast: it was alright, a bit dry
-Grilled Calamari: good, but not wowed
-Truffle risotto: WOW, delicious.  I don't even like risotto, but I loved this one.
-Creme Brulee: solid

Overall tastes more like an Asian fusion than Traditional French bistro.  Good to try once, but is not a place i must return to.
author: Muttika C.

description:
i've been wanting to try ISA for a couple of years, and this year finally i made a reservation for DAT here. Monday night, although a holiday (MLK day), seemed pretty busy in ISA. As soon as we seated, the waiter came over talking to us about the menu. I thought it was rather rude that he was pointing to the menu w/ a pen and waiving the pen right in front of our faces while explaining the menu. We brought our bottle of red because the wine list at ISA was pretty small, However, our waiter didn't bother to let the person brining the wine taste the bottle before pouring full servings into our glasses. Finally we placed the order, the food took FOREVER to come out, and there were so many mistakes. For example, only 1 of our second courses made it to the table, after another 20 mins of waiting, nothing came, and all of a sudden one of the 3rd courses showed up at the table. I politely told the bus boy that we haven't received all our second courses yet. After another 15 mins, we finally got the other second course we should've gotten 35 mins ago. The funniest part was that the busers were so confused all around that one of them actually came up to our table and asked us " what are you waiting for right now?" REALLY? isn't that your job to make sure you're sending food out to the correct table w/ proper timing and not asking us to do your job for you? It doesn't help that we have to ask multiple times with multiple waiters to get a basket of bread. it's like playing russian roulette that we might get lucky to get  a buser who wouldn't instantly forget about our request when he turned around. geez...

although food was decent, duck breast and flat iron steak were cooked nicely, steamed mussels was also nicely done, the service kinda ruined the whole experience for us.

i have no idea why the service was THAT bad the night we went, but i hope to see improvements because some of the things that happened during our dinner were too surprising to be true for ISA's reputation.
author: Joyce C.

description:
My partner and I found this place walking by and exploring places for dinner in the area. It's competition of restaurants in the street was quite high but this one won us over by its menu.

Our servers were not very rare with their smiles which was disappointing on the service end. There felt a lack of enthusiasm. 

They gave complimentary bread (with oil,balsamic, garlic, herbs and chilli to dip into) which was absolutely delicious and the best I have ever had.

The place had great ambiance with a few big groups and couples. 

We ordered the parmigiana and fettuccine bolognese  which were great. The parmigiana was processed instead of home made style which was noticed. 

A place we would come back to again.

Note: There is no phone reception inside
author: Sally-Ash S.

description: Food was delicious and the ambiance and service was great as well!  I would especially recommend the goat cheese appetizer and the duck main dish for sure, but the  tuna and rack of lamb were great as well!
author: LJ H.

description:
Came back to Isa and was thoroughly disappointed, i am pretty confident the ownership has changed, the service was a disaster, the front of house would use an experienced person ASAP. The food, was good, if you had not gone previously you would be wowed, but after 5 years the menu is the same, i did not know that was possible especially in SF. 

After placing our drinks, i noticed i had a knife and my dining partner had a fork....so i had to flag him down, only for him to act like it was doing us a favor to bring us a complete set of dinnerware. Also, none of our dishes had an explanation, just kinda dropped off, luckily they were exactly the same dishes i used to order 5 years ago when this was one of my favorite places. I ordered 4 plates and our crab salad never came out, and i did not realize it until after finishing our other dishes, i called the server over and explained to him we were missing a dish but since it was a salad, it made no sense to get it at the end. He just kept saying "it's cool if you want it, i'm cool i can bring it," but it was the manner if which he said it and he actually NEVER apologized nor offered some kind of gesture to make up for it. We were going to switch it out with something else but the awkwardness of the situation was so off putting we just asked for the check. He came back 3 minutes later and said " i thought it was my fault but it's not, it was the kitchen, i just wanted you to know that"...oookkkkaayyyy...0 stars for service 2 stars for the food and the menu that has yet to be changed in 5 years.
author: S C.

description: The food and service are amazing! Sea bass and wild prawns were the best things I've ever tasted in my life.
author: Steph T.

description:
Here's a review for Dine About Town lurkers.. more like a full menu listing..

Late dinner on Sat. for party of 7 

SERVICE: Great service. Hostess gave us updates and options. Waiter was knowledgeable about the menu. Service was on point. 

FOOD: Isa has a prix fixe menu regularly. The DAT menu is actually 6 apps, 7 entrees, 4 desserts. The dishes are great for sharing. 

Appetizers (salmon carpaccio, dugeness crab salad, butter lettuce salad, arugula salad, Laura chenel goat cheese, PEI mussels) -- I recommend everything but the crab salad -- the weakest dish on the appetizer list. Might have been better if it came out before the stronger flavored dishes.

Second Course (scallops, seasonal fish, spaghetti, truffle risotto, range chicken, duck breast, flat iron steak)-- we have everything but the steak and doubled up on the duck breast. 
Seasonal fish is petrale sole. Everything was excellent. I don't normally order spaghetti or risotto, but like William Hung, I have no regrets at all. Each plate was very hearty -- the duck breast was one of the bigger plates. 

Third Course (Grapefruit granite, semifreddo all'amaretto, vanilla bean gelato, vanilla bean creme brulee) -- we had everything but the grapefruit. Semifreddo is very almondy, if you're into that, and goes well with expresso. 

PRICE: Prix fixe ~$35. Mix drinks $8-9. Tip included for larger parties. Damper -- they have a 3 course prix fixe for $29. I am sure the DAT is a better deal... I hope.

TIPS: Make reservations early. Parking can get difficult. Isa has parking reservation service but we didn't try it. Happy hour before 7pm -- $5 drinks. Free wine glass per prix fixe Sun-Thurs. Choices for vegetarians were delicious! Kitchen is small -- our dishes came out a few at a time which was great for sharing.

CONCLUSIONS: Definitely a good choice for DAT. Great choice if you have a vegetarian friend. Flavors match like Pixars Ratatouille. Breathe the same air as 49ner's great Joe Montana!
author: Stanley L.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend for a casual spur of the moment dinner and was very impressed!

Everything we had was great. We got 2 appitizers and 2 entree's and 2 drinks each and the bill didn't break $100 which is shocking for the marina. 

Recommendations: Raw Ahi with Avocado & Baked Goat Cheese for Starters and the Truffle Risotto and the Scallops for Entree's

Also, they make delicious cocktails with Soju which we learned is a Japanese vodka that is 40% alcohol. It is there loophole because they only have a beer and wine license but what I thought was a delicious and creative way to be able to serve cocktails!

We will defintely be back...and we found out that during the week you can have a three course meal for $29!
author: Ashley G.

description:
The first time I went, maybe 7-8 years ago with my best buddy -- it was great.  Then I went back about 4-5 year ago, and it was just ok.  Then we went about two months ago, and it was great again.  

Portions were generous for the prie fix dinner.  The mussels and salmon appetizers were pretty scrumptious.  The steak and the truffle risotto were also yummy.  Overall, for the price and amount of food, definitely worth it!  

I'd go back FO SHO.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
First review and first time eating a fancy four-course meal!

My sister and I took advantage of the Dine About Town deal. Made reservations in advance and were seated within 3 minutes of walking in. The lighting was dim and ambiance was quite intimate. The perfect romantic date. Oh wait, it's just my sister. Eugh. We made sure to order different dishes so we could taste more of the menu.

First course: 

Lobster Broth- I felt like I was drinking a small swimming pool for shrimp mixed with some tomato juice. Super raw. Even the shrimp was a bit below average and seemed a bit overcooked so this soup was only half eaten.

Potato and Leek Soup- DELISHHHH! I love leeks and this just had enough flavor and the perfect amount of potatoes. My sister had a miss on hers so she kept trying to sneak in spoonfuls when I wasn't looking.

Second course: 

Yellowfin Tuna Tartare- Can't really vouch for this since I don't like raw seafood but my sister seemed to really enjoy it and I guess tiny bit of seaweed salad met my standards.

Mussels: OH MY GOD. FLAVOR EXPLOSION IN MY MOUTH! This dish was big enough to be my whole dinner! I felt like Isa reserved their biggest and tastiest mussels just for me. I even got seconds on bread because I wanted to soak up all the delicious garlicky mussel broth. Take that, lobster broth! 

Third course:

Duck Breast- YUM!!! I think this baby was cooked to tender perfection. The salad complimented the duck and the vinaigrette married the flavors together. I would definitely order this one again.

Flat Iron Steak- My sister thought it was too gamey. I had no problem with it. Ate all of it because I didn't want to ask for a to-go box. But flavors as a whole, it wasn't very memorable.

Fourth course:

Creme Brulee- Soft and fluffy. And sweet flavors.

Semifreddo- Great presentation and tasted a bit more like coffee rather than almonds but delicious nonetheless.

What I really loved about this place was their service. I was seated near the kitchen so it kind of took away from the ambiance but servers and waiters kept checking up on us which sort of made up for it. Our waiter was a bit awkward but was very attentive. While my sister was doing her usual photo shoot with the food, I was moving the tiny candle around to give her more light. By the third course, I accidentally tipped it too far and put out the light which made my table dark and bummed my out for a good 10 min. When our waiter came by to refill our water, he noticed our light was out. "OH, what happened to the candle?" I innocently responded, "I don't know..." He immediately told us he'll grab us another one and 20 seconds later, I got a new candle on the table. YESSSS. Dinner just got 100x better. So thank you, dude! It's the little things that count! All in all, food was pretty good (minus lobster broth) and service was terrific. I'd definitely come back when I'm feelin like a baller.
author: Arleen F.

description:
Came here a few weeks ago for Dine About Town. It was the first time we decided to try DAT and ISA has always been one of the places I've had booked marked for months to try.

Our waiter had issues with our table and ended up moving us twice, even though we had a reservation made weeks ago and were on time. The menu was extremely long and there were definitely too many items we wanted to try. The portions were small and I am assuming it has to do with the promotion of DAT, but it was okay because the 4 course meal makes up for it. The soups, if I were paying full price, I would skip. Nothing out of the ordinary, pretty plain and bland. The appetizers, the ahi tuna was delicious! For the main entree, I would skip the scallops because you only get 2 scallops for the entire meal. The steak and the lamb chops were very good, but not the best I've tried. The dessert was great, the creme brule was just perfect, so was the alfredo. I don't think I would come back here again, but I am glad we got to try it out.
author: Karina A.

description: Pretty good. Great ambience outside dining area. Good for groups or date nights. Reasonable prices. Food is above average but not exceptional. I'll be back as it was great food and fun times with reasonable prices.
author: Marie A.

description:
Parking was super easy on a Wednesday night- the Lombard St. garage is only $1/hr after 6pm! 

The restaurant was very nice, all of the staff were very friendly, helpful and attentive. I had the Arugula salad which was delicious, and the truffle risotto which everyone in my group agreed was the best!
author: J D.

description: Our waiter Dean was very friendly and knowledgeable and knew the menu inside and out.  His recommendations were helpful, and his service was excellent- we really enjoyed having him as a waiter as much as enjoying the awesome cuisine. The menu has a delicious selection of dishes.  Everything was fresh and creative as well. The 3 course meal for $30 is a fantastic value.
author: Dan L.

description:
There's not many times my eyes roll back involuntarily... but DAT TRUFFLE RISOTTO. The other items we had: lobster broth, scallops, & dungeness crab salad were nice, but if you're wondering why i'd give the overall experience 5 stars:

Ambiance - very nice, easily date material. We sat in the outdoorsy patio and it had alot of natural light, but not too much. 

Service - This was probably one of the nicest experiences I had in a while. The waiter really showed he had a passion for food & wine. He recommended the Sedna which blew my mind: I was never a big fan of Chardonnay til he insisted on the pairing. I could drink a bottle of that on the daily. 

My date told him about my eyes rolling back when I was eating the risotto, and we stayed a bit after the check to hear about a story of another patron who had a drastic reaction to the food @ Isa. Just to make sure I truly enjoyed it THAT much, he had the courtesy of asking my date, "Does he do that often?" (cue The Weeknd - Often (Kygo remix) 

I don't remember his name, but it's a older gentleman with glasses. It's really rare to see a waiter with such enthusiasm for the restaurant they work at, and the food they serve. As a result, I had a very memorable experience and look forward to coming back. 

Truffle. Risotto.
author: Yodo S.

description:
All in all, this place was a hit! I went here with two girlfriends. Hungry ones. We started with Soju cocktails- a yummy blend of blackberries, soju, and champagne was a lovely start to the deliciousness to come. 

We began with the crab salad, simply sauteed Sea of Cortez prawns, and yellowfiun tuna, which was served with (a scant tossing of) sriracha, avo, and seaweed... and low sodium soy, but far too much of it. The Dungeness crab salad became my favorite thing I put in my mouth on this day- up to this point. It was actually more crab than salad- a generous portion of fresh local crab with grapefruit, julienned apple, and tarragon atop a lovely display of butter lettuce. The tuna was good, but far too salty in my opinon. However, the quality of the fish was top notch. As for the prawns, they were great, but, as the name implies, simple. The prawns themselves really stood out, as it should be, in my opinion.

We then shared the scallops, truffle risotto, and potato-wrapped sea bass. The scallops were divine, but small- a fairly inefficient dish, albeit a lovely taste. It basically amounted to four bites. However, I loved the brussel sprouts tossed with bacon that accompanied them, making it slightly heartier. The potato wrapped sea bass was heavenly! The fluffy potato wrap- with its brown butter, lemon, and tomato confit- was a perfect compliment to the fluffy, delicate, and succulent sea bass. The truffle risotto was nothing short of life-changing. 'Nuff said there.

I will say however, that all this food, although delicious, was very small and pricey. One of my friends ended up ordering another entree and a dessert, which she ate in their entirety and seemed to enjoy. We had wine with the meal, and our bill was $223, so a very spendy dinner, but a delightfulk splurge nonetheless!
author: Chelsea T.

description:
Oh Isa!

--Why did I come here?
Isa was on the 2011 SF Dine About Town website and offered the greatest variety on its menu for the prix fix promotion.  Judging from the pictures, the patio looked like a cozy place to dine (which it was, despite SF's cold climate).

--What was exceptional?
The dishes are "family" style.  My friend and I easily shared our dishes.  Our main courses were the highlight of the meal.  We shared: the grilled flat iron steak and the duck breast.  I was a little weary of the steak as my friend wanted her steaks "medium-well," whereas I prefer mine still moo-ing (not literally!).  Anyway, despite the steak being "medium-well," it was surprisingly still juicy and full of flavor!  It was amazing!  I can only imagine had it been medium-rare!  Droool!

--Also good?
*You have to get the dungenous crab salad!  Basically little lettuce cups filled with avocado, apple, grapefruit and taragon deliciousness!  
*The organic loch dart salmon was good, but I wouldn't be able to distinguish it from the stuff I get from Trader Joes.

Overall, Isa is a great date spot, or spot to just catch up with a good friend.  The ambience is great, and the food is even better!  I'll definitely be back to try more of the menu.
author: Matt S.

description:
Isa is a small restaurant with a bar out front, which is a great place to grab some drinks and wait for a table. There's a little tablet like thing on the counter which is filled with games. An interesting way to kill time. They have an open kitchen (the wall separating is not there) it looks like so you can see the kitchen people make food.

== Food ==

I went here for their Dine about Town special and they did not scrimp out on portions or selection of food. The ~37 price got four dishes with choices that included dishes such as oysters and mussels.

For the first dish, they ran out of their lobster bisque so there was only the potato soup left. A bit disappointed, but their potato soup was simply great.

The second dish had a bunch of different choices such as mussels, tuna tartare, to oysters. All those were simply delicious and quite amazing. One plus side of the mussel dish is that you can use the broth as dipping sauce for the free bread they give. The broth is tasty so it's so worth it.

The third dish is the main dish, which I got the duck meat dish. It was pretty good, but it wasn't amazing to me. The special rib dish looked quite amazing compared to the duck. 

The last dish was dessert, which I got a grapefruit granite. It tasted like a grapefruit snow cone. It was alright.

Drink: Try the #7 drink. I recommend it.

== Service ==

Good service overall. Waitress came by and checked up on us a few times. Bread was replaced whenever asked. The food comes out slowly depending on the dish so they recommend doing things family style.

== Overall ==

Pricey, but delicious. I would definitely come back again for a dine about town or a special occasion.
author: Steven B.

description:
I enjoyed the cozy ambience of the restaurant, but the food was just average.  The tablets they have at the bar are pretty cool, especially the fun games and couples' quiz (...miserable fail...)  

The smooth potato and leek soup was very bland and tasted watered-down, but the lobster broth with prawns was a lot better.  I had the yellowfin tuna and was not impressed by the freshness of the seafood.  The entree I ordered came with 2 tiny scallops that weren't cooked properly...over-seared on the tops/bottoms and then too slimy and rubbery on the inside.  I tried some of the duck breast also and didn't like that dish either b/c it seemed like it was seasoned with pepper only, but I did enjoy the latke it came with.  I had the vanilla bean creme brulee and semi-freddo for dessert.  Our waiter described it as gelato, but it really wasn't....I didn't enjoy it that much and the vanilla bean creme brulee was just average (it tasted like it was from the creme brulee cart).  

I think all the food was decent and everything was flavorful, but I just didn't feel like any dish was unique or came together especially well.  I'm glad I got to try a lot of different things on their menu, but I think SF dining has a lot better to offer!
author: Chinh T.

description:
My first Dine About Town experience and OH.MY.GOD...so happy I went to Isa!  Ambiance was great, not too loud but definitely lively and you could have a conversation without yelling at each other.  Servers were very helpful and dishes were ALMOST perfectly timed when coming out (had to tell them to slow it down in the middle of the entree section).  But they kept our bread bowl and wine glasses filled so I can't complain.

Came here with 3 gfs and decided to go family style to take advantage of all their offerings and pretty much went with everything our awesome server, Jared, suggested.  

Apps-
Salmon Carpaccio: My favorite of the apps we got.  Salmon was so deliciously fresh and the toppings complemented it very well.
Goat Cheese:  Another good one but you definitely need to eat this with the bread, otherwise the cheese overloads you unless you like that sort of thing.  
Dungeness Crab Salad:  I also liked this dish.  It served with grapefruit as a topping and I'm not a fan of grapefruit, but I couldn't really taste it so the crab wasn't overpowered like other reviewers mentioned.  Maybe we got a grapefruit-less one?
Mussels: Mussels were average but the highlight was the consistent dunking and soaking of the bread in the amazing sauce they use.

Entrees-
Seared Scallops: TRUFFLE OIL!  That's what made this dish so amazing.  Gave the mashed potatoes and scallops a great, extremely addicting flavor.
Duck Breast: Was really excited that this came with a salad since almost everything previous had been very heavy.  Duck was good..not too red and the potato thing that came with it was a surprising delight.
Truffle Risotto:  Again...truffle oil.  Can't get enough of the stuff.  The mushrooms do overpower everything else though so if you don't like mushrooms, don't get this.  But if you do, definitely get this!
Flat Iron Steak:  Before coming here, I was so excited about the steak because I needed me some red meat.  Since this was the last dish we got, we were all sooo full by then but when this came out, I couldn't stop myself from drooling.  It was cooked PERFECTLY medium rare.  Tender and succulent and delicious.  Again, very happy that this came with veggies too.

Dessert-
Grapefruit Shaved Ice:  Like I said, not a fan of grapefruit so I only had a bite of this and left it alone.
Creme Brulee:  I don't think I've ever had a bad creme brulee, but this was seemed particularly good.  Creme brulee is creme brulee to me though, I'm indifferent.
Vanilla Bean Gelato w/ Biscotti:  Vanilla Bean flavor wasn't too overpowering so very good.  Again, this is something almost everyone could like.
Semifreddo All'Amarretto:  MY FAVEEEEEE.  Almond ice cream was so so SO good.  I was so sad that I was too full to finish the rest of it and that it had to go to waste :(

I have no bad things to say about Isa so stop reading reviews and just go try it out!
author: Jane N.

description: After many recommendations we decided to try Isa and we were blown away. The specials were spectacular, the wine selection adequate, the ambiance of a cute covered patio was adorable. The service was very good and they were able to accommodate all of my gluten free (Celiac) questions and prepare my food easily. We will definitely be back!
author: Kathryn H.

description:
Came with a group of 7 for Dine About Town menu on 11th June.

I'm not sure about their standard menu, but their Dine About Town menu was both extensive and excellent.  There were at least 5-7 items to choose from for each of the course!  Portions were generous and food tasted great! I'm not sure I'd call it a "French Restaurant" though.  I'd be inclined to think that it was more of a continental cuisine.

They have $5 wine and soju cocktails before 7pm (I'm not sure if it's M-F or 7 days a week though).

Here's what we had:

Appetizers:
Dungeness Crab salad - easily enough for 3 people to share as an appetizer.  It was refreshing!

Tomales Bay Oysters - half dozen.  Not sharable - I think I can easily have 2 dozens of oysters by myself haha.  Oysters were fresh and the dipping sauce (though not necessary - I like mine sans anything!) was actually pretty good

Baked goat cheese - was perfect with their bread (we were never out of bread on the table!)

Entrees:
*Pork Chop with baked polenta and sauteed veges - huge pork chop!
*Duck with roasted beets, arugula and goat cheese - flavourful (portion wise not as big as the pork chops)
*Mushroom Risotto with truffle - creamy but not mushy.  It was too hot when it was served so had to wait a while but it was very good
*Scallops - probably least exciting dish out of the lot
*Chicken with mashed potatoes (I think it looked like mashed potatoes) - I didn't get to try any of this so I can't say - she was sitting too far away from me

Dessert:
All of us except for one had their Semi freedo with Amaretto.  It was served with 4-5 round biscotti.  Beautiful but we were so full by the time dessert came round that none of us really managed to finish.  One girl ordered the goat cheese dessert drizzled with honey and served with candied walnuts.  It was a massive chunk of goat cheese  - imagine 50 pieces of salami stacked on top of  each other. That was how thick it was (and it was round).  It was a little too much goat cheese for everyone's liking. Candied walnuts were good though.

The bar area and the restaurant area at the back have very different atmosphere.  Bar - very dark and romantic feeling. Then when you get to the restaurant area out the back it felt like we were outdoors (actually I think it was an outdoor area that was converted into an indoor area with a cover - so i'm not sure how quiet it'll be on a rainy day)

All up though we had a fabulous time.  Definitely coming back for food - tasty, generous in portions (I hate going to upmarket restaurants and leaving feeling like I need a burger or a pizza to satisfy my hunger), and great service.
author: Sujan H.

description: One of the best restaurants in the Marina area. The service was impeccable. Our server made excellent recommendations based on a few food allergies at our table and was very knowledgeable. The seared scallops and yellow fin tuna are a must try. It can get busy but is worth the wait.
author: M M.

description:
Tasty food.  Small and cozy place.  Tables are bit closer than I liked.  Could hear your neighbors conversation, which isn't too surprising.

Small caveat though.  Waitress who was very friendly, kept making excuses about a billing error, which I thought was lame.  She stated it was a system error that the computer always rings up wrong.  What does that mean?  Customers always get over-charged for that particular item?
author: Dan K.

description:
I wasn't completely blown away by this place but it's definitely worth trying at least once. I like hearing negatives, so my complaints:
We waited an additional 10 minutes after our reservation to be seated. The bar only serves a few beers, cosmos/martinis amd wine. I couldnt get a mixed drink of choice. 
Everything on the menu looked tasty. The crab salad was oustanding. The mussels were above average. I would pass on the yellowfin next time. It was overcooked. The chicken entree was very tender and tasteful/as were the mashed potatoes.
They brought out a complimentary dessert which wasn't the best but it was the thought that counted. Great place to share and try a variety. Overall an above average meal.
author: Nate S.

description:
FYI Isa- When your website states "Free Glass of Wine Sunday-Thursday for DAT" that led me to believe DAT was only Sunday through Thursday as well. Needless to say, I was a little disappointed when I arrived to a truncated menu. :( This, is probably my own fault, but still fails to justify why I just spend $44 (including tip) on dinner. While the meal was good, IT WASN'T WORTH IT.

My girlfriend ordered the crab salad- she licked the plate clean. I ordered the argula salad- and while I liked it, it was such a huge portion! (I know it's meant to be shared, but how much arugula can you eat?)

For mains- we ordered the scallops (this was yummy- I especially liked the asparagus) and the fish. The fish was good too- but I still can't believe how much they charge for this!

Dessert consisted of creme brûlée (which I've never liked- I have issues w/ textures) and vanilla bean gelato. I liked the gelato- but I can get that just about anywhere.

Sorry Isa- you failed to rock my socks.
author: Annalise F.

description:
We have a new Gold Standard for eating establishments in San Francisco or the general Metro area!  We went to Isa, tonight, on the SF Dine About Town program where participating restaurants offer Prix Fixe menus - 3 course dinners for $34.95 and lunches for $17.95.  Wow, this is as good as it gets!

Unlike most places, they have a very good assortment to choose from for each course.  We never felt constrained in anyway.  And, the way they serve the courses, they are intended/designed to be shared - a really nice way to dine with friends.

We were a foursome.  We started with 3 orders of Crab Salad and 1 Steamed Mussels.  Both were fantastic and easily shared.  They were both generous portions with lots of crab on the salad and plenty of mussels in a fantastic herbed broth.  We all shared and we could not leave the broth alone as we sopped it all up with the wonderful, endless bread.

Our mains were 2 Duck Breast w/Sautee Spinach w/pine nuts and bacon in a wonderful Balsamic sauce - a terrific and satisfying combination.  We had one Truffle Risotto and one Seared Sea Scallops.  Again, we were totally thrilled withe quality of food and the wonderfully efficient and warm service.  The duck was tender, moist, full-flavored - done perfectly.  The scallops were also done just right with a beautiful sear with perfect interiors.  The risotto was just as good.  You could, genuinely, taste the truffle!  Texture was perfect.

Our desserts were 2 Creme Brulees and 2 amaretto Semifreddo.  The latter was good but the Creme Brulee was the best I can recall having in a long long time - perfect vanilla flavor, perfect texture - creamy/custardy and nice caramelization of the sugar top.

OH, AND DID I MENTION THE FREE GLASS OF WINE THAT CAME WITH OUR MEAL??!!  It was a very nice, smooth glass of house red!

I think you can tell how excited and how much we enjoyed this dinner tonight.  We're all the way over in East Bay but we would come back in a heartbeat!  There is no better value in the Bay Area!

And the service was really great.  Raoul really took superb care of us.  He's an efficient, friendly, helpful fellow from Spain!  Everyone was so very gracious and we really felt welcome!  These people "got it right" - in spades!

If you in the area, you owe it to yourself to try this super place.  And tell Raoul that the Asian with a crew cut said "hello!"

Jim
author: James Q.

description: I like this place -- not necessarily your traditional idea of a French meal, but I liked it nonetheless. The service was great, and I ordered the spaghetti which was really satisfying & I enjoyed it. My boyfriend and I had the cute window seats as well, so the ambiance was great.
author: Mel G.

description:
KEY: 3 plates should be just right for two people.
HAVE AGAIN: Dungeness crab salad and rocky chicken were very good.
NOT HAVE AGAIN: the fish special (fried sole) and corn soup were ok, but I would not order them again.
High energy and noisy. Somewhat odd service.
author: Keith R.

description:
The waiting area is cramped when you are with large group but the side is a bar waiting area and outside are a couple of chairs as well. Hostesses were attentive - checking on when table will be ready and telling you. Busy Saturday night but still seated 10 people in the backyard area that's sealed and heated. 

The waiter pointed out that Isa serves dishes family style. Our group wasn't really on board with that so we just ordered like we normally would 1-2 dishes per person as suggested. Unfortunately, the way they serve dishes wasn't making our evening i.e. some people were left hungry sitting and waiting an hour for their dish to be served (big dislike.) The way they serve actually makes more sense for a couple or even four people sharing their food (a more intimate setting) but really doesn't work for large groups. No one wants to share their rack of lamb (4 pieces) with 10 ppl!!

I ordered an arugala salad and seared scallops. The salad was refreshing but I'd prefer that they slice the oranges into smaller pieces so I get the same ratio of arugala to orange ratio b/c arugala is bitter.

Seared scallops were alright I'm not big on scallops but this dish didn't change my mind about them. The mashed potatoes were good and creamy. The asparagus tasted like it was boiled then pan fried - it was kind of mushy. I like my asparagus grilled or baked so it's more crispy.
author: Donna C.

description: OMG was the food and drinks amazing or what! The scallops, the fish, the dessert, the wine (chocolate dessert wine was delicious) were all amazing! Best of all, our waiter, he was extremely friendly, gave tons of useful information and recommendation on the dishes and drinks, honest (told us exactly how much to order since we had a party of 8). Just an all and all AWESOME experience!!
author: Ling C.

description: Dined here during restaurant week and had an excellent experience. My husband and I ordered from the 4 course pre-fixe menu for just $40 each. Each dish was perfectly executed. We especially loved the salads (endive frisee and the arugula), the yellowfin tuna appetizer, and the braised short ribs. Service was also excellent. Although the restaurant was packed it didn't seem as loud as other restaurants in the Marina we've been too. Overall a wonderful experience. We will definitely be back!
author: Kathy B.

description:
I wish I LOVED this place.... it started off so great. My boyfriend and I were first time diners and were really excited to try this place out as we are big foodies in the city. 

My biggest complaint in no shape or form is from the food. Everything we had from the 2 appetizers (tuna & crab salad), to the two entrees  (sole and lamb), to the side dish (wild mushrooms) and finally the dessert (flour less chocolate cake) was excellent.

Where this place fell short was THE SERVICE - it almost ruined the entire meal. I pick up on a lot of things since I used to be a bartender and waitress. That said, the waiter greeted us very friendly but he talked EXTREMELY fast... it was like he was either nervous or was trying to win a game of  "who can say the most words in under 2 mins!".

Although he was knowledgeable, he came off as really trying to sell the fact that this place has  "been around for 11 years and the chef really knew what he was doing."(which I don't doubt due to the delicious food).

Had he not set our expectations so high... maybe the lack of service would have gone less noticeable.  OK that's A LIE... We waited forever. Our wine and appetizers arrived fairly quickly.  Then there was quite some lag time and a disappearing waiter act from  our appetizers to getting our 1st entree. 

That wait however was extremely short compared to how LONG  we waited for the 2nd entree. About 30 mins after the 1st entree, we finally had to ask if they forgot our 2nd plate - that is after we had to hunt the waiter down once again. We nicely suggested "hey we thought we lost you" as he finally came to the table.. trying to get him to realize it had been some time. He made a comment about how the lamb rack takes time to cook (even though we ordered the lamb shank) which made me think that comment was a "doh" I forgot moment. 

Long story short another waiter (not ours) brought out a single plate of mushrooms (our side order) which sat for about 10 mins till the 2nd plate finally arrived.

The last straw was when our clean plates were left sitting at the table for an additional 30 mins after we were finished and cleared by yet another waiter (not ours). When the bill however did arrive somehow our waiter was right on cue and how funny - very attentive! 

I'm usually NOT this picky - but when I see bad service it really gets under my skin, especially  when you are shelling out about $150 bucks for dinner. I'm not into excuses and there shouldn't  have been any because by the time we were eating the place had really died down.

We  arrived at 9:30 for our reservations and left close to midnight.. would have liked to go out after but we were too tired from waiting (and our own food coma) to even fathom the idea of one more drink.

Food:  4 starts

Service: 2 stars
author: Callie O.

description: I just couldn't believe what happened when I went to ISA three weeks ago. I made a reservation for five people and and one of our guests was running late. They gave us a table and we ordered some appetizers and drinks. After 15 minutes had passed the waiter came to our table and asked if the other member of our party was on his way. He explained that we should order our main course because we would have to vacate the table in one hour. He added that they were expecting a large party soon and that we would have to leave when they arrived. I was shocked by that kind of treatment.
