 As far as the restaurant experience, you are really close to your neighbor, and things are a little noisy, but it was still a great experience and I will look forward to my next trip to SF to re-experience Isa.
author: Jacquie L.

description:
Immediately after posting about my bad experience the manager from Isa emailed to to apologize for what had happened.  She explained that since my visit they had undergone quite a few changes and encouraged me to return.  So I did!    Wow, what a turnaround!  The service was so friendly and warm with lots of recommendations, and they even added the recommendation that each person order two items on the menu.  I am really glad that I went back to give it another try.  

Recommendation:  The Foie Gras ....AMAZING!
author: Alyson M.

description:
My boyfriend and I tried Isa last night for the first time to take advantage of Dine About Town. 

Everything about the restaurant was amazing! The service was extremely good, and the food was so tasty! 

We especially liked the:

Lobster Broth
Oysters
Scallops 

Both of us agreed that the scallops were the best we ever had! 

We would definitely go back again!.
author: Kate K.

description:
We were lucky enough to score a reservation the day of and came for the Dine About Town.  I was SO impressed with my experience.  Each member of the staff was so attentive, from the hostess to the busser to the server.  We came at 6:30 PM and they host a happy hour special until 7PM with very good wines for a discounted price.  Our awesome server gave us the happy hour prices well passed 7PM.  The DAT menu is served tapas style and my boyfriend and I shared the following dishes:

Maine lobster broth with prawns -- the prawns were very big and the broth is similar to a cioppino.  We both got this but I wish I had tried the potato leek.  

Dungeness crab salad--very good.  So many details in the dish, from the fat pieces of crab to the grapefruit and tarragon.  There were so many flavors.

Steamed Prince edward island mussels--EXCELLENT.  The mussels were huge and I wanted to drink the broth in a bowl.  This is one of the best mussel dishes I have had.  We soaked up every last drop with the warm grilled bread, then went for more with the complimentary breads.

Seared Scallops: four large scallops surrounding mashed potatoes, brussel sprouts, bacon...and TRUFFLE.  Amazing.  

Truffle Risotto:  Thank you ISA for not skimping at all on the truffle.  This dish was not too heavy for a risotto and full of flavor.  The array of mushrooms was very generous as well.

Vanilla bean crème brulée:  At first bite I liked it but didn't love it, but as you continue eating you can taste the real vanilla bean.  It's not too sweet and a very good dessert after a large meal.

Buche Au Lait De Chèvre:  The goat cheese with honey and walnuts is served with toasted crostini.  Excellent.

The meal was so unbelievable, especially for a DAT menu.  We had the priviledge of meeting the owner, a very sweet lady who told us that ISA spends their entire marketing budget on DAT week hoping to generate repeat customers.  They definitely won us over.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Come here hungry and come here with friends... but not with someone you want to have a long intimate chat with, it is absolutely packed in this restaurant and very noisy... regardless, come here for the amazing food and stellar service.

I would return here in a heartbeat! 

Tonight i had the pleasure of indulging in 
*****potato wrapped sea bass (OH MY HEAVENS SO GOOD!!!!)
*****crab loaded salad
*****maine lobster broth with prawns
*****truffle risotto
I highly recommend all of those. I would come back here the next day for the tuna tartar, salmon carpaccio, mussels, scallops, brussel sprouts, mushrooms, basil zucchini, goat cheese, prawns, calamari, oh and more potato wrapped seabass!!! so good! 
oh and please don't ignore the bread you carb fearing weirdo.... it is absolutely perfect!!
author: Libra J.

description:
Our waiter and bus dude were amazing, giving the toddler at our table leftover Halloween candy (after asking mom if it was OK) and free mashed potatoes (unasked for.) Water glass was never empty and they made sure we had everything we needed. Normally, I don't care about service, but this was remarkably good.

Had the Truffle Spaghetti, Chicken, Flat Iron Steak, Two Salads and lots of cheese. Truffle Spaghetti is amazingly flavored but the noodles are a little soft and the presentation lacking. It's like they combined amazing truffles with Chef Boyardee noodles and still managed to make a good dish. Chicken had amazing crisp skin, with moist flesh, very nicely smooth textured mashed potatoes, and crisp green beans. Flat Iron Steak was the most boring dish, yet perfectly cooked, a little bloody in the middle and dolloped with butter. Salads were well dressed and included fresh fruit, but the lettuce salad was a little light on lettuce.

And man, that almond semi-freddo tasted amazing, though I'm a sucker for almonds and the almond macaroons were a bit too crunchy.

Prix fix menu had almost all of the normal main courses, which was nice. $30 for appetizer, main and dessert.

Only gets 4 stars, cause 5 is reserved for places that are little different or extra memorable.
author: Alexander J.

description:
Halibut and Braised beef are to DIE for. 

Plates are perfect for sharing, which they encourage. I didn't want to share. I wanted everything for myself. 

Wonderful meal and dining experience. I don't know what else to say! Yes, it was that good!
author: Lily M.

description:
Would be a 5 star if the soju cocktails didn't suck so much.  I tried four of them, and they all tasted disgusting in the same way: tasted like cheap soju.......

Everything else was really good though so I'm excited to go back.  Their pre fixe dinner is REALLY worth it.  They're not all skimpy about which courses you can choose from their regular menu since practically all items are available for selection.  

Their patio/outdoor seating was great!  They had canopies covering us and were cognizant of temperature fluctuations and turned on the heat lamp when it got cold.  I love that the busboys and any staff that passed by would come clear our tables.  Just really attentive service.  My only other gripe is our actual waiter.  He was not present most of the time and we got most of our requests fulfilled by our busboys.  Thank god for those hard working busboys refiling our bread baskets again and again! 

I want to go here again with my bf because it's definitely a great date place.
author: Anna T.

description: Had a wonderful experience here on New Year's Eve. Food was exceptional, especially the scallops. Staff attentive without being overly so or too "in your face". Highly recommend
author: A C.

description: Celebrated a birthday here tonight with friends. Everything about this place was lovely. The staff was incredibly sweet, attentive and accommodating. Everything we ordered was delicious. I especially liked the potato wrapped sea bass and the yellowtail appetizer featuring avocado and sriracha. Everyone in our party of five was impressed and we had a very enjoyable evening. I look forward to returning again. There needn't be a special cause to celebrate!
author: Adam R.

description:
My husband and I are long time Marina residents and still always go to Isa for a special night out because it has always been so pleasant and the food consistently wonderful.  We have gotten to know the owners and staff and they are most lovely and accommodating.  The menu has something for everyone and we particularly enjoy going during the week for the pre fixe, which is so satisfying and at a very fair price.  Most people I know that visit Isa love the back room, but we always love to sit up in the front.  There is a certain ambience that I can't quite describe, that makes it even more special.  

Recently had a girls' night out at Isa and we all had a memorable evening.  I also manage a few vacation rental units here in the Marina and always recommend it to our guests.  So I guess you can say I am a fan!
author: kathy w.

description:
I came here for my birthday dinner with a few close friends, and we all absolutely LOVED this place. Here's the breakdown:

1). Food- we ordered calamari, dungeness crab salad, tuna poke for appetizers; truffle risotto, scallops, duck breast, fish of the day, and steak for mains. Highlights were by far the truffle risotto (mouthfuls of creamy heavenly goodness.. although it's very rich so I'm glad we shared!), scallops (literally melts in your mouth, with just the right amount of searing), and the dungeness crab salad.  For dessert we had flourless chocolate cake (super yummy).

2). Service- delightful! The waiters were super attentive and refilled all of our bread baskets without us having to ask (and we ate a lot of bread).  One waiter got me a glass of champagne on the house for "my longevity and wellbeing" :) so sweet.

3). Atmosphere- I had never been here before, so I was nervous about eating here for my birthday dinner, but it was exactly the kind of place I was looking for. There were adorable christmas lights strung across the walls in a cute/classy and not cheap/gaudy kind of way.  There were enough heat lamps to keep us warm enough, and the servers were kind enough to keep changing the heat lamp settings as the night progressed.

Overall will definitely bookmark this place to come back sometime.

Tips: Definitely designed for smaller groups or for romantic dates, so plan accordingly. Also, the menu recommends 2 dishes per person, but for a group of 6, we found that 3 appetizers and 5 entrees were more than enough.  We were happily stuffed by the end of dinner.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Marina yuppies beware: there is a pretender in your midst.  The girlfriend speculated that there was a change in management/ownership, as she's reviewed this place at 4 stars before (covering up for her error?  I'll let you decide...), but neither of us left happy last night.

It's not a terrible restaurant, but Yelp says two stars means "Meh. I've experienced better." and that's a pretty accurate way to describe my sentiment.

For a place marked on Yelp as being "romantic, classy", I wasn't feeling either of those vibes.  We were first sat out on the back patio (covered, heated on a cold and wet SF night, to their credit), but it was insanely loud. Like every table yelling loud. Which made us have to yell to talk to each other.  Which just contributed to the loud. Not cool.

So we asked to be reseated inside, which happened quickly (again to their credit). From there on out, service was fine. Not great, not bad, just fine... if a bit on the casual side for a place marketing itself as romantic and classy.

On to the food:
Oysters - fresh, a bit meatier than optimal, but very good.  Mignonette was fine, and we both enjoyed this. It's oysters, so take from that what you will, but Isa gets credit for at least sourcing good product here.

Grilled calamari - smelled the honey spice when it landed on the table, but the taste was not really present.  Flagolet beans a bit overdone, arugula thrown in there more for fun and visual contrast than anything else.  Overall, just not remarkable.

Lobster broth - ok, I get it.  It's a broth, not a bisque, and I should expect as much. The server wasn't kidding when he said "it's a very intense lobster taste" as he set it down... he could have just said, "it's like being slapped in the face with a lobster." Dipping some buttered bread in it was my preferred manner of consumption, as it made it a bit more mild.  The girlfriend just gave up... and I didn't even bother to eat hers as I normally would.  Edible?  Yes... Good? Ehhh... if you're THAT into lobster flavor, maybe.  Not for us though.

Mussels - again, ok, but not knocking my socks off.  Aaaand that's all I have to say about them. Meh.

Brussel Sprouts with Garlic, Bacon and EVOO - Not enough garlic, bacon was unremarkable in quality, and not enough olive oil.  Sprouts came out very undercooked and still bitter. Sent them back to roast again. Came back a bit better, but a little charred as there hadn't been any more EVOO added to the mix and they clearly had it under some high heat trying to rush it back to us. Sprinkled with a little salt, one could now eat it... but we ended up just picking the bacon out as snacks as we waited for the risotto to come out.

Mushroom Risotto with Truffle Oil - By far the best dish, but if this meal was a relay race, then the other dishes had left the risotto with a bunch of ground to make up as the anchor. Solidly put together, but also pretty straightforward and didn't surprise.

Wine - Eric Louis Sancerre Sauvignon Blanc - Good, $46 for the bottle which looks like the standard 2.5x retail.  No complaints there.

Waiter comp'ed us the brussel sprouts when he saw that we barely touched them, and was friendly enough.

All in all, if I was was walking in to a random mid-range restaurant in a smaller city, my rating would go up. But for dining in SF, and with a Marina price tag, I don't see myself showing up again.
author: Kai Y.

description: a keeper for sure. Charming place that offers authentic  french cuisine
author: Rozita N.

description: Great service and food. We walked to the restaurant after  parking at the marina, then walked back to a show at the Palace of Fine Arts. Plan about a 20 minute walk from the Yacht Club/Palace of Fine Arts parking lot. It was "Dining About Town", the last two weeks of January in SF. So it was a fixed price menu. But the options were many...and delicious. $38 for four ample courses!
author: Kim M.

description:
I'd read some great reviews of Isa and heard from friends that it was a nice place for dinner. We made reservations for their prix fixe New Year's Eve menu for 10:30 pm, figuring that we'd be there through the countdown to midnight.

We arrived and were ushered out to the cover back patio. It was fine for a casual dinner, but a let down for NYE. There was no ambiance and it was a little dirty - the previous diner's used napkin was still on the floor by my seat. As a small insult to injury, I was also placed right below a spotlight which was uncomfortable. I will say, I think if we'd asked to be moved, we could have been.

We then waited for some time for the waiter to come for drink orders. In the meantime bread and butter were slammed onto our table by a bus boy who was literally running by at the moment. I mention this only because it proceeded to happen again when they refilled the basket. When the waiter finally came, he brought complimentary glasses of sparkling wine (nice, but part of the menu, so not special treatment), and made no offer of other drinks - you had your champagne and you liked it.

We ordered dinner around 10:45 or so and within 5 minutes both our first and second courses were out and the waiters were cramming them on the table. When the second course came about about 1 minute after the first, I said that I preferred that they slow down service a bit - we'd booked 1.5 hours for dinner and I suddenly felt like they were rushing us out before midnight. I was told, "the kitchen closes in 10 minutes, so we've got to get the food out." He sent the hostess to speak with us and she was very gracious, but ineffective, because sure enough 10 minutes later my entree was being served. I swear I am not this person usually, but I sent it back. I asked for it to be served when 1) my husband's entree was also ready (they never once served both of us at the same time for any course), and 2) for when the previous courses plates were cleared. He did as I asked, but when it was re-served later, it was ice cold. Clearly just sitting in the kitchen, not even under a heat lamp.

We did the countdown and the crowd was fun! And we waited and waited and waited for dessert. The whole thing was a hot mess. And frankly, the food was passable at best. I will not be going back.

I am open to the idea that Isa is a better place to go when it's not such a busy night for them, but it was an epic fail, so I for me that will be my last experience there.
author: Courtney S.

description:
I came here for a birthday group dinner while taking advantage of their dine-about-town deal.  At first, I thought it was a deal, but later I found out they just added one additional selection for each of the three courses on their regular prix-fix menu, and charge $6 more!  

The meal was not bad and I enjoyed the duck breast a lot.  The sharing  portion was also very generous.  I was a little disappointed at the creme burlee - the caramel layer was too thick and the custard consistency was not smooth enough.  I also didn't like the fact that they took advantage of the dine-about-town so they can charge more for almost the same prix-fix menu they have regularly.  They were also very slick by stating that they "only serve the dine-about-town menu", so we had to fork up the additional $6 per head.  

Dine-about-town is supposed to be a time for restaurants to offer great deals, not an opportunity for pulling a fast one.
author: Jamie L.

description:
There's very little I can complain about at this place. The Foie Gras was amazing, but that's going away soon.  The crab salad was average, short ribs were amazing, flat iron steak was well prepped and tasty, the goat cheese was so flavorful, and the final chocolate cake and Semifreddo were great ways to cap the meal.

The only thing that bothered me a bit was the patio out back wasn't as nice and the waiter was a bit odd... but besides that I'd come back again.
author: Michael C.

description:
Isa!!  Finally!!  I've heard about this place for years and finally got to go during the January 2012 Dine About Town.  Good times!  It was packed on a Wednesday evening at 7PM - woo!  Good, solid food, and the $5 happy hour wine until 7PM is not bad either!  

Dinner consisted of:
* Steamed Prince Edward island mussels with garlic, white wine, parsley & grilled bread (Yummy, big, healthy portion of nicely cooked mussels, gone gone gone in seconds - my friend doesn't like seafood, so it was gone gone gone in my tummy quick!)
* My friend got the Baked Laura Chenel goat cheese with basil pesto, tomato concassée & pinenuts (wow, this was velvety creamy tasty - I would definitely order this again too!  I placed the cheese on bread and dipped it in the mussels sauce - mmm!)
* For my entree, I ordered the Seasonal Fish with artichokes, tomato confit, olives, basil & zucchini (I forgot what kind of fish it was, a mild white fish that was cooked just right, I couldn't finish it all because I got full from the mussels, bread and cheese - the fish was good though, solid)
* My friend ordered the Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce (I tasted some, solid, cooked to her liking)
* For dessert, I got the Semifreddo all' amaretto (mmm, refreshing, tasty) and my friend ordered the Vanilla bean gelato with biscotti (cool, creamy, loved the biscotti)

All in all, a solid dining experience, and I would recommend Isa.  Attentive service too; bread and water were generous and with our Dine About Town meals, a lovely glass of Malbec was included - I'm all for that!  Merci beaucoup!
author: Maile N.

description: just had a wonderful dinner with a friend this past weekend here. the tuna tartare is divine. The scallops are delicious, and their desserts are mouthwatering. we also ordered the veal sweetbreads, which were maybe a little overcooked for our taste. otherwise, wonderful service and a wonderful experience!
author: Roujin M.

description:
I am in love with Isa. Wow. 

Loch duart Salmon Carpaccio: Light and balanced with creme fraiche, a few capers and crostini. Delicious. 

Crab salad: Spot on; light and refreshing. Delicate butter lettuce cups, a healthy portion of fresh lump crab, thinly sliced avocado and a light citrus dressing. 

Potato Wrapped Sea Bass: Cooked to perfection. The brown butter sauce and parsley tomato confit was paired elegantly (and a really 'light' feel to it). 

Sea Scallops: The winner of the night. Large portion and the orzo/cherry tomato truffle sauce was the best thing I have had all year. 

Wine: great list! We had a nice bottle of savignon blanc that paired well with everything.

Service: Our waiter was intelligent, friendly and let us know about the history of the chef and loved to talk food. Down to earth - he was great! 

Ambiance: Sat on back patio. Casual atmosphere. This is a huge reason why I love this place: 5 star food in a casual atmosphere. Nice, but not stuffy. 

Isa is a special little gem. The food is light, refreshing and made with the freshest ingredients. The price point is fabulous (same quality of food at Boulevard, but bigger portions and more laid back vibe). Ill be back again and again. A+
author: Brooke S.

description:
I came to Isa for my birthday.  I wanted to dress up for hte occasion, but my friend had informed me that it's really not that fancy.  The inside is more upscale than the patio area.  I dressed up anyway just because I wanted to =P.

When we came into the restaurant, the hostess brought us out to the patio, and we sat down in a corner.  Two minutes later, she seats another couple next to us, and mind you the restaurant was not packed AT ALL, esp the patio area.  I was slightly annoyed at this, and requested to be moved inside since it was also chilly in the back patio.  They were fine with moving us inside.

Once insde, it was a little darker, a little more loud, but definitely had a nicer ambience inside.  With Isa, they claim that their dishes are for sharing like tapa style.  Being that it was our first time here, we ordered 4 dishes that we thought were good enough for sharing.  They bring the dishes out one by one, they say it's so that your taste buds don't get overwhelmed by certain dishes and they order the way the dishes come out accordingly.  But in reality, I think it's because the table just doesn't have enough room.  In reality, the larger dishes can be a regular entree.  That's what the regulars do.  

The food was pretty good, but just pricey.  We ordered the foie gras, which you could definitely taste the fat!  it was really tasty and came with this type of bread with it.  We also got the salmon tartare, which came with toasted bread crisps.  For the larger entrees, we got the special, which was some kind of fish ( I forgot) with corn, asparagus, and some other sauce.  That was REALLY GOOD.  i would highly recommend getting their specials.  We also got their duck, which was ok... it came with some bacon bits, which I'm not a big fan of.  The duck was cooked perfectly, medium rare.  it was the perfect tenderness and pink.  Although, it kind of tasted like ham to me...

Our waiter was also great.  He was so enthusiastic and gave good descriptions on the specials.  The other assistants were also very attentive, and came by frequently to make sure everything was ok with the water and bread supply.  

Overall, the restaurant has great food, but just tends to be on the pricey side.  The entire dinner cost about $90 for two people, with 2 glasses of wine from the happy hour special ($5/glass).  Parking may be difficult to find since it is in the marina, however, we found street parking on the main street and walked about 1 block.
author: Diane L.

description:
I love eating out with a large group.  It gives you the opportunity to try a variety of dishes--which we did.  

What did we order?  I don't remember since just about everything was underwhelming.  The foie gras was pretty damn tasty if you don't mind the extra side of guilt; everything else, however, was easily forgettable.

Service was eager, but overbearing.  "Uncle Isa" needs to calm down.
author: David C.

description:
I normally don't do these Dine About Town deals because the food isn't normally worth the price--usually restaurants will offer measly salads and soups for the first course and something easy like ice cream for dessert. But Isa was definitely worth it. I got the baked mozzarella for the first course, maple syrup duck breast for the second and vanilla bean creme brulee for dessert. We also split the foie gras too and it was delicious, especially coupled with the brioche toast. All of it was amazing and it came with unlimited bread too. And despite us having a table of 11, the service was impeccable. They also offer a free glass of wine Sunday-Thursday and if that doesn't make your experience, I don't know what will! We all came away very happy campers. 

Note to guys: The patio in the back with the white tent and twinkly lights overhead make for a great date atmosphere. ;)
author: Steffi L.

description:
a party of 3 for DAT.

We were way early for our reservation and they were busy so we sat at the bar for drinks. Just missed the 7pm mark for $5 drinks, darn! 

I must comment that the host was very awkward...and weird...

we didn't wait too long before we were led to our table in the back patio area! very cool, reminded me of Zazie's.

We ordered

-$1 oysters!, good bang for your buck!
-leek soup was okay
-butter lettuce...ordered it b/c I saw a review that said it was "well executed"...uh it was alright.
-arugula salad..BITTER, but the apple and oranges were good.
-salmon carpaccio tasted more like smoked salmon you get on bagel...guess I prefer the asian way of carpaccio with the citrus..
-yellowfin tuna was like a ceviche, best appetizer of the night.
-mussels were ok, tomato base broth.
-truffle risotto was good, lots of mushrooms, gets a little salty but acted more as a side of rice to our other entrees.
-maple leaf duck breast. lovely crispy skin. nicely cooked. came with beets, yum. 
- flat iron steak was okay. not enough flavor to me.
-grapefruit granite...it was like a grapefruit flavored shaved ice thing....EAT THIS FIRST if you have other sweet desserts! or else it becomes bitter and sour....
-creme brulee was dense and the top was pretty thick for torched sugar..
-favorite dessert was the semifreddo amaretto! not sure what it was, ice cream or something...but it was yummy flavored!

overall it was an enjoyable meal, everything was family style. Our waiter was much better than the host, most of the food came out timely. As we were leaving, a waiter or someone asked if we wanted to join their foie gras club...as we were already out the door...maybe my imagination but it sounded like we were going to do a shady deal HAHA. 

oh and we were lucky with parking! score!
author: Christine M.

description:
I can't tell you how much I enjoyed my meal at Isa. I won't lie - I went here because Bistro Aix is closed on Monday AND Tuesday (only God knows why).

I chose Isa because it was well reviewed on Yelp and because I'm a fan of Prix Fixe menus.  

Contrary to popular belief I do enjoy sharing so I liked the emphasis on these being family style dishes to ebe shared. 

For the first course I shared the Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese with pesto, tomato, concassee & pinenuts and the Grilled Honey Spiced Local Calamari with rice beans, arugula & lemon. 

The goat cheese was great. It looked like mozzarella but the taste was unmistakably goat cheese. I"ve never had calamari before and my first experience with it at Isa was also very tasty. 

For the second course I had the Boneless Local petrale sole meuniere with lemon, caper, parsley & noisette butter and the Grilled Natural Flat Iron Steak with potato dauphinoise & cognac-green peppercorn demi-glace. I'm not an expert on Sole (actually - first time I've had it) but it was very good. I do have steak with some frequency and the one I had at Isa was fantastic. It wasn't a very large portion but it was incredibly tasty.

For desert I had the Vanilla bean gelato with biscotti and Vanilla bean crème brulée. The gelato was ok and the creme brulee was very good. 

I am definitely going back if I crave a moderately priced meal of excellent quality. 

Tab for party of 2 + wine and drink was $80 which I think is very reasonable. 

You should definitely take advantage of the patio!

Thanks, Isa!
author: Carlos A.

description:
A very eclectic menu: everything from rare tuna tartare, asparagus soup, lobster soup, endive salad, clam spaghetti, steak, scallops, prawns, cheeses, and much more! Everything is SO delicious including the table bread which is lightly toasted and addictive!

I've been twice and must say that the waiters can be a bit stubborn... they must be instructed to push family-style eating and not back down. Miraculously, we convinced our waiter last night to let us order our own dishes so everyone got exactly what they wanted. The portions are perfect girly-sizes where you don't have to feel too guilty about finishing your plate... You can get yourself an amazing dinner without wine for $30 including tip and tax... gotta love the $24 two-course prix fix!

Sitting out back is amazing and so cozy with the garden feel and heating lamps. I've been twice with big groups but plan to go back for a more intimate dining experience too...
author: Meghan P.

description:
I had an amazing dinner here for my boyfriend's 35th birthday! I have never been here, but my fellow yelpers helped me decide that this was the perfect place. I dined here when the Dine About Town deal was going on. $34.95 for a three-course meal and a free glass of wine.

First meal, he had the crab salad and I had the mussels. Both were amazing! Although he doesn't like mussels, they were still amazing because the flavor it was infused with.

Second meal, he had the flat iron steak and I had the range chicken. The medium rare steak was pretty good to me, but he LOVED it. Both of us loved the range chicken as well, as it was very flavorful.

Third meal, he had the vanilla bean creme brule and I had the semifreddo al ammareto. He loved his and I loved mine!

We also ordered a side of foie gras and that was okay, we didn't finish it. The waiter gave us each a complementary glass of wine that was great!! I don't remember the name of it, wish I did. I'd definitely come back for that!

Overall, it was a delicious experience.
author: Robert M.

description:
Tried this place out last night after seeing I listed on the "dine about SF" website.  We had a great time!  

We had a reservation so I am not sure how they handle walk ins.  The main part of the restaurant is fairly intimate.  It looked like there was more seating in the back, but we were seated in the main area. 

The staff is extremely hospitable.  It seems to run like a true team with everyone helping at every table.  They were all extremely attentive, warm and friendly.  They made great conversation with us and made sure we were comfortable and happy.

The food isn't too shabby either.  The plates are smaller than typical American restaurants, but they are meant to be shared (family style) even though everyone orders their own dish.  Hopefully you go with people you like, haha!  The salmon carpaccio was unique and tasty.  Due to an allergy, I couldn't try the crab salad.  My fellow table members said it wasn't bad.  The goat cheese was truly a surprise as a dish, but we loved it.   Mushroom risotto was sooooooo good!  The scallops were accompanied by mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts.  They were tasty, but not as substantial as the other dishes we had.  We also had the steak, which was extremely filling and flavorful.  

We are glad we got to experience this place through "dine about".
author: Lauren R.

description:
Had to give this place a try before the foie gras ban comes into place. 

I'd heard great things about the preparation and it didn't disappoint. What a beautifully integrated dish - the custard brioche, poached pear and huckleberry sauce all complimented a generous portion of Hudson Valley foie gras. If this is my last dalliance with the delicate fatty liver in SF, I've pulled a George Costanza by "leaving on a high note".

Many more highlights here - a thick salmon carpaccio that bore a closer resemblance to generous pieces of salmon sashimi, sublime truffle risotto, and large, delicious desserts.

Our two year old was equally impressed with his spaghetti entree, gobbling it up eagerly. A ringing endorsement, given he is currently in the 'fussy eater' stage of his life.
author: Darrin K.

description: Possibly my favorite French place in SF. Most of us opted for the pre-fix menu. The mussels, flat iron steak, and duck are all excellent dishes and the sides they complemented the meat with were great. The salmon carpaccio was also very good. Dessert-wise the grapefruit granite (a type of sorbet) was refreshing but I prefer something more creamy. They restaurant gets crowded so you may want to make a reservation.
author: Ali F.

description:
The place is okay at best. The food was good (not very French though). The service was good too. However, think twice before going there. We had a party of five. Our waiter told us that the restaurant uses "the family style" approach, which means dishes are shared; so, everyone can enjoy all the foods. Great statement if there was enough food to share. The portions were minute. Shrimps were good but it was just five of them on the plate, which means everyone got just one shrimp, the same was with all the dishes. The result after ordering five different dishes a bottle of wine and  the desert  was unsatisfactory. All five of us left hungry. This "family style" BS feels like a dirty trick used to rip people off. 
P.S. Did I mention the place is very noisy.
author: Alex B.

description:
I never eat at places as fancy as this, so this was an awesome experience.

I'm quite inexperienced with shellfish, as I've been too afraid to try oysters and mussels in the past. But when I came here for an Easter dinner last Sunday, the pressure was on from my boyfriend's seafood-loving family. I closed my eyes, took the oyster shot, and chewed. 

It was incredible. It tasted like the ocean in the best way. They served the oysters with a delicious spicy citrus sauce that reminded me a lot of Thai ingredients. And I'm a huge citrus freak, so everything was just perfect on that front.

I tried the mussels next, which are also great as long as you don't look at them. They were served up in a delicious garlic-tomato broth, and they tasted surprisingly like chicken.

I have to mention the wine, because it totally made the meal. The parents picked out a cuvee from Chateu du Chatelard. It also says Beaujolais Villages on the bottle, so if you're looking through the wine list and you see any of those words, go with that. It was a nice, rich red that sat well with the food without being overpowered by any of the intense flavors, like the truffle risotto I'm about to rave about.

Goddddd. Only get this if you're a huge mushroom fan and love a rich risotto. They throw just about every type of edible fungi into this dish, and I'm not complaining. The flavor is so full and decadent, just as it should be. 

To top it off, our server was a sweetheart and took great care of us. Take advantage of their prix fixe offerings--you can't go wrong.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Went here for Dine-About-Town, and really liked it.

Appetizers

Butter lettuce salad = fantastic
Arugula salad = very good
Salmon carpaccio = very good, but could use a bit more citrus
Crab salad = very good

Mains

Steak = fantastic
Chicken = fantastic
Scallops = very good
Duck = good, but nothing to jump up and write home about.  More to do with the bland-ish flavor than the way it was cooked (which was to perfection).

Desserts

Semifreddo = fantastic
granite = ok
vanilla bean gelato = excellent
vanilla bean creme brulee = excellent

Discovered a wine from Paso Robles that was very affordable & tasty - Niners, I think.


What's up with them hustling you to finish up and get the hell out on a sat night, though?  I was sorta expecting that a nice-ish place like this wouldn't do that :-(
author: Vandana N.

description:
Came here for DAT the past sat night.. I'm writing on behalf of my group.

We got all the possible mixes that you can get between the entrees, appetizers and desserts + 2 foie gras that the waiter raved about.

1). foie gras - seared w/ peaches? excellent.. weren't lying about the portion.
2). salmon carpaccio - standard no wow factor
3). mussels - good :)
2). scallop - woah.. portion cut in half compared to last year's DAT. My scallops were small and the presentation was MESSY.
3). duck breasts - two of my friends didn't touch them.. overdone? dry? flavorless.
4). halibut - overdone and dry.
5). steak - standard.
6). pasta - standard.
7). creme brulee and molten cake were bleh.

After we got our check.. the waiter comes over and tells us that during normal days (non-DAT days), they have the same 3 course pre-fix for only $29!
WOW.. okay.. thanks for ripping us off ?? They forgot our to-gos (the duck breasts and the steak but that's okay cuz they had no flavor)

.. I would never come again the food here is definitely going downhill.
author: Catalina C.

description:
The food, service, and ambiance at Isa is a solid four stars. Went here last night with a friend to do the $29.99 prix fixe menu, which they do Sunday through Thursday. We also had the chance to partake in happy hour - $5 for a glass of wine. 

Server was very friendly and answered any questions we had about menu or wine list. I liked how he encouraged us to try different items on the prix fixe menu and share. I'm a glutton for variety, so this was right up my alley. 

Bread. Amazing. 

Appetizer: Grilled squid and mussels. Tasty. Big portions.

Dinner: Steak and Fish of the Day (Halibut). Both decently cooked with veggies on the side.

Dessert: Flourless chocolate cake with vanilla gelato (an extra $2 to the prix fixe) and an almond flavored gelato. Both decent, but not earth shattering.
author: Tracee W.

description:
There was very little leeway with me when it came to picking a restaurant on the Dine About Town list. I HAD to go to Isa. I'd never been, but Isa had the appeal of having 5-6 options per course (all of which sounded AMAZING) so I was immediately sold. This meant settling for a 9:45pm reservation, so I walked into Isa starving and ready to chow down.

Upon arrival, the place was packed! A good sign, I guess, but remember it's 9:45 and was ready to die of hunger. I was a little miffed, but we were promptly seated after 5 minutes or so. Our waiter was soo cute. He was this cute little old mad with the heaviest accent ever. He started speaking and literally the only words I could understand were "share" and "have fun" which in my mind didn't really equate to having a "fun" time, but I nodded my head and convinced him I was enthused. 

For the first course, I had Salmon Carpaccio and my friend had the Steamed Mussels. Each dish came out individually, which really did mean we were going to share everything--a nice twist which meant I got to try everything AND this 3 course meal turned into a 6 course one. The Salmon Carpaccio was delicious. Nicely seasoned and incredibly fresh and melt in your mouth tender. I didn't think the mussels would top it, but they were seriously the best mussels I have ever eaten. Hands down. Period. Perfectly PERFECTLY cooked and they were soft and plump and flavorful--so much so that they really tasted like oysters. I had died and gone to food heaven. 

For the second course, I had the Seared Scallops with Brussels Sprouts and Bacon in Truffle Sauce and my friend had the Duck with a side of Spinach in a Balsamic sauce with Potato Roti. Both were absolutely amazing. The scallops were seared perfectly, the potatoes sweet and smooth and garlicky, and the brussels sprouts were tender and only slightly bitter. The duck was a perfect medium rare and superr tender. 

Our choices for dessert, Creme Brulee and the Amaretto Semifreddo, were the perfect caps to our meal. The Creme Brulee had a nice, thick sugar crust and the perfect creamy filling and the Semifreddo was like a soft icecream with cake mixed into it. 

The wines we tried were fantastic! I had the Riesling and my friend had the Chardonnay. Totally girly, but both were sweet and not too dry. 

I would definitely return to Isa, any day, any time. And the Dine About Town menu makes this meal a great deal at $34.95! The only thing is, I wish we had come on Sun-Thurs so we could have gotten FREE glasses of wine, but for a fabulous meal, I really didn't mind spending $8 on a great glass. Even though parking is rough, I can't deduct any stars for this outstanding place because my experience here was absolutely phenomenal.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
We came here for the dine about town menu.

Service is good.
Food is great.
Will definitely come back for the quality of food.

Since we are a group of 6, we got to try a lot of food. 
Appetizers - crab salad, good.  goat cheese, good.  Smoked salmon, alright.  Mussels, big plate and cook perfect, yum!  

Entrees - duck breast - rare and yum!!  Steak -rare and yum!!  Seared scallops - perfect and yum yum!!  Fish- didn't try but I heard it's good.

Dessert - love the semifredo almond, it's something different.  They had gelatos and cream brulee which is alright like it should be.

I'll definitely come back mainly because I trust how they cook the scallop, duck breast and steak... I love it when a chef knows how to cook these items perfectly. 

Service is good too... almost forgot to mention.
author: Jo L.

description:
Hello Foodies,

WOW...I can't believe it, but this is my 1st review and let me express how disappointed I am. I am a lover of French food and have tried countless French restaurants around the world.

I am sad to say I took my beautiful wife for her biirthday dinner and was sorely disappointed after reading all the reviews here on Yelp. 

The hostess received us and seated us without a smile. Not a great start. It was pretty much downhill from there.
The table were 12" apart. Not very private or intimate for a couple. you could hear your neighbors conversations and vice versa.

Sorry to say, but the food is NOT VERY GOOD and for you Yelpers who think this compares to French Laundry or any other French restaurant in San Francisco, I am sorry.

The Foie Gras was very "oily", the potato wraped seabass  tasted like my  local pub fish and chips. Overall, the food was not very good. 

I would not go back, nor recommend this place to my friends or family.

Chef - If you are truly open to learning from a customer, feel free to reach out to me and I would be more than happy to help provide my open and honest feedback. Hopefully, it will help.

Cheers Everyone. Hope this helps.
author: Love B.

description: Staff here is very nice and helpful, the food here is very good, we were hooked since the Dine About Town menus when they have it.  So far our favorite dishes are the risotto and the steamed mussels.  Parking is bit tough to find, but if you have paybyphone app on your phone, you can (if available) park across the street for a lot cheaper than going to a garage
author: Eric C.

description:
Dine About Town Experience: 

Salmon Carpaccio - wish the salmon were colder. But this dish is better than the mussels, which i find not very fresh. 
Truffle risotto - this is delicious! Your party must try this! The iron steak was good too.
Semifreddo all' amaretto- almondy. Pretty yummy, better than the creme brulee!

Portion is small. Normally after eating from Dine About Town menus of other restaurants, I'd be stuffed, but I did not experience this feeling from eating at ISA. If you are a guy and are super hungry, do NOT come here. 


In summary, the food here is decent, but nothing stood out. I would NOT come back unless I'm being dragged to dine here, or when a glass of wine is being served complementary.
author: JFer C.

description:
So disappointing.  My husband and I had heard good things and were invited to dinner by another couple who had a 30% off coupon through Village Vines.  

The waiter was obnoxiously over-describing everything on the menu without actually having an opinion or making a strong case for anything in particular.  Interrupting us every few minutes to annoy us with more useless info, he cleared our plates then disappeared for over an hour before offering dessert or the bill.  

When we finally got the bill, the 30% discount hadn't been applied and when we questioned it, a manager came out.  She explained that we had been 15 minutes late for our reservation and even though we called to say we were running 15 minutes late (which is polite) she could no longer honor the coupon.  On a $250 bill--with wine we probably wouldn't have ordered if we didn't have the coupon--this was pretty frustrating.  

Had we known when we called about running late that 15 minutes would cost $75, we would never have eaten at this overpriced, mediocre spot.  Nothing on the menu was standout (this could be the fault of our waiter) but there's your usual fish option, beef option, and chicken option if that's all you need to qualify spending $$$ for dinner.

There was no resolution.  The manager refused any level of discount, despite our friends having paid $10 for the coupon, even after we said they would never have our business again.  Disappointing.
author: ellen v.

description: I have been twice to Isa and I love it. I like the concept of sharing several dishes. I particularly enjoyed the truffle risotto, avocado and salmon tartare apetizer. The menu has a nice combinaison of california-french dishes. The back patio is also very nice. I would highly recommend this restaurant greatly located in the Marina.
author: Emilie A.

description: Great service, butter lettuce salad, mushroom risotto, steak and semifreddi amaretto ice cream was the best I've ever had. Definitely will come again!  Parents loved it here. Wine selection is good too.
author: suki y.

description:
Food was good. Service was exceptional. 

I'm a bit upset with how they boxed and bagged my food togo since it leaked out of the box and drenched half my stuff in my bag/purse. I recommend people to bag their own food and ask for a plastic bag, so it won't leak out of the box. I got short ribs and I couldn't finish it so I asked for it to be boxed. Bad idea!

Otherwise, everything else was great. We were full which was nice.
author: Kissy F.

description: This was a mixed bag. We had the Dungeness Crab Salad which was excellent !  My wife had the Truffle Risotto, which was overly truffly. It was 'ok' for her. I had the Paella, and I usually love paella. It was 'ok', but nothing out of the ordinary.   In general the service was great, but the food was just 'ok'.
author: Andy W.

description:
I was here with a large group and and had a 3-course prix fixe menu, though the waiter said that they do it family style here, which sounds all warm and friendly, but in reality means that if you order a dish that you find delicious, you only get a sample of it because it gets passed around to the other 8 people at the table too.  Not cool, if i only want to savor my dish and don't really care for what others at the table have ordered....

But anyways, I ordered the calamari appetizer, which smelled amazing and the flavors worked well together.  The salmon carpaccio served with crostini was good, but nothing special.  The arugula salad with fennel was very bitter and boring - it needed something sweet to complement the flavors, such as orange.  The yellowfin tuna was very good, just the right amount of spicy kick and creamy avocado to balance.  

Entrees:  Due to the family style nature of the place, I ended up tasting the truffle risotto, lobster bouillabaisse, sole, and duck breast with spinach and bacon.  Of course I ordered the duck and regretted that I could not selfishly enjoy the entire dish by myself, since it was AMAZING.  The skin was perfectly crisp, providing that delicious juxtaposition of textures expected in a duck confit.  The sole and risotto were both good too, but not as memorable as the duck, and the bouillabaisse was not as fragrant as I would have liked so I would not recommend that dish. 

As far as desserts go, I wish they had more sweet options.  I got the semifreddo and though it was infused with almond flavor, the ice cream was a bit icier than I would prefer.  Not as good and creamy as Ben & Jerry's or Haagan Daaz or Mitchells or Bi-Rite....
author: Beatrice W.

description:
It's been a while but I came back to Isa and, true to my word, and memory of the food here, tried the yellowfin tuna again and it was, of course, fantastic!  

We also had the range chicken, dungeness crab salad, seared scallops, roasted rack of lamb and potato wrapped sea bass.  The crab salad was a lot of fun, it was almost a dungenous lettuce cup dish and the small slices of green apple added to the light, fresh, taste of the dish.  The scallops were perfectly cooked and really nice in the orzo.  We also tried a little appetizer with goat cheese, the cheese was melted and a bit incongruous with the tomatoes, maybe if there were a little more greens I would have enjoyed this dish more.  

All in all, still an enthusiastic 4 stars.  On a nice night, request a table outside, the atmosphere is so cute.  There are also heat lamps out there and the area is covered/tented, so I imagine it would even be nice on a cooler night.
author: Janelle C.

description:
This place deserved a perfect review on so many occasions:

1) We were late for our reservation, like about an hour,  (not that I encourage you do the same) but they couldn't have been nicer about it. They had a table, sat us down, no fuss
2) The serving staff ahh... Helpful, joyful, kind, always available and around. Just wonderful
3) Baked goat cheese: absolutely recommended! Salmon carpaccio - meh, not impressed but it wasn't bad at all. 
4) Mushroom risotto: I'm a big fan of making risotto at home and can get super picky about them. This was great. The halibut: perfectly good, well blended with the sides they placed under the fish (i.e. spinach etc). 
5) The desserts on the prix fixe menu was somewhat lacking. Blue cheese plate: recommended - great cheese, great sides (grapes, jam, baguette)
6) Oh and we were so reluctant to leave - kept  sitting / chatting /  enjoying the dessert way past their closing time and they couldn't have been nicer about it...
7) Great atmosphere for a date!
author: Tina B.

description:
WOW 

Came here with my lady friend on a date last summer as one of those fancy dinners that you only do once in a great while. This place lets you choose from a three course menu and has a selection of red wines and dessert wine. The atmosphere is dark and cozy with candlelight with an interesting street view and bar. 

The bread and butter: oh my god, so good! Going into our first course, our waiter took my last loaf away by accident and I was so sad :( The butter was just so creamy and delicious! 

As for the first course, a nice apple salad and some scrumptious corn/potato soup. I wanted more of that soup! 

Main entrees: their select chicken and potatoes and truffle risotto. Chicken went down smooth, no trouble at all, excellent nomming. The risotto was a tad disappointing however; a little too much garlic for my palette, but nonetheless an interesting finish. 

I had the creme brulee for dessert. Never had creme brulee before, but I assume it was made well since it made me happy :) 

My friend and I took a long journey to this place (she wearing heals!) and I feel it was definitely worth it.
author: Alex S.

description:
A night out with my awesome Roomie!

Nice and sweet atmosphere. Romantic place-- not exactly.  Can't go wrong when you dim the light!

Tuna Tartare - eh
Foie Gras - de-vain process??? ugh!
Sea Bass wrapped with potato - Totally metls in your mouth.  Love it. Phenomenal. 
Scallops - eh

Vanilla gelato w/ shot of espresso - Totally "TO DIE FOR"  
It taste exactly like a Tiramisu but way better.

Definitely would return for dessert!
author: Jessica P.

description:
Absolutely lovely restaurant. Delicious food, impeccable service, and a well-versed menu.

We had the halibut. Oh my, my, my! And the salmon carpaccio, mussels and lovely desserts.
author: Sara B.

description:
I am giving this place 5 stars! At first, I was thinking of maybe 4 but after the exceptional service we received...there is no doubt that it is 5! 

Thank you to the Isa Staff for finding our Muni pass. You saved us $60! Thank you for remembering us and calling us. We are super grateful. 

Now on to the actual dining experience....

Small, intimate restaurant that surprises you with a large back room which is decorated with hanging lights and heat lamps. It made the pseudo outdoor seating area very enjoyable and cozy. Noise level was a bit high but we still enjoyed the ambiance.
Our waiter knew his menu and explained everything. Every entree he mentioned, I salivated. 
Starters: 
Dungeness Crab Salad: fresh and delicious! Must Have. 
Organic Salmon Carpaccio with creme fraiche. Good.

Entrees:
Truffle Risotto: mushroom galore! love it!
Maple Leaf Farm Duck Breast: Must get. Tender and juicy. 

Desserts: 
Grapefruit Granite: so-so but still refreshing
Flourless chocolate cake with vanilla bean gelato: SUPER delicious!

I wished I had my coffee with my dessert. Our waiter forgot. That was probably the only downside of the meal.

Overall, I was completely satisfied with the dining experience. The food was delicious and unforgettable. The staff works hard and I can see that. 

Thank you!
author: Molly T.

description:
Wandered into this pretty place after a nice day at the Palace of Fine Arts. We were the first ones in for dinner because we have the internal clocks of 80 year olds. 

Since we are hardcore, we ordered two Sojou cocktails. One was a Negroni and one was a Seven PM (?) I can't remember. A drink with blackberries and ginger. Both were tasty so we ordered two more. I told you we were hardcore. 

For dinner, we stopped lavishly imbibing and ordered the arugula salad, potato leek soup, scallops and potato wrapped sea bass. Arugula was fresh and included some delicious apricots. Potato leek soup was solid though Boyfriend says mine is better. (I didn't tell him to say that.) Scallops were lightly seared and not rubbery. Sea bass was delicious and I don't really even like fish! 

As mentioned in a previous review, the food IS tapas style, so the portions aren't too big. Definitely ordered two lighter items and two heavier items. I'm tiny and I still had room for some tasty Creme Brulee. But, there's always room for dessert!
author: Anne W.

description:
Before I had the chance to taste the food at Isa, I was blown away by the awesome service.  They were super attentive, even while we waited outside as our table was prepped.  I suspect mind reading on the part of the waitstaff, who always seemed to come by exactly when I needed something.

Even the bread and butter at Isa were top notch.  I had to physically push them away to ensure I'd have space for what I knew was coming: amazing foie gras, and truffle risotto.  And so much more.  Our large-ish group ordered maybe 10 dishes?  The chef obviously took care in the order the dishes came out, making sure to serve the most complementing dishes side-by-side.

Everything at Isa was so fresh - produce, seafood, meat - it tasted like they must have just gone the most delicious killing spree possible and spread their tasty bounty before me.  I inhaled everything on the table, and there was a LOT on the table.

I prefer to try new restaurants as often as possible, to get a little taste of the whole city.  But I don't think I can stay away from Isa for long.
author: Mallory M.

description: I had my 1st year wedding anniversary with my husband here on Sunday evening, 3 days ago. The environment was intimate and perfect for our event (small, lights dimmed) , except the large group of 13 next to us was kind of loud. The waiter was really knowledgable of the menu according to my husband, because I didn't hear half of what he said due the large group. I ordered lamb rack with extra rack(well done) & my husband ordered Flat iron steak(medium) and local calamari, grapefruit granite. When the calamari came out, I was kind of disappointed since I was expecting fried. Then entrees came out, they don't look like the pictures I saw on Yelp which disappointed my husband most. The steak was ok according to my husband and he is big fan of steak and had high hopes due to the pics I showed him before. My lamb rack was looking good, but it came out more raw than the steak( medium) and I ordered well done since I am not supposed to eat undercooked due to pregnancy. I was so disappointed in the food by this point( appetizer, entrees were beyond lower than our expectation) the taste of lamb, I couldn't eat it due to its seasoning ( my husband ate one rack, I barely had one, & I asked them to pack since both of us couldn't eat the lamb anymore. I was already down with the food taste and how they couldn't get my order right. The only things I will say that I liked are the bread and butter ( since I couldn't eat the food, I had like 3 baskets of it) & grapefruit granite (for my husband, it was sour, but I am big fan of sour things and I liked it) so the environment, bread/butter, dessert and waiter barely gets this place 3 stars in my book. But the food presentation and taste definitely takes off 2 stars and I will come back here just for the bread/butter and dessert if there is no other place to eat or I am not that hungry to begin with. Otherwise, it is not worth the hour drive on one way and expensive price for the food. (In case some say of course lamb not many people can eat it, but guess what I am Mongolian and grew up eating it in many ways but this lamb cooked wrong and taste not good) btw, my husband is not Mongolian and he didn't like it also, we ended up throwing away the rest at home.
author: Nancy K.

description:
This is actually a nice place to have a dinner outing with friends. We tried this place last Saturday for Dine About Town during dinner. For our friends and ourselves, this was our first time there. We also brought our toddler along with us.

The main restaurant is small but they have an outer area under a tent. The decorations reminded one of my friends as if we were on a ship. Considering it was cold that day, we barely felt anything but a few drafts here and there. It was pretty busy and it was a bit hard to hear everyone. The service was attentive, checking on us and refilling water.

Everyone had either similar or different dishes. For the first course, I got the arugula salad and my husband got the dugeness crab salad. The arugula salad was okay. I think my least favorite out of the three dishes. One of my friends got the steamed Prince Edward island mussels and that was great. 

For the second course, a few people got the truffle risotto and that was a good choice. I got the pan roasted rockey jr. range chicken and my husband got the steak. I mainly got the chicken because of my toddler and it was pretty good. 

For dessert, I got the vanilla bean creme brulee and my husband got the semifreddo all' amaretto. Everything but the arugula sald was great. My friend who organized the Dine About outing did a great job. 

Parking there isn't all that great. There is a meter parking garage on Pierce St, which is where my husband and I parked. You're lucky to find any parking in the surrounding area. Our other friends parked in a different parking garage but I'm not sure where that was. On the website, you can reserve parking.
author: Jenn D.

description:
I liked the food, however I did think it was a bit pricy for what you get.  The reason I'm writing this review is because it took the waiter about half an hour to describe each dish (not our request).  This became very annoying after the first few dishes.  I kept saying to myself, "I can read the menu,  just let me order". It was like wanting to buy a car and the salesmen starts reading the owners manual to you.  I felt that was pretensous, annoying and very tiresome.  I would much rather they tell me what they are known for, and if there is something new on the menu.  Not read the menu to me.  I know how to read!

Don't get me wrong, the service was excellent, and I may actually go again.  I just have to figure out a way to let the waiter know I don't need a classroom lecture about the menu.
author: Rex E.

description: Great menu options w/ a fresh twist. Excellent service, nice vibe. Check out the back patio. Order the chicken. They've been around for 14 years.
author: Vicki L.

description:
The food here was fantastic. My friend dislikes dark meat chicken and he just ate it up touting the wonders of the goodness.

Everything we ate was so delicious.

The service, while informative, became a bit condescending after a few visits from the waiter, we began to worry if he was going to come over and tell us how to use a fork.

We will be going back there regardless because we can't wait to try the rest of the menu.
author: Marz W.

description:
We came here for Dine About Town and were so incredibly impressed. This really was the epitome of a fantastic dining experience..

Service: We are talking about a well-oiled machine..they have everything down pat. From getting seated to paying our bill, everyone was courteous and efficient. Even the reminder call I received was polite and personable.

Food: Dine About Town menu was phenomenal..
-Salmon Carpaccio: the fish was so fresh and not over powered by the capers. Sprinkle on egg and light drizzle of a citrus-testing sauce on top. The freshness of the salmon battles the fresh fish I've had in Hawaii..and writing about this dish makes me salivate! 
-Dungeness crab salad: overall not my favorite dish. The grapefruit in this salad was way to bitter and it overpowered everything else ok the plate.
-Flat Iron Steak done medium: don't you hate it when restaurants say it comes with potatoes and it is just one tiny piece?? Well prepare to be wowed! This dish was fantastic...perfectly cooked, the meat was moist and tender, the string beans  weren't soggy, and the potatoes..oh the potatoes!! Crispy on the outside and big hearty  bites..yummmyy!
-Duck breast: The texture in this was completely different from the beef, really moist, and soft. I looked the salad it came with. The medium was already pretty red for me, but they suggested medium rare for the duck. Try it is you don't mind the blood as much.
-Vanilla Creme Brulee: was like vanilla pudding..not too sweet, perfectly creamy.
-Grapefruit granite: This was really interesting. I've never had grapefruit shaved ice before! Don't eat this after the creme brulee!! It is really bitter if you do..

The BREAD here is so good!!

Overall, this was an amazing dining experience. Loved it and will definitely be back, Dine About Town or not. :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
One of the best meals I've ever had! Seriously! And I've eaten at some of the best restaurants in SF, LA, Sonoma, you name it. The atmosphere is great - I would recommend sitting in the back - when it's a cold night they cover it but it still has a cool-outdoorsy-yet-classy vibe. Top quality ingredients and everything was cooked to perfection!

We had the crab salad to start (bomb!), the scallops (AMAZING), and their special that night which was a massive lamb shank that was literally falling off the bone and melted in your mouth... TO DIE FOR.
author: Janina T.

description: Yummy dollar oysters during happy hour and great soju cocktails but everything is okay.
author: Anne T.

description:
Hands down, one of the best dinners I've had to date! My grandparents and I consider ourselves to be total wine and food snobs and we all left Isa last night saying how amazing our meal was. I recommend asking the waiter whats good. we did and he couldnt of given us better plates. AMAZING! 5 stars :)
*Try the truffle risotto- cant go wrong!*
author: Alex H.

description:
Service: 5 stars 
Food: 4 stars 
Ambiance: 4 stars 

Revisited Isa on a Thursday night after a few years and was very impressed! I remembered the food being good with a cute & cozy ambiance but was pleasantly surprised by both the great price fixe (lots of variety) and the $5 HH drinks :) Our server was extremely attentive and made some good menu recommendations. 

They recommend sharing which is perfect since all of the dishes were so delicious:) We both went with the 2-course ($28) and had some glasses of pinot grigio & pinot noir ($5). 

1st course: 

Salmon carpaccio-delicate, fresh and drizzled with creme fraiche. I wish it came with a few more crostinis since there were so many pieces of salmon. 

Baked Goat Cheese-a must-have! So rich, warm and melt in your mouth good. The pesto, pine nuts and tomatoes compliment the goat cheese perfectly. Tastes excellent on the bread served at the table. 

2nd course: 

Halibut-lightly crunchy on the outside & delicately flaky on the inside & packed with flavor. The fresh zucchini and artichoke pieces were also very tasty along side the halibut. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=Vr3TSTRc9E6-xDfFAe5TFA 

Flat Iron Steak-wonderful flavor & yummy potatoes. Only had a bite (not a big steak person) but it was very tasty with the sauce. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=Y2vPbD-QRZ9Ytric6W-W8g 

Highly recommend going on a weeknight and on the early side as the service was spot-on! Our waiter even gave us happy hour wine prices well after 7pm. A wonderful neighborhood dinning experience that isn't too pretentious in atmosphere and huge wow factor for food. Also, a great date spot - request a table in the back with the white lights - as it can be both casual or dressy. I will definitely go back soon!
author: Mel A.

description: Food was very delicious. The 3 course meal special is an excellent value. Our waiter and his colleagues were courteous, attentive, and knowledgable. The owner was down to earth and gave us attentive service as well. Decor was very comfortable and warm. Most enjoyable dinner experience I have had in a long time. We will definite return to try other dishes.
author: Hungry D.

description: We had dinner here a month ago and it was pretty good. Just nothing super rad to yelp about. Still, great quality and value. They have these three course prix fixe menus that are a bang for you buck. The cuisine is French/Caifornian, yet leans toward more on the Californian side. The food quality tastes like it's like it's right out of your gourmet friend's kitchen, meaning that this is close to home comfort food. I have no complaints with any of the dishes. The sweet breads and scallops are both great. The only problem I have with Isa is that it feels a little cramp. We had a table of five yet we were seated at a somewhat small table in the corner. Our server was very cheeky and humorous. Isa is very popular for good reason although in the end I feel like a lot of it is hot air.
author: Michael H.

description:
I never thought a restaurant in the Marina could handle a group of 20 people as well as Isa.  From the street, it looks fairly small (some would call it "cozy").  But there's a patio area that's tented and heated, giving several options for larger groups.

When organizing a large group dinner, I tend to expect certain sacrifices in the quality of food and service.  But Isa came through like a champion.  Our tables were ready on time, food came out at a good pace, everything was prepared expertly, and we never felt rushed.

Even before we had arrived, I was impressed with how the management took the time to understand our needs in planning the menu.  While it's not unusual for a restaurant to be aware of food allergies and vegetarian preferences, I appreciated how much thought went into creating a menu that would satisfy everyone's preferences.

PROS
- Handled a party of 20 people with aplomb.  Service was good, food was excellent, and everyone enjoyed themselves
- Very flexible with menu planning - between the vegans, the pescatarians, and the food allergies, we had a number of requirements
- The goat cheese with pesto was by far my favorite dish (and I'm lactose intolerant).

CONS
- Not that it's really a con, there was TOO MUCH food!
- No full bar - only beer and wine
- The patio can get a little loud, depending on the crowd

TIPS
- There's a parking garage one block away on Pierce Street.  Parking is enforced until 10pm, but it's the best way to park in the Marina.  Buy a prepaid parking card and load up the meter.
author: Drew P.

description: Unforgettable dinner with friends!  Trendy, happening place when you want good food & conversation.  People are friendly and the ambiance is lively.  The food presentation is spectacular and colorful.  When sharing amongst friends, the more the merrier.  We ordered everything from oysters, halibut, scallops, chicken, steak, duck, wines, desserts, mojitos, spirits, to cappuccino.  They all melt in your mouth.  The hostess Sam was truly gracious and offered us a glass of wine while waiting to be seated.  I love the cozy decor right in the heart of the Marina, no other place like it.  Thanks to my friend, I have found a neighborhood gem!  We'll definitely be back for more...can't wait.
author: Christine R.

description: Came here for Dine Around Town. The food was excellent and the portions were very generous. My favorite dishes had to be the scallops and the potato leek soup!
author: Ryan I.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the entire city! I've always sat on the patio area, which is quite romantic with little lights, street (heated) lamps, and quaint wooden furniture. The dishes are small, so you'll want to order a few (in my party of 2, we always order ~4-5). Wine list is also really good, and I would recommend the riesling they have on hand. Every time, we've had great service (minus one time with I think  a new waiter)

Best dishes: 
We usually start with the dungeness crab salad, which looks a bit like lettuce cups filled with a generous helping of crab, sweet tones from the apple, and creamy avocado. Next comes the potato wrapped sea bass, which is my favorite dish here. The fish is so tender and cooked to perfection, while the potato wrapping adds a nice heavy crisp to the dish. And lastly, the truffle risotto. I've never met a truffle dish I haven't liked, but this is one of the best risottos I've ever had. 

Okay dishes: lamb, lobster broth, seared scallops
author: Christine H.

description:
Do I love Isa just because it is French?  No!  However, I do love Isa and it happens to be French.  Yes!

Came here about a month ago for dine about town.  The highlights at Isa for me from what we ordered as a group:

Appetizer: I loved the Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese with pesto, tomato, concassee and pinenuts.  How ought one consume baked goat cheese?  Simple!  Eat it with the bottomless bread that they kept providing.  The warm and nutty favors were a divine combination.  

Entrée: The Seared Scallops with butternut squash, sweet potatoes, spinach, bacon, and truffle sauce was beyond compare!  Apparently I am becoming more French as I am obsessed with anything with even a bit of truffle.

Dessert: The dessert was ho-hum and not really worth discussing here.

Usually I am skeptical when it comes to recommendations from the restaurant itself because frankly there is a conflict of interest there.  However, the waiter was spot on with his recommendations!  I have regained trust in humankind which is a wonderful thing.

**Also a great spot to watch first dates.  Can you guess who will be together in a month?  I can!  This game is fun, I promise.
author: Fei L.

description:
Had a dinner here with coworkers. My favorite by far was the foie gras. We had to order a second for the table. The duck breast was also good. For our group of 5 the bill was just under 400 with tip, which wasn't too bad considering we had over 10 dishes to share, a bottle of wine, a few beers, and we each had desert. 

Would definitely recommend it to someone looking to go out to have a conversation over food. =)
author: Felix K.

description: We went here for dine about town last week. The food was good, nothing special - we ordered potato leak soup, mussels/grilled asparagus, spaghetti/seared scallops and semifreddo all'amaretto/vanilla bean creme brûlée. The mussels and asparagus were probably my favorite, lots of flavor. The ambiance is good and they have a nice patio area.
author: Leona G.

description: I was pretty impressed by my experience here. The ambience and atmosphere was very nice. Loved their backdoor seating area with lights hung and pretty decors. The food was also impressive. Everything on the menu is pretty yummy. The duck and scallops are recommended. The steak is not  pretty good too if you are a steak person. I also enjoyed the yellowfin tuna appetizer. Everything had great Flavors. Will come back again.  Only down side is Parking was hard!
author: Carrie T.

description:
Made reservations on OPEN TABLE a couple days before we had dinner (6/4) and got a call back that day to confirm our reservation which was nice. 

LADIES & GENTS,FYI if you haven't been in the Marina area parking can be a bitch esp during weekends. Our reservation was @ 7:15, but we had to call them around 7 to inform them that we were running andtheywere very understanding so they pushed our reservation to 7:30-7:35. My friend and i got there around 7:10 AND COULD NOT FIND PARKING ANYWHERE! I was going round in circles for 20+mins! that's how much of a bitch parking can be! We got to the restaurant around 7:35 and waited like another 10-15 minutes, obviously our table was not ready yet. 

This was a special day so i wanted to sit somewhere very private and somewhat intimate and cozy...AND BOY...it was toooo cozy! We all know that if you're going to the a French place, most likely that the ambiance will be small and tiny and it was! wasn't surprised at all! 
When they finally seated us, they sat us close to the exit door in the front of the restaurant and my friend and i were sitting next to each other, cramped next to the wall...very uncomfortable. I did NOT want to be THAT intimate geez!  It was sad that we had to sit next to each other and we could be face-face, which made me upset. - 1 star 

FOOD- For reason our server, who i think was French only gave us the DAT menu..They did not give us the regular restaurant menu which was strange. I mean i was there for DAT but i also wanted to see the normal menu. 

First Course: 
*Dunganese Crab salad- OVERRATED NO TASTE LITTLE MEAT CRAB 
*Mussels- these were delicious, except they were small

Second Course: 
*Duck- loved it! 
*Lamb pork chops- Delish! but the sauce is a little too salty 

Third Course: 
*Gelato- taste like reg vanilla bean ice cream 
*Creme brulee- good, nothing to remember or brag about 

WE also ordered these flavored fruity sodas $3 eachX3= $9

Each course did not come at the same time, so i felt like i was doing a tasting rather than dining so when i walked out of the restaurant i was still hungry, but then again it's a french place. haha
- 1 star 



BILL= DAT $34.95x2+$3x3 flavored soda= $83+ $10TIP $10

GRAND TOTAL $94
Overall i was pleased with the food, but the service not really satisfied AND the face that i had to sit literally next to wall i felt claustrophobic  - 1 star 

I'm not sure if this was authentic French or not, but if i don't find a better place for French i probably will come back for the mussels and lamb chops only!
author: Rose P.

description:
My boyfriend made reservations for this place when I visited for the weekend.
We were seated right away and they even took our jackets. The interior and ambiance was really nice, good for catching up with friends or a casual date.
We were seated right up to the window which was kind of awkward and had to sit side by side. Our view was out the window with these dusty blinds in the way, not ok!

We decided to order 1 appetizer and 3 items from the main course.
We ordered:
*Yellowfin Tuna - really good and flavorful but the seaweed salad on the side was too salty, it messed up the flavor a little
*Potato wrapped Seabass - Also good but again the sauce for it was too salty from the olives
*Flat Iron Steak - My favorite, well cooked and full of flavor!
*Duck Breast - I don't care for duck but my boyfriend loved it...too fatty for me

And all throughout the meal they kept refilling our water and bread and even changed out our plates and utensils after each dish. A little excessive but the service was excellent. 

For dessert I chose the Grapefruit Granite which was perfect after such a salty meal and the bf got the Flourless Chocolate cake with Vanilla Gelato. I didn't care much for the cake but the gelato was really good. 

Besides the food being too salty and the awkward seating, we still had a good time and left very satisfied!
author: Stella L.

description: I wanted to give ISA 3 1/2 stars.. but I went for 4 because I personally think it deserves a 4 more than a 3. Anyways moving along. I was hesitant to come here for a friends birthday because of the price range listed here on yelp. When I saw the prices in person, I was relieved. It wasn't bad at all. I had the Yukon Potato soup  and the skirt steak. By the way.. people were not lying when they said ISA has an intimate feel to it, it sure does.. it's really cozy.. and it was a bit too warm because of the heater lamps. I was really disappointed that they ran out of the muscles. Very unfortunate. Overall the wait staff was friendly, good food.. and good company.
author: Tiff C.

description: This was the best Dine About Town that I've experienced so far. Our server was super nice, funny, and accommodating and the food was amazing! I also really liked the ambience of the place; it almost seemed like we were sitting outdoors, without the cold SF weather. Their DAT menus include not 3, but 4 courses! and they had a wide selection of salads and entrees to choose from unlike other restaurants I've been to. I ordered the corn soup, which I really liked, but I tried my friend's lobster broth and that was so good too. For the salad, I ordered the dungeness crab salad. They put just enough crab on top of lettuce and avocado on the sides. After much debate, I ordered the flat iron steak as my entree and I did not regret it; so deliciousss. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned. It also came with zucchini slices and 2 thick fries. For dessert, I ordered the creme brulee, my favorite dessert ever and it was soo goood. I mean, I was a little drunk off of wine at this point, but I think it still would have been amazing sober. All of this was only $36.95??? So worth it. They only accept 2 credit cards (yay for Venmo), but our waitress was super accommodating and even offered to split it among all 6 of us. I highly recommend this restaurant for any occasion!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
This review is for my Dine About Town experience at Isa in January 2011.

FOOD (4/5)
First, there's no debate about the culinary aspect at Isa-- the food is delicious!  Like all the reviews say, the food is well prepared, fresh and a true gem of haute French cuisine.

DAT (4/5):  We ordered the dungeness crab salad (delicious chunks of crab meat; we also tried the scallops and it was so tasty and crispy from the pan), flat iron steak and Semifreddo all' amaretto.
