author: Minako S.

description: Totally recommend this for date night.  Service was well above expectations, as was the food.  This is clearly one of those places that the people in the neighborhoods nearby go to, but after telling our foodie friends who live around the city about it, they said they'd never heard of it--classic SF--too many great options.
author: Sp S.

description:
This is a way overdue review but the fact that I still think about it must mean that Isa was worth it. The other reason was because I went for the last dine about town and they are part of the up and coming one. 

It is worth it! I brought newbies to the dine about town experience and they loved it. They loved it so much they came to Isa twice! All of the dishes were delicious and they were not kidding when they said that the risotto was well done. After watching contestants being ousted on cooking shows for bad risotto, this must have been really well done. 

Desserts were delicious as well. Though we all took a bite of each other's food, what we really wanted was another plate of food. It was so delicious, and the staff super friendly. There were no complaints and the outside dining area was full of lights and great for a romantic dinner or just a good time with friends.
author: N T.

description: I ordered delivery through Grubhub and got the Potato Wrapped Seabass and Flat Iron Steak. I thought the food was great - very tasty, but the quantity for 1 dish was not enough for 1 person, and was quite pricey. I shared these 2 dishes with another person and was still hungry. Although both entrees were really good, the portions of food for each dish should have been bigger!
author: Sonia D.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town over the weekend and had a fantastic time. FYI, Isa is ONLY serving from the DAT menu until Jan 31. Luckily the menu is fairly extensive and they have a couple of additional items and add-ons.

For $5 extra you can get the lamb chops entree, and I think you can substitute any entree for foie gras. I sometimes wish they told you the specials when you sit down so that you haven't already committed and fantasized about your future meal before they spring on some new options. How rude is that! I'm mostly joking. 

Couldn't help but get a cocktail (who knew it was happy hour! it was so dark outside I didn't even realize it was between 5-7 and cocktails and glasses of wine were only $5!) I decided on Number Seven, which I think was a soju cocktail with huckleberry and ginger. Twas good, but what an unoriginal name. At least it was actually the seventh cocktail on the list. 

The coolest thing about Isa is that "everything is served family style" or to share. So even though we all chose our own appetizers and entrees, they did a nice job of bringing out each dish individually so that we could focus on one dish and share it among the three of us. It lengthened our meal and made our eating experience more  enjoyable! I liked the style a lot; it allows you to actually focus on a dish and savor it.

Out of all the appetizers, I most enjoyed the salmon carpaccio. It's a nice one to share. The dungeness crab salad was also really good. The prawns were okay, it surprisingly came with five(!!) and the oil is perfect for dipping bread into. I found the prawns to be a little too salty though and I usually don't complain about saltiness. 

By the way, the bread is on point. It's like lightly toasted and still warm and just perfect. Beware of accidentally eating too much while waiting... and in between courses. 

As far as entrees go, I got the chicken with mashed potatoes (sounds boring I know) but the chicken was moist, flavorful, and tantalizing! It was the last dish to arrive yet I still ate a hefty portion as it was just that good. 

The petrale sole was also quite good. I wasn't that fond of the veggies it came with (some squash and artichokes) because they gave us the same ones in the steak entree. I did NOT enjoy the steak with bernaise sauce. Not worth it. Plus it comes with polenta and I have a deep seated hatred for polenta because it never tastes like anything and I don't understand how it could ever be good with anything.

As for desserts, do not get the grapefruit granite unless you LOVE grapefruit and can handle the sour-ness. It is incredibly intense but probably the lightest option out of the four. The very creamy vanilla bean gelato comes with both the biscotti order and the flourless chocolate cake. I loved the chocolate cake, which was quite light and almost souffle-like on the inside. The portion is perfect in that the last bite is JUST enough to not push you over the edge to discomfort but you're still scraping at the sides of the ramekin to clean off the chocolate remains because it is just that good.  

After all of these words, I would definitely recommend Isa either for DAT or just on a regular day. Apparently their usual prix-fixe menu is cheaper than DAT. 

Also, their back patio seating is super cute, warm, and feels kind of like a tent! It is spacious enough and also has a homey feeling.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Great food & drinks. Service was friendly. 
I really liked the appetizers. I would go back
author: Adam M.

description: This place is wonderful. Design is great, especially their patio! Food is delicious as well. We tried almost all of their main dishes and were not disappointed at all.
author: Krystyna T.

description: Love this place. My bf and friends took me here for my birthday and we had an awesome time. We got in early around 5:30 pm so we were able to take advantageof the happy hour special. All of us ordered 3 glasses of wine all at the same time so the 16 of us had enough to drink. Would definitely come back for the foie gras !!!
author: Claudine V.

description:
I came to Isa on a Sunday night with some friends and they had a two course special going on that month for 24 dollars.  Apparently, all plates are suggested to be shared family style which I like since it lets everyone get a taste of what the restaurant has to offer.  

The food was good overall with a couple of minor hiccups.  We enjoyed most of our appetizers: oysters, salmon carpaccio, tomato salad but the grilled calamari was a huge miss.  The sides and garnish that accompanied each dish were not always complementary.  For example, the halibut came on a bed of beet cubes which stained the fish a reddish color.  The steak dish was cooked perfectly and flavored quite nicely, but it would have been better without the horseradish sauce on top.  

Services was slow and gruff at times, even on a slow night.  They do not have a full bar license, so only wine or beer is available.  All in all, Isa is a decent dinner spot to try if you are open to their rather unique food combination.
author: Wei K.

description: AMAZING!!  Still sitting here and I can't wait to come back!  The sea bass is out of this world!!
author: Chris W.

description:
We came here last night as part of Dine About Town and had a fantastic meal! 
The four course prix-fixe menu had so many great options and the portions were that of normal full portions, all for the price of $37. 
The dungeness crab salad was really fresh, chicken was done to perfection, rib-eye steak just melted under the knife, and the sides were all delicious. I will definitely go back here even if they don't have the prix-fixe menu.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
This restaurant is still a little gem to me minus the parking in the Marina.  I love coming here for a decent dinner just to catch up with good friends.

It's a must that I order scallops for my main entree whenever a restaurant has it on their menu. By far my favorite seafood item.  Their scallops are moderate in size, but definitely good not great.  

Their Foie gras is definitely savory and jumbo in size ( compare to the places I've tried). 

Ohh and the creme brulee is to die for.  Super creamy..

Isa is definitely worth the visit..
author: Sophia S.

description:
I was lucky enough to go to Isa with Rebecca L. (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=KZal6lyuiBn59GufGXi9zA) for my last dinner in the City. At least for the time being (relocated to Southern CA). 

I was kinda scurred when Becca said French but the dishes at Isa have alot of Asian influence. Becca already did a pretty expansive review so I won't go into the nitty gritty too much. I didn't feel this place was too commercial. Mainly because I ordered well. By chance all my dishes were well prepared and hit the spot. Especially the Spicy Tuna Crudo (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=9r347Ed5xCyxtq-7zvJQ7Q) & Scallops (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QINiEjMRGA7pKfvhPQtfBg?select=Wc5soaXHSCKnh2OT3NS2hA). Becca's Bouillabaisse was disappointing as the fish was overcooked and the broth was not that flavorful. 

Our waiter had the thickest accent too I had to translate for my dinner partner. Even though this restaurant is touted as having bigger, family style plates. I am a healthy girl and if they wanted me to really share then I need more food! I guess the portions are big for fine dining.
Overall just be careful about your dinner choices and if you do dessert do NOT miss the flourless chocolate cake with vanilla bean gelato.
author: Amanda R.

description:
My friends and I came here for Dine About Town and it was definitely a great choice considering we were in a huge group. 

Most of the restaurants during DAT offer a "small" (literally) portion of their regular menus but Isa really outdid itself by giving us more than enough food. The restaurant is "family-style" which is very unique for a place so expensive. They bring in the dishes with servers and each person takes a little onto their plates. Isa had a prix fixe menu and from there we ordered:

Appetizers:
- crab salad:
- goat cheese: not a huge fan of goat cheese but the bread along with the cheese made it really good.
- Salmon carpaccio: i am a hugeee fan of salmon. According to our waiter, this type of salmon is hard to find in everyday grocery stores. they were thinly sliced and paired with bread toast crackers. SO FRESH.

Entrees: 
- Seared scallops with butternut squash, sweet potatoes, spinach, bacon, and truffle sauce (perfect scallops, the sauce for the vegetable was delicious)
- Grilled Golden Gate angus flat steak iron steak with zucchini, polenta, verte, and bordelaise sauce (AMAZING steak.... soo juicy and flavorful that I didn't even need steak sauce)
- Pan roasted rocky jr. range chicken with fresh herbs, creamy potatoes, and jus de poulet (chicken was well cooked--not dry at all. The herbs went really well with the meat)

Dessert:
- Semifreddo: it was a gelatto + biscotti. 
- Flourless chocolate cake: I got this one bc of the interesting name. It was definitely.... interesting. The consistency is what threw me off. It looked hard from the outside but right as I stuck my spoon into the cake, it was airy and kind of like a souffle. The vanilla gelatto that came with it was delicious and the hot-cold contrast did make it better. 

Isa also has happy hour until 7pm so my friends and I ordered their $5 Soju cocktails. I got the greyhound which is a grapefruit-soju drink. It tasted very bitter and it seemed as though there werent that much soju in it, but an hour or two later, I definitely felt the alcohol. I wouldn't recommend the greyhound if you like drinks that are a bit sweeter.

Negative: Parking. We luckily found a spot right by the restaurant but if we hadn't, there would have been a lot of circling around--esp. because the area has a lot of restaurants and street-parking only.

Overall, for the price we paid for DAT, the food was AMAZING, 5-star worthy and filling.
author: D S.

description: We had the tasting menu for dine about town and left very satisfied. The scallops and short ribs were both very good. Back patio was comfortable and heated.
author: Mark B.

description:
Parking situation: pretty good street parking(Wednesday night)

Event: birthday celebration for 2 :)
Consumers: two graduate students in their mid-twenties = read: tight budget.
Atmosphere: Warm and dark colors that are very inviting.. and around closing time can be pretty romantic (8:30pm - only 5-6 other tables).

Service: [5 stars] Had to wait 3 minutes for the maitre d' to come back to her post.. but honestly, I couldn't care less because we were late for our reservation (I know.. bad bad bad!!). Despite being late, they didn't seem to care and were very courteous and prompt. 
The staff at the restaurant were very quick, professional, attentive and never intrusive.
Our server was tall with glasses (highly recommend him.. didn't catch the name) with a very serious demeanor but very friendly and accommodating. He gave us the best advice ever which is that for 2 people 1 prix fixe (3 courses) and 1 extra dish is usually enough to fill you up unless you're both absolutely starving - he was right! He also was very kind to give us a taste of the pseudo Beaujolais they had that he recommended for our meal.

Food: [4.8 stars] We ordered the following:
prix fixe: Heirloom tomato salad - beautiful, simple, delicious and amazing. Truffle + mushroom risotto - nicely seasoned, not too creamy, just right. Aged goat cheese + honey - wonderful, the candied walnuts that accompanied it were fresh and not too sweet or sticky - perfect!
Not on frix fixe: Duck - OMG did I die and go to heaven?? As soon as I had the duck I had to stop talking, close my eyes and savor the depth, smoothness, and deliciousness of this meat - supreme!!! The -0.2 comes from the fact that the salad that comes with the duck was greasy (too much bacon and olive oil), had no where near as wonderful tastes or flavors as any of the other dishes - what happened??
In general all the food is what a food-lovah could want: depth in flavor, exquisite use of subtle textures and seasoning - wonderful. I'm coming back just for the duck!!

Wine: [4.5 stars] The selection was very small, considering there is a large variety in the dishes. However, all three glasses of wine we had were delicious and went well with our meals.. despite the high price. I suggest going in a larger group where you can split a bottle if this is a consideration.

Damage to the wallet: ~$100 (with 20% tip)
Overall experience: Must find a way to make more money to come back!
Damage to stomach: none, nothing was too sweet, too acidic or too heavy to make you feel like you ate too much or it wasn't good for you. Great balance in the dishes!!

Additional note: Waiter says he thinks the duck is #1 along with the foie gras and that the lamb is a very close second.
author: Acid B.

description:
Isa isa very very good. (Couldn't resist throwing in some Jar Jar Binks speak in there.) :D

But seriously, Isa probably has THE BEST Dine About Town selection I've seen. There were tons of options for all 3 courses - practically the entire regular menu was on there! 

Since there were so many choices, it made it hard to decide. But since the plates are all meant to be shared, we got two orders of the mussels, sauteed prawns and Tomales Bay 1/2 dozen oysters to start. 

For the second course, we spied what others around us were having and the halibut looked the best. Three of us got the halibut (which was indeed fantastic) and one flat iron steak. For some reason, the steak came out a good 15 minutes after the rest of us had already FINISHED our halibut. Obviously we were peeved about this (the experience was definitely 5 stars prior to this), but our server rectified the situation and offered a glass of wine on the house and let us choose our desserts from the regular menu.  

For dessert, we had the flourless chocolate cake (which was more like a fluffy souffle) and creme brulee. The amount of food was just right and we all left satisfied with the entire meal.

I've probably only been back to Isa less than a handful of times from my original review (wow, how my palate has changed! I could never do meat medium well again), but it's hands down, still my favorite restaurant in the Marina! They only have a wine and beer license though, so we had to continue our celebratory drinking elsewhere after dinner.

Take advantage of the daily $35 DAT dinner menu before it ends on 6/15. Otherwise, they do have a Monday-Thursday prix fixe menu which is an even better deal at $28 for 3 courses.
author: Connie C.

description:
Chef Luke Sung named his restaurant after his darling daughter, Isabel, and it's no wonder why this tiny bistro is a hit with their French tapas.  His training various top restaurants, such as being the garde-manger at La Folie, the vegetable guy at Masa's and the saucier at the Ritz Carlton Dining Room, has helped him create some interesting concepts for dishes.  

The one thing every French restaurant should have is good baguettes that are soft with a crinkly, crusty shell even if it's not baked fresh and bought elsewhere.  This is key for all the dipping dishes, such as the goat cheese and cleaning off the plates of the scallops with truffles and lobster boulllabaisse with the delightful sauces even if that is not good etiquette.  The sea of Cortez is a plate of succulent, jumbo prawns gone wild in terms of its size.  Usually, I'm a fan of duck, but this place presents it with a tender center and hard casing as if it was duck sausage or breast.  Although the sauces are at times too strong and salty for skirt steaks and seafood, the charming atmosphere of the candlelight dinners on high chairs keeps your spirits high and craving more with a wiff of all the sweet aromas coming from the kitchen.  

Finally, the best way to end your meal on a sweet note is with the creme brulee and flourless chocolate cake with vanilla bean ice cream.  The cake is so soft that it's like a souffle that will collapse once you take a bite.  The only thing that could top off the cake is a molten chocolate center.

Other than the flare that this restaurant brings to the Marina, this place is worth a try especially when there is street parking around the corner on Fillmore and lots near the Wells Fargo bank on Chestnut (between Fillmore & Steiner) and Pierce (between Lombard & Chestnut).
author: Jenny L.

description:
Every time I come to Isa I am blown away by the service and fantastic quality of the food they prepare. 

This has been my go to spot with the bf for every anniversary, Valentines and literally any other excuse we can find to enter goat cheese heaven. I cannot recommend this restaurant enough! If you're considering this as an option for a special occasion or romantic date, book it! Very classy ambiance inside, and the outside seating has lights strung up and is so sweet and romantic.

My boyfriend and I have a set menu we follow every time we come in. Everything is shared portions but not in a huge, gross Buca di Beppo kind of way.

We start with the butter lettuce salad and Baked Goat Cheese appetizer. I am obsessed with the goat cheese, it is absolutely incredible and melt in your mouth amazing. I....I can't even....just get it.

We always argue about which two main dishes to choose from out of our three favorites, which are the truffle/wild mushroom risotto (so cheesy and earthy), the spaghetti (amazing flavor and texture), and the SCALLOPSSSSS. mmmm... seriously seared to perfection. I can't even order scallops anywhere else because everything else is just disappointing after Isa's.

The semifreddo all' amaretto is divine. But seriously, you can't go wrong here. Everything is made with the freshest ingredients and I'm always so impressed by the service. They bring everything out as it is ready so you're constantly immersed in yummyness. Also, they don't judge us for our massive consumption of bread...which is a plus.

This review is 3 years overdue and I owe it to the good people of Isa to share with the world how heavenly their food is. When I move out of the city I'll still be here for every Valentines Day, without a doubt.
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
We ended up here because the Italian place around the corner (name???) was closed on Mondays.  I was slightly disappointed that it was ANOTHER tapas restaurant, since it was the theme of the vacation.  

The menu looked pretty good, but I opted for a salad and just nibbled at a few of the small plates.  The steak was cooked rare and, unfortunately, it did not fly with me.  We weren't really asked to specify, though, so I assume that was the recommend way of cooking.

Our waitress seemed to have a few fumbles of her own.  I am not sure whether she was new, or because it was a case of the Mondays, but she could not seem to get with it.  Fortunately, she was very nice, which made up for it.

Overall, not a fan, but since I don't live in SF, I don't have to worry about eating there regularly.
author: Damian C.

description:
We, my 24 year old daughter and boyfriend, had dinner at Isa last night.  We had a great time.
The fun was nicely presented and yummy.
author: Rob W.

description:
*8/3/10: Edited some minor grammar errors because typing reviews at 2 AM causes me to babble incoherently.

I love the Marina area as it reminds me of old, quaint SF with its rolling hills and antique houses.  T'was a nostalgic time where one could actually eat in the sunlight, unblocked by the mega-skyscrapers of Market St. that suck away luminescent happiness; much as the corporations within them drain the lifeblood of our nation... like Edward does to Bella in "Breaking Dawn" (OH WUT SPOILER LOL).

Our waiter was most amusing and informative.  After seating us, he embarked upon a nearly 20 minute lecture of the menu filled with a plethora of praises for each item such as "delightful", "heavenly", "most excellent", "most exquisite", "perfectly delightful", and "perfectly perfectly perfectly delightful".   I sat in rapt attention as he explained the origin and awesome-god-like power each dish held as if it was a holy relic in ancient history.  So in depth did he plumb, I felt quite abashed that I was not furiously taking notes about the palate-cleansing properties of the sorbet nor the number of peasants-now-migrant-workers it took to churn the fromage bleu à pâte persillée.  Such a build up thusly created high and lofty expectations of the subsequent food to come....

....and I was not disappointed! Isa is an exception to French cuisine due to the image one conjures of "French Cuisine": succulent food...but served in a quantity fit for a baby hamster.  Not so at Isa's!  Ordering from the fixed menu of $28, each person receives a choice of appetizer, entrée, and dessert.  Portions were enormous, fresh, and ,yes, perfectly perfectly perfectly delightful.  The salmon carpozzio (spelling? f*ck it I'm not that refined) was literally an entire plate enveloped by fillets of meat.  The mussels could barely fit within the bowl of champagne they were roasted alive in.

Oh and the potatoes! HEAVENLY SUBLIME POTATOES.  I highly suspect that there were no mashed potatoes with our entrées. Rather, the chef crushed a stick of butter into a mash consistency and served it right next to the roasted chicken.  Honestly, my flat iron steak was amazing, but if I could replace all appetizers, entrées, and desserts with Isa's mashed potatoes, I would do it in a heartbeat.

Overall, spectacular food. Very welcoming staff.  Somewhat pricy, but hey, it really can't be beat for the quality.

TL;DR: Ask the waiter to describe the mashed potatoes and if he doesn't spend at least 15 minutes explaining how they conquer the taste buds like Alexander did to Eastern Civilization, then you got gypped with the un-extended abridged version.  Subsequently request that all menu items be replaced with said mashed potatoes and water glasses only refilled with melted butter & gravy.
author: Gabe W.

description:
I know, I know. I'm a slow delayed yelper. I came here about six months ago in February for my birthday and had a party of 10. Despite making a reservation for 7:45PM, we didn't get seated until at least 30minutes later. Not surprised considering it was a Saturday night. The waiting area is also very tiny, like a mini walkway that easily obstructs the entrance.

We were seat in the back patio area. Decor was pretty cute, low light setting, bits of wooden furniture. The one downside was the flickering Christmas lights that couldn't make up its mind to stay on or shut down. It nearly gave me a headache!

Our server said that dishes were best served family style, but we weren't too keen about that, so everyone ordered for themselves or shared with a friend. I myself shared my meals with a friend, so we could sample more dishes. Dungeness crab salad was very fresh and light.  The Laurel chenel goat cheese was pretty good. I ate it together with bread and the cheese was quite flavorful. Truffle risotto was not so good. The rice was a hard and not flavorful. Lastly, the lamb was very juicy and packed with flavor.

This is a good place for couples or smaller groups, has nice ambiance, pretty location. I just wish the food could've been more memorable.
author: Jenny M.

description: This is a very good place! Very delicious food, fast and hight quality service and price really worth it! Decided to go here every week.
author: Oxana E.

description: Best restaurant ever. The only bad thing about it is that it's located over 1,500 miles away from where I live. The food was excellent and the staff was even better. I cannot wait to go back!
author: Amy M.

description:
It was my first time dining in the Marina district, and I loved it!  Isa is a busy restaurant, we went on a tuesday nite, but the restaurant was full both indoor and in the patio dining area.  After circling around the block for 10 minutes for parking, we made it to the restaurant rite on time for our reservation ( and got the 100pts from opentable.com  =)  ).
Even though it's tapas style, but the dishes were pretty filling.  To make it easier, i'll just rate it on a scale of 5 with 5 being the highest.

foie gras---------5!!! (they give u the actual chunk of foie gras, not the
                              mashed kind.  WOW the flavor is much more rich.
                               we asked for more bread to dip in the remaining
                               sauce and duck fat!)
duck breast-----4  (asked for medium rare, but it turned out to be
                                 medium well)
lamb tenderloin-------3  (taste was alrite, but it's nothing more than a
                                       lamb stir fry with vegetables)
 veal sweetbread--------4
vanilla bean gelato with expresso--------5 (the expresso made it much
                                                                           better taste.  And being the
                                                                           coffee addict that i am, i was
                                                                            hoping that it could help get
                                                                            rid of my headache from not 
                                                                            having coffee the whole day)
author: Tadaa T.

description:
So I went here for the dine about town menu and I think the food here is OK. 

Got here during the happy hour so our wine were $5 per glass which is not that bad. This place is really small since it's one of those small restaurants in marina. The hostess was nice and friendly, kindly greeted us and sat us to our table.

Since it was dine about town week, they were only offering the DAT menu, I was hoping they had the regular menu to see what else they had. So we started with the lobster soup and the leak soup, which i thought it was ok. Lobster soup kina smelled fishy, which i don't think it should be, but the chunks of the lobster was BIG. The leak soup wasn't anything special, just a typical leak soup, it didn't really wow me or anything but it was ok. For the second course, we had the crab salad and the Baked Laura chenel goat cheese, the crab salad was good, it tasted fresh and i think the portion was perfect for 2 people. The goat cheese was also not bad, it was like a spread for the bread. Oh, the bread they serve here i think is good. For the third course, I had the risotto and my friend had the steak. I think the steak was good, perfectly cooked in medium well, perfectly seasoned, the sauce was really good too. The potatoes that came with it and the zucchini was perfectly cooked and seasoned as well. The risotto was o-k. Taste wise it was good, but I think it should've cooked a little longer since I think the rice was slightly aldente, which should be cook all the way. For the dessert, got the creme brulee and the semifreddo amaretto. The Creme brulee was good, it had a perfect crust and the sweetness and the texture was just right For the semifreddo, it was ok, can't really tell if it was good or o-k so i would say it was ok, didn't really wowed me. 

Overall this restaurant was ok. I would give it 3.5 stars, not 3 stars or 4 stars but 3.5. It didn't really wowed me, I think it was just ok. I would probably come here only for the DAT menu.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
" Isa" sounds very Japanese so I thought that the place is a new sushi place but it isn't.

FRENCH.

My GF took me here the other night for my B-day dinner.
I've heard of the name for a long time but I've never been here before but she has.

So I was very excited about the night.
When we walked in, It was very dark in side, I was kind of dreaming that C3PO & R2D2 are going to see Jabba, beginning of Return of the Jedi.
The floor manager guy came up suddenly from the kitchen area, who looked like .... reminded me of Bib Fortuna, said, " would you like to sit in front or the back patio?"
I was like R2-D2, " Beep beep, patio sounds good."
.................
So, he took us threw the kitchen area to patio.
I was lookin' for a fat guy looks like Jabba but there wasn't.

It's a pretty big patio but I felt cozy at the same time.
We took a small table in the back.

On the drink menu, there are Soju cocktails.

I said, " Hey, look, there are Fu-Fu Drinks! Can I get it?"

My GF, " Whatthefxxx? Well, OK, it's your B day, what ever you like but you don't even like Soju. What's goin'on? but, doesn't matter, which one you like?"

Me, "Cosmo!"

My GF, " Say what?"

Me, " I say Cosmo!"

My GF, " That's the most Fu-Fu- Girly drink ever! Do you know what that even is?"

Me, " I don't know anything about it. But Cosmo sounds like Kramer. Btw, How about you?"

She said, " I'll have a Greyhound."

When my drink arrived, I was like, "Whatthefxxx I ordered?" because it's a pinkish purple drink.

My GF said, " Yup, That's what you ordered."

Fu Fu Soju drinks are gay, I mean fun. I liked it.

There was a special menu the night.
Sea bass rapped with sliced potato.
My GF said, " This was their signature dish here but for some reason it was removed from the menu over the years."
That was what my GF ordered.
I ordered flat iron steak.
We ended up sharing both.
The steak was perfect. Tender, juicy and great smokey flavor.
The sea bass was ..... phenomenon!
My GF told me that thin sliced potato rapping thing is very popular in French cuisine but I've never had it before.
It was a great combo between the crunchy thin potato and the juicy fat sea bass.

I'd like to mention that the waiters were all right-to-the-point professionals. They were very polite, funny, in and out, always eye contact, smile, asked us what we wanted and listened to what we asked.
I have to say that they also made our dinner great.

And, of course, to my GF, What a great B-day dinner! Thank you! I loved every single moment.

P.S., On the way out, I saw the floor manager guy again. He didn't look like the Bib Fortuna, Return of the Jedi at all. At all.
author: Nobu K.

description: 2 Words! Lobster Broth. Huge chucks of perfectly cooked lobster in a frothy foamy warm broth. There are definitely some hints of tomato mixed with some extra simmered selfish goodness. Other standouts at Isa are the the duck breast, salmon capriccio, tuna tartare, and the short ribs. Though they looked amazing, I would definitely skip on the day boat scallops. They just tasted very bland. One unique thing about Isa is the outdoor back patio area. Quite charming homey feeling though it can get a bit load there in the back. The service is superb and personable. We were told of a foie gras speak easy was happening at Isa but no signs of such thing happening. Maybe it's a secret.
author: Charlie L.

description:
Loved this place! Had one of the best dinners in years. Partly because of the food, the ambiance, the service and of course my amazing boyfriend!

Food: This place encapsulates what I love about French food that I feel many American French restaurants do not understand. And that is that the food is so amazing, well prepared and mouth watering that you do not need to inject intense flavors. The flavors of the meat and sauces speak for themselves. 
We had the duck and the steak which were some of the most succulent (not a word I use often!) meat dishes ever. All the sides and garnishes went perfectly with the palette of each dish. 

Ambiance: The back patio is my new favorite place. So cozy, trendy, romantic, yet unpretentious and very laid back. You could come here in normal clothes or a fancy dress and feel at ease. The lighting was perfect and even the table arrangements felt cozy but not crowded. 

Service: Very helpful and brought the food out in perfect timing. They even gathered several roses from the tables (we were one of the last couples there) and gave them to me as a farewell. 

Boyfriend: Major brownie points ;)
author: Lauren P.

description: I went here about a year ago for my birthday. Hands down the best duck you will have ever tasted! Owners were really sweet and treated us with glasses of dessert wine at the end of our dinner. Great service, fantastic food, what more can you ask for?
author: Rene L.

description:
This is a low five for the Sun-Thurs prix fixe

The arugula salad with citrus wedges (orange? tangerine?) and parmesan was high quality if unexciting. low 4 stars

The bread, which arrived after the salad, was slightly overdone. I hate burnt food taste. Oh, the waiter noticed I hadn't touched the butter and asked if I wanted oil and vinegar? No, thank you, but it was good service of you to ask.

The Alaskan halibut with olives, tomato, spinach, and I'm not sure what they were (some kind of bulb thingy) was out-of-this-world flavorful. 5 high stars

The Point Reyes blue cheese plate with red grapes and currants and a small basket of (not burnt) bread was so amazingly simple and so delightful. The blue cheese was intense and so good. Yeah, you're seeing it coming, 5 high stars for this. For f'ing cheese, bread and grapes.

$29.95 is a very good value for this meal.

No attitude for my not getting alcohol. Water glass kept full. No suggestion selling.

Service friendly. They warn on the menu that the food is delivered when it's ready, and true to their word, the fish arrived before I was done with the salad. Not a problem because the salad was already supposed to be cold, but could have been a problem if I had ordered two hot dishes, since I like my hot food hot.

Slight mishap at check paying time, but this happened at two different restaurants in the same week, so I might have to adjust my check-paying behavior.

The following takes a lot more words to explain than it is actually an annoyance, so please keep that in mind as you read this. It wasn't bad enough for me to withhold a star. But it does take away slightly from the overall experience, so I'm bringing it up:

The bill with tax was $32.57. (Yay! No hidden service charges.) I paid $40.57 (actually, come to think of it, I accidentally paid $40.52, but that's a small error.) The guy picking up the tab asked if I was set, and I misunderstanding what they were asking, said yes. Then my waiter noticed I was still sitting there and asked if I was waiting for change. (Props for a perceptive waiter! At the other place this happened they forgot about my existence.) When the change came, it came for $40. Not a big deal for this size of check, but mildly annoying. But it's the same thing that happened at the other place. As if they had to reconstruct what had happened once they realized I wasn't leaving the entire amount as payment + tip, and no longer remembered that there was change with the check.

I suspect it was my leaving the change that threw them off. So I guess I'll stop doing that and find a way to get rid of my change elsewhere.

As for how to avoid the problem in the first place, restaurants would do well to say "I'll bring your change" and leave it to the customer to say, "No, I'm set" if they mean to leave the entire return amount as tip.
author: Charles B.

description: the environment was nice, my girl friend and I were sitting at the table right next to the entrance, so we could do people watching.  The food was great!  The service was awesome!  I would come back next time!
author: Jen C.

description:
The style of the restaurant is more family style (or like larger tapas). Their menu suggests ordering about 2 dishes per person to share. Or they have a prix fixe meal (3 courses, but still dishes that are easily shared). I came during SF Chefs 2011 Restaurant Week. They had a special, where their prix fixe meal was served with a glass of wine.

We started with the mussels and the salmon carpaccio. Both were great. The salmon was very subtle and it was good quality fish. The mussels were a lot and very tasty. Good broth and bread to soak it up.

For the second course we got the chicken and the flat iron steak. The chicken had a crispy roasted skin (it includes a breast and a thigh) and was so juicy. The mashed potatoes that came with it were smooth and buttery. The flat iron steak was nice and rare, with roasted potatoes and green beans. The steak, while good, did not stand up to the chicken.

For dessert, we had the creme brulee and the semifreddo. Both were delicious - not terribly sweet or too large.

From sneaking a look at my neighbors, the arugula salad also looks amazing. I will definitely be back to try more of their plates.

Environment: The front room is quite small and dark. When I came, it was pretty crowded, so I highly suggest making reservations. There's not much waiting room, so I would not suggest it for large groups. It's casual, with a pretty friendly atmosphere. Great for a somewhat casual date.
Service: Our waiter definitely knew his stuff, but was not all that friendly. I don't remember ever being asked how things were going. But service was efficient. Dishes were removed promptly, water refilled, and the pacing of our meal was quite good.
author: Kailyn G.

description:
This is an excellent restaurant. I've been to a number of other restaurants in this lovely neighborhood and this tops them all. My sister had a nice small wedding reception here -- the main reception will come later. The staff was very attentive, the place was very clean and the tent held up well under heavy rain last evening; it did leak on the edge. (I had we've had enough rain in Bay Area for now!!!!) 

We ended up having most everything on the menu -- and shared it family style. The duck and the beef were outstanding. The staff was very understanding and accommodating -- as little children in our party were running around and special meals had to be prepared for them. 

I would say it's a great restaurant for any occasions.
author: Peace L.

description: Awesome back patio (tented) is romantic yet comfortable. Fantastic, and super friendly service. The french food is traditional but not stuffy. Full portions and wonderful flavors. Plenty of options for whatever you may feel like. I love this hidden gem. Definitely suggest for off the beaten path for San Francisco dining.
author: Nickers S.

description: We sat in the outdoor seating area out back. I went with the Rack of Lamb after seriously considering some of the seafood selections, and the lamb was delicious, well-prepared and flavorful. The trouble was that the staff forgot about my meal and I had to remind them to bring it out. This took some time, and I imagine they had to cook the lamb because they either didn't make it or they served it to someone else. By the time it arrived, my date was nearly finished with her fillet. And each time I moved my feet, the table shifted between two short legs.
author: L. E.

description:
Saw their DAT menu online and decided to go on the last day.  We couldn't get reservations because it was already booked!  So we just stopped by to give it a shot anyways.  They were jam packed full and said they only had the bar open.  That's fine for the two of us.  I didn't care to sit in the patio anyways...I was there for the food.

Some of the things on the DAT menu were different from what we saw online and the crab salad was not offered. O well, we tried something else.

We started off with the
SPICY TUNA CRUDO: the best i've had at any restaurant! This was our waiters FAVORITE dish.  I am so glad we tried it! As I mentioned in an earlier yelp. I love raw tuna and avocado.  The fish tasted so fresh with a dab of the soy...it melted in my mouth
and
SALMON TARTARE: it tasted fresh and I loved having it with their baked crunchy toast like bread, the capers added a little zest to it

then our entrees came
HALIBUT SPECIAL: out of the two entrees i liked this more. the fish was cooked to the right tenderness for my liking. went very well with the string beans and corn.
and
FLAT IRON STEAK: I've had better! I didn't think this dish was all that great, maybe because I'm not big on meat.  I felt that the meat was a little to bland and the meat was a little on the rough side!  The plate was too big for the amount of food that was actually on the plate.  This dish didn't impress me. sorry.

FOR DESSERT:
we had the CHOCOLATE CAKE with Vanilla Bean GELATO: This was DELICIOUS!! I loved that the cake was warm and fresh out of the oven, combine it with some ice cream and YUMMY!!! I couldn't get enough of it!!
we also had the CREME BRULE:  Personally, I thought the caramelized crunch was a little bit too think. I like it when its not too thick, but other than that we enjoyed the creme brule.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Ah- I came here when they had the Dine-About - TOwn. I brought my family here for dinner, celebrating my mom's b-day. They had the appetizers which were delicious,  main course which was a lil small for my father, for he eats a lot. Also the dessert was delicious. 
I am pretty happy overall, being the decor was really nice, and romantic, definite, a dating place to charm your sweet heart at.
author: Monika T.

description:
Went to Isa with a bunch of friends.  I normally don't like restaurants where you're supposed to share small dishes, because it gets awfully expensive and I never feel like I've gotten enough of the dish that I wanted.  However, this system worked well at Isa.  Portion sizes were generous enough, the food was easily shared and there were options to suit all of us, including the vegetarian in our group.  It did end up being a little spendy, especially once we started drinking, but the overall experience was worth it.

The atmosphere is comfortable and casual.  Service was great.  Our waiter was very friendly and made some good food and wine recommendations.  Some of the dishes I particularly liked: Northern Halibut a la Plancha, Potato-Wrapped Seabass, Asparagus Soup.

A word of caution:  Do not park in the Pierce St. parking garage when dining in the area at night.  First of all, a quarter will get you like 3 minutes, so unless you've got a purse full of rolled quarters, you'll need to go get some more.  Also, my car got broken into in this garage while I was dining at Isa.  There's no security here, and at night it's a magnet for thieves.  You've been warned.  There are lots of meters on the street around Isa (and mercifully, most take credit cards), so get there early and take your time finding one.
author: Erin L.

description: Food and service were great. Perfect place for a romantic dinner. (Sadly, the night we were there the loud drunk ladies next to us made it less so, but I suspect they are not there on most nights!)
author: Steve F.

description:
Two family members and I went to ISA last Thursday without reservations after online searches for a French Restaurant in San Francisco. My wife was initially concerned because oneline reviews she had read kept mentioning cheese platters. I do not see how we could be happier with the food or the service.

Salads: We shared two salads. Both were excellent, used fresh local ingredients combined with flair. 

Entrees: We shared mushroom risotto, Brussels sprouts with bacon, flat iron steak, lamb, new potatoes, green beans, spinach. The use of the different mushrooms in the risotto was very nicely done. The sprouts were excellent. The lamb as good as I have ever tasted. The sauce for the flat iron steak was rich and delicious.

Desserts: We fought over the double chocolate cake and the crème Brule.

We had lived in the Bay area several years ago, but I never had a French meal there as good as the one we had at Isa. When I visit next, I plan to go to ISA again.
author: Bill F.

description:
Came here with a group of six on a Friday night. We were seated promptly by the hostess in the garden out in the back. Our waiter was a bit pushy and told us that each person needed to order one entree and one appetizer. We were pretty hungry and ordered a lot of food. We also shared a bottle of wine.

* Butter lettuce salad with bartlett pears, candied walnuts, watercress & roaring forties blue - I really enjoyed it. It was very crisp and refreshing. Didn't hurt that they mostly used the heart of the lettuce.
* Arugula salads with mandarines, fuji apples, fennel, lemon vinaigrette and reggiano - It was good, although I don't remember tasting any fennel in there.
* Calamari with honey spice, flageolet beans, lemon zest & arugula - I only had one piece and it was pretty nondescript and a bit tough.
* Scallops with sauteed asparagus, mashed potatoes & truffle sauce - It was one of the favorites of the night. The scallops were perfectly cooked -- caramelized on the outside and tender on the inside. The sauce didn't overwhelm the delicate flavor of fish.
* Truffle risotto with baby shiitake, hon shimiji mushroom & reggiano - It was creamy and unlike some other places, the rice wasn't under cooked. The aroma of the fungi was intoxicating, so luxurious!
* Rack of lamb with sautèed eggplant, zucchini, red peppers, nicoise olives & lamb jus - this was my favorite of the night. The lamb was so tender and flavorful, not gamey at all. The meat is cooked to perfection, if it were cooked a little less, it would be stringy; a little more, it would be tough.
* Duck breast with bacon, baby spinach, pinenuts, raisins, sherry & vinaigrette sauce - like the lamb, the meat was cooked perfectly. The skin wasn't as crispy as I would have liked though.
* Flatiron steak with zucchini, fingerling potatoes, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce - This is a pattern, but all the proteins at Isa are handled with care and spectacular.

By the end of the meal, we were too full for dessert. All in all, the place is very good, although I thought the food lacked imagination, pizazz.
author: Alice W.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate there Thursday night on a whim walking by, and we were surprised and delighted. 

We decided on the prix fix menu, and both had the salmon carpaccio, one of us ordered the truffle risotto, and the other the flat iron steak. We shared. There was happiness. 

We drank a bottle of wine, I would love to say I remembered what it was, but the couple that was leaving as we were sitting said it was delicious, and they had ordered pretty much what we planned on eating, so...when in Rome... slainte!

I plan on returning to Isa to try out the rest of the menu for sure!
author: Kelly W.

description:
I have nothing but great things to say about this spot.. Came here with 3 other people for a friends birthday.. ordered a bunch of food and just ate it family style.. everything we had was amazing and the service was on point! 
1. yellow fin tuna: Fabulous, fresh, amazing flavors.. spicy, but calmed by the sesame and seaweed.. presentation is also beautiful.
2. grilled calamari: lite, pleasant, nice balance of flavors, and a new twist on a regular on most menus
3. spaghetti:  again top notch.. and it was a vegetarian option! truffle oils and tomatoes had a great mix together and produced something memorable which is hard to do with a regular spaghetti dish.
4. potato wrapped sea bass: just get this people... wow! wow! we were fighting over this
5. pork chop: came with 3 on the plate.. and i don't eat pork.. but the 3 people at my table loved them.. came on the bone.. looked pretty
6. heirloom tomato salad:  this was mostly me eating this.. fresh, firm tomatoes, delicious balsamic glaze and fresh basil
7. creme brulee:  looked good, didn't touch it thought because i was eating the..
8. flourless chocolate cake with vanilla gelato:  yum.. i love chocolate and i love gelato.. this was win in my book
9. 2 bottles of wine and 1 bottle brought by me... all three were amazing, however since we had 3 of them.. the names escaped me! 
AWESOME! TRY THIS SPOT! I CAN'T WAIT TO GO BACK
author: Ashley M.

description:
Made reservations for 5 people at 7:30PM. When we hit the Richmond from the Sunset, friend realized she forget to get her ID, so had to go back to get it (wasn't for this, but for after). Well...the birthday girl and another were here on time, while the rest of us came in around 8:15?

When we arrived in the area, there was NOOOO PARKING!!! Parked 2-3blocks away, normally i can walk over an hour without breaking too much of a sweat, but today I wore HEELS. 2-3 blocks...that was kind of hard, and it was sprinkling...I guess it wasn't too bad, it wasn't pouring.

NO PRIX FIX MENU ON FRIDAY, that sucks. We had to order from the regular menu. Remember this place serves family style. We ordered...Salmon Tartare, Seared Dayboat scallops, flat iron steak, sole meuniere, prawns, & creme brulee. I don't know what I liked the most...but the bread is on the top of the list along with the butter they
had. Steak came with potatoes, potatoes had rock salt on it, so that was not very nice, made it too salty. Creme brulee had a thick top layer, which was nice but the inside wasn't as warm as I would have liked.

Split between 4 people, I left $35. I don't know if I'd come again, since it's not near my hood & PARKING WAS UGHHH.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Absolutely amazing experience with Isa - Dine About Town. Isa is known for their family-style french cuisine. Although some resteraunts post their pre-fix menu to be very limited choices for the $35 dinner DAT, Isa give you so many options!!! Our party of 6 devoured the amazing dishes and went home fat and fluffy :)
If you're here, I highly recommend the Baked Goat Cheese for appetizer and the Halibut for the entree. De-li-cious mmmm.
author: Kumiko N.

description:
Great place for a bday dinner. Requested covered patio seating for 6:30 on a Thursday. The main dining room is business-like, simple yet uptight almost... Walking through and out into the patio, can't help but go "whoa...", like watching Avatar the first time around... You walk in and the place is very comfy, pleasantly lit with strings of xmas lights, and sufficiently warm with heat lamps; superb even with pouring rain outside.

We could've done the 3-course prix fixe meal for each of us, but that didn't include the option of scallops nor seabass... so then...

Bread and butter starter.  It is what it is folks. 

Dungeness crab salad was absolutely delicious. FRESH. The avocados and apple pieces played well with the crab meat... AND holy crap, there is no mayo in the salad! Well done, well well crafted... the Lady loved this dish the most, I can't really argue with her either...

Then the mussels: good, but I've had better. The portion was generous, but was hoping for a bit more flavor really, either from the mussels themselves or the broth... 

My other favorite dish had to be the scallops.  Five grilled scallops on a bed of buttery mash potatoes, topped with asparagus spears.  Asparagus is difficult to mess up; either you overcook them or you don't. These were perfect, of course.. The mash potatoes were great; don't remember ever having potatoes this good. Must have been all the butter in it.. And the scallops, juicy and tender. Reminded me of lobster in terms of flavor, tofu in terms of firmness.  Really amazing dish. The only drawback (kinda) was the small pool of butter from the remaining potato mash.  Women get turned off by this... Guess there's more for me then, sweeet..

The seabass was good, but can't agree with the establishment that this was their best item. Kinda overcooked in my opinion. The potato skin wrap supplied most of the flavor to the dish. It's really freakin delicious potato skin I have to say, but expected the seabass to play a bigger role in the dish.

Creme brulee dessert with candle and a familiar sing-a-long for the Lady. Simple festivity, adoring recipient. Wish I had steadier camera hands.. doh!

Two coffees. Normally, I never drink coffee at the end of a dinner, it makes no sense. Shouldn't a meal start with coffee??  Nevertheless, never let a Lady drink alone... ok wow, its actually great-tasting, non-starbucks, delicious brewed coffee! Keeps the night warm..

Ok, so with two big hits in the dungeness and scallops, and two subtle misses in the mussels and seabass, why do I place Isa in the 5-Star echelon?

Give it up for Dean. Best server in the world. He was working the patio along with his runner, was always open to random chit chat, never seemed to be in a rush to turn the table. Knew everything about the restaurant front and back, wasn't the scripted upseller, and spoke from the heart. Kept me and the Lady smiling the entire evening.You gotta meet him. Ask him something in French. Shake his hand. Thank me later.

I wish all dining experiences from here on out could be this memorable.
author: Ethan L.

description: Off to a great start with the yellowfin tuna tartare and Dungeness crab salad. Tartare was delish! Remarkably fresh tuna. Entrees don't come out of the kitchen at the same time but are presented "family style" and are meant to be shared. Not sure if I entirely liked the idea for the particular type of food being served. Seared scallops were cooked well, but the side of corn, fava beans, potato puree, and truffle oil was the real winner for me. Potato wrapped sea bass was good, especially loved the crispy potato wrapping. Good food overall, with a few memorable components from some of the dishes.
author: Sophia B.

description: Gluten free and very happy! Some of the best food I have ever eaten! I tried the chicken, beef, mashed potatoes, asparagus, goat cheese, mushrooms, Crème brûlée and the flourless chocolate cake along with a couple cocktails and everything was delicious. It's kind of a tight squeeze inside but I didn't mind the staff was great and we were seated right away without a reservation. I highly recommend this place. Please note that I don't usually ask if the food I'm ordering is gluten free I use my best judgement and hope that I don't get sick. Also I have severe gluten allergies not celiac disease.
author: Onna S.

description: I came on a weeknight with some coworkers and I thought this place was great! The food was good and at a very decent price, and the service was also great (which is sometimes hard to find). Anyway, I ordered the tasting menu that came with 3 courses for $30! Not bad for a French restaurant! (although the food didn't exactly seem like French cuisine) I got an appetizer, main dish, and dessert. Everything was delicious and I was very satifisfied.
author: Iris L.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars because the food was heavenly, but the service my table had was pretty much some of the worst service I've had at a fine restaurant in my life.

I'll start with the bad - our server seemed quite overwhelmed, and I grant that the restaurant was very busy. He forgot to bring one person's glass of wine for about twenty minutes. He forgot to take our food order for equally as long, and actually started to take away the menus before we let him know that we had not, in fact, told him what we wanted to eat. Possibly the most awkward interaction I had with the waiter was when I went to order the arugula salad. I was to share the salad (they encourage sharing on the menu) with my friend who's allergic to dairy, and she had called ahead to make sure they would allow substitutions based on dietary restrictions (they said yes), so I asked for no goat cheese. The waiter said that would be entirely impossible due to the restaurant week menu, so my friend had to explain that she had called ahead about this, etc. At this point he said that only she would be allowed to order without goat cheese, so she ordered the salad and I ordered the appetizer she was going to get... talk about overly complicated and frankly annoying.

Anywho, the food itself was incroyable. I had the potato and leek soup, which was really nice though a bit thicker than I expected, and I also sampled the lobster broth soup. Hooray soup.

I then had the arugula salad - very fresh, light - and mussels - some of the tastier mussels I've had in SF. For main course, I did the seared scallops - perfectly cooked - that came with creamy mashed potatoes and Brussels sprouts. There was also bacon on the plate, but it seemed kind of unnecessary to me. I tasted the steak, too, which was really tender, though by that point I was stuffed. I had the grapefruit granite for dessert, but I should have gone with the ice cream dish.

This is the kind of place I'll take my parents when they visit SF, but it was fun to do the restaurant week menu with a group of friends. A bit more $$ than I usually spend on dinner, but it was a nice Tuesday treat.
author: Kristina C.

description:
Somehow managed to get a reservation for Isa for a group of 4 at the last minute, and I was very happy with the result. The group is an experienced diner/foodie squad who have eaten in excellent restaurants around the world.

Summary: Everything was surprisingly delicious. Really blown away by the quality and attention to detail. I struggled with 4 or 5 stars, but I reserve 5 stars for 'best restaurants of all time' experiences ... and Isa was close. Somewhat unusually, the mains out-shined the apps although all were excellent.

Appetizers:
 - Oysters. Lovely. Local west coast bad boys from Point Rayes that were perfectly fresh with a snappy mignonette.
 - Baked goat cheese. Perfect texture and temperature, melty smooth.
 - Tuna tartare. A bit spicy from peppers, silky, soft and with a nice bite the way perfect tuna has to be. A gorgeous red color to complement the table.
 - Crab salad. Very tasty and light.
 - Mixed salad. Tasty but not special.

Mains:
 - Scallops. Absolutely perfectly cooked, with fresh bright brussel sprouts and bacon for complementary flavors and textures. I only shared because I had to.
- Potato-wrapped bass. House signature dish and worthy of the name. Fantastic presentation and delicious
 - Duck. Best duck I've ever had, and that says a lot. These people know how to handle meat.
 - Lamb Roast. Special for the night, and it came out with a dark, glistening glaze, fell off the bone and had the lamb lovers fighting over the scraps.

Service: Attentive, a little overly enthusiastic, but we thought it was cute.
Price: Typical for a mid-scale restaurant, food quality similar to much pricier restaurants.
Wine list: Minimal as others have mentioned. If this is important, bring your own special bottle.
Desserts: Adequate, but not the focus.

Tips:
  - Sit in the back room if you can. it's the most spacious and not as noisy as the front area. A little cold (it's a covered outdoor space with heat lamps), but I was very comfortable on a cold winter night . 
 - Give yourself a little extra time to park. Parking in this neighborhood (especially on a Friday/Saturday night) can be pretty annoying.
author: Richard F.

description:
Happy Birthday Mom! We hardly ever venture to the Marina - too many good places in my hood. But Mom insisted since my cousin recommended it. So glad I trekked over! SO GLAD.. What a charming place! We sat in the back - outside covered with heat lamps. The servings are small - served family style. The waiter was fantastic! So engaging, personable and spot on with all his recommendations. I forget his name but we was a super nice Asian man. 

Grilled calamari - amazing, I dont think I've ever had it grilled like this.. highly recommend it! HIGHLY..
Foie Gras - rich, decadent, melts in your mouth
Truffle Risotto - sometimes when you order something with truffle in it, its hard to taste the truffle, which is disappointing.. not this time.. it was perfect
Maple Leaf farm duck - a total hit!
Flat Iron Steak - Cooked to perfection

We ordered too much but ate every last piece.. perfect place for a bday celebration.
author: Monica S.

description:
Always a good meal to be had here.  I've never left a meal here unsatisfied.  The service is always good, no matter how crowded it gets (props to all the attentive supporting wait staff).  

On to the food!  The portion sizes are generous for tapas style sharing but I've been known to order something specifically just for myself (boyfriend hates mushrooms and I always get the truffle risotto...sometimes it's okay to be selfish).  My favorites (risotto does not a meal make) include the flat iron steak, butter fish in parchment paper (pretty sure this is not on their regular menu), scallops, sea bass, and duck.  They usually have a very nice selection of oysters too.  You really can't go wrong with a meal at Isa.
author: Chanthi L.

description: This place was amazing! Great service and food, will definitely be back soon.
author: Britani J.

description:
Usually don't write reviews for established institution with more than 20 reviews but this restaurant was special enough for me to make this exception. 

It was my wife's b-day and I totally made a last minute reservation at Isa.  All my request was accommodated by the staff and I was very pleased.  

Food wise, we ordered the maine lobster soup and it was delicious as expected.  The sea essence was calibrated just right allowing the flavor of the shrimp to peek through.  Foie gra is a MUST as the portion and taste was out of this world.  But I would recommend skipping the wine pairing because the wine white was a bit too sweet for my taste.  Potato wrapped seabass was tender and tasty.  Truffle Scallop was again a plate clearing affair, they were black truffle bits everywhere.  Although they claim to be a tapas restaurant, all the entrees were big enough to be shared with two people.  

We made reservation through Open Table so we were not able to take advantage of the Happy Hour Drink special.  Since we ordered heavier entrees, the last dish was a bit rich in taste so make sure you order appropriately.   

For the price to value stand point, this French restaurant is nearly unbeatable.
author: Hing W.

description: Took advantage of SF Restaurant Week - first time dining here and we were very impressed with the prix fixe menu and quality/taste of the food. I don't know if it was intentional, but our plates arrived one at a time so we ended up just sharing everything. FIrst course of potato leek soup and arugula salad with apples, mandarin oranges and parmesan. Second course of steamed mussels and salmon carpaccio. Entrees of seared scallops and brussel sprouts and flank steak with haricot verts, asparagus and a bleu cheese butter sauce. Finished with vanilla crème brulee and semifreddo all'amaretto (kind of like a light ice cream cake - tasted a lot like tiramisu). We also added in warm foie gras served with a kind of strawberry jam and brioche bread. Throughout the meal our servers were very attentive constantly refilling our bread and butter basket, water, and changing out our plates and silverware as needed. Wonderful meal from start to finish - the first two courses were perfect teasers to the main courses and the desserts cleansed the palate perfectly without being too sweet or heavy. We sat in the front room of the restaurant which was a little bit cramped and got very loud once full - we had to raise our voices at times to be heard. Still, our dining experience was overall great and we'd definitely come back here for another round.
author: Elaine W.

description:
I came here with the hubby and kids and had a wonderful evening.  We had just gone to the Exploratorium and were looking for a place to have dinner.  Love good food, but we needed someplace where the kids, ages 7 and 10, would be welcome.

We were seated right away, and the staff was very friendly and welcoming.  We shared the butter lettuce salad, mussels and lobster broth to start with.  The salad was tender and well dressed, the kids loved the mussels, and there were very generous portions of lobster in the broth.  Then we dined on the sea bass, spaghetti, and duck breast.  They were all excellent!  The hubby and kids thought the sea bass with its crispy potatoes was best.   I fell in love with the crispy well seasoned duck.  Yum!

The staff that evening (12/28/12) was really on.  I cannot stress how welcome they made me feel.  The food came in a timely fashion, empty dishes were cleared, and water was refilled regularly.  There was a little mix up on our bill which was fixed right away.  We had  a wonderful evening at Isa, and will come again soon to experience other items on their menu.
author: Sandy L.

description:
Came here for father's day dinner because my parents wanted to try French food.  I chose the place because there were significant amount of reviews on yelp and had 4 stars.  Sadly, i was disappointed. With that many reviews on Yelp and high ratings from everyone else, I expected good French cuisine. *sigh* This was the first French restaurant I have been to since moving back to San Francisco, someone PLEASE tell me that the French food here is better than this place!!!!.. PLEASE!!!!! 

Ok, i make this place sound horrible. Don't get me wrong, I didn't think the food was bad but it was just not amazing or great or good.... It was simply, for the lack of words, EH. Nothing left an impression so for my usual "MUST HAVE LIST" I will have to leave blank.  Another thing I did not like about the restaurant was how everything is done family style/ tapas.  For certain dish that's fine but seriously if you order entree like dishes it just DOES NOT make sense to break up the presentation and do it family style. I understand that this way everyone can try a little of something but it ruins the presentation and some dishes ie the fish is just not meant to be shared!!!!

"WHAT WE ORDERED" :
1. Lobster Broth - it was very runny and not very heavy at all. the taste was ok.  tasted more like tomato soup to me.  

2. Foie gras - The only dish that I thought was pretty good.  Not because the Foie gras was super good quality but the way it was prepared with the peaches.  pretty yummy

3. Halibut - My sister had this and as i said before it is definitely not a dish that can be shared. If you cut into a fish like that it will just fall apart and everyone will get like one bite. I stuck a piece of the fish and thought it was seasoned well but once again nothing special

4. Duck breast - this was my dish. the duck lack flavor even with the sauce. However, it was cooked just the way i liked it, so not overly cooked.  

5. lamb rack - I like lamb and can take the gaminess of it but this was a bit too gamy for me.  It tasted fine but a bit too gamy.  My Dad like it so thats what matters!!!!

6. Sweetbread - very heavy. sweetbread itself is not something that is light and the sauce that it was in and the mash potato just made the dish very heavy.  My mom like it till the end when she couldn't finish it.  

OVERALL: The service was ok. I appreciate how they acknowledge the dads with a glass of desert wine.  It was very nice of them.  The food was EH but the price was pretty decent for French food.  Our bill came up to be ~150 w/ tip +tax for 4 people.  I am not sure if I would come back....
author: JY L.

description:
This is a review for their Dine About Town meal.
We came with a reservation for a party of 6 and were promptly seated.  The table we got probably only seated 4 comfortably but getting cozy with close friends did not bother any of us. The dinner prix fixe menu has a choice of 8 dishes each for the 2nd and 3rd courses, so we decided to eat family-style and have everyone have a taste of twelve different dishes. We also ordered a bottle of sauvignon blanc to go with our food.
All of us started with the lobster broth which was very tasty and perfect for dipping the bread. The second courses that stood out were the salmon carpaccio, the yellowfin tuna tartare, and the baked goat cheese. The third courses that were exceptional were the seared scallops, duck breast, and flat iron steak, and the shortribs. The shortribs, which was a special addition to the menu that night, was probably the best dish. It tasted like it was slow-cooked then charred on the outside, which gave it a smoky, crispy outside and tender meet on the inside.
I don't say this often, but nearly everything was delicious.
Service was fantastic and the atmosphere was intimate yet relaxed.
author: Alfred L.

description:
I chose this place for DAT mainly for the variety in the pre fixed menu. We had really great friendly, quick, and speedy service from bread refills to getting our check.  The bread was so warm and crunchy!  The heated lamps out on the covered patio made me forget it was raining outside.

We really enjoyed our meals that had good size portions and everything was very flavorful.  I especially liked how we made it in time for $5 happy hour drinks on a Saturday!  The #7 drink with ginger and blackberries was surprisingly tasty considering the combo.

We would definitely come back to try their non DAT menu.  Parking can be tricky but its worth the search to try Isa's.
author: Kit L.

description:
So it's been three years...and i definitely need to update my review. This place is amazing and over the years, i have visited quite often and was satisfied with every meal. I LOVE IT HERE! 

Sitting out in the courtyard gives your dining experience a romantic feel. Well at least for moi...;)
author: Maria S.

description:
It's a decent place. I like that they have the whole $35 (or whatever the price is now) for the three courses. It's a good deal for decent food. Tasty and satisfying. I would definitely go back. 

Highlights- the bread (warm and yummy) and the mussels (dips that warm bread into the sauce it's great!) 

Steak was good but a little rare for my taste, but good nonetheless. Grapefruit granita was refreshing, but nothing wow.
author: Rose T.

description:
I had the pleasure of dining at Isa last Saturday while on vacation in my old stomping ground of San Francisco. My mom and I took two of my girlfriends out to dinner to celebrate my dear friend (yelp name AudyV) who is not only 7 months pregnant with her first baby, but it was also her 31st birthday.  Conveniently we arrived during Dine About Town, and for $230 had a fantastic 4 course meal with delicious wine for 4 ppl.  
The aesthetic in the back "patio" is gorgeous.  I was actually surprised how warm it is under the heatlamps and we even had to turn ours off at one point! So it is definitely the best if both worlds out there given the unique indoor/outdoor space.  I can't believe I lived 3 blocks from Isa for 4 years and never dined here as a local.
Anyway the food was just divine.  I had the potato leek soup which was creamy with robust flavors, but not heavy at all.  The others at my table ordered the shrimp in lobster broth and neither of us had a drop left in our bowls.  
For the second course, most of us ordered salads although we were amazed by the wide variety of offerings, most of which included some form of seafood.  I had the butter lettuce salad with goat cheese and I could eat that delicious light and flavorful salad every day.
For the main course I had the chicken and mashed potatoes that were far from ordinary.  This dish was on par with something you would get at One Market or Town. I snuck a few bites of Audy V's truffle risotto and I swear, I teared up a little when I tasted the insane flavor punch.  I will dream of that risotto....
For dessert we had the gelato dish, the grapefruit icy sorbet and the creme brûlée.  My gelato was the winner, and the grapefruit was not our fave.
Most of all, the best part of Isa is the service.  Our server Justin was simply incredible.  He made great suggestions for wine that both suited our palettes and our budget.  He was patient, kind, attentive without being overbearing, and absolutely made our evening.  
The only possible negative was the timing of the meals, although Justin was careful to set our expectations properly.  Because Isa is typically a Tapas restaurant, the timing of the courses is really sporadic, so many of us received our dishes at different times.  We kept having to remind everyone to begin eating and forgo the tradtion of waiting to eat until everyone's been served.  So that was a little confusing and frustrating t times, but otherwise an A+.
Well done and thank you Justin for being a part of our wonderful evening!
author: Christine S.

description:
I went to Isa friday night with my boyfriend for Dine About Town. We had a reservation for 7 PM and were seated within 5 minutes. 

The service, needless to say, is very quick. I appreciated that, considering how hungry I was. The portions are generous as well, as each dish is served family style. We had the baked goat cheese and steamed PEI mussels for starters. For the main entree, flat iron steak and truffle and shittake mushroom risotto. Everything up to dessert was fantastic. 

I didn't really like vanilla creme brulee all that much. To be honest, while I was eating it, I thought to myself that I'd rather get a cup of vanilla bean creme brulee from the creme brulee cart. 

Overall, a wonderful dining experience for my boyfriend and I. We had leftover risotto to take home because we were just way too full at that point.

Isa's also in a very great location. Plenty of shops and cafes to hang around if you arrive early for your reservation. I'd definitely come back again.
author: Patricia Q.

description: Had dinner with my father for father's day. Great service. Food was well prepared. Ahi tuna and smoked salmon appetizer was fresh. We had mushroom risotto, white corn soup and scallops. Excellent. We actually ordered an extra soup to take home. We brought a bottle of wine. Corkage fee was $20. I will go back again. Recommended. Only issue is parking.I recommend doing to the garage on the next block, much less stressful than fighting for street parking.
author: andy w.

description: This is an interesting place to eat,  you order one or two items each, and share.  The food was very good, the veggie sides where wonderful & fresh.  That is always a big plus for me.  Deserts we all ordered were perfect.  Wonderful gem of a place, in a great neighborhood too.  Our waiter was very friendly & hepful.
author: Winny S.

description:
Bam! Five stars.

Here's why.

Service: 

From start to finish...impeccable. We arrived an hour before our reservation time. Knowing that most likely we'd need to go grab a drink elsewhere and just return at our scheduled time, we popped in to inquire just on the off chance that there was a table available for the three of us. The hostess let us know that there was a table finishing up but that it would most likely be about 15 minutes; she then personally escorted us over to an open spot at the bar and put us in the capable hands of the bartender. Who was fantastic! The hubs asked if they had Guinness and they did not, but the bartender suggested an alternative beer and described it so delectably that of course, we ordered one. Personable beyond belief. Our server, well, he was among the best parts of the evening. He explained the "rules of the road" and let us know that Isa recommends that each person at the table order one appetizer and one entree, and then everyone splits everything as the orders arrive. We were cautioned that things would arrive to the table as they came out of the kitchen (so, we didn't expect all three apps to land at the same time, or even before the entrees, etc.) and that was just fine with us! He also went into detail on the specials and took the time to make several specific recommendations. In the course of our initial conversation (and it was a conversation!) he let us know the correct pronunciation of the restaurant's name (EEE-sa) and let us know the story behind it (named for the chef's daughter Isabelle). Just a side note for any Yelpers thinking of trying Isa - 1. highly recommend it. 2. it's a California French style, not strictly French as categorized on Yelp. Not a huge thing, but it is definitely not purely French. Personally, the Californication of the food makes for a phenomenal product. Lastly about our knowledgeable, grin-inspiring server before I start in on the food: in the course of our conversation he came out with a from-the-gut laugh that was irreverent! It was one of those laughs that just makes you laugh as well. His laugh left all of us giggling along with him long after he'd left the table.

Food:

We followed protocol and ordered three appetizers and three entrees, along with one side dish. First up: Tomales bay Pt Reyes oysters (6 oysters on the half shell with spicy orange mignonette). Fresh oysters are hard to mess up, but the orange mignonette really took them over the top into sublime territory. Next came the Yellowfin tuna with spicy sriracha, toasted sesame, seaweed, avocado, nori and low sodium soy. Fresh, bright flavor! The clean flavor of the tuna was nicely offset by the mellow creaminess of the avocado. Yum! Our third appetizer was the Dungeness crab salad with avocado, apple, grapefruit & tarragon. Once again, a perfect symphony of complementary ingredients. The mellow of the crab was balanced with the creamy avocado and sweet apple, then perked up by the grapefruit and tarragon. C'est magnifique.

Our entrees began to arrive next. Our first entree was the Seared scallops with sautéed asparagus, garlic & truffle sauce. Four seared scallops were arranged on the plate with a mound of what may have been whipped potatoes topped with several spears of asparagus and drizzled with truffle sauce. The flavors came together beautifully and the truffle flavor was nicely subtle. We actually ordered a side dish of asparagus as well, not realizing that the scallops came with asparagus, but believe me, every stalk of asparagus on the table was eaten and enjoyed. The next entree to arrive was Seasonal Fish (halibut) with artichokes, tomato confit, olives, basil & zucchini. Delicious! Our final entree was the Potato wrapped Seabass with capers, fresno peppers, parsley, tomato confit, brown butter and lemon juice. The dish was excellent, but I am a sucker for anything brown butter so it put the entree over the top.
