Our server (also our busboy and our host) seemed to disappear into the darkness and reappear only when he was needed.  If you want to have a quiet conversation with a friend without being interrupted, it's what I call "perfect service."  I wouldn't call our server particularly knowledgeable, but his timing was perfect.

I went for the $28 prix fixe, which is a pretty amazing value for a fine French meal.  I started with baked goat cheese . . .  Why have a salad when you can get something fatty as your appetizer?  That's my motto.  The goat cheese was served in a pool of oil with tomatoes, pesto and pine nuts.  The goat cheese was really good, but I could have done without all that oil.  

For my second course, I ordered the angus steak with potatoes.  The steak, of course, was very small, but I expected that.  It was perfectly prepared and incredibly soft and juicy.  The waiter asked me "is medium rare OK?" when taking my order.  Since I order all my steaks medium rare, I was pretty excited.  The potatoes were very similar to au gratin (although they were called something else), and I love au gratin potatoes.  These were baked perfectly, although they needed just a pinch of salt.

The third course was dessert, and I went for Semifreddo all' Amaretto.  I arrived at Semifreddo by process of elimination: there were 4 desserts available to me, but two of them were cheeses and one of them was a grapefruit something-or-other.  Since my meal started with a cheese course, I felt like it needed to end differently.  Grapefruit is a big no-no in my book, so . . . Semifreddo it is.  Semifreddo, I believe, means "half cold" in Italian.  It was a serving of cold whipped cream with Amaretto liqueur and almonds.  So many almonds!  The taste of almonds, mixed with the taste of Amaretto, was a bit overwhelming.  I ate 2 of the 3 mini-biscotti decorating the plate, too.  It was a nice way to end the meal.

While the food at Isa is neither outstanding nor particularly original, there is something to be said for great value.  $28 at Isa goes a long way towards impressing your date or your parents.  If I had to break it down, I'd say 5 stars for the value and 3 stars for the food.
author: Yan G.

description:
Highly recommended restaurant for a great price... Price fix is awesome!
Good food and nice portions that will make you full. Grapefruit shaved ice was good.

+'s - price is very good, food is tasty, nice atmosphere

-'s - When I went here a few months back, I made a reservation for 2. When I got there, i remembered that they had a patio and I asked to be seated there. The waiter said "No" and I asked why and he just said because it is closed.. Closed? I saw people going back there through the whole night... Whatever, I didn't have to see the waiter for the rest of the evening so it was good.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Outdoor seating with a canopy and heatlamps. Felt like we were indoors. Very nice.

Waiter was working hard for his tips. Selling us bottles and bottles of wine, which some of us fell for.

We had a little of everything, tapa-style:

Pt. Reyes Oysters - Fresh oysters, can't go wrong.
Crab salad - Nothing special, plenty of mayo.
Foie Gras - Get some before they're banned!
Potato wrapped seabass - Delicious, melts in your mouth.
Rack of lamb - Perfectly cooked, will order again.
Flat iron steak - Not bad.

They have a prix fix menu as well, if you prefer.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
This last weekend was my second time here. I was here with a large group and so was the first time. This is a great place for large parties, as the food is reasonably priced and can be somewhat dressy or not. so everybody can feel comfortable coming here whether you are in jeans or cocktail dress. 

My husband and I shared four appetizers and two entrees. 
- salmon capaccio: I thought the salmon would be really thin, but it's actually on the thick side. it was delicious though. 
- asparagus soup: this was disappointing, not too much flavor
- foie gras: my husband thought it was just a little bit cold in the center. I thought it was just excellent. good portion and good flavor. it wasn't the best I've had, but this isn't one of those really expensive French place. I guess it could've been more tender. they are doing a "good bye to foie gras" deal, for $15. it's a great deal, makes me want to go back there before I have to say good bye to it. 
- some sort of salad: I forgot which one, but it was good. 
- lamb chop: the waiter asked me if we wanted 4 chops to share instead of the 3 chops that normally came with the dish. I said just 3 would be fine, since it's my husband's dish and I just wanted a bite. but when the dish came, with the large group and some people getting 4 chops, there was a extra 4 chops dish and we ended up with it. We didn't know we had to pay extra for the extra chop. oh, well, I just wish it didn't work out that way. Otherwise the lamb chop was good. 
- potato wrapped seabass: I was deciding between that and the fish of the day. I'm glad I picked the seabass. I like the crispy potato contrasting with the soft texture of the seabass and it was cooked just right.
- creme brulee: very good, lots of vanilla beans and excellent sugary crust on top. 

Our friends also got the crab salad, which they said was really good. I also tried the mushroom risotto and pasta from other people's dish, the risotto was great and the past was just ok.  There was happy hr on the drinks on a saturday, which was awesome. I'm pregnant, so it's sad I can't have any. 

Oh, yes, my husband and I ordered a lot of food and we ate it all. I was very full at 8 months pregnant. so I would order less food normally. I would say one appetizer, one entree and one dessert per person is enough. If you have a large group, you should definitely share appetizers as there are so many good ones to try. 

We were told that we had to be kicked out by 9:00 pm, but we ended up staying until 10. We weren't asked to leave. We had a lot of credit cards, but the restaurant only let us use 2 cards. We negotiated with them to use 3, which they agreed. just FYI, bring some cash with large groups.
author: Cicie W.

description:
It's been a year since I've been here and I'm barely writing this review now.. I'm Sorry ISA! The food was memorable that I'm still salivating about it. We went here randomly one day because Bistro Aix was closed next door. I'm glad we did! We didn't know how it would turn out but it did have a Zagat rating sticker on the window, so why not! We got seated right away. The service was awesome. The food was delicious. I can't even explain. Everything was GREAT, especially the Chicken and steak, both super tender. The most tenderest chicken I've Ever had.

We got the Prix Fix: (copied from the website)
1st course:
Grilled Honey Spiced Local Calamari with basil pesto, tomato concassée & pinenuts

2nd course:
--Pan roasted rocky Jr. Range chicken with fresh herbs, creamy mashed potatoes & jus de poulet 
--Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with moutarde verte a l'estragon & roasted yukon gold potatoes with garlic, butter, rosemary & parsley

Couldn't find the dessert on the website (we went a year ago) but we just got an espresso and some sort of ice cream, it was pretty good too.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I've seen pictures of the food from Isa from friends and I wanted to come here so badly! When I saw that it was a participating restaurant for Dine About Town, I was extremely excited! My friend and I came here on the last day of DAT. You would think after two weeks, it wouldnt be so busy, but it still was! Came in at 7 and was told there is nothing available for the rest of the night.  Good thing I had made reservations at 9 for 4 just in case some other friends joined us.

The menu items that was being offered at the restaurant was not what was posted prior before on the website, so that was a little disappointing. Both of us ordered off the DAT menu. For appetizers, we got the salmon carpaccio and grilled calamari. For entrees, we got the lobster bouillabaisse and flat iron steak. And for dessert, some cheese thing with walnuts and creme brulee. The salmon was just plain smoked salmon with a few capers and a lemony-egg sauce dripped around. With the calamari, I prefer it battered and fried with dipping sauce.  The lobster stew was pretty good, came with a lot of different types of seafood and was warm and hearty. The steak came sliced already and was perfectly cooked and tender, but I wasn't a big fan of the sauce.  It was too heavy on the cognac taste. I thought the cheese was so gross, and just a slab of cheese with a few honey walnuts did not seem to be a whole course worthy. The creme brulee was simple but good.

I really liked the setting of the restaurant, with the backyard tent with heaters and garlands for round lights.  Overall, the food was good, but not exceptionally great. Everything was pretty plain and slightly on the blander side. Our waiter was very nice and it was a good dining experience, but it's not a place I would come back to again.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Delicious food and a cheery back patio- it's a cute, romantic little spot perfect to be swept off your feet on a date night. Love it here and need to go back. 

I ordered off of a fixed price menu and it was delicious. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
My bf and I came here for Dine About Town a couple of months ago. We loved the food! Everything was really yummy. 
The food was good for the price that we paid.
author: Connie C.

description: Came here for a birthday celebration during Dine About Town in June this year. OMG the seared scallops were AMAZING!!!! and the steamed mussels in tomato sauce was to DIE FOR!! The portions were decent as well for the price. Also, I don't know what they use for the bread but the bread was very addicting. Only complain/negative about this place is a bit small so we were kind of cramped.
author: Julisa L.

description: Best Creme Brûlée I've had! I'd come back for the dessert! Great service too! I thought the food was good but not extraordinary.
author: Daniel M.

description: Went in at first seating at 5pm so we could catch a movie.  Domingo our waiter was great and helped up select perfect choices:  lamb, chicken, heirloom tomatoes, tuna - great family style combos for our table of 4.
author: Tom S.

description:
I came here once before and clearly it was NOT memorable because when my best friend mention us going here for Dine About Town, I thought I'd never been to this place. 

The menu looked amazing and I'm a big fan of tapas because I like options. 

We spit the arugula salad, baked goat cheese, halibut, truffle risotto, creme brulee and grapefruit granite. 

it was delicious and flavorful- loved the outdoor canopy seating and white christmas lights. 

Oh and the service was great. I went home full and happy (although my wallet...not so much).
author: Tenika S.

description: We came to this place for my best friends birthday and had reservations for 8:30 but ended up standing outside in the cold until an extra 40 minutes. The place was busy I understand but having to wait 40 minutes for a reservation is ridiculous. The food was bland and tasteless, the crab salad was full of the crab shells which I don't believe for the money we paid I should have to pick out.
author: Vlad M.

description:
An unpretentious French restaurant with great food!  My husband and I started with the foie gras and yellow fin tuna.  The foie gras was fantastic.  It went very well with the buttery brioche (which soaked in the huckleberry sauce) and roasted pear.  The yellow fin tuna was good but not memorable (this is probably my own fault as I ALWAYS order tuna tartare and am probably getting jaded by the fact that there aren't many unique varations to this dish).  Our main/bigger plates were the truffle risotto (they didn't skimp on the truffle) and skirt steak (cooked perfectly).  Both dishes were delicious and full of flavor.  

The only minor set back was the inattentive service and awkward seating (we sat in the back patio).  Although the food came out on time, the wait staff seemed to rush the diners.  This could have been due to the three large parties that were seated where we were, but for the price, a little added attention would have been nice.  I'd also appreciate not sitting so close to the other diners (it almost felt like I was on a double date).
author: Kat L.

description:
Boy is this place cramped. As a result of last minute Saturday night reservation, we ended up sitting at the bar - which ended up to be a pleasant expereience as we chit-chatted with the bartender and he gave us free wine-tasting :) 

We ordered from the prix fixe menu. I got the maine lobster soup which was extremely flavorful and the dinstinct lobster taste did not get washed away by all the other condiments. For main entree I ordered the seafood casserole (yup, a very seafood-ey meal) I really recommend this one since you get a taste of each kind of seafood. My casserole consisted of a piece of halibut, two big clams, some fat scallops, and multiple pieces of prawns and calimari basked in a creamy broth. For dessert, nothing on the prix fixe menu was particularly appealing so I asked if I could get the cream bruele instead and the bartender was totally fine with it

The ambiance & decor were decent, although I thought that the furniture arrangement would've looked better if the space was a bit larger, but not a big deal. What would've really made it better was the lighting - aside from the one teeny tiny candle on each table there was no other lighting...would've been nice if I could also enjoy the presentation of the food
author: Melody L.

description: This restaurant is one of the best restaurants that i have ever been to. Went here for Dine about Town. GREAT DEAL!!!! Super good food. you can not go wrong at all going here. The food is soooooo good and very well prepared. The wait staff is excellent. They talk to you and are very very nice! Highly recommend going here!!!
author: H D.

description:
The food is solid.  Yummy grilled calamari, duck, and lamb.  No complaints there.  Everything else was mediocre.  

The whole "plates for sharing" concept seems like a gimmick.  There was no real difference between the way the food was served at Isa vs. any other traditional 3 course dining establishment we've been to.  It could have been what we ordered, but that was my take on it.  

The wait also irked me.  We made reservations for 7:45, arrived at 8:00, and didn't get seated until 8:30.  Grrr....if they released our table, just say so when we check in.  Having us wait so long in spite of reservations just doesn't say much about the management.

I'm glad we didn't pay full price there because while the food was good, the prices aren't great for the experience as a whole.
author: Wendy L.

description:
This place is cute and cozy, dim lighting and friendly staff.
Now for the food: they are delicious! every item has its own unique taste.  Nothing was too blend or "too much" of anything. It was just right! Their dessert is pretty good too.  I'm a dessert snob, so the dessert wasn't THE BEST, but it was pretty good. =)
author: farzana k.

description:
Just got back from Isa and felt compelled to write a great review.

First things first, the service was IMPECCABLE. The bread basket never stayed empty for more than a minute. Those two waiters servicing the entire crowded tent are straight up professionals. Everyone was so friendly and attentive, even through this busy Dine About Town week. 

We ordered the Crab Salad and the prawns for the first course. Pretty tasty but nothing too special. Our mains, the flat iron steak and the duck breast, were superbly cooked, tender, and very flavorful. The desert was not bad either. Everything was pleasant, if not amazing. 

But word of caution: finding parking, even on a weekday night, was horrific. please allot AT LEAST 20 minutes circling around the darn neighborhood. It's really a test of patience, luck, and just flat out aggression. When we arrived at the restaurant, we were informed that you could "reserve" parking spaces at a private lot for a reasonable fee. Will look into that.
author: Andy S.

description: Food here is delicious and reasonably priced.  Good selection but parking can be tough around the area.
author: Ray L.

description:
Despite my initial concern about the empty-appearing restaurant and bickering front-of-the-house staff, all misgivings melted away when the host led us to the back patio.  The dimly-lit but warm atmosphere of that patio was cozy and inviting, and our server was jovial and clearly passionate about the restaurant's concept and its food. 

As the waiter is keen to emphasize, the concept at Isa is family-style dining.  It's a little misleading as the portions are neither large enough to feed a family nor budget-friendly.  The suggestion is to order double of every dish to ensure there's enough to go around.  Too often this means you're tricked into ordering more than necessary.  In this case, there WAS enough food to feed a small militia (or at least six very hungry people), but I didn't mind as everything was good to very good.

Salmon Carpaccio: I had carpaccio only once before and thought it just wasn't my thing.  This carpaccio proved me wrong--it was cool and fresh, and the creme fraiche was smooth and provided great flavor. Atop the crunchy crostini, this was the perfect bite.

Grilled Calamari: Overly salty and just a little plain, this was the weakest dish of the night.  But I liked the beans, and overall it really wasn't that bad.

Laura Chenel Goat Cheese: A bit heavy and the flavor was too strong for my liking, but it tasted better with bread.  My coworkers are big goat cheese fans, and they liked this appetizer a lot.  

Northern Halibut a la Plancha: The fish was well-cooked but rather forgettable flavor-wise.  I liked the beets, which soaked up the tangy vinaigrette rather nicely.

Maple Leaf Farm Duck Breast: After reading the Yelp reviews, I was adamant to forgo the prix fixe for this entree.  I love duck, and this one was fatty and delicious. The crunchiness of the (fried?) arugula provided nice textural contrast.

Grilled Golden Gate Natural Angus Flat Iron Steak: My least favorite entree of the meal, probably because of the mustard greens in the sauce, which overpowered the meat.

Truffle Risotto: Truffles, where have you been all my life?  How could I have gone this long without sampling your savory earthiness?  I practically inhaled this dish and greedily picked out all the remaining truffles when no one was looking.  Hands down favorite of the night.

Pan Roasted Rocky Jr. Range Chicken: The first piece of chicken I tried was juicy and tasty, but the rest of the bird (i.e. the breast) was a little dry. Not exactly mind-blowing.

After the satisfying deliciousness of the appetizers and entrees, we were honestly too full to enjoy stuffing ourselves further.  It was for the best, as the desserts were a rather underwhelming denouement.  The Bucherondin De Chevre (aged goat cheese with honey) was just okay but far better than the Roaring Forties, which tasted like how my brother's foot smells (seriously).  No one much cared for the grapefruit granite, which had a very pure, sour grapefruit flavor.  The semifreddo all' amaretto was soft and delicious and tasted just like biscotti, but I wouldn't go out of the way to order it.

Overall, the savory dishes were tasty, with a few high notes. Isa restaurant offers quality food, attentive service, and an enjoyable dining experience.  Despite the $$$, this restaurant is worth a try if you're in the area and looking for a good place to take a date, close friends, or even coworkers.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
My husband and I dined here for our wedding anniversary and we really liked it. The customer service was superb. The food...really good. As a vegetarian, they had a couple of veggie entree and appetizer selections, which is not the norm for many French restaurants. The ambiance was really good too; though we didn't get to experience the outdoor area as it was a very cold day. 

Overall, we definitely plan to return and dine at this restaurant. I highly recommend it.

Provecho!
author: Debbie B.

description:
Came here for the first time during Dine About Town 2011
Arrived about 10-15 minutes late for our reservation because it was super hard to find parking even for Sunday dinner.  I should have known because that's always the case in the Marina/Cow Hollow area but the hostess was very nice and sat us right away in the patio area which was very cute and warm.   Although, the service was sometimes on the slow side (they were very busy that night), I felt that they were still very attentive - I never had to ask for more water or bread or wine - they came by just on time. Food was served family style so I got to try everything.

So for the DAT, it was ~$35 for 3 courses.  
Here's what we had.
Dungeness crab salad w avocado, apple, grapefruit and tarragon:  very fresh and very tasty.  Everything went surprisingly well together.

Wild prawns w parsley, garlic and lemon:  very succulent and tasty - one of my faves...

Seared scallops w/ butternut squash, sweet potatoes, spinach and bacon:   The butternut squash was a nice surprise to this dish.  The scallops were perfectly seasoned and cooked.  My only complaint would be that there were only 3 pieces of scallops.

Flat iron steak with zucchini, polenta cake, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce:  this was probably my least favorite of the dishes.  It was good but somehow, they didn't go together from my perspective.  The polenta cake was great however - I'm not really into polenta but this was very tasty.  Meat was not tender.

Vanilla bean gelato with biscotti:   the vanilla bean gelato was very creamy
Flourless Chocolate cake with ice cream- cake melted in your mouth and it went well with the ice cream

Ginger and Blackberry cocktail - very refreshing 

Overall, it was a wonderful dining experience.
author: glen o.

description:
I LOVE ISA! 
this is one restaurant that i always go back to. Ive been to many fine dining restaurants but i still keep going back to Isa. Their food is amazing and their prices are reasonable. I am absolutely a fan of their foie gras!
make sure your seated in the back area for a more romantic feel.
author: Rose W.

description: We came here for my birthday and we were late for our reservation, but they were able to accommodate us.  It happened to be during dine about town so we were limited in our menu choices, but the food we had was amazing.  We ordered 2 orders of foie gras and it came with strawberry sauce on a pound cake.  It was delish. We also had the mussels in a garlic-white wine sauce and it was so good.  When we ran out of mussels, we used the bread to soak up the sauce because it was so good.  Great attentive waiters and a nice cozy atmosphere.  Would definitely come here again.
author: Antonette L.

description:
More like a 3.5, so I rounded up. 

We went for the DAT this year. They're DAT menu is very much like their regular menu, just plus and minus a few dishes, great selection overall. 
The food is good, but didn't wow me away. Using LP's words, if we're in the neighbor then we'd maybe come back cuz we know the food's good, but we probably won't be driving out there specifically for the restaurant again. 

The atmosphere was really nice, but dark. It's like a great dating spot. But for us old married couple (haha) it's a little too dark since we can't see what we're eating. The back patio is warm and closed-up in the winter, so it was pretty nice. The space is small, but cozy. The servers worked as a team and were so nice and welcoming. 

For apps, we had the crab salad and sauteed shrimps. The crab salad was plentiful, and very nicely balanced. It's a great light app to share. The downside is we found a small piece of crab shell in there. That was not fun when it was dark and we couldn't see what we were chewing on. The sauteed shrimp was decent, but a bit too fattening with all that butter. I mean, I can make sauteed shrimp, and it doesn't need to have that much butter. We can taste the freshness of the shrimp though. Oh yeah, the bread for the table was good. Crunch on the outside, soft on the inside. Just the right crunch, not too hard not too chewy. 

For entrees, we had the flat iron steak and the seared scallops. What I can remember is both dishes were on the oily side. The steak was pretty tasty for a cut of meat that's not the best. I liked how it was grilled nicely, medium rare. The polenta cake and the sauces were nice too. The seared scallops were on the small side, there were 5 of them surrounding a plop of veggies. Again, oily veggies. I know there's bacon and all, but really, cut down the butter/oil a bit would be nice. Good taste though, only I can't seem to make out the truffle in the sauce. 

Ah desserts. This is the climax of the meal. The flourless chocolate cake was lite a souffle, not overly sweet, it went so well with the vanilla gelato. Oh and the semifreddo all'amaretto, mmmm. Dessert is the reason for me to dine out, and this did not disappoint.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
This was a tough one to sit through.  Heard about a service called Savored, which seemed like a good idea.  30% off your bill at ISA was reasonable... you aren't gouging the restaurant like a Groupon can, yet you still get to lower the price point to try it out.  We came around 6 for our reso, and were promptly seated at the table next to the door.  Next to another couple using savored.  The restaurant was empty, yet they still wouldn't move us anywhere else upon request.  Seemed quite odd, but I can get over this.  

The part that was hard to stomach was our waiter.  He was horrendous from start to finish.  Didn't ask us at one point during the entire service if our food was good, gave no recommendations when we asked, forgot a course we ordered, and also never asked us if we wanted another drink after we finished our first.  The busser was nice, and the GM or another lady who started coming by towards the end were also very nice.  Unfortunately it was still far from salvaging the experience.  Probably a 4 star experience for the food, brought down to a 2 by Mr. Friendly Server.  Note to Mr. Friendly Server: I get it, you are unhappy that our bill will be less than full price.  Welcome to SF where Groupons, Scoutmobs, and Living Socials are all acceptable as forms of payment.  Tell your management to put you in another section so I can leave a 30% tip to someone who actually cares, and I can enjoy your restaurant how it is supposed to be enjoyed.
author: William B.

description:
I enjoyed the mushroom risotto, but the steak, crab and arugula salad were just okay.  
I think it would be nice place to go with a group of people for sharing plates.

service was very nice.  I forgot my phone and the server ran to bring my phone to me.
Thanks
author: sam s.

description: First off, the food quality is definitely 5 star worthy. Their marketing tricks and lack of management from management staff cost them all the negative points. Long story short. Special offer from their customer e mail that we were in. Prefix menu 3 things, 29.99 reservation only. Pretty simple right? When you are seated it's pretty normal, your given the menu, water and bread, and give you a few minutes with the 2 page menu. No introduction to the menu,Now here is the catch. BOTH pages of the menu clearly say "prefix menu 3 for 29.99 Sunday thru Thursday " on the top. Plain and simple. Not please see page 2, please ask server for details, nada. So it's a safe assumption to make that the prices next to the items are for people who want just one item, or two, but not the 3 for 29.99 thing.  One menu is full length, the second is shorter. So without any formal explanation from staff, you go by what's printed on the menu. So long story short, dinner tastes awesome, service was ok, waiter seemed tired, but when we got our bill of $200+ we asked the waiter why it was seperate items, he said it was wrong and he said he will get it corrected. Manager Indian  lady comes over , says you didn't order prefix. I say, how did we not, what's the very top of the menu say?? she says prefix 3 for 29.99. I go ok, how did we not. She goes, the second menu is for prefix, I ask what's the difference, they both say prefix on the very first sentence. She goes, this menu is to let you KNOW that we have a prefix menu, so I say then shouldn't the menu say, please see OTHER menu??? She goes this menu has ala carte prices, I go yes it does, for people who dont want 3 items, but above that it says 3 for 29.99. She goes well thank you for your criticism, we will take it into consideration. WHAT?!?! It's not criticism, I'm complaining that your menu is deceiving and the pricing is misrepresented and you just acknowledge it and didn't do anything about it.
author: Andrew J.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in San Francisco! Went on a Monday night and had the 3 course prix fixe menu for only $29.95. 
Appetizers: Salmon Carpaccio and Mussels - AMAZING
Entrees: Flank Steak and Risotto - AMAZING
Highly recommend this place!
author: Sheeva B.

description: Salmon capaccio...amazing! Halibut...amazing! Potato wrapped sea bass...amazing! Do yourself a favor, and eat dinner here immediately, you won't he sorry.
author: Ian P.

description: This was a second visit, but the last was 2 years ago. It was as good as I remember. I love the small plate concept and sharing with everyone. You don't have to share, but it makes for an enjoyable evening. The service was excellent, and I will not wait 2 years to return!
author: Kim K.

description:
Last Saturday, I found myself in the Marina District for dinner with no inclination and no idea what we wanted. We saw the atmosphere of Isa and the menu outside and were automatically intrigued. It was 7 o'clock and we managed to get a table for two without reservations. Sweet.

I would say we were seated quickly but in retrospect, we were seated briskly by a slightly abrasive waiter. He handed our menus to us and informed us that this restaurant is designed to be family style, dishes are meant to be shared and things come out as they are prepared and ready without any particular order. Okay, I can deal with that. I can also deal with the darkness of the restaurant and the fact that our waiter is pacing back and forth like a panther. I can deal with that.

The evening started out fine. We started with the prawns (a bit overcooked, but with a fantastic sauce and not terrible) and a very nice bottle of sauvignon blanc (don't remember the vintage as I was not the one who ordered it). However, it was poured quite poorly.

And then I realized how terrible the layout of the restaurant was because a couple was seated at a table practically on top of us. The two 2-tops were separated by maybe 5 inches of space. It felt like we were on a double date at a classless rectangular 4-top. I get a bit uncomfortable with crowds and people, I have a difficult time speaking freely, this was not good for my date. Our waiter continues pacing back and forth like a panther, clearing plates in a speedy fashion that made me a little uncomfortable.

1 glass of wine later, problem solved and everyone can talk freely. I notice our waiter less, I notice my companion more, and our scallop course arrives (we were both in the mood for seafood that night). Scallops came with a truffle sauce with asparagus and mashed potatoes. The sauce and the asparagus were both fantastic with the perfect texture, but I thought the mashed potatoes were too creamy with a texture that detracted from the dish as a whole rather than added to it. And the scallops were small though flavorful, if we're looking for a cloud with a silver lining.

Now that we want a refill of our wine, we have to pour our own glasses. I can understand pouring our own water, but our own wine...? Really? 

Now I wanted to order the lamb initially but we ended up getting the halibut special instead. I am very glad we did this. The flavors were spot on (coriander, nutmeg, allspice to give a very earthy flavor to this fish). It was cooked properly and served with string beans. Everything was perfect about this dish. 

Pour our own wine. A different, more experienced waiter comes by to clear plates and recommend the flourless chocolate cake for dessert. He jokes, we laugh and we forget about our tiger-esque waiter prowling by the hostess station. 

We order the cake and double espressos. Our espressos arrive easily 6 minutes before our dessert (they were okay, but not the best). However, the dessert was absolutely fantastic with a wonderfully light texture (much closer to a souffle than any cake). 

Overall, we had a wonderful evening. The food ranged from good to great, but the service and layout of the restaurant totally killed our dining experience. I would come back with reservations in a different section (perhaps on the back patio) but not for quite some time...
author: Stephanie H.

description: Went here after a full day of wine tasting.  I wish I was a little more sober so I could enjoy the food more because it was delicious.  There were 7 of us and we tried almost everything on the menu.  To top it off we brought a bottle of Quintessa, it went very well with the duck breast and foie.  Sucks that foie is getting banned in Cali.  This place is ideal for a group where you can share all the plates.
author: Christopher D.

description:
You are nothing short of spectacular. 

I decided to celebrate the last of my 20's with a dinner here in their cozy backyard patio thingamabob. I'll complain first. I left it for ze boyfriend to make the reservations. He calls earlier in the week, but the person told him not to worry about it and call back Thursday and they would still be able to accommodate the party of 13. He calls back Wednesday just to be sure, and.. sure enough.. It was too late. Original plan of having it at 8pm vanished because of that bozo. The lady ze bf talked to tried to make it better by offering a 9pm slot. say what??? people will starve by then. at this point, i was peeved and steam was coming out of my ears, but fine, 9pm it is because i really loved it the last time. the next day, the lady calls back saying they can bump us up to 8:45!!! WOO HOO!! 15 minutes! at least they really put that effort into trying to get us in earlier.

The servers and staff were all very friendly and helpful. He helped pick out a very delicious wine. the Long Gamma. definitely beat the Vinho Verde. Onto the food.

For the size of our group, we ordered double of everything. And here goes: 
- Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio - served with crostini. still amazing. not fishy, refreshing from the lemon, order it.
- Yellowfin tuna - actually more fabulous than the salmon carpaccio! i love the bit of kick from the sriracha, and the avocado adds an extra creaminess. Order this!
- Grilled local calamari - not my cup of tea, but my friends were practically fighting over the last pieces.
- Simply sauteéd Sea of cortez wild prawns - simple but extraordinary. the lemon, garlicky butter is like having a bite of heaven. 
- Hudson valley grade A foie gras - still haven't mustered up the stomach for it, but it smells awesome, and everyone melted down their chairs when they bit into this.
- Potato wrapped Seabass - AWESOME. that's it.
- Truffle risotto - soooo creamy!!! i loved it!!! 
- Roasted rack of lamb - don't touch the stuff, but the friends that did eat it lOOOOOVed it. said it wasn't gamey (which makes me not like it) and it was roasted to perfection.
- Maple leaf farm duck breast - still can't go wrong with this mother.
- Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak - buttery meatiness.
- Brussels Sprouts with garlic, bacon & extra virgin olive oil - mm.. not buttery enough, but they were cooked to tenderness. 


$57 per person for all that food and 3 bottles of wine, plus endless amount of cocktails, and 2 desserts, that ain't bad at ALL! Ok... all is forgiven for that earlier mishap.
author: My C.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco!  The restaurant is family style tapas and ordering about 2 dishes a person is more than enough.  The modern ambiance is great for dates, but Isa's also good for groups around 4 to 6 people (make a reservation) so you can try a lot of the dishes and get more than just a tiny bite of each.  I've always sat in the back patio lined with stringed lights which seems a little more casual than the front section.

The ingredients are super fresh and Isa really brings out great flavors in each of their dishes.  My favorites are the seafood dishes, though I've tried many of the other ones and can't think of a single one I didn't like.  Here are my selected favorites:

Little Skookum Oysters - so fresh and the sauce goes great with them
Dungeness Crab Salad - I'm a bit of a sucker for crab and even more so when there's no work involved in getting the meat out of the shell.  This salad is light, citrusy and refreshing.
Scallops - perfectly cooked, a bit on the small side
Shellfish risotto - creamy, and the prawns are great

For dessert, the creme brulee is delicious.  It's in a bit of a wider ramekin which means more caramelized sugar to break!  The custard base is the perfect richness and texture.

Overall, it's a fabulous, fresh, French restaurant.   The service and wine selection are great, and the food is amazing!
author: Christine L.

description:
Thanks to yelp (as usual) I was directed to Isa via my personal craving for a French dinner and my insistence on trying a new restaurant. Thank goodness every one noted the truly great fun, atmosphere, and service. Isa delivered! 

Isa does fresh French cuisine tapas style. They have a lovely selection of small plates to share. We did a grand tasting and ordered many dishes including a dungeness crab salad with mango and avocado, grilled calamari, backed goat cheese with sun dried tomatoes and pine nuts. They also have larger plates which are equally great for sharing. The lobster bouillabaisse is a must try if you're into seafood and enjoy a great tomato sauce. Meat dishes of the night included rack of lamb, beef short ribs, and seared day boat scallops. 

Save room for dessert because the creme brulee is light and fresh, although the chocolate cake is truly where it's at. Glasses of port (10 year tawny) are only $7 so don't skimp on the dessert and wine pairing. 

Wonderfully fresh (not too rich) French food served by a friendly staff. Corkage fee is $18, but their wine list is very reasonable.
author: Theresa T.

description: Delicious food, good services. I will repeat for sure in the future. I really enjoyed my time there
author: Miguel Diez Ferreira F.

description: Amazing place excellent food. Also love the atmosphere, and service is always with a smile. If you love seafood this is the place to go.
author: Judayle D.

description:
Disclaimer: It's been a few weeks since our Isa experience so this will be light on details. 

We stumbled into Isa without a reservation and were promptly seated in the front room. We enjoyed that dishes were served as soon as they were prepared. We flavors were intense, the temperatures just right, and the wine selection recommendation was top-notch. We were dressed very casual, but saw a number of couples entering dressed up for date-night. 

I read some reviews about people complaining of the ambience in the back patio/tent. All I can say is that the front room was dark, moody, and all romantical-like. 

Overall, we were extremely happy with the meal and would likely return with friends.
author: J Z.

description:
I went with a group of friends and had one of the better meals of my life. We ordered 8-10 dishes, but the stand outs were the truffle risotto, flat iron steak, and the foie gras. I'd go back alone just for that risotto, ahhh god I have to stop thinking about it or else they might as well have access to my bank account.

The service was amazing. Dean is the man. He was super friendly and kind even though some of us were noobs at fine dining. The ambiance was warm and charming. Great for a date or a memorable night with friends. I'm pretty much saving my next visit here for when I really want to impress someone. Or when I break down and need more truffle laced things @_@ 

Must... end... review... before the craving takes over.....
author: Patrick C.

description: After hours of trying to figure out where to take my girlfriend for our 1 year anniversary, Isa was the place i decided on. We booked on open table and mentioned It was for our anniversary, which the lovely hostess (can't remember her name but she had curly blond hair) acknowledged right when we walked in. She gave us this cute table by the window where the seats sat next to each other as opposed to across from one another, We each got the prefix (arugula salad, flank steak & ameretto ice cream for her) (warm goat cheese, seasonal fish, and cheese/honey/nuts plate). Everything was amazing! The food was simple but good, and it was all cooked perfectly. Our server was very friendly and attentive as well. I really dont have a single bad thing about this place. They have a happy hour that is from 5-7 and has $5 glasses of wine and soju cocktails..  Definitely will be back! Great value for the price, comfy/romantic environment, not "stiff" at all (like some nice places can feel).
author: Tyler L.

description:
This place, for me, was love at first bite.

We ordered the following dishes:

-Dungeness Crab Salad with with avocado, apple, grapefruit & tarragon dressing:
Like summer in my mouth!  Whoever thought of this combination was a genius.  The combination of flavors was well done and distinctive while still being delicate.

-Seared scallops with brussels sprouts, bacon, potato puree & truffle jus de poulet:
A hearty, delicious dish.  The scallops were the perfect texture and blended well with the bits of bacon and the potato puree.

-Simply sauteéd Sea of cortez wild prawns with parsley, garlic & lemon:
Literally melted in my mouth.  Went fantastically with the large pieces of lemon zest it was paired with.  A succulent dish; I enjoyed every bite of this one!

-Truffle risotto with baby shiitake, hon shimiji mushroom & reggiano: this dish is 1,000 times better than any risotto I have ever made or tried in recent memory.  It is delectable and all-around perfect.  Also a great way to round a meat/fish-heavy selection.

For me, Isa was a gourmet experience for a reasonable price.  I definitely appreciated the ambiance (dimmed lighting, cozy, etc.) and the promptness with which the waiters brought out the dishes from the kitchen.  

The only thing that was slightly disappointing about my experience is that we were seated in the corner, next to each other, since there was not room for us to sit across from one another.  This seating arrangement was slightly awkward for having a conversation with my husband, but this didn't take away from my experience too much.
author: Nina B.

description:
We had a reservation for 9:15, but were seated around 9:40.  When we got to the table there was a candy wrapper on the table they must have missed when they cleaned the table. All the dishes were pretty mediocre. There was one dish that was plated lazily. The medium rare duck dish was more well done than it was medium rare. By the end of the evening 2/3 of their deserts were sold out, so that was kind of weak.

All these things separately were not a big deal, but all together the restaurant was about average and their performance was just below that.
author: Yuan T.

description: Food was delicious. We went for my friend's birthday party. this was our second time to ISA and we weren't disappointed. We had Muscles, Crab Salad, Rack of Lam, the Risotto and Truffles, and the Paella everything was superb.
author: Mahasti T.

description:
I took my girlfriend here for a nice Saturday evening dinner and had an great time. 

The best things about this place is the FOOD. Everything is good. They serve plates of various dishes that you share at the table. Get 3 things and a side dish for two people.

The service is good. Our waiter was a little bit strange. His personality was a little dry. He did all the right things as far as keeping us happy but I wouldn't say he went out of his way.

Be aware of taking anyone here if you are looking for a bit of quiet time. It is extremely loud in the back dining area. I will go for the bar next time which was a bit darker and seemed to fit my style. 

Overall a very good experience and I will definitely go back.
author: Kris P.

description: Amazing.My favorite restaurant in San Francisco at the moment.
author: Shahla M.

description:
My friends and I went to this restaurant for a friend's bday. The food was excellent! What stuck out the most was the scallops, potato wrapped halibut, and the duck! We ordered a lot of dishes but I don't remember what else we ate. I haven't been back in a while but I want to go again soon hehe.
We really wanted to sit outside but we ended up sitting at the bar because they lost our reservations. Yea.. we were pretty upset by that but at least the food was good. That's why I can't give this place 5 stars.
author: Shu L.

description: This place was great!  I took my friend here for her 25th birthday dinner, just the two of us, and it was perfect.  The atmosphere was great.  We set in the back enclosed patio area and the lighting was great and it felt like you were sitting outside a cafe in France.  the food was delicious, we ordered one of the three course selections and then a few other separate dishes - definitely the way to go!  our waiter was also awesome!  he was super friendly and offered great suggestions.  and then of course they came out and sang happy birthday and had candles in a delicious dessert.  i will definitely be back here again!  it's a must check out restaurant in SF.
author: Dominica B.

description: I took Dad there to jointly celebrate my 53rd and his 84th birthday. Notably, we were there during Dine About Town, with its fixed price menu. We enjoyed ourselves. However, our dining experience was not outstanding. The service was only adequate (they refilled our bread but not our butter; they didn't ask if we wanted coffee with our dessert), the food presentation was only adequate, and the food was good, but not WOW. Really, every single dish was good but not WOW. We enjoyed the emphasis on sharing dishes, and we did share. I'm glad we went but it wasn't as special as their prices led me to expect.
author: Terry F.

description:
I left a 4 star review for this restaurant a few months back, primarily because we got reseated from the extremely crowded front to the pretty seating in the back.  However, I had a very uncomfortable dinner here because of an issue with the waiter.  After I made my review for this restaurant, Kitty and Luke proceeded to harrass me about when I went, my name, so that they could look up my receipt back in December, etc.  They proceeded to leave very condescending comments about how I was a cheap tipper, etc. on my page.  I felt so humiliated that I took my review down.  

Then, I came across an old high school friend's page, Jennifer H.  and she had received the same harrassment that I had!  So this got me riled up again.  

Beware.  If you write bad things about this restaurant, they will be riding your ass until you take down that review.  

I can't wait to hear the derogatory things this business owner has to say about me now!  

To say the least, this is not good customer service.  My advice: don't be so condescending and rude when you respond to your customers.  I was willing to give this restaurant another chance before, but after all of this bad aura coming from this restaurant, I will never return and will definitely not recommend this restaurant to any friends/family.

Oh yeah, and after the server demanded more tip from us, my obliging plus one left more tip even though I told him not to since the service was foul.  I really don't think he should have left more cash for these people.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
The good: The Baked Goat Cheese with Pesto and Pine Nuts was a spectacular way to kick off the meal. The Flourless Chocolate Cake with Vanilla Gelato was also very delicious and seemed to be made with a hint of rum which added to its appeal. The ambiance is warm and lively and there is a diverse mix of of diners here that's not typical of most restaurants in the Marina (i.e., not everyone is a Yuppie!).

The bad: Maple Leaf Duck Breast with Wild Huckleberry sauce. I thought my duck was way undercooked, a bit too fatty, and lacked sufficient seasoning. I also felt the sauce was far too sweet and didn't complement the duck very well. I also felt portions were on the smaller side, but I guess that's typical of most French restaurants. Finally, I didn't think it was cool that we weren't seated until 40 minutes after our reservation time.

The ugly: Horrible service. Our waiter catered to the adjacent group's every whim, while leaving our table virtually unattended. In fact, while he was making multiple visits to the table next to us, he basically ignored my group until he brought out the bill 2 hours later. He event sent a bus boy to take our order. What the eff?! But it didn't end there. He went on to bring out the wrong desserts to my friends and me, and even ended up overcharging us by about $60. When we told him about the billing error, he apologized and brought out the "correct" bill--which was still wrong! Finally, 2 attempts later, he brought us an accurate bill. Maybe if you spent more time talking to us and actually being the one to take our orders you wouldn't have fucked up the first and second times! God, what horrible service.

Overall, my dining experience was just okay. I was looking forward to Isa after reading a number of glorious reviews, but was a bit disappointed with the service and my main course. I don't think I'll come back for round two. There are many better French restaurants in the city (and ones that don't treat their customers like crap).
author: Joseph F.

description:
Been to this restaurant several times and the food  is pretty consistent. Love that they have prix fix menu from Sundays to Thursdays and the family style portions. 

Must haves:
Calamari: cooked perfectly, love the slightly sweet sauce with the smokiness from the grill. 
Sautéed prawns: large and flavorful. 
Mushroom risotto: yummy!  You wont be disappointed especially with fragrant pieces of truffle. 
Shortrib (special): huge portion and tasty. Wish it would be in their regular menu. 
Flat iron steak: cooked to perfection, sauce does not overpower the flavor of the meat. 


Decent items:
Paella: definitely can taste the saffron in the dish
Mussels:  never overcooked and shriveled. 
Grapefruit granite: light, refreshing, and you can definitely tell it was made in the restaurant and not store bought. 
Semifreddo: good and not too sweet. 

Will definitely go back to try other items.
author: Foodie F.

description: this is a nice little french place, it's romantic and has a nice ambiance. but parking is a pain around here, it's san francisco, you can't complain that much.  i had the truffle risotto and my friend had the duck .  it's was my first time eating risotto so i didnt' know what to expect. it was ok to me. but i had a bite of my friends duck and it was tender but i felt that it had a little too much fat.  i have to say i think i didn't order the right food.. i had the creme brulee and it was ok too me. just like a regular creme brulee. but i do want to come back there and try their lamb and flourless chocolate cake.
author: Belinda C.

description: great ambiance! food was really good but not 5 star, more like 4.5 but I'll give it a 5 star cause I really enjoyed the atmosphere and our friendly waiter. Would definitely recommend this place.
author: A A.

description:
We went in for an early dinner with the kids. They seated us in the back in the tented deck. It was a really neat area. As the night wore on, it got really loud. 
They recommended 2 dishes per person we ordered 2 dishes person, including for my 4 1/2 year old. We had way touch food. I would recommend 1 1/2 dishes per person. The crab salad was delicious. The sea bass was good but the saltiness of the potato skin and the tomato sauce really masked the otherwise wonderful taste of the fish. The land chops were really tender and delicious. The duck breast tasted like smoked breasts a bit and was not that great. The calamari was very good. My son loved it. The foie gras was a really good size. It was delicious but the foie gras at Jardiniere was better. The special of the night was oxtail. It was in a red wine sauce. The dish was huge. It came with a ton of risotto that was under seasoned and overcooked. The red wine braised short ribs that I made from a Bon appetite recipe was better than the oxtail. 
Overall, the service was excellent and I'm glad they did well with the kids. Not sure if I would go back though. There are way too many great places to try in SF to settle for mediocre.
author: Wanlan X.

description:
I have eaten here twice. The service is only so-so (a waiter carrying bread walked towards us as if to give it to us--we didn't have any--looked at us...then walked away!); it can be difficult to flag down wait staff.

Also, it is very loud in the restaurant; you can hardly hear the person sitting next to you. And the tables are cramped and uncomfortable.

The mushroom risotto is SO SO SO SO GOOD! Delicious! I love it.

Otherwise, the cocktails are good, and everything else is not bad, but not necessarily anything special.
author: Lucinda P.

description:
I love this place. One of my favorites. 
Came here Saturday night with a group of friends. 
Food was delicious as always. 
My favorites were scallops, mussels, steak and risotto. 
Service was also very good. 
Thank you Domingo for helping me with my reservation that I kept changing to add more people.
author: Julie P.

description:
In one's life, there are certain restaurants where one remembers or identifies or associates with a significant event. For me, Portland's now closed Scarlet Begonia is where I first tried and was immediately turned off foie grois. And Isa .. oh Isa .. is the remarkable restaurant that turned me back ON to it! I LOVE their seared foie grois! I am so thankful that (1) my date brought me here, and (2) he convinced me to give foie grois another chance. For that, I am forever grateful. :)

Among other notable culinary delights were the parchment paper steamed butterfish (I figuratively died and entered fish heaven .. it was cooked to perfection ... like butter, it seemed to melt in my mouth!) and a couple other tapas-style dishes (they were quite delicious, but my mind was still so hazy from the foie grois and butterfish, I have completely forgotten what else we ordered!).

The ambiance is perfect for an intimate date, or a small gathering of friends. Service was impeccable. And, it is in my neighborhood (even if it wasn't, I'd surely make the trek!).
author: Jill T.

description:
I had been meaning to try Isa for a while and I finally did a few months ago.  Here's what I remember:

The food:

We tried a salad (maybe the arugula salad, I don't really remember), the foie gras (which they are known for), the potato wrapped sea bass (also one of their reputed dishes), the rack of lamb and a pork chop special.

I hardly remember the salad, so that's all of the review that it needs.  

The foie gras is one of their most popular and talked about dishes.  It was definitely good.  However, I have to disclaim that it is the only foie gras I have ever tried, so I don't have much to compare it to.  Regardless, once I got past the initial disgust of how fatty foie gras is, being warm, sweet, and creamy, it was absolutely delicious.  

I was surprised by the sea bass because it did not taste like fish, nor did it have the normal texture of fish.  The flavor was neutral and the texture was firm.  In fact, my friend who "doesn't like seafood" was enjoying it (he thought it was chicken) until I told him it was fish.  I was a little disappointed with it, though, because I didn't think it was very flavorful.  

Pork chops are one of my all time favorite foods.  The flavor of this one was good, but it was definitely over cooked and therefore dry and tough.  

Rack of lamb is one of my other all time favorite foods.  This one was mediocre and unremarkable.

The service:

Our server was adorable (cute, smiley old man).  He definitely made me smile.  The service was as exactly as good service at a nice restaurant should be.  Nothing notable.

The ambiance:

The ambiance of Isa is really nice.  The inside is modern and the back patio is a nice garden setting.  My biggest complaint (which is a huge one to me and, unfortunately, is way too common in SF) is that it is very loud.  Like super, duper loud.  I could not hear my friend sitting across the table from me, but I could hear everybody else in the restaurant shouting at their company.

Overall, Isa is definitely good, but I wasn't especially impressed, especially for how expensive it is and how high of reviews it gets.  I probably won't go back to Isa because, for the money, there are better restaurants.

Reservations are definitely necessary.

Without drinks, expect to spend roughly $50 a person.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I'm generally not too critical about service and food quality, but my dinner at Isa was disappointing enough on both those points that I actually had to - for the first time in recent memory - give less than my standard tip.  

Service...glacially slow, inattentive, and abrupt.  They also constantly rotated waiters, so one would bring me replacement silverware.  I noticed I got a dirty plate, but then the waiter disappeared to fast that I couldn't flag down another one for a bit.  Same when they took away a dirty fork, but forgot to replace it.  

As for the food - the foie gras was burnt, and not in the good way.  A big chunk of it was inedible, and the edible piece was actually separate from the main one as if they gave me a piece of someone else's.  

The one thing I did like was the $5 for a glass of wine - every day - from 5-7PM.  This includes weekends, so cheers.
author: C L.

description:
Did a 35$ prixe fixe when they were having SF Chefs restaurant week and decided to settle on Isa for dinner...and it was FANTASTIC.

I went with a group of 4, and we all ordered different apps/entree/dessert and so there was a lot of variety on the table.  This is how Isa suggests that you order (family style).

Every dish that came out of their seemingly small kitchen was above-par...from salmon carpaccio to a fried chicken...awesome.  Perfectly cooked, moist, tender, chicken in a restaurant is difficult to find and they have done it well.

I recommend the goat cheese app.
author: Jimmy K.

description: I am sad to say but the food at Isa is starting a down hill slide.  Service was polite and attentive but a couple mistakes came up: dessert spoon with the soup and our foie gras showed up after the main course once we reminded the staff.  While the foie gras was still excellent, it was the duck that was less than spectacular.  Normally accompanied with crispy skin and served medium rare, the skin was soft and still moist and the breast itself was rare.  The main culprit here seems to be a still capable cook staff minus a true exec chef to keep them in line.  This was apparent while waiting for the bathroom and getting a good long look into the open kitchen.  A top notch kitchen minus at least one academy graduated chef is destined for failure.  Throwing a different colored jacket on your once trusted assistant is no substitute. Given this extremely competitive market, I give this place 5 years before the doors close for good.  Take note owners and save this once proud little gem of the Marina.
author: henry m.

description:
I haven't been to Isa in several years, but I have to say that I have never had better scallops in my life.  My experience with scallops, prior to Isa, was that they were rubbery and fishy.

At Isa, the scallops practically melted in my mouth and were not at all fishy.  This place is a little more formal and spendy, which is why I haven't been back for a little while.  But, if you are looking for a great wine selection and quite possibly the best scallops you've ever had in your life - this is the place to go.
author: Anne Marie F.

description:
Our first real restaurant in San Francisco.
Really good cooked cuisine. Try the scalopps with bacon and sprout. Amazing mix ! We loved it !
author: Eric L.

description: I have been to this restaurant several times over the last year.  Each time the food and service has been outstanding.  I have not had a dish that was not really yummy.  I think my favorite is the Potato Wrapped Sea Bass, but others that I recommend are the Truffle Risotto, Angus Flat Iron Steak, and Yellow Fin appetizer.  One of my favorite wines is the Rombauer Chardonnay.  I have recommended this restaurant to several of my friends, and will be back. - Tom N.
author: Tom N.

description:
I would've given them a 5 star if the place had a little bit more elbow room in the back (and I'm a small, petite person).  Instead, for me to get in my seat, I had to squeeze in between another chair and a heater lamp that my elbow could touch from the table.

Let's talk about food.  We had a pescetarian with us that night, so that means all we ordered was the yellow fin tuna, truffle risotto, wild prawns and steamed mussels.  Everything was fresh, melt in your mouth and succulent!  This was a great intro to french food for me since this was my first time.
author: Teo B.

description: 3 course prix fixe.  Compared to Range it was a disappointment.  Death by unfair comparison!  Halibut a touch overdone, forgetful waitress, more bread but no butter, hunk of blue cheese uninspired, great atmosphere, otherwise good service; amazing foie gras.  Good value.  risotto dish amazing!  Gravlax was good.  My other dish, forgettable, I can't even remember what it was.  The portions were pretty big, we thought this was a tapas place, turns out it's french food served family style. Okay, fine.
author: Julian H.

description:
Sensational cuisine and service make this restaurant the perfect selection for any special occasion.  My boyfriend suggested Isa for a romantic 1 year anniversary dinner...I always listen to him: simply because if he enjoys the food, I know I will.  He has never steered me wrong before in the food department!  The ambiance was extraordinary and the service was steller.  The servers really know the menu and don't stumble over their words while rattling off the specials! 

It didn't take long for us to make our menu selections.  We started with the Maine Lobster Broth soup.  All I can say is...yuuuummmy!  It wasn't too rich and it was very savory with a delectable flavor of Maine Lobster.  The second item was the Foie Gras...and OMG!  It was so rich and flavorful.  It's served with soft toasted bread, huckleberries and apples.  After that, we shared the duck breast with arugula, black figs and goat cheese.  Our fourth dish was the rack of lamb.  All of the dishes are very distinct in flavor and they all leave a sumptuous taste in your mouth, leaving you wanting more!  

For dessert, we shared the flourless chocolate cake w/ vanilla bean gellato.  My boyfriend had told me about this, so I had to try it.  It was simply amazing.  I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys fine dining and amazing French cuisine.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Absolutely wonderful dining experience! 

Took advantage of the "Dine About Town" promotion and went last Friday with a friend. 

Note: Parking really sucked around the area and it took us almost 30 minutes to finally locate a spot. May want to spare at least half an hour as parking situation can get crazy. 

Made reservation on Opentable.com at 07:30p.m., but we still had to wait 10 minutes. During our wait, we were given free drinks (any wine we could pick from the menu) on the house as compensation and an "incentive" to keep us waiting, so that wasn't too bad after all. 

We ordered from the "Dine About Town" menu and every single course was truly delicious and wonderful. Loved the prawns, duck breast, flat iron steak, sauteed mushrooms, as well as their desserts. Our server is super friendly and nonstop smiling the whole time. I could sense his genuineness and he truly made me feel welcomed. 

I highly highly recommend this place to anyone--you should give Isa a try too. :D
author: Vicky H.

description:
Absolutely. Spectacular.

Went on my birthday - champagne at the bar, then my finance and I were joined by another couple. We were there because of the guest sushi chef. 

I didn't know about the sharing dishes deal, but it worked wonderfully. We ordered the poke tuna appetizer and convinced my formerly vegetarian / sushi-virgin finance to try. Unfortunately, we've ruined her, because she will never have fish like that again -- it was stupendous! We were dumbfounded by the perfectly crafted flavors of this dish and the freshness of the fish. Our friends chose several sushi dishes at each one was outstanding and represented the best sushi any of us had tasted to date. Gorgeous tuna and salmon layered over a delicate, flavorful mix of things within each roll. No wasabi, soy or ginger needed. Though the ginger, which was literally slices of cured ginger, not the pink floppy things you're used to, was quite a treat to munch on.

I decided on the prix fix choosing mussels and flank steak medium rare (maybe I'm a big jerk, but if you don't order steak medium rare, maybe you should just stick to chicken?). My finance did, in fact, order chicken, which was the meal's only failure - overcooked! The mussel dish was elaborate, to say the least. 30 of them, piled high. And the number of shells was not diminished by the size of each - they were all well appointed. The steak was divine and the potatoes au gratin were a cheesy top-browned slice of heaven.

Only slight draw-backs  -- no liquor -- only beer and wine (though I recommend drinking champagne straight through dinner if you like it). French wait staff has the cards stacked against them being in two categories often lambasted for their snootiness. But our waiter warmed up to us when he saw how much we were enjoying the meal. The other drawback can't entirely be said to be the fault of the restaurant, but they did let her in: a girl of not more than 15 who walked in and sat next to our table, wearing snowman-adorned pajamas and a Michigan t-shirt. She was with parents, or were they step-parents, who appeared not to notice.

I guess if I'm fine with passing a plate of glorious steak and potatoes over the table to a friend in exchange for exquisite ahi tuna, I should be fine with pajamas. I know I enjoyed getting into mine and passing out in a state near bliss when I got home from this birthday dinner.
author: Jonah C.

description:
I went to Isa with a group of friends for Dine About Town. It was so good! What we didn't know was that the food is served family style so it wasn't really necessary for each of us to get the 3-course dinner, but we DID ANYWAY! It gave us an opportunity to try more items on the menu.

Our first courses included the baked laura chenel goat cheese with pesto, tomato, concassee & pinenuts, dungeness crab salad with avocado, apple, grapefruit & taragon, and Sea of Cortez wild prawns with parsley, garlic & lemon. My favorite were the prawns by far. They were well seasoned and plump. The goat cheese was very good and the server kept the warm french bread coming. The dungeness crab salad was my least favorite, but had I had it alone I probably would have liked it more. 

Our second courses were truffle risotto with baby shiitake, hon shimiji mushroom & reggiano and pan roasted rocky jr. range chicken with fresh herbs, creamy mashed potatoes & jus de poulet. Both were so good. The servings of risotto were big and very tasty. The chicken was moist and very well-seasoned.

For the third course everyone agreed on getting the flourless chocolate cake with vanilla bean gelato. It was more of a souffle, but very good and the gelato was so good. 

Last note, the service was really great and the hostess checked on us multiple times. She was as friendly as they come.  Our server changed a few times, but they were all very attentive. I would definitely eat here again and recommend to friends.
author: Erica H.

description: Great service from knowledgeable and accommodating waiters.  Tasty food with attractive presentation.  All 4 of us were pleased with our experience.
author: Nanette R.

description:
My boyfriend's mom chose to come here for the Dine About Town program. Driving up to the place made me a bit weary. The decor does not match the type of food they serve. It looks like a casual place, with brown paper instead of white table cloths..

We wanted to try everything so we ordered family style. We first started off with the spicy tuna crudo (with toasted sesame, seaweed, avocado, nori & low sodium soy), Loch Duart salmon tartare (with lemon, crème fraiche, cucumber, egg, capers & crostini), and asparagus. They were all delicious. I especially loved the salmon tartare. The crostini was buttered and thin and the toppings complimented the salmon perfectly.

For our entrees, we ordered Seared Dayboat scallops (with asparagus, potato purée & truffle jus de poulet), rilled creekstone natural flat iron steak (with potato dauphinoise & cognac-green peppercorn demi-glace), and duck breast (perfectly pan fried skin and hash browns over a spinach salad with currents and bacon). The winner was the duck breast, hands down. It was medium rare and oh so flavorful. The scallops were delicious, but small compared to the ones I had at Peasant and the Pear (Danville). The steak was also good, but my least favorite out of the three.

Dessert time! For dessert we had the flourless chocolate cake and creme brulee. Both were so tasty. The flourless cake was so nice and fluffy, almost mousse-like. It was accompanied by a yummy vanilla bean gelato. The creme brulee was also good. I thought the sugar was a bit thick. I still prefer the creme brulee at Paradiso (San Leandro).

Overall, Isa exceeded my expectations. The food was delicious. They should work on their decor though.

GREAT SERVICE!
author: Michelle P.

description: I have been in SF for 14 years and this is still hands down my very favorite restaurant.  The food is always fantastic and the service is superb.  The owners are an adorable husband and wife couple that are always there with a smile.  Several of the waiters have been there for many years -  it's always fun to see their familiar faces.  The menu is family style - all sharable plates -  so you can experience all of the fantastic dishes.  Definitely sit in the back on the patio - it's tented and heated with great lighting.  I have had big group birthday dinners there several years in a row I love it that much!  My Mom comes to visit from L.A. twice a year and she always insists that we go there, sometimes even two nights in a row!
author: Courtney M.

description: Yelp asked me to review Isa. I was there once before so I returned because I was going to see a movie in the area. The place has declined. Risotto was not made w/Arborio rice & improper texture. Waiter droned to us-overwhelming. Food was mediocre. Won't be back.
author: jj c.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and am definitely a fan of Isa. The service was spot on and the food was yummy! The portions are good portions too and this includes the apps! 

The menu is a bit eclectic which usually makes me a bit skeptical about the quality of the food but in Isas' case, it totally benefits them! The food is all good, the service is as I mentioned, spot on and the price is totally reasonable given the portion size! Oh and the dessert doesn't disappoint either!
author: Soozie H.

description: The food is absolutely wonderful.  Because of their Prix Fix menu (Sun-Th), I am a frequent visitor and have ordered most dishes on their menu, some that never change, but many are seasonal, and have an Asian flair.  I love that they encourage sharing plates.  Don't go here with a picky eater or someone who doesn't like to share food.
author: Karen R.

description:
Wow, last night's experience with the food here was a lot better than the first time I visited. I was swooning over the crab salad, slurping up the asparagus soup, salivating over the baked goat cheese and sighing over the vanilla bean gelato. I doubt the restaurant has changed, I think I just didn't order the right shiz last time! 

One thing I wasn't too thrilled about was their dessert menu (or lack there of). The selection was just not what I would expect; after I eat a great meal I can't wait to top it off with some fantastically sweet delight. You know when I settle for ice cream there wasn't much to choose from. Not that I'm knockin' it...it was still damn good.
author: Julia N.

description: This place has nice ambiance, but the food was mediocre and expensive. Maybe we just ordered the wrong dishes, but our experience wasn't good and I will not be going back there. We had to send back the PEI mussels because they weren't fresh. I had couldn't hardly finish even one mussel. We had some kind of appetizer with navy bean that was very bland. The yellow fin tuna was pretty good. The butterfish I had was not too bad, but along with the truffle risotto, it was way too rich and repetitive. Both dishes had the same kinds of mushrooms. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this place. We ended spending over $100 on a meal that was mostly disappointing.
author: Jade C.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed every bite we had. This is an outstanding restaurant. The ambiance is interesting in that most are seated in a well heated tent in the back of the building. The service was wonderful. Dean was our waiter. What a character. I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Jim O.

description:
Very rarely do restaurants last; but the chef at Isa's is extremely talented with mixing up the menu while still keeping the core elements intact.  I like that they don't muss with the food too much - i don't particularly like my food 'handled'. 
Best prepared foie gras ever! Price point is excellent for the quality of the food and its preparation.  Casual but special ambiance - perfect balance.
author: Marie V.

description: Loved the foi gras when it was still legal.  Love the raw oysters.  Still enjoy coming here for the ambiance and great food.  One of our few favorites.
author: Von C.

description: came here on a weekday for a birthday party of 12.  food was good, prefix menu price was real good.  ;)  but one thing for sure, this is not a place for a big group.  the lady who was taking our orders messed up several times, even our table was not completely set up so 4 out of 12 had to sit at crooked side of the table.  Anyways, I ordered drink, she wrote it down but never came.  I didn't order soup but it came and ended up paying for it.  Also, we found out they charged us an extra shrimp dish.  i read some of the reviews talking highly about the service & ambiance but it wasn't my case.   *shrug*
author: Jee C.

description: Food are fantastic overall.Also, the good ambiance made my dinner. However  the price is a bit  high to me.
author: Cedric L.

description:
My favorite dinner place in San Francisco...so far...and I do eat out a lot because I don't (can't) cook. The food is unbelievably delicious. I've tried everything on their menu as I've eaten here 2x/week for the past 2 years. I'm ADDICTED! Excellent, attentive staff. They call me by my name, they know and sit me on my favorite table, and they don't let my wine glass dry out :) 

This place can get really packed especially on the weekends so try make reservations (sometimes you still have to wait even with reservations) but definitely worth it.
author: John T.

description:
My friend and I had a truly wonderful experience at ISA and we will be talking about it to friends and relatives.  I am thrilled so see how well the new owner has taken over this restaurant and steered it into a remarkable direction.  Every dish was very flavorful, well thought-out yet not too sophisticated that it becomes high-brow.  Some of my personal favorites: Dungeness crab salad, steak with Bearnaise sauce and the creme brulee, perfectly crispy.

The service was impeccable and the atmosphere, enhanced by the cozy décor, was very lively.  Very versatile crowd, too.

A top-notch experience altogether.
author: Fabrice H.

description:
I've passed by this cute little restaurant numerous times, but never paid it too much attention. BIG mistake! 

Luckily, my friend suggested we try this place for DAT. We went with a group of six and we seated in the most adorable back "room". I say "room" because it was almost like it was an outdoor patio with strug lights, wood paneled walls, heat lamps, and foliage. It was almost a perfect setting for a first date. However, I was dining with 5 dudes, so the romantic atmosphere was non existent. :) 

We were able to try almost every appetizer- the salmon carpaccio, persimmon salad, and mussels were delish. The calamari was a little chewy for my taste, but the flavors were very distinct. I had the petrale sole as my main dish- it was cooked perfectly, but the sauce was a little too rich for me. It was a butter sauce, but the fish was soak with butter. Tasty, yes....but it was a little overpowering at times. I had a piece of the flat iron steak- good flavors, but they recommend cooking it medium rare. I normally eat my steak that way, but this medium rare was still cold in the middle. We had it sent back to cook a little longer, so I would recommend ordering it medium. 

For dessert I had the Grapefruit Granite- a dressed up Slushee. It was very refreshing, but the tartness of the grapefruit flavor was overpowering. The Semifreddo all'Amaretto was definitely my favorite of the night! It was absolutely delicious and I would come back just for that single dessert!
author: lauren j.

description:
Oh my goodness, Isa you have really outdone yourself.  If I were to have rated this restaurant the first time I ate there about a year ago, I would have given them 4 stars.  Last night they deserved 5.  It just exceeded my expectations being especially good last night.  I think I had three of the same dishes too (the chicken, scallops, and steak) but this time it was phenomenal!  

I never typically order chicken when I eat out but this was one of the best I've ever tasted - incredibly juicy, crisp skin, fabulous sauce.  In fact, every single one of our sauces were amazing.  So good that all the girls at the table protested when the server tried to take away our plates - because they wanted to lick the plates clean.  The truffled sauce for the spaghetti was just unreal.  Foie had some kind of rhubarb-tasting sauce that went nicely.  The flat-iron steak, a delicious chimichurri, and the perfectly seared scallops over mashed potatoes and asparagus in a very good mushroom-y marsala.
