Came here for Valentines Day and had the prie-fix menu. Amazingly delicious food and artful presentation. Everything about this restaurant is appealing. The ambiance is dark and romantic, the service is attentive without being obnoxious, and the food is sublime. Portions are fitting of the small plates concept, but is enough to share with your special someone. 
Highly recommend! 
P.S - the creme brulee is to die for
author: Stacy T.

description: An amazing find in the Marina. The French California fusion is  tantalizing for your tastebuds. The yellowtail was amazing and the duck was superb. Make a reservation and ask for the patio for a Parisian bistro experience. Go forth & enjoy!
author: Todd S.

description: Went here on a double date and was truly "wow-ed!" The food and wine was absolutely delicious. I loved how the server recommended the bottles and really listened to our preferences to do so. We've been to other restaurants in the area "known for their wine," and they've never been as helpful. Anyway, since it's family style plates, we all started off with a bowl of the asparagus soup. It was great. I've never has asparagus soup before, but it won't be the first and last time. After that, we ordered some warm brie cheese and calamari. The  cheese was delish and they said they calamari was too. For the entrees to share, we ordered the chicken with mashed potatoes, the truffle spaghetti, and the truffle risotto. Can you tell we are truffle fans?! The chicken was so juicy and cooked perfectly. I could of eaten the whole plate myself. The truffle spaghetti and risotto were very tasty also. I usually stay away from risotto because I think it's so thick and boring, but not Isa'a risotto! I also could of eaten this entire dish myself. Although we had a WONDERFUL time with great company, my hubby and I joked afterwards that we can't wait to go back and each order at least two entrees and eat like pigs. We are really looking forward to bringing out of town guests to Isa. P.S. Reservations are a must. They were nice enough to squeeze us in at the last minute, but warned us that the table was only good for 2 hours. They meant it! Once 9:00 hit, they politely asked us if we'd indulge in dessert at the bar. We cooperated and sat in the seats they were saving for us. Although ideally we would of stayed where we were, they did squeeze us in and give us a fair warning. They definitely felt bad and gave us all a complimentary glass of Prosecco to go along with our creme brûlée.
author: Kelsey K.

description:
it was ok, not memorable. foie gras was nice, but the lamb and steak were overcooked and really were not impressive
the mushrooms side was nice
author: I B.

description:
I went the first time for a yelp "grub" club dinner, and was able to sample many dishes (well, not super many, as I am a pescatarian) and I very much enjoyed the spicy tuna tartare, but as other yelpers have noted, it really is not spicy.  I went again last night with a more humble group (just 3 of us) and I decided to try the lobster broth, this was exquisite!  The distinct broth actually tasted like lobster, and it was delightfully presented with tiger prawns.  Having previously tried the potato-wrapped seabass, which I thought was too dry, I passed on it but my buddy ordered it.  She loved it, but it really did appear burned. On the burned note, this time the creme brulee was not, but it was very mildly flavored.  Isa has a nice back patio, and it is perfect for those rare, warm and clear San Francisco nights.

 (p.s. A waiter that sincerely compliments you on your shoes, is a waiter whom I will request for life).
author: Mai G.

description:
$30 for 3 course meal!?!
insanely cheap for how good the food are, this is easily $60+ at Santana Row
on top of that the service is excellent! I will definitely recommend to more people!
author: Jordan D.

description:
I am a foodie...I love food. I cook food. I eat food. I know food...and I know that I love Isa.

I've dined here four times and I'm still in awe of the adorable back patio. Makes me feel like I'm at a friend's wedding and she tented her (very expensive) backyard.

My favorite dishes:
Seared Scallops...perfectly cooked, tender and flavorful.
Maple Leaf Duck Breast...juicy, flavorful, rich and tender enough to cut with a butter knife.

Another plus for the wine list.  They have plenty of bottles under $40.
author: Betty Y.

description:
Great... I really hate being that mensch bag who thinks that their review, which just so happens to be the 385th, will mean much at all to anyone anywhere.  As if this schlock of a review will somehow mention something that hasn't already been briefed, critiqued, noted, evaluated, and or examined.  Fear not though, for I will spare you this parade of mumbo-jumbo-ness with a simple recapitulation of the salient facts of this fine establishment.   

ISA is the shit... it's tapas so the portions are small; hence order many dishes.  For the quality it is dirt cheap.  In addition, Isa has been coveted the rhett s. "oenophiliac golden goblet" award for their plethora of fine wines.  

what to eat:
*Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese 
*Farmers Market Tomato Salad
*Baked Butterfish in Paper
*Caramelized Dayboat Scallops
*Potato Wrapped Halibut
*Grilled Natural Flat Iron Steak

decor/ambiance... just read any of the 384 other reviews
author: Rhett S.

description:
Isa's...

Is a form of art - Dungeness Crab Salad
Is a godsend - Potato Wrapped Halibut
Is a tantalizer - Caramelized Scallops
Is a sweetie - Flourless Chocolate Cake

Isa's is a quaint Asian Inspired French restaurant in the Marina I can't afford to frequent, but treasure every opportunity I go...
author: Sue L.

description:
As a native of San Francisco, I can't believe I've never been here before. This place is Great! 

Love the Food (Mussels, Oysters, Scallops, Ribs, Dungeonesscrab) was all extremely satisfying. Perfect for 2 for sharing. Total Bill for 2 was about $150, including wine.

LOVED the heat lamps and candles in the back patio. Super Romantic and perfect 2nd date place. (It's a little noisy for 1st dates).

Parking.. sucks on a Friday night, but there's always a metered garage 2 blocks away. 

I'll definitely be back!
author: Emily L.

description:
If you're ever planning a surprise birthday or any other kind of party for me, you should know that I don't like tapas.  I'm assuming, of course, that you like me.  If you dislike me and are willing to go to all the trouble of planning a surprise birthday or any other kind of party for me, you should definitely select a tapas place.  That way, you'll know that I really hate my surprise party even though I won't say so; I'm just too gracious for that.

I think I've reviewed enough tapas places for people to know why I don't like tapas.  And all tapas places seem to demonstrate the mediocrity of tapas places.  They're just not very different even though they're supposed to epitomize culinary and cultural diversity.  Whatever.

When I came with family to this place, my normal reasons for hating tapas were compounded by the fact that we had to wait a long time to be seated and then had to wait an hour or so for our food.  Then we had to wait a long time for more food.  The back patio thing is nice, and our server was OK, but I really don't like tapas, and if I had been paying, it would have felt like April 15.  Except that somehow, some way I actually get indirect benefits from paying taxes.  I don't get any benefits from paying too much for glorified finger foods.
author: John S.

description: A Yelp! success story! Thanks to Russ S. for the initial recommendation. Service was flawless. Food was perfect and delicious. Atmosphere stylish. The duck and seared yellow fin tuna small plates were the highlights.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I really enjoyed everything i had here from the risotto to the scallops to the oysters..everything was so tasty and the place was super cute. We sat out in the enclosed patio. The service was fast and efficient. The only thing i can criticize is what is up with the creepy host lady with her eyes...I noticed it after an hour into our meal. She would walk around and just LOOK with her eyes. The first time she came to our table to check on us to see if everything was good and it was great but she just got creepy eyes later. Not sure sure if it was because the place was getting busy or what but other than that, I would definitely come back and bring friends.
author: Ravenous T.

description:
I have been waiting long and hard for this moment.  Writing an official, honest to goodness update to my review for Isa from 2006.  How many times have I been there now?  I've celebrated at least two birthdays, been there on first, second, and third dates, shared numerous bottles of wine with some of my most loved people - my best friends, my family.  Sat in the back patio, sat in the front, sat at the bar.  Oh the memories ... 

And now 2 years later, I take a moment to reflect.  just like how the restaurant was named after the chef/owner's little girl, we've all in grown up, seen a few changes, learned a few things over the years, made quite a few fond memories.  We've all changed up our menus, looked at things from a fresh perspective, had some ups, as well as some downs no doubt.  Found ourselves perhaps or at least continued to strive to do so.

And for this, Isa has truly persisted to be, through the years, my favorite restaurant in the San Francisco.  No place feels quite so much like home yet dazzles  afresh every time.

I will never stop ordering the baked butterfish and the butter lettuce salad (hmm... pattern?).  I will definitely start ordering the baked goat cheese and mussels.  And for you foie gras loving folks out there, you will be happy to know that my parents will probably continue to indulge in that dish without me.  And with 20 other amazing small plates on the menu, I know I won't be getting bored.

Plus, Mondays through Thursdays are prix fixe nights!  Supposedly they did it to give some love back to the real locals.  How Yelptastic is that?
author: Audrey T.

description:
Thanks to my fellow yelper recommendations, I had a very enjoyable meal here. I go out about 4 times a week and this is probably one of the best meal in the last 3 months. I know I will be thinking of this meal many months later. What did I order?

- Foie Gras serve (The Foie Gras was served with bread that taste like sponge cake/soft toast bread. The two items go really well together. 5 stars)
- Local Fish Ceviche (Fresh fish that tastes like scallops sashimi. 5 stars)
- Baked Butterfish in Paper (yummy and good fish. 4 stars)
- Caramelized Scallops (The top and bottom were slightly brown "burned" but not bitter, that is the way I love it. 6 stars if I could)
- Lamb (good but we were a little too full. 4 stars.)
- Cream Brulee (3 stars)

I will give five stars for the service. Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Ervinna L.

description:
I joined a few fellow Yelpers last night as part of the first installment of the Yelp Supperclub here for dinner. Perhaps I internally over-hyped Isa...It's not that it was bad by any means, it was actually quite good...However, it just wasn't as delectable as I had built it up to be. Hence the 4 star rating...It just wasn't quite good enough to be a 5 star experience but perhaps that is totally my hang-up...

We sampled the menu quite extensively and while I find nothing wrong with anything that we ate (most of it was quite delicious) it just left me somewhat underwhelmed. That said, at least I didn't go down to the street after wards and get something from the KFC-Taco Hell combo of evil which would have been the ultimate insult to any restaurant worth it's salt.

I will say this, the service was excellent our waiter was both knowledgeable and attentive. He made excellent suggestions and had just the right blend of obsequiousness and sarcasm. 

If you go I would recommend that you perhaps try Nectar next door for a few pre-dinner glasses of wine as the bar area in Isa is small and they have this large annoying flower thing in the corner that we keep poking you in the eye (at least it did it to me). As far as suggestions go from the menu I would recommend the following (they are small plates so assume 2 plates per person when sharing):

To Start:
-Tuna Tartare (this was perhaps the best thing I ate last night)

Main Plates:
- Potato Wrapped Seabass
- Grilled Flatiron Steak
- Roasted Rack of Lamb
- Dayboat Scallops
- Truffled Risotto

All were quite delicious and the portions seemed to be appropriate.
author: Todd E.

description:
One star less because:
1. parking was a bitch
2. i hate the marina
3. the place was a zoo

...but the food was perfect!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Slightly forgettable meal.  I did love the covered patio area.  You could have blindfolded me on the way over and as soon as you took the blindfold off I'd know I was in the Marina...you gotta love the gosh darn Marina...

Anyway, an o-k restaurant but I wasn't impressed, especially with the slow service.  I was honestly wondering if our server was drunk, so oddly that made me less annoyed about the not so good service. 

I had the ceviche and the truffle spaghetti.  The menu is pretty random, but I do love small plates usually.  I was starving, so I ate every bite.  The spaghetti was pretty amazing, very truffle-y.  

I was dining out w/my ladies, but this could be a nice date spot because the patio, while slightly crowded, was a nice atmosphere.  They also had a flourless chocolate cake that looked to-die-for!  I might come back for a glass of wine and some dessert.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Dinner at Isa, despite the subpar service, is absolutely delicious.
author: Miriam W.

description:
For my birthday dinner, I came to Isa w/ my roomies after hearing great things about this restaurant.  We sat in the covered patio area, which was cozy and dimly-lit.  The patio is heated with several heat lamps so no need to worry about the SF chill.  We also had a cute male waiter who was super friendly and attentive ;).    

I LOVE that the dishes come out one at a time, in order of the items listed on the menu (apps, entree, sides, dessert).  My biggest pet peeve is when restaurants, especially tapas ones, bring out food too quickly.  I like slowly enjoying my meal, one dish at a time.  
 
We shared:  
*dungeness crab salad w/ apple, grapefruit and avocado - light and refreshing.
*yellowfin tuna tartare with nori, wakame and avocado - surprisingly fresh tuna and delicious avocado/guac.
*steamed prince edward mussels in garlic and white wine - perfectly tender mussels served in an intoxicating broth that I couldn't stop dipping my bread in.
*potato wrapped seabass w/ capers, tomato confit and lemon juice - loved the crunch of the potatoes and the seabass was flavorful and cooked beautifully.  capers are always a plus for me too!
*truffle mushroom risotto with shaved reggiano - this dish is very rich, creamy and cheesy.  I loved the variety of mushrooms and sharp cheeses. 
*roasted rack of lamb served on a bed of sauteed eggplant, zucchini, red peppers, and nicoise olives - the lamb was too undercooked (we asked for medium) and the veggies were over-salted.  this was my least favorite dish.
*brussel sprouts w/ bacon and garlic - savory, but nothing special.  brussel sprouts were overcooked and on the mushier side.
*flourless chocolate cake w/ vanilla bean gelato - the gelato was great, but the cake had a slightly aromatic scent, which threw me off.

The total was $120 (excl. tip) for 3 girls, no drinks.  Loved this place and definitely coming back for more!
author: Jen Y.

description:
Page 308 - - - - 
Dear Diary,

Do you remember when I wrote to you about "my Firsts"?  I know there have been many.  Remember the time I kissed Paul and how my lips got stuck on his braces, ahh...he was cute!!  Or when I "inhaled" for the first time...WOW...i think I ordered the entire Jack in the Box menu.  Or when I went home drunk for the first time, which also happened to be the first time I saw a penis...hehe...i said penis!!  Let's NOT even go to the first time...I...UMmm...you know..."did it..." cuz having a cop knock on the car window is not something I consider very romantic...oh well, it was just a F#@K anyway.

Well Diary, I experienced another "First" last night and it included a wonderful woman. I was so anxious and nervous but for good reason.  We decided to make Isa our rendezvous and we were nestled in a quaint corner not too far from the window, but yet the scene flickered with candlelight in a dimly lit room.  It was not so busy that we were able to engage in a wonderful exchange of thoughts and words and expression without having to yell or scream our deepest secrets.  

The evening was flowing wonderfully and so was the nectar.  We enticed our palate with a delectable goat cheese with pine nuts, basil and tomatoes on a sizzling plate. The experience continued with a butterfish...Ohhh...so divine...and beautiful and succulent scallops with asparagus...My GOD...it was amazing....BUT the evening did not finish there...it climaxed with a sweet Vanilla Bean Creme Brulee which was accompanied by a glass of sauternes.  

Diary...this had to have been the best dining experience in quite a while.  Not only was the food to die for, but the company was perfect!!  Couldn't have asked for a better night.
author: Karen B.

description:
We were introduced to Isa back in mid 2007, well before we actually relocated to San Francisco.  We still go back to this very day and enjoy this lovely little gem of a restaurant even more with each visit.

Our must have dish is foie gras.  Everything else ordered and happily served is mouth watering.

I beg you to not be afraid to order any item from this wonderful menu.  You'll not be disappointed.
author: Jay D.

description: Came here for DAT and was really excited because it offered a great variety of choices. Before even getting to the restaurant I already knew what I wanted to order: crab salad, scallops, and creme brûlée. The crab salad was alright, not as awesome as everyone else raved about. My date got the tuna tartar which I really liked. Next came the scallops - only 2 pieces! I was under the impression I would be served more than 2... Thankfully I ate a filling lunch otherwise I would be starving! The scallops were good and the mash potatoes even better. Creme brûlée was good as well. The outside seating area is a great place for a date as the tent is hung with Xmas lights and heated lamps. Service was really good too.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I asked for French Fries.

Delicious.

I mean how can French Fries compare to the delicious flavors of
Seared Foie Gras with white peaches & a custard brioche, 
Seared Duck Breast balsamic onions, potato rosti & huckleberry sauce, 
Grilled Flat Iron Steak watercress, potatoes, moutarde verte & a wine sauce, 
Seared Dayboat Scallops with baby Brussels Sprouts , tomatoes, olives & basil, and
Truffled Risotto with mushroom fricasse & reggiano.

We were about to order more Seared Foie Gras with white peaches & a custard brioche because that was a far second from the french fries but we opted for dessert.

Flourless Chocolate Cake
Semifreddo

Both were delicious but the Semifreddo was better.

Totally don't come here, **Wink**.  

Those are probably the best tapas size dishes you can order here.  Service was on point.  Split by four people with a total of $140 which included tip and was the right amount of food.  A great date place with low light, not loud atmosphere, and when you give your date those french fries clothes will be dropping.
author: Po L.

description:
"They call me the hiphop-potamus
cause I got flows that glow like phosphorous
Poppin off the top of this oesophageus
Not because I'm a water dwelling mammal from Africa
Called a hippopotamus I'm not a hippopotamus, I'm a hiphop-potamus
Where did you get the preposterous hypothesis that I was a hippopotamus?
Did Steve tell you?
What's he got to do with it?
Bloody Steve!!"

So, why did I start out my quote with a flow by the illest, hyphiest, flow dropper out there (the hiphop-potamus)?  Because, much like the hiphop-potamus, Isa has flow.  After your party places your order, your food is brought out in a flow beginning with the lightest courses first, and the heaviest courses last.  

First, our party ordered the Dungeness Crab Salad and the Prosciutto de Parma a la Bruschetta.  Both dishes were excellent and can be highly recommended: especially the prosciutto which was served with melon and fresh figs.  

The scallops came highly recommended, and though I didn't personally try any, I can say that they were very popular.  The Halibut was perfectly cooked and seasoned, also receiving a gold star.  

Finally, I enjoyed the Flat Iron Steak - which was absolutely fantastic.  Additionally, our service was excellent.  Not only did our server recommend dishes to try, he steered us clear of the options he didn't personally think were their best.  Personally, I truly appreciate that type of honesty from a server.  

So if you've heard this place isn't worth your dime (Did Steve tell you that?  What has he got to with this?  Bloody Steve!), you've been mislead.  Check out Isa next time you are looking for a romantic dinner for two - or even better on your next double date (so you can sample more of their fantastic dishes).
author: Matthew H.

description:
Yeah, yeah...the Marina. I should have known better on a Friday eve or basically in general. Celebrated a joint bday with my mom, aunt and uncle here. Food and reviews looked promising and when we got 2 glasses of wine at the bar for $10 (happy hour I guess) I figured it was a great start to the evening (although the prices on the website winelist are outdated).

Sitting in the heated outside immediately sparked a fight with my mom over my crappy low blood pressure and her adversity to heat lamps. But we worked it out.

The latest trend of all restaurants is the "small plate" bullshit pitch which is basically a money maker for restaurants, and only proceeded to confuse my poor old uncle. The ahem "large" plates are basically like your entree with smaller falling into the appetizer category.

My mom ordered the boulibase which came full of muscles (which she hates) and not the clams as promise on the menu. When I asked the waiter about it, he mumbled something about needing a new writer and checking with the kitchen. He never followed up, so I asked again and he said it was a new chef. uh..ok. We had like 4 different people bringing out food in a rush, and all plating in front of the wrong person. They snatched our measly 2 pieces of bread away before we could finish chewing. My aunt's entree showed up late and my uncle had barley put his fork down before they snatched his plate as well.

All and all, the food tasted good, but not worth all the hassle for the cost. They even gave us some other table's check, so we had to wait and flag down some other waiter to get the correction. I know it was crowded, but we had advance reservations for a while, and a skinking candle or comped coffee would have been nice considering the mess ups. Eh-not again...
author: Dani D.

description:
In the past year I've heard several people mention Isa as a definite "must try" and last night I finally got to check it out for myself. The food was fantastic and it was really cool to walk by the kitchen on our way to the table, it gave you an appreciation for just how busy the cooks are.

I really enjoyed the risotto and the flat-iron steak, those alone made the trip worthwhile. I'm also a fan of their roasted chicken (I know it sounds boring but it most certainly isn't). 

We were in a group of 5, which worked out well but I can imagine getting better service if you were in a smaller group. The table was a little small for all the plates we were receiving and if I go back again I'll probably keep the group to a maximum of four people.
author: Bryan B.

description:
This is not a place that WOWed me.  

The first courses were bland and tried to make it up by being salty (and this is coming from someone who likes salt!).

The second courses were excellent: we ordered the chicken and the steak, both were seasoned and cooked to perfection.  The steak was moist and tender and could quite possibly be the best steak I've had.

Not worth the hype, come but skip the first courses
author: Tangerine L.

description:
When you find yourself in munching mood for tapas especially  after a happy hour bar hopping- make Isa a choice destination.  The hostess was happy to accommodate us on a walk in basis on a THURSDAY night 745  seating!

My friends and I wanted to eat but wanted a lean and light meal with a few small plates.   I had bookmarked this on Yelp - and remember that it  was known for its small plates goodies.   It wasn't long before we arrived with other diners vying for seats.  My kudos to our gracious host who tried to seat everyone ASAP and having inspected her board and talk with the manager, we got our go signal- and got a table in the back tent.   With our libation mood still intact- we ordered a bottle of Pinot to start on these plates:- 

The Saffron Paella was wonderful- it contained fresh juicy mussels, tender sweet prawns, and soft briny calamari deliciously buried in the saffron rice stew of peas and bell peppers- I would have preferred a little drier version- but this was a tasty alternative.

The Spicy Tuna Tartare was rendered in an Asian influence with a tangy sweet seasoning-sesame ginger wasabi taste.  I wasn't particularly attracted to the avocado compote with  edemame and pinenuts.

The Honey Spiced Grilled Calamari arrived on a bed of arugula and rice with lemon wedges.  It was wonderfully charred with just enough sweetness to compliment the sour lemon zest.

PS- Get a table in the back - it was so much more cozier and the al fresca ambiance makes it a worthwhile dining experience.  This restaurant also makes My List of Paella destination in the city- 

The Paella shall be judged on the following: 1) Rice: The delicate saffron and broth used to cook to rice- It was just a little too wet for my liking but rice was almost* mushy but compensated by rich taste.2) The Seafood/ Meat- Freshness and Variety - Isa met the fresh and quality  3)Overall- I would definitely order this again to see if it passes the next time ;-)  3.5/5 stars on this plate!
author: Arissa C.

description:
I've been waiting to try Isa for months... and finally had the chance to try it with my boyfriend last night. And it was divine!

I made a reservation for two on OpenTable for 8:15 on a Friday night.  We got to the Marina at around 8, and surprisingly found parking in under 5 minutes.  We waited at the bar for our table for around 15-20 minutes, and proceeded to order some wine.  We were seated in the patio area in the back, and it was lovely.  Our server was very friendly and we ended up ordering 4 dishes to share.  I love the medium to smaller dish concept because it lets us try more things!  We had such a hard time deciding which dishes to try, but ultimately decided on butterfish, flat iron steak, paella, and special of the night: beef short ribs. 

The butterfish came first, and it was baked in paper with mushrooms and truffle oil I believe.  It was very tender and the flavors pretty much worked wonderfully.  It was definitely one of my favorites.

The flat iron steak was topped off with some bleu cheese, to which I dont really like but the steak itself was delicious.  bf devoured it in five minutes flat.

Braised short ribs was the super star of the night.... tender, juicy, perfectly cooked and paired with broccoli and mashed potatoes.

Saffron paella was just okay.... I like my paella a little different and without edamame, so i could do without this dish in the future. tasty, but not memorable.  I'd go with risotto next time maybe.

We must sound like pigs but we literally finished off every plate and licked it clean.  They were smaller portions so I guess three would have been sufficient but I'm glad we ordered what we ordered....the experience was terrific. 

Great ambiance, great service.  Nice wine list, and I'd say this is a great place for a nice Friday night dinner with friends or just your sig other. 

Too stuffed to try dessert, but will def return next time to try.

Isa, youre now my favorite dining spot in the Marina! xoxo
author: Peggy W.

description: The food is tasty, but the service is not good and  awkward. I was excited to go, but wasn't too impressed. Maybe I would have enjoyed it better in the back patio. Not planning on going back.
author: Olya S.

description: very good food! Grilled calamari severed with flageolet beans is my favorite~  One comment: The waiter/ waitress usually recommends two dishes per person, but I found it is a bit too much. We order 5 dishes for 3 people and we couldn't finish it. I think I will order less next time and save some room for deserts.
author: Yve H.

description:
ISA GOOD!

Ok, that was lame. But hot damn, the food at Isa is GOOOOD!!

We were late, naturally, but Isa was ready to seat us as soon as we arrived. Too bad they squeezed the four of us onto a two top! Sucky move on their part, but actually, I hardly noticed (maybe it was the booze). Ultimately, it didn't matter too much since we ate family style, but appropriate space would've been nice.

The tiny quarters make for a cozy dining experience. With the heat lamps and low lighting, this place is best suited for dates, but they can still handle medium to large groups. The waitstaff is attentive and take care of your needs without being intrusive.

Onto the food! 

We started with oysters, which were absolutely delicious. Perfect starter / amuse bouche. GET THEM.

Next came a quick succession of appetizers, with each dish timed perfectly to arrive as we finished the previous one. The transition to entrees was seamless.

Crab salad was really good, but small-ish. I'd get it again, but it's pretty expensive for its size.

Grilled calamari was a nice change of pace from the typical breaded stuff, but got mixed reactions at our table. I thought the flavors were good, others were unimpressed. Be prepared for whole baby squid! (How else do you think they'd grill it? haha)

Dayboat scallops were OMFG TO DIE FOR GOOD! We devoured these, and I was tempted to order another plate just for myself. Easily the best dish of the night, hands down.

Baked butterfish was tender and buttery, not dry at all. The truffles and mushrooms paired well with it. Definitely a winner.

We also ordered the chicken, and what a great choice! We were wary initially, but Isa makes fantastic chicken! The (white!) meat was tender and juicy, the skin fried to crispy perfection, and mmm, the sauce! 

Our last main dish was the Saffron Paella. I thought it had potential, but my friend Virginia (who loves paella) pointed out the glaring lack of crispy paella pan-crust. The lobster broth was also so delicate, you could barely taste it. On the other hand, there was plenty of seafood piled into it, so points for that. Overall, we thought this the worst dish of the night.

For dessert, we ordered the vanilla creme brulee for dessert. GUH. Jebus, this was good! You know how most of the time you want more of that carmelized sugar on top? The custard is so good, you'd be happy with just that. But they give you plenty of crunch anyway!

When our bill came, I was plesantly surprised. Two bottles of wine and plenty of food (I was still hungry, but I'm ALWAYS still hungry), and it was only $50 a person! For such great food, I thought it was a steal.

I love Isa. Take me here, and I'd definitely put out ;)
author: Albert H.

description:
I cannot truly tell you how good the food is.  How amazing the service was or how fabulous my time there was but I am definitely going to try..  The scallops, truffled pasta, and the lobster broth soup was to die for.  If a restaurant can present to me happiness on a plate then I am certainly ready to shout from the roof tops telling everyone to try this place.  

After running late (and calling to let them know of course) our table was ready as soon as we arrived.  The waiter encouraged the Romanticism of the evening and gave recommendations that were fabulous.  Instead of encouraging us to eat more than necessary the waiter made sure to let us know if we had ordered the right amount of food.. and you know what?  It was perfect.  I was pleasantly stuffed full of amazing food that had flavors that made my tongue jump for joy.  Fabulous food, service, and ambience.  It was a fabulous night...  Hopefully yours will be as well
author: Kylie L.

description:
Came here on a Monday night for the first time with no reservations and had no problem getting a table.  Guess it is much crazier later in the week and weekends.  Sat on the patio and thought it was fantastic.  Went with a friend of mine from out of town and we mentioned that another might join us for dessert.  Some restaurants would have a problem with this but they set us up with a great 3-set table outside.   The server was chatty and nice and seemed willing to put up with my bad attempts at humor, which is always a plus.

Food was all good.  Tuna tartare, tiger prawns, and halibut were all solid.  Goat cheese and chocolate cake dessert were outstanding.  All went well with the bottle of Sav. Blanc they had on special for $30...  :)

But have to give special mention to the asparagus - maybe the best I've had in the city if not ever.  Wow.   Asparagus like this is worth having funny-smelling pee any day.
author: Brad C.

description: Family style French = genius. The mushroom risotto, short rib special, potato wrapped seabass were amazing and the scallops were perfectly cooked. Try not to eat too much bread and save yourself for all the courses! A bit loud, but the patio was a great group setting.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: We went to Isa.  Good choice for a seafood fusion spot in the Marina district
author: Ray W.

description:
Before I tell you, dear readers, about our amazing meal at Isa last night, I'd like to comment on the vegan, hippie Nazis giving negative reviews to any restaurant serving foie gras.  Better those little duckies and geese than me!  What's a little pain and cruelty compared to the end result that is foie gras?  What's the difference between a humane death and an inhumane death for these animals that are to be eaten?  Are you all telling me that you go throughout life without causing ANY harm to other living things?

Also, why can't they use veggie stock?  BECAUSE IT TASTES LIKE SHIT.  I applaud the chef for not compromising his craft by giving into these asinine requests.  If you don't like what's on the menu, go elsewhere.  I recall a vegetarian restaurant right around the corner that I'm sure you'd love -  you'll make fast friends with the malnourished patrons I saw exiting:  maybe you guys could even plan your next PETA rally?

Ahhhh...I fell better.  Please make this recent California transplant feel welcome.  Flame on, hippies!!

Isa is more like a "design your own tasting menu" - proper pacing and excellent service make this stand out from more typical, tapas-style restaurants.  The food we ordered was excellent for the most part, and I'd say that this is the best small plate restaurant I've been to in recent years.  What we ordered:

1) "Smooth" Asparagus Soup
2) Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese
3) Rigatoni with black truffles
4) FOIE GRAS
5) Potato Wrapped Seabass
6) Grilled Flatiron Steak

I was expecting smaller portions, and on our next visit we will order one or two less plates.  The Foie Gras was my favorite followed by the  baked goat cheese and the flatiron steak.  The moutarde verte was an excellent compliment to the steak and don't forget to eat the watercress!  I saw many tables leave these greens untouched.

The asparagus soup was WAY under salted and the rigatoni used very low grade black truffles with almost no taste or aroma - but I didn't expect much at this price point.

I'd give Isa 5 stars if they properly seasoned their dishes coming out of the kitchen rather than relying you utilizing the dish of salt at the table.  Also, the wines by the glass were relatively uninspiring and didn't match well with our courses.

I'll definitely be back soon
author: Will H.

description:
I'm pretty sure my last trip to Isa was the best meal I've had in months. Terrific service, awesome company with the BF and the parentals, perfect table on the outdoor patio. I promise you can't go wrong with the following: butter lettuce salad, grilled calamari, flat iron steak, baked butterfish, halibut, asparagus, and truffle spaghetti. And don't pass on dessert - I don't care if you are dining alone, get both the warm chocolate cake AND the creme brulee.

So, why not five stars? While OUR server was absolutely amazing, the guy taking care of the table next to us clearly was unaware of his physical being. Though not a huge guy by any means, I cannot tell you how many times I was almost taken out during my delicious meal by his elbows and his ass. Personal space, please!
author: Carolyn C.

description:
I had a very disatisfying experience with the service.  ...

My party arrived about 10 minutes late (it's super crowded and busy in the Marina, so hard to find parking!) but we had reservations.  They ended up giving our table away and we were seated 35-40 minutes later.  The waitress was actually really nice and we went through the hour well.  However, one of our dishes was not served, a pasta dish with mushrooms (one of my vegetarian friends ordered this dish), and the lead server comes out and rudely told us that it wasn't coming out since the kitchen was closed and he didn't know why we didn't get served this last dish, speaking to us as though it was our fault that they missed the dish!  Not to mention, the fact they seated us late coincided with their kitchen closing!  

As one of my friends started to tell him that he was speaking to us in a rude way, he cuts her off, tells us that it's better if we don't make a scene, and walks away!  We were totally floored!  I've never been treated so rudely before at a restaurant!  For the price you're paying for small dishes, you'd expect the service to match it. 

I personally would not go back!  Would not recommend it as a good place for larger groups, probably better for couples, and would recommend not going during the busy Friday-Saturday night timeframe.
author: SF Diner A.

description:
Num num num. The sound of savoring every bite of these small tapa dishes. 

1. Crab salad - Fresh crab meat with crunchy lettuce and slices of grapefruit. 

2. Goat cheese - Warmed the perfect amount and topped with pine nuts. Try it with the bread.

3. Foie Gras - The creaminess of duck liver was never so good.

4. Scallops - SCALLOPS!!!!!!!! MASH POTATOES!!!! *drool* On top of that, they included brussel sprouts -- my least favorite vegetable. Yet, somehow they made it taste great.

5. Yellowtail - Said fish garnished with cucumbers, tomatoes, and artichokes. 

6. Risotto - Not a risotto fan in general so not much to say.

7. Duck breast - Duck was never sooooo goooood.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Sometime in June, Euge L. brought me here for the very first time. 

We decided to dress up for fun. Him in a suit, and I in a dress. We went out to dinner at this wonderful little restaurant called Isa. People were looking at us weird. Yeah, we were quite a bit overdressed, but we were on our way to the "opera" or "theatre." ::sticks nose up:: Okay, we really weren't, that was our excuse! "Fuck 'em," Euge would say. All what really matters is us enjoying our night! 

And that's what we did.

Try to get outdoor seating if you can, it's so nice!

Isa serve their plates in small portions; family style. They usually recommend about 2-3 dishes per person, so it would be good to go out with a whole bunch of people so that way you can try out more of what they have.

I really liked the smooth potato and leek soup; the croutons in it is the best part. They never give enough croutons, so be sure to ask for extra on the side.

Spicy tuna tartare - A must for every visit.

I never had lamb before because they're such innocent animals, but I figured it's time for me to finally try it out. And it was really good!

Seared duck breast - Mouth watering.

To go with your meal, a nice bottle of Taz Pinot Noir.

Slightly chilled.
author: Nance W.

description:
Sampled the foie gras, lobster bouillabaisse, flank steak- all were extremely tasty.  Four dishes for 2 people seemed to be plenty.  We topped it off with a vanilla gelato, which I found to be anything but "vanilla."
The restaurant was quiet on a Monday night, the wait staff exceptionally polite and accommodating. An enjoyable Anniversary meal to say the least.

Parking is the only pain. Although that is typical for many great SF restaurants.
author: David M.

description:
Has a really wonderful--and extremely reasonable--dinner at Isa. 
Recession pricing seems to be in full effect, so my friend and I were able to get a decent bottle of wine and two courses each for about $50 each with tip. I'd suggest sitting in the covered back patio if you can... it's really a very charming setting.

The place seems to bill itself as a tapas restaurant, but I thought the portions were rather generous for what I've come to experience at other "small plates" places. (The recommend two courses each and that is about right.) In addition, everything we ordered was executed pretty well and really tasty.

The mushroom risotto was delicious... great mushroom flavors, and the risotto was cooked well. The skirt steak, while cooked a bit unevenly, was absolutely delicious in flavor. The au gratin potatoes were also exceptionally delicious.

Service was attentive, not pushy, and rather pleasant. Nothing overly remarkable, but indeed quite competent. Isa may not have some of the "name" as other places, but what it lacks in prestige it certainly makes up for in everything else that really counts.
author: Aaron L.

description:
A definite San Francisco favorite.  Not only do you get great food, you get less of the crowd and hype as other well reviewed restaurants.

Small plates are the way it's served here - and thank God because you'll want to try everything.  It's actually nice to go with atleast four people because you'll get a chance to order more items then if it were just two.  

It's all about consistency for me.  If I can go to a place and I know that I'm going to get the same great flavors I experienced last time, you're tops in my book.  This place delivers that standard.

To start, the lobster broth is delicious.  A great flavor with a bit of froth.  Almost never have a meal here without ordering it.  The grilled steak is always very good, but my favorite (when they have it) is the truffled pasta.  OK, maybe I'm a sucker for truffle anything, but this is just a very nice combination.  Regularly, they will have the truffled rissoto, but it's not quite as good.  The potato wrapped sea bass is also very good.

Other notes : try to get a seat out in the back.  There's just a better ambience back there.  And don't forget to ask your waiter if you've ordered enough food.  They surely steer you toward the right plates if you need more.
author: Minkz N.

description:
We had dinner for the second time in a month at Isa after discovering it from its reviews on this site.  It has quickly climbed up to our top tier of favorite San Francisco restaurants.  The food is consistently prepared with superb quality -- flavorful and fairly priced.  We are huge fans of the "small plate" concept and find that it allows diners to taste a wide variety of dishes in a given evening, and it's a lot of fun.  Everything we've ever had at Isa has been superb.  

Their wine list is pretty basic, but fairly priced.  It's a place where you can go have a high quality meal in an appealing bistro-like environment, at a fair price.
author: Ron R.

description:
EEE-sa (think "eee-va" from Wall-E) was B-O-M-B.

That's right, I said it.  And given the 400 reviews of this place, they're clearly doing A LOT right.  We went last night for my bf's bday, rolling 10-deep plus a few stray drinkers/ non-eaters.

* Ambiance was awesome.  Nice outdoor patio atmosphere, loud, fun, good times.
* Food was SPECTACULAR.  We just ordered about 14 dishes (which is almost the entire menu) and it was high quality and amazing.  Some highlights included:

* Oysters (sooo good and salty!)
* Dungeness crab salad (that crab was so fresh and amazing)
* Chenel goat cheese -- ridiculously good
* Truffled risotto... ridiculous!
* Tuna appetizer... still dreaming about it!

* Service seemed to be the biggest variable among the reviews, but our waiters were incredibly friendly, fast, and knew exactly what to get (booze, booze, booze) to make the bday festivities Legen... wait for it... Dairy.

God, Isa was amazing.  I am dreaming about it as I sit eating my Easy Mac, feeling a sense of incompletion.
author: Julie L.

description:
The atmosphere here is romantic and cozy.  There is a front section that is dark with a bar as well as a garden patio that is lit with pleasant yellow lighting and heat lamps.  It used to be difficult to get a table here, being turned away by snobby door staff, however it is getting easier.

This restaurant serves French tapas, which is small plate French food.  There is a wide selection of meats, fish, and vegetables that are fresh and uniquely prepared.  There is also a prix fixe menu, but the prices aren't very different from ordering a la carte.  I would suggest merely ordering what you want over the prix fixe.

The food is probably French with a Californian flair.  A bit rich for my taste, but enjoyable atmosphere makes it a good place to go with a group.
author: apple r.

description:
Haven't been back to Isa since they first opened ... probably 3 years?  But since I had an opportunity to dine with the "ladies" this week I thought I'd go back for another try.  Thankfully it has kept me in their good books as Isa did not let me down!

The one item that remains in my mind still is the lobster broth!  Served with yummy shrimp and croutons, it's everything a lobster bisque should be, minus the added fat  ;-)

And the semifreddo w/ amaretti.... absolutely amazing!!!!
Waitstaff were kind of.... inexperienced or completely uninterested.  I don't know which.  But when asked they were still responsive - it just bugs me when people shove a plate of food at me like a short order cook!  Suck.  Oh yeah, and the fact that the kitchen refuses to take orders more than once?  Perhaps that could have been suggested more gently.

Ambiance is also very cozy with pseudo-outdoor dining in the cold winter months.  So.. with that said, it was forgiven that the duck came out uncooked and rubbery cuz all I can think about is the yummy lobster broth and the semifreddo amaretti.
author: lulu p.

description:
First of all, no homo on everything i say here. 
I'm a picky eater, when I say there foods are good, they are. me n my girl went there for Dine about town, we had the mussels and salmon as first, mussels was juicy, we murder that dish in no time, salmon was ok, just ok. then we had scallops and iron steaks as second, I'm not a big fan of scallops, so i had my gf kill it instead, so MY main dish came. I ordered medium rare, that steaks were SO juicy OMG, bite into it, melt inside my mouth right the way, steaks so good you can taste the meat and the sauce, not like other restaurant, u can only taste the sauce they put on, meat was so soft, not chewy at all, I can break them apart with my weakass teeth. Finally dessert time, gelato and creme brulee, my girl LOVE the creme brulee, but I like to mix the creme brulee and gelato TOGETHER, I like the texture of the brulee and gelato taste together. also ordered a glass of red wine, forgot wut it was call, some like Windy Hill, not sure, it has the merlot  smell but it doesn't has the merlot taste. haha yea it sounds weird but thats how i feel about it. service was friendly and fast.
author: Kai L.

description:
My best friend and I decided to try out this place for DAT since their menu had one of the most choices for their three-course meals amongst other restaruants. We made reservations for 2 at 7:45pm, left her house early because I knew parking would be a hassle. No joke, it took us over 50 minutes to find parking in this neighborhood. It is straight up crackin' on a Friday night. I think I racked up 7 miles just circling the neighborhood for parking.

25 minutes after our reservations time and 2 late girls scurrying to the restaurant, we finally made it and still had a table reserved.  Our hostess was a doll and sat us down right away, excusing our tardiness.

All the cocktail had soju in the mix. I ordered a Lemon Drop and bff ordered a Grapefruit Cocktail (The Greyhound). My drink tasted fabulous. Lemon drops are hardly wronged by bartenders, thank goodness. The grapefruit cocktail was good, yet bitter. After having a gulp of my lemony sweetness, the grapefruit was purely bitter. Got a buzz, that's all that mattered!

All the dishes were prepared for two people to share. 
Going in order of the items ordered on the DAT menu:
- Organic Loch Duart salmon carpaccio with lemon, creme fraiche, cucumber, egg, capers & corstini : The salmon wasn't as fresh as I read on other Yelp reviews. It could have been more fresh. It tasted exactly like salmon sashimi with a hint of smokiness to it. The creme fraiche threw the taste off a bit and didn't compiment it as well as I hoped. It came with a few thin corstinis which I enjoyed the most on that dish. 
-Dungeness crab salad with avocado, apple, grapefruit & taragon: The fruits in this salad went surprisingly well with the crab. It was real crab meat (bits and pieces of shell were found in my portion) and all in all a good appetizer.
-Pan roasted rocky Jr. Range chicken with fresh herbs, creamy mashed potatoes & jus de poulet: The presentation to this was very poorly done. It was literally just two pieces of chicken and a blob of mashed potatoes on a huge plate without any extra garnish to touch it up. Regardless of the way it looked, it was the best course of the meal. The chicken was tender and not dry and its skin was fried and crispy. The mashed potatoes were buttery. Simple dish.
-Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak with zucchini, polenta cake, moutarde verte & bordelaise sauce: By the time this came out, we were pretty full. I didn't like this dish. The steak was not tender and had a lot of tendons attached to it. Chewing the meat was not a pleasant experience. The zuccinis were bland to the taste along with the polente cake. Putting all three onto my fork and eating it didn't touch-up the taste. We finished less than half of this entree and called it quits. 
-Semifreddo all'amaretto: I couldn't put a finger as to what this exactly was. It was an ice-cream texture because it started melting and there were bits and pieces of almond and cookie crumbles mixed it. It reminded me of almond milk tea... I don't know what it was, but it was amazing! The light almond cookies were soooo good. 
-Vanilla bean gelato with biscotti: Best fried loves vanilla ice-cream so she finished this up and allowed me to have a bite. The vanilla was very strong but it went well with the biscotti. A simple dessert.


Our waiter didn't seem very happy and probably gave us half-assed smiles twice the entire night. Reservation seems like a must for this place. It got pretty packed by the time we left and saw people still waiting to be seated for dinner around 10. I think Isa is a place to try just once...
author: Rosanne L.

description: My girlfriend pointed out the food is kind of Asian flavor and later we found the chef is Taiwanese. Great food combining French and Taiwanese cuisine. The casual style make us feel much more comfortable than usual French restaurants. The waiters are also very nice.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Accidentally stumbled upon Isa on a friday night when we had no reservations. The restaurant was fully booked but we tried our luck and after one cocktail we were in! 

We had no expectations but the menu looked good, and it did NOT disappoint.  There were 3 of us, so we shared our meals (which is what the waiter recommended) 

our meal included: 
1) Grilled Calamari - good, not great. the sauce on the calamari was a little sweet for my liking. 
2) Fresh Oysters - delish
3) Seared foie gras - amazing 5 stars 
4) Duck breast with blueberry sause - also a winner @ 5 stars

the wine was great, the ambiance was nice though a bit noisy and we really liked the wait staff.

definitely will go back again
author: Christine f.

description:
Reviewing restaurants is a tricky thing sometimes.  You can catch a place on a bad night, you can try the few dishes that are excellent (when maybe the overall menu is not great), you can get a server that is not on the game, you can get put in the worst table in the house.  All of these things can affect your "rating" especially if the rating is coming from one visit (which in a city with this much great food, is sometimes the only chance a restaurant will get).

That said, I have been to Isa well over 20 times through the years.  I can honestly say, that it is deserving of the 4 stars.  I have had some 3 star nights, but I have also had some true-blue 5 star nights.

The most recent experience was a 4 star.  The food was excellent.  If you have not tried the sweetbreads here, you are really missing out.  It is one of the best preparations in the city.  The richness of the mashed potatoes, the sauce, the mushrooms and the sweetbreads is truly like a little rich slice of heaven.  The goat cheese is a consistently excellent app, the oysters were fantastic, the flat iron steak was very nice (though I like their old preparation of this this dish much better), and on and on.  We had the grilled calamari, which was great on our previous trip, but very weak this time around.  It is an example of why Isa just misses the 5 star mark.

The service is generally excellent.  This time was decent, though our server was close a talker and had some rocking body odor going on.  If you are lucky enough to get the short floppy haired guy, you are in a for a treat.  I think he is one of the best servers in the entire city.  It's rare that you remember a server, but he loves his job, loves the food, and isn't afraid to give his opinion about that night's particular dishes.  I've even had him check on us if he sees that our server is being inattentive.
author: Andrew M.

description:
San Francisco's best!

I've eaten at many many restaurants in San Francisco, many of which are proclaimed as THE best restaurant in San Francisco.  None are better than Isa (and ISA is 1/2 the cost of many of them).

I have NEVER been disappointed in the quality and flavors of the food at Isa.  The black truffle risotto and the skirt steak are especially good choices.  The aspargus is always cooked perfectly and the Oysters very fresh.

Last time I was there, I discovered that they have an incredible happy hour where all wines were 1/2 off.  Don't know if they still have it, but they have a great wine selection.
author: Robert J.

description:
I had a very nice dinner at Isa last night. We went with the pre-fix $22PP, 2 course meal. They offer this M-T and I thought it was a pretty good deal. I found the portions to be perfect size for two.The wine list is not that big, but very reasonable.
Make sure you go with someone you don't mind sharing with, because they tell you that all dishes are meant to be shared!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Oh Isa, you already know how I feel about you.  How is it going to change anything if I say it out loud?  

Because you want the whole world to know?

Fine, fine, fine.  

I luh...luh...love you.  Happy now?
author: .elin f.

description:
Alphabet Soup- I dinner

Great quality of food, delicious entrees, but nothing too inventive or outside the norm of what you get elsewhere.  I also don't really like paying $3 per slice of sashimi, but it was very high quality and tasty.   Service was good.  Very cute outdoor tented seating area with heaters might make for a good first date.

I hate the Marina, but will cross over to the dark side in the name of good food!
author: Geri-Ayn G.

description:
I've only eaten here once and it was over a year ago.  My stomach's a little sensitive and it flipped out when I ate the squid.  When I say "squid", I mean fancy-squid with all squid-parts pretty much raw and intact; not fried calamri-squid.  And when I say "flipped out", I mean went to all out war with the food I was trying to digest (in case you're wondering, the squid won).  Not fun.  The fact that I'm giving Isa 4 stars regardless means this restaurant is thaaaat good.

Everything else I ate at Isa my stomach loved.  My friend and I still talk about the amazing dinner we had here a year after the fact (btw, the tuna tartare is ridiculous- order it and thank me later).  Service was A+.  Ambiance was a solid A. 

I finally have plans to go back and I couldn't be more excited.  Yup, I got food poisoning and Isa was still one of the best dining experiences I've had in sf.  This is the perfect little restaurant for a special dinner.
author: Nicole K.

description:
My lady took me to Isa last night for my birthday.  I'd never heard of this restaurant before, but it was delicious.  The food is served "family style"...although I can't imagine what kind of family could sustain itself on such portions.  Still, for two people three dishes was the perfect size.
The back patio (although completely closed off from the elements, which kinda defeats the purpose of having a patio to begin with) was nice.  Very romantic.  
Our waitress (server) was very nice to the other tables, which she spent the better part of a half hour chatting up.   We didn't mind because she wasn't actually the one bringing the dishes to the table, so it didn't effect us at all.
I would recommend Isa to anyone, especially couples.  

We got the Spicy Tuna Tartar, Grilled Steak somethingorother and the Seared Duck Breast, which were all very good.  I plan on going back to taste some of their other items (the lamb looked delicious).

My only qualm was the fact that it was in the Marina, which some of you may or may not have a problem with.  Be prepared to deal with yuppies up the whazoo.  But if you can deal with the Banana Republic shirts and frosted blonde tipped spikey hair and not lose your appetite, you'll definitely love Isa.
author: c o.

description:
Although I wouldn't categorize this as Seafood it is definitely French California cuisine located in the Marina (right next to askew grill). The back patio is so intimate, warm, and romantic. Whether you are going in for a casual bite, or a romantic dinner date this is a perfect place for every occasion. 

I highly recommend their PRICE FIXED menu where you can get two plates for a great 21.95$. I highly recommend the Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese and the Pan Roasted Chicken. Although some complain of having to order your meal all at once, this usually isn't a problem for me. The service is excellent, and each plate arrives at perfect time. I have yet to have a bad experience here, which hopefully I will never have. 

I absolutely love the atmosphere and the crowd that shows up at Isa. I'll definitely be eating here for awhile.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Their chicken is to die for, the potato wrapped halibut I can't even describe it is sooo delish! 

Love this place, and the patio outback is great!
author: Jessica D.

description:
celebrated my birthday here last night with 3 friends. we booked through village vines so we saved a lot on the cost of the meal, but were not allowed to participate in the happy hour or prix fixe deals. this however is totally understandable when you're saving 30% on the entire bill.

this was my second time at isa and it was even better than the first. we ordered way more food then we needed and ate it all. the salmon carpaccio is fantastic. the calamari is incredible and the scallops, wow.

you won't be disappointed!
author: Jae C.

description: I took my girlfriend here for our two year anniversary and had a wonderful experience. The food is amazing, service is impeccable and my only complaint is that I had to be rolled home in a wheelbarrow. Lots of food to be enjoyed!
author: Jay G.

description:
I love eating at Isa. I've been there twice now and both times the service has been excellent, the food has been exceptional and the prices seem very fair in my opinion. Also, the enclosed patio dining area is very charming and cozy. 

Incidentally I've had the same waiter twice and he was very enthusiastic, knowledgeable and genuine, I think his name was Dean. 

I definitely plan on going there again.
author: Eugenia T.

description:
Just finished the bar exam this week and wanted to whoop it up Friday night.  Honey planned a nice dinner, but little did I know that the awesomeness was going to rise exponentially.  My best girlfriend surprised me and met us there!!!  They rock and so does Isa.  

Ceviche
Foie Gras*
Baked Butterfish in Paper*
Dayboat Scallops*
Saffron Paella 
Grilled Natural Flat Iron Steak

BTW, if you heart truffle like me, you'll love this place.

*indicates my personal faves of the night
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Great menu of small plates that are meant to be shared.  
We loved everything from the grilled calamary to the seared scallops to the seafood risotto.

The waiter was not pleasant but the food made up for the so so service.
author: Alex L.

description:
So - the first time I came here was on a date, and the second time I came here was with a group of girls...Both great experiences...but....

I have to say the date was much better leading me to believe that some things are meant to be enjoyed in this capacity only. 

I guess the next time I am interested in someone - I will do the ol' hint hint. :)
author: Yelper A.

description: Lovely ambience, excellent food, and wonderful service.  Great place for a casual, fun dinner with friends.
author: Gina C.

description:
Visiting San Francisco for the first time, my experience was definitely enhanced by my visit to Isa with my boyfriend last week. I went to Isa with high expectations based off of the other reviews that I had read on Yelp, but Isa went far above and beyond. Our table was ready on time, which is always a good start. The atmosphere in the back room, where we were sat, was charming, warm and inviting. The servers were very friendly and knowledgeable - we never had to ask for a water or bread refill. The managers stopped by to ensure that everything was well. Finally - the food was amazing. The dishes were flavorful and beautifully presented in a prompt family-style. The baked goat cheese was outstanding and paired really well with the French baguettes at the table. The scallops were perfectly cooked, and the sauce they were in was savory and so good with the asparagus (also cooked perfectly; who likes overcooked, wilted asparagus?). The truffle risotto was life-changing; the texture was just what it's supposed to be, and it was chock-full of wild mushrooms that really complemented the truffle oil and Parmesan flavors. The potato-wrapped sea bass was enjoyable; the contrasting texture of the crispy potato and the sea bass was good. At that point in the meal, however, we were so high off the meal as a whole the sea bass kind of got overlooked. To finish it off, we had coffee and creme-brulee - what could be better?
Isa is obviously dedicated to using fresh ingredients - I appreciated the bowl of freshly ground salt on the tables instead of the typical salt shaker, and also the cubes of natural cane sugar that came with my coffee. The restaurant just embodied a kind of rustic natural ambiance that is so comfortable in such a fast-paced city. 
Also indicative of Isa's charm is the fact that every table contained smiling, laughing, joking couples/friends/families that were celebrating, toasting, and chattering away. Everything, and everyone was just so pleasant and dedicated to having a good time. 
One thing that I really appreciate in restaurants today is simplicity. Don't overshadow the food with crazy flavors/decorations/garnishes, etc. Don't embellish the restaurant with crazy table settings, napkin folds, over-dressed staff, artwork, music, etc etc. That doesn't equate to quality, in any way, shape or form. Let the food stand by itself, and complement it with classic flavors. Isa did this just right; there's something to say for sticking with the classics, and this French restaurant has certainly mastered the delicate balance between classic preparation and innovative flavors in a setting that transcended the city and became an intimate French retreat for all of its guests. The result is nothing less than fabulous. 
Thanks, Isa, for a lovely evening. I can't wait to come back.
Five stars.
author: Molly B.

description: I have been to this restaurant many times and each time I get the same amazing experience. The food here is so delicious and and the ambiance is great. Good place for a date or a small crowd. I highly recommend going here.
author: kate o.

description:
Food = 5 STARS!
Service = 2 stars

My girlfriend and I went on a double date and we all decided to do the special prix fix menu that was going on at the time for charity.  

First off, let me just say that the food was AMAZING.  Nothing was disappointing.  We pretty much tried everything on the prix fix menu (since there were 4 of us and 4 options for each of the three courses) and no one was better than the other.

The service is what drove this review down way more than it deserved.  I felt we were being rushed through the appetizers and main courses.  The dishes did not come out in any kind of order and the servers kept moving our plates, while we were still eating off them!  I suppose they still may have been on their "small plates" cycle, but if you can't handle the prix fix menu, DON'T DO IT!  Quite simple.  And if the initial rush wasn't bad enough, it took _forever_ to get our dessert.

So yes, I'm sure it was a fluke due to the special prix fix menu throwing a wrench into an otherwise well-oiled machine, but still kind of left a bad taste in an otherwise satisfied stomach.
author: Chris M.

description:
3.5 stars.

Our group of seven came here on a Saturday night originally to sample the prix fix menu, but realized quickly that it's only offered Monday-Tuesday. Although the individual dishes are all priced pretty much under $20 each, keep in mind that your total racks up quickly when they recommend you order at least 2 per person + drinks. 

We ordered:
-Oysters: Definitely good but your standard quality oyster. Served with a mignonette that I chose not to flavor it with - I'm a pretty firm believer that good oysters should be served just as is =)
-Salmon Tartar: Tasted awesome with the creme fraiche and I'm always a sucker for the capers and salmon combo. Recommended!
-Foie Gras: We were very excited about this item and ended up ordering 3, but it didn't quite live up to the hype. Served with this bread that I found unnecessary. (Side note - for the best foie gras in the city head over to bushi-tei. I promise you won't be disappointed!)
-Veal Sweetbreads: I liked this one! Sweetbreads were juicy and tender and cooked perfectly. 
-Duck Breast: Heard good things about this one and it did live up to the hype. Ordered it medium rare and it was perfectly cooked and well balanced with the veggie accompaniments. Recommended!
-Flat Iron Steak: Nope. I thought it was underseasoned and someone else thought it was too salty - either way we agreed that it was not properly cooked and completely dry. Skip this and go for the duck instead.
-Bouillabaisse: Good but forgettable.
-Creme Brulee: Standard - nice crust. Vanilla beans on the bottom were a nice touch =)

Overall the ambiance was very quaint in the back and I would be back for the few key dishes and a glass of wine. However, if you're planning on doing a full on mean for ~$70 per person (food, drinks, tax, tip), I would probably recommend you head over to one of the "pricier" restaurants in the city as you'll end up paying the same here for food that is slightly less impressive.
author: Christina L.

description:
Isa is one of the reasons I miss SF like crazy. Crazy like the time my friend and I ordered a dozen kumamotos to go after we devoured a dozen at the bar at Isa. I've had kumamoto oysters many times before, but somehow they managed to snag some ridiculously buttery sweet ones that day and serve them to us lucky diners. In a word? Quality.

Every time I've dined at Isa, I have been impressed by their fresh ingredients, inventive offerings, and consistency in turning out impeccably palatable and well-presented dishes. In the summertime, their simple heirloom tomato cold dish is unparalleled, and the tuna tartare is perfect. 

If you can, ask for a table in the back where the patio/garden is. The twinkle of tiny lights above you and the cozy enclosed 'outdoor space' is a treat for any city dweller. Uber romantic and uber yummy food.
author: tania t.

description:
I went here with friends, and had a really nice time.  Not only was the staff SUPER helpful, especially for a nicer restaurant where some explanation might be needed, the food was really good and simple.

We got a number of small plates and shared them.  A number of seafood dishes, tuna, scallops, crab, and a duck, among others.  Everything was really good, not too rich, but definitely satisfying.
author: Maureen S.

description: I'm currently sitting in Isa. This used to be a tasty romantic place. Now it's a mess. (I will add however that my father sitting across from me might rate it higher because he liked his sea bass.) Firstly we were guided into a crowded back room seating area which felt like having dinner in the middle of a live circus act due to multiple long dinner party tables and crowds arriving and standing, seemingly confused about where to sit or just standing and talking in the small spaces between tables...right next to our table (you also have to walk through the kitchen to get there... Something I don't normally experience). We were moved to another part of the restaurant that was less crowded, in the front, but as there are only 3-4 normal chair tables we were made to sit on bar stool chairs at a tall table which is a little difficult for elderly people. Then we were told, after we each already set our minds on what we would order, that the meals would be served family style and come staggered. That was ok, though it was different from the norm I experienced there before. I mentioned we would rather have everything at once What ensued wasn't OK. We ordered two duck entrees and one sea bass. The menu also looked like it said that one soup was $7.50 and two soups $10. My father and I understood it to read that way. In fact it's the same soup, but $2.50 to split it (a split charge). Then my fathers sea bass arrived. Time passed ... A lot of time. Then I was served lamb, which I didn't order, then we pointed this out and waited again. A long time. Dad is finished with his entree. We waited again. One duck entree was served. My mom watched me eat and insisted on waiting for her dish though I offered her my food. I had trouble enjoying my meal though as she was sitting there hungry and tomorrow is mother's day. I finished. (I might add that I felt my duck was a little undercooked and that the spinach with bacon and raisins that accompanied it was a rather ordinary way of adding flavor- we all know that adding sweet (sugary raisins) and bacon (fat and salt) adds flavor- a great chef knows how to add flavor without resorting to extra fat & sugar.) We kept waiting. Finally we told the waiter we didn't want to wait any longer and would rather leave and expressed our disappointment. A better establishment, realizing their mistake with the lamb, would have comped us something, anything, at that point. Nothing. Mom left hungry, I left frustrated. That night and into the morning mom kept exclaiming she wouldn't return. I have been here 3-4 other times. Once I came here two nights in a row! I never experienced this "family style" serving and all that waiting... If you enjoy watching other people eat at your table this is the place for you.... And I should add that the manager had kindly offered since posting this review, for us to come back and receive one entree free for my mother. As appreciated as this offer is I'm not sure my father & my mother want to go back after that experience, as we would still be paying upwards of $60+ for two entrees to go back. We also live in Tiburon and are rarely if ever in the city together. I express my thanks but it feels like too little too late. The moment to offer a comp was when we were still at the restaurant. Making the offer now is good for the restaurant as it brings them additional business. But, as appreciative as I am of the gesture I just don't think wild horses could bring my mother back. At least that's what she has expressed to me so far.
author: Nicole S.

description:
What a great new find!  I had visited a popular sushi place some years ago in this hip Chestnut area of town.  This time friends from across the bridge suggested Isa and I am so glad they did.  The service was excellent -- our waiter was great.  Although the back patio was recommended by a friend, I am glad we sat up front as the patio was covered so not very interesting.  

Every single plate of food was delicious. And, since their meat products are mostly natural, no-hormone, no-antibiotic, I was very happy to partake in most of the meal...of course I skipped the Hudson valley grade A foie gras with vanilla, rhubarb & custard brioche for ethical reasons....people at my table were raving about it.  

Everything else we had was very good except the salmon carpaccio which was not memorable.  The absolute best items were the calamari in a zesty lemon sauce grilled (or maybe sauteed to delicious perfection) --  definitely a healthier option than the deep fried variety AND the #1 plate of the evening was the Slow Braised Beef Short Rib...amazingly tender yet slightly crisp in some places with a delectable reduction sauce and mashed potatoes and tender broccolini.  Beer, wine, and soju cocktails available.  After Range in SOMA, this may just be my #2 favorite in SF so far.
author: Rafael Y.

description:
Best tapas around the marina , IMHO. I love hitting up this place when I've got a few friends in town (like tonight). Best to go with more than two so that you can order a wide variety of plates. 

Go big on the tuna tartare, sea bass and goat cheese. You won't be sorry! Make your reservations in advance.
author: Allen X.

description:
I had a friend visiting here on business, which was the perfect excuse to try out one of SF's finest...
My friend and I worked up quite an appetite trying to find a parking place.  When we entered I saw a few non descript tables in the front.  I thought it was bar seating.  The hostess came up and asked if we would like to sit in the front or the back.  I caught a glimpse of white lights and a larger room in the back, promising a more festive atmosphere than the solemn front room.  I was about to make a joke about how funny it would be if they sat us outside in the freezing  night air...and then I realized they really were seating us outside!  It was so well decorated and the tent provided adequate enough covering that you sort of forgot (except I kept my scarf on).  Thank goodness the heating lamps did their job well.

We decided to share our prix fixe dinners so we could try as many of the dishes as possible.  Here are my thoughts:

Spicy Tuna tar tare:  fantastic!   Great size portion, although we laughed at the pine nut salad as it was more of a dollop than a salad.  The spice and lemon were just right.

Lobster bisque:  Jeff loved it.

Endive, fennel, raddichio salad: solid salad.  I'm a sucker for caramelized walnuts and pears though.

Flatiron steak:  cooked just right.  It was a great steak without being too "interpretive".  It was simply great steak.  Jeff loved it with a little sea salt to season.  The rosemary steak fries were a great compliment.

Truffle risotto:  I usually get tired of risotto after a few bites, but this one had enough going on in flavor that I enjoyed the whole dish.

By the time we got to the dessert we were both stuffed.  The gelato was so rich we took 2 bites and called it a night.

I left full, warm, and happy...can't ask for a better dinner!
author: Sonic D.

description:
This is one of my fave places in the city!! The food is innovative, and always well prepared and very reasonably priced.  Taking cost in the equation, I think this is the perfect mix of fine dinning at a very reasonable price.
Mon- Thurs. there is a prix fixe menu, 22 per person for 2 courses. a  starter and an entree Which is a great deal!!!! since its all small plates its very fun, i go often, and have had almost everything on the menu. 

My faves: Salmon Crudo, Paella, Chicken breast. SOUP(any and all)
author: Kathy M.

description: Shame on Isa for selling fois gras, which is the oversized liver of a duck or goose that is made by literally shoving food down the throat of the poor animal to overstuff the animals' body.  All just to contort their liver to create something some people like to eat.  I will never go to Isa again.
author: David M.

description:
French tapas?  I wasn't sure what to expect, since I'm used to my tapas being Spanish.  Well, I was very pleasantly surprised.  Went there for a friend's "23rd" birthday.  The gaggle of us split a few appetizers:  the tuna and goat cheese were deeeeeeelish!  The combinations of the tuna + avocado and the goat cheese + sun dried tomatoes and pine nuts were fabulous.  My main dish, the chicken was quite tasty as well.  Yeah, I know it's hard to F up chicken, but I thought this chicken was exceptionally good.  My friends' steaks were great also.  My dessert of amaretto-infused ice cream-like thing was really yummy, but I was too full to finish it.  My aging friend enjoyed his dessert of fruit.

Sorry, had to take a star away for the slowness of the service.  Not that we cared, since the leisurely dinner gave us more time to chat.  Atmosphere was great.  Nice for a birthday dinner; has good ambiance for a date, so if I ever go on one again, I might pick this place.

Oh yeah, this place is goooooooooood!
author: Danielle B.

description:
Went on a Friday night to celebrate a friend's 40th birthday. The atmosphere was the perfect amount of festive. We sat in the back covered garden area, complete with holiday lights and heat lamps. Not too loud, but felt like an escape from the busy streets of the marina and the cold rainy downpour. We ordered a bunch of plates, some champagne and ordered more as we went. 

Top moments: scallops (cooked perfectly), calamari, fuyu persimmon salad. We also ordered the "roaring 40s" cheese plate, the flourless chocolate cake and port for dessert, which were all wonderful. The food was really tasty, the service was great and the company was the best. Good to go with good friends or on a date.
author: Nicole Sooah C.

description:
