Based on a very high ratio of positive review, I decided to choose ISA as one of the restaurants to go for 2012 Dine about Town. Parking was an issue, spent 20 minutes drove around but luckily got a spot close by.  

After we sat down, the waiter came and provided the menu. Amazed by the # of selections for each dish. A good impression to start our appetite. We asked the waiter for recommendation and told him that we do not eat cheese. Unfortunately, he did not ask the kitchen to remove it.  So..we got butter lettuce salad with cheese, duck breast with cheese salad, and truffle risotto with cheese. It would for sure change my impression if the waiter did listen to the customer's need.  Disappointed. 

Nothing special for the salad. 
Salmon carpaccio - the portion is big and very fresh.
Truffle risotto - the best one for the night. smell good and taste good.
Duck breast - under cooked. too raw to cut.
Foe Gras -  It's okay with the pear but not sure about the bread. I think it might be due to the plate presentation, not impressive to me. 
Creme brulee - good
Semifreddo all ameretto - well made dessert. 

I am not sure if ISA only offered one fork and one knife per customer as their standard service.  This is wired especially when it is for French cuisine and the rating is so high.
author: Cynthia S.

description: I went to Isa for my birthday with some friends and my experience was spectacular! The waiters were polite, the food was magnificent, and the atmosphere set the mood for a fun and cozy meal. Anything on the menu is delicious so don't be afraid to be adventurous! I also loved how the waiters suggested to eat family style! All of the options on the menu are excellent so don't be afraid of family style! It's worth it!
author: Sophie W.

description: Delicious! And good, fast service. The potato wrapped sea bass is absolutely delicious. Truffle risotto also great. Scallops were cooked wonderfully. Our favorite spot in the marina. The back patio is cool but a little loud for conversation - inside seems a bit quieter. Great experience all around, definitively going back.
author: Laurel K.

description: So when I dined here almost a year ago, I was not on Yelp. Forgive me for being late but it deserves a review. It was my second night in SF and I met up with friends for dinner. We sat in the back on the covered patio which was so cute. We all shared everything. The oysters were great, the duck was perfect and all in all I enjoyed everything. I hope to be back to SF this fall and if I do make it, I will most assuredly return to ISA. Sorry from being late ISA, but I have  not forgotten your wonderful food!
author: Marie E.

description:
Yummy, yummy, yummy! I'd highly recommend making reservations because it gets quite busy. The ambiance is very intimate with dim lighting. But don't let that fool you, it's also a great place for a few friends, order the tapas and cheers to some good wine. 

My friend and I started with the MAIN LOBSTER BROTH and BAKED GOAT CHEESE, so delicious!!! I had a few OYSTERS which were really good but as you know oysters aren't for everyone. We followed up with the ROASTED LAMB and DUCK BREAST which were prepared perfectly. 

The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that we were neglected at times. Because there were only 2 of us, we were seated in a very intimate corner which I figured was not in plain sight to the server. Regardless, I shouldn't have to wait for something as simple as water.
author: Jamie Q.

description:
Wow.  This place is awesome!  Friendly, attentive service; delicious food (more on this in a minute); great wines and cocktails; nice ambiance; reasonable prices.  

I had the asparagus/lemon soup, which was a rather large bowl of creamy but textured soup; and grilled angus flat iron steak with moutarde verte a l'estragon & roasted yukon gold potatoes with zucchini.  The sauce on this was amazing, the steak tender and a perfect medium-rare.  Huge portions.  My friend had a butter lettuce salad with pear, walnuts, and bleu cheese, and sole.  With wine for both and a drink for one of us, the tab came to less than $70 (ok, we were there during happy hour, so drinks were only $5 per).

I'll definitely be back, and will eat inside next time.  It's so much prettier in there.
author: LM K.

description:
We had our second dinning experience at Isa and both occasions were fabulous.  The setting is great, service and wait staff were attentive and very nice, the menu is diverse anyone can find an amazing dish of their liking. 

Highly, highly recommended.
author: Jon M.

description:
Great atmosphere at Isa!  I wish we could have sat on the back patio-it looked super cute at night with its Christmas lights up.  

We were excited to try the Pre-Fixe menu, but were scratching our heads when we actually sat down to order from it.  Depending on what you order from the pre-fixe, it isn't necessarily "cheaper" than ordering the items a la carte from the normal menu - so yelpers, beware!

We had the potato wrapped seabass and the flat iron steak, along with a smoked salmon appetizer.  The steak was tasty and the potato wrapped seabass was unique....H. got worried because he thought it was deep-fried! :)  C'mon hun - a little oil never hurt nobody!

Overall, the food was good and the atmosphere was warm.  We'll probably be coming back.
author: Annie C.

description:
This place is soooo good and CHEAP. Every dish that came out was super delicious. If you have a party of more than 4 then you would have to order double of everything. But it is definitely worth it! Even the bread is good..we had the shookum oysters, spicy tuna tartare, dungeness crab salad, ceviche, grilled calalmari, seared FOIE GRAS, scallops, flat iron steak, mash potatoes, flourless chocolate cake, and the creme brulee! 

I will be coming back real soon!!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
WOW. This place is really amazing. I will even go so far as to say its the best restaurant in the Marina. I can't believe its taken me this long to go to eat at this place.

The portions are meant to be shared. Though I did not try the the butter lettuce salad everyone raves about, I did get the tomato salad which was absolutely amazing. The steak was amazing, the truffle spaghetti and the scallops were amazing as well. 

The ambiance is very cozy and cute and our waiter was sooo friendly. This is a great date spot, LOVE the patio.
author: Krystle M.

description: One of my all time favorite restaurants! A great place to go with family or a group of close friends!
author: C S.

description: I haven't been to Isa in ages and boy am I glad to have gone back.  The menu is a bit bigger than I remember but it is still all delicious.  The outdoor seating is my favorite - something about twinkling little lights always makes everything wonderful.  The wine list is really reasonable and our waiter recommended a tasty Pinot.   Oysters were fresh but didn't love that the sauce was really spicy, overpowered the oysters.  Ordered 2 portions of the seared foie...love eating with people who are willing to order 2 portions of foie!  Didn't really like the special grilled yellowtail but the duck breast was cooked perfectly.  My favorite dish there still is the mushroom risotto.  Oh and the brussel sprouts were a little under seasoned.  Too full for dessert.
author: Jen C.

description:
I love this place and since it's kind of expensive, it has become my special occasions place. If you like small plates and French food, you should definitely check out this place. I love their foise gras, and their veal, and their salmon carpaccio. I always wanted to try their desert but I always get so full on their food, that I have no space for desert. 
If you get a chance try to sit out on the patio with the heated lamps, that makes your experience even better. 
The service and staff are really nice too! I
author: Z O.

description: The food was great. We had two plates: scallops and duck. The fourless cake was not my favorite. I would, however, go back.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Isa came highly recommended to me from my most awesome dental assistant, Emily.  So I decided to take the bf here for his birthday.
Now that I've had some time to think about the night and meal, I think I can give a more fair assessment about my dining experience.

Pros:
- For the most part, the food was very good.  We ordered from the prix fixe and I especially enjoyed the salmon carpaccio appetizer and free range chicken entree.
- The decor was nice, although I think we would've gotten more attention if sat in the rear or main part of the restaurant than in the front by the window
- Price: the prix fixe does get you a lot of quality food for a very reasonable price tag

Cons:
- The service was a bit off; not rude but not also attentive.  Our original waiter seemingly disappeared after delivering our first appetizer and asking us if we wanted a 2nd basket of bread.  Instead we had different wait staff throughout the night for each course.  And our 2nd bread basket never came.
- We did not like the calamari appetizer... the spices used tasted odd and did not go well with the dish.  I wasn't a fan of the flank steak either, as it was a bit tougher than I have had at other places.
- The pacing of the when the plates were brought out was very disjointed.  Our second appetizer and steak arrived around the same time, and there was a big gap between the entrees, detailed below.
- The steak and chicken were brought out at quite a large time span apart.  I understood this was a supposed to be a "family style," type dining experience where we share our dishes, but the tables to our left and right (also couples), had their entrees brought out to them at the same time without a 25-30 minute wait in between (and one of the tables had the steak and chicken as well, so there really wasn't any excuse for our entrees not to come out together or at least reasonable close together).
- We weren't given a steak knife (or knives - if this was truly supposed to be family style dining - for both of us), and had to ask for it.  And then were only given one set, so I basically cut the pieces for the bf.

I might be a little more pickier with this review because I am more critical of restaurants I choose for special occassions, and I chose Isa for a special birthday.  In truth, the taste quality of the meal in proportion to the price weighs positively in Isa's favor.  Would I go back?  Possibly, but I'm not in a rush at the moment.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
AMAZING FOOD. Wonderful menu. Difficult to choose a few dishes when all look amazing. Good value compared to comparable restaurants in the city.

The duck, served seared and medium rare with a beet, goat cheeseand Mache salad had me soaking up every last bit of the melange of sauces on the plate with their perfectly soft and crusty french bread. 

The Butterfish en Papillote (in parchment) with a truffle sauce and mushrooms was divine... full of flavor and beauty, yet light.

The hereford hanger steak was yummy, but the little taters stole the show.. the skin snapped as you bit through and flesh of the taters was warm and slightly sweet. Perfectly salted.


I would give this place 5 stars if the service was consistent. The first time I went the hostess was not so inviting and the waiter was just busy. The second time the hostess was still flustered, but cordial and sat us at 9:15 for an 8:30 Reservation.

The place gets packed, but it is worth the crowd, the wait and the occasional attitude, not to mention a bit of a homogenous crowd.
author: Claudia O.

description:
As the 102nd reviewer of Isa's all I can say is Kudos to the chef and the establishment. For a lighter dinner for two I had: 

Potatoe wrapped seabass...great flavor, potatoes where perfect, heartly but light dish at the same time.  

Baked goat cheese w/ pesto, tomato and pine nuts. yum... simple but, satisfing, and sauted pea shoots with garlic.

In conclusion to add to the other reviewer out there this places was "berry good food, berry good atmosphere and I berry much will be back!!!!!
author: Kristina A.

description:
Isa is by far one of my favorite restaurants in SF!

I came here for a lovely first date and everything was flawless. The spicy tuna tartare, potato wrapped halibut, baked butterfish in paper, and carmelized dayboat scallop small plates are amazing! Every small plate seemed to be prepared and presented with careful consideration and kept us wanting more. 

After having such a wonderful experience, I decided to book ISA for my co-worker's going away dinner and everyone who went was thoroughly impressed. They loved the above small plates along with the saffron paella, roasted mushrooms, and flat iron steak. They also couldn't stop talking about the wines that we had. My only gripe was that we had to order several plates since portions are so small, but I understand that that's pretty much standard when it comes to small plate restaurants.

BTW, be sure to book a table that's in their back patio. Even if it's a chilly night you have nothing to worry about, as the patio is enclosed and heating lamps are set-up. Also, the patio's strung w/ little white lights which helps set the scene for a cute, romantic feel.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Nothing on the menu disappointed. $22 for a 2-course pre fixe meal where each dish is big enough to share with others makes this place worth the visit.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: I had a dinner with my husband on my B day. The foods, drinks, and service are all awesome! We definitely come back!!!
author: Wendy W.

description:
3.5 Stars actually

*Would definitely comeback 
*Good food
*Good service
*Nice outdoor seating (good temperature)
*Good Prix Fixe Menu & Happy Hour (Mondays-Thursdays)
*Highly enjoyed:
Calamari Appetizer, Dungeness Crab Salad, Shellfish Risotto, Scallops
author: Christina D.

description: We went on New Year's Eve, and although it was as crowded as you might imagine, all of the food was outstanding - starting with the bread, which always sets a good tone for the meal.  Each of the 4 of us had something different, and everyone loved it. I have a hard time not ordering duck; it's become a running joke with my friends. Well, this was probably the best magre de canard I've ever had.  We plan to check it out again, to assess consistency.
author: Clemencia C.

description: Cow Hollow has a neat little restaurant community that are good in general. Isa is good but my meal felt skimp and not entirely fulfilling. Dungeness crab salad had good chunks of crab meat but neither the dressing nor the vegetables were anything special.  Salmon carppacio (more like tartare) was good but way too small. Duck breast had a nice berry sauce but meat was well overcooked. Seared scallops was cooked well but again very small portions. Like the setting and the ambiance, just wish the food had more of a memorable punch.
author: Ed L.

description:
Food is delicious, wine list is decent, and overall I really enjoyed it. I really loved the yellow tail and the goat cheese. Truffle and mushroom risotto was good as well. My beau loved the lamb. I tried the crab salad based on some of the other reviews and it was good, but not great in my opinion. 

Only downside was the long wait. We got there at 8pm on a Saturday and had to wait for over an hour, just a party of 2! Also, the tables are really crammed in there. I'd definitely recommend making reservations. 

I'd definitely go back!  Some of the other reviewers had bad service and ours was great.  Maybe its or miss depending on how busy it is.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
YELP, needs some half stars....

3.6528 out of 5 times since I've been at this NYesque quaint straunt I've been a little hammered..but satisfied no less. However I'm going to make one of those blanketed statements and say, the crowd needs to let down their hair as this is a clearly a trendful place that's less Chanelishly stiff and more McCartneyesque where you can have fun. Apologizing in advance for the ode to fashion ex amplifying, but it was only necessary.

Oye, delicious.
author: Shaun L.

description:
Update:
OMIGOD!!! I went to Isa's last night and the former chef from Kubuto is working there! Thanks God an amazing place to have sushi!

---------------------------------------------------------------------
I have soft spot in my heart for Isa. It was the very last place I worked as a waiter in this town before I got into yoga full time. Luke is a great chef and his staff is beyond top notch. 

I am excited that the expanded the size of the place since I worked there! Much roomier!

The food is always consistent and you never leave hungry.

My only regret is that I never had the balls to ask out one of my fellow coworkers at the time. Manon where are you!!!

Hat's off to you Kitty and Luke! Congrats on making it!
author: Brian M.

description:
I went to Isa last night to celebrate Mardi Gras and Super Tuesday with Lindsey S. and Michelle L. It was one of those obligatory goings outs spurred on by post-weekend anxiety and well, it's Mardi Gras! So I was looking for a night of good conversation, wine, fun venue, and of course great food. Isa was perfect! 

Lindsey and I ordered from their prefix menu (Mon-Thurs) and as our adorable waiter recommended, we shared our food family style. Michelle's vegan and she definitely got the short end of the stick bc we got to enjoy all her dishes and ours as well! The stars of the evening were the baked butterfish (so much buttery goodness!), the saffron paella (although a bit too many tentacles and NO CLAMS), and the truffle risotto (hmmm....creamy and savory). We also tried a salad and the salmon something (it comes out like a tuna tartar) that was good, but not as remarkable as our later dishes. 

Our servers were fantastic about timing our dishes. Our conversation and feasting was never interrupted by an empty table or overflow of food. On my way home I was shocked to see that we'd spent 2 hours at dinner. It all passed by so quickly!  All in all it was a great night and I would definitely return again. Hmmmm.... risotto...............
author: Kelly K.

description:
I love, love, LOVE this restaurant. 

I have been 5 times since March and it is my go-to restaurant for when people are visiting from out of town or for when I don't want to take a chance on an iffy meal. 

Yes, the service can be spotty. On one occasion it was downright horrific - but my friend and I decided to find humor in how bad it was and then it just became more and more comical each time he did something totally lame. 

But the food is never less than great. Things I've had in the past that still stand out - the tuna tartar, the crab salad (yum!), the truffle spaghetti (and let me state that I am NOT a spaghetti person but this stuff is just plain incredible), the scallops and the lobster broth. This is also where my friend popped my oyster cherry. Fun times, indeed. 

I have no problem sitting inside...but the patio has a great ambiance that is unique to so many SF restaurants. Let it be known, though, that it can get a bit toasty for some guys that tend to get hotter than girls.
author: Jen N.

description:
a solid 4.5 stars, but if my foodie snob friend (don't tell him i said so) can be impressed, i suppose i could round up to FIVE stars. 

the run down: 
service 4/5 (reservations at 7:15 on a sunday night, and we were sat within minutes... attentive waiters - i noticed he would constantly eye our table to ensure the timing of our food was impeccable)
ambience 3.5 (we were sat by the window, which had it's pros and cons. cozy and as "private" as you can be by the window. lol. i just meant we could have our own conversation and hear each other talk)
food: 5/5 (see below)
value: 4/5

FOOD! OMG... the food. 
we were here for DAT... we asked if we could add the fois gras, which he had to ask because of the prix fixe menu (which i thought was odd... why wouldn't you want more money?), but ultimately said yes. 

i loved that all the dishes were served family style so we could share... 

we started with salmon carpaccio which was just divine coming from a gal who doesn't care for raw fish, but i swear if it taste like that, i could eat it all the live long day. 5 stars. 

the goat cheese was warm and delightful. a good mix between the tomatoe, pesto, and pine nuts. 4.5 stars. 

seared scallops was overall good, but disappointing. i liked the bits of sweet potatoes, but i felt the spinach was overdone just a bit and the bacon overpowered the rest of the flavors.  3 stars

flat iron steak wasn't what i expected. i suppose it wasn't as tendor. still good though. 3.5 stars. 

fois gras. this was my second time having fois gras and i must say i enjoyed it more this time since i tasted more of a liverwurst flavor instead of just buttery goodness. the blackcurrant (??) sauce was a little much. but the polenta was like a savory soft cake... so yummy. the first polenta i actually enjoyed. 4.5 stars

finally... the drinks and desserts. all 5 stars. 

lemon drop tasted like lemonade. hands down one of my favorited. i could down this like juice. 

grapefruit was a bit bitter after drinking the lemon drop, but still very delicious if your into your citrus.

the flourless chocolate cake was like a souffle ... warm, not overly sweet and just delightful in my mouth. mmmm...

finally, the semifreddo all' amaretto - what was this creation? cake? gelato? i didn't know what to expect, but i rather enjoyed this. if you like icecream, cake, cookies, almond flavored things and amaretto... try this.
author: Milly S.

description: I had the best restaurant food ever. THE BEST! :) Minus one star for the waiter that we had. The guy was awful. Loved the place and will be back again.
author: Jasmina T.

description:
You never want to start the game with a penalty, all that pregame helmet smacking, chest bumping, dog barking, "WHO'S HOUSE?!?!" chanting energy goes right out the window with a penalty to start the game.  

So when I arrived for my 9:00pm reservation for my party of 5 and had to wait 40 minutes in a narrow, crowded lobby/bar/hallway-of-my-apt area you can imagine I wasnt too thrilled.  

What made it even worse was right after noting my arrival the hostess disappeared seemingly well aware that there were angry mobs ready to attack her if she poked her head out from the hole she was in.  The only thing worse than a penalty is not having a ref to berate to make yourself feel better.

So she finally reappears and just as I was about to unleash my verbal tirade she smiled and told me my table was ready and everything was right in the world again.  

We are led to the back patio area which is beautifully arranged and decorated yet comfortable and inviting.  The waiter is very nice and accommodating, asking if we have dined at Isa before and laid out the recommended dining routine.  

I wouldnt necessarily call this a "tapas" restaurant and not just because it isnt Spanish (dont get me started) but also cause the plates were more medium, "passable as an entree like an H3 is an SUV"-sized and not small and straight forward like traditional tapas. 

The food was good in general..I can think of off the top of the dome the foie, duck (got the triangular top piece of the breast with the maximum crispy skin and fat to meat ratio mmm) and mushroom medley but keep in mind this was only 3 days ago. 

The one thing that irked me was that the vegetables served with the entrees were the same exact 3 vegetables offered as side dishes!! AND some vegetables made cameos alongside completely different entrees!!! (Duck with veggie X and Lamb with veggie X)   

Showed a complete lack of effort in even trying to fool the audience into thinking that you paired the specific protein with the specific vegetable because their flavors complemented each other nicely.  Mental mistake, lack of concentration, cost cutting..call it what you will it was pretty bad. 

Overall, good time with good friends..restaurant didnt hinder it but didnt enhance it much either.  An erratic drive with a big play here and there followed by mistakes and penalties ends with a field goal.  Uninspired but its still 3 points on the board.
author: Hansen S.

description: Cute restaurant with great food and ambiance! Love the outdoor cozy seating. Can get a little crowded but how could it not? Appetizers feature interesting combinations. Entrees were spot on with heavenly mashed potatoes. Dessert was nothing memorable so I'd skip it next time.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I have liked this place for years.  I try others and always come back and am impressed by the continuity of their always fresh ingredients, friendly service, and portions that are actually shareable.  The patio is charming and it is romantic, but not too dark.  I also like that you are not right on top of your neighbor as at other like restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Rita G.

description: ISA isa real good! Highly recommend the lobster broth for two, seared dayboat scallops and the pan roasted chicken. The butter lettuce was nothing special. Too full for dessert but can't wait to come back and try it!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Isa is a great restaurant out in the Marina district.  We started with the spicy tuna tartare, which was served with mashed avocadoes.  It was a wonderful started.  We then had the baked goat cheese with basil and pine nuts, also delightful.  It was an original twist on the mozarella, tomatoes, and basil italian dish.   The seabass came next and is, as the waitress stated, their signature dish.  That surprised me a little bit.  It was beautifully presented wrapped in a potato slice, but the seabass wasn't particuly amazing.  I did, however, enjoy the lemon and caper sauce that came with it.   We rounded out the evening with some seared Foie Gras (very generous portion and quite tasty) and the Truffled Risotto...   I'd skip the risotto, it didn't do much for me.
Overall the setting is nice, they have a large covered back patio, and you're looking at about $50/person for 5 dishes + a bottle of wine... quite reasonable considering the quality of the cuisine.
author: David O.

description: Would have been 4 stars if I had know about VillageVine and gotten a discount on my dinner.  But I think it's bit expensive for the above mediocre food quality and very noisy ambiance.  One of the diner had to put on earplugs because it was so loud!  The lobster broth, beef ribs and truffle risotto were good but sea bass was overcooked and  the creme brulee was too "eggy".
author: Bob S.

description:
I just went to Isa this past weekend, and my tastebuds are still all a'tingle!  :)  Went w the bf, and let me tell u, two plates per person is more than enough.  We got the heirloom tomato salad (I think with feta and balsamic), the scallops (topped with sweet corn kernels and mashed potatoes on the side), the truffled spaghetti and the duck...  

Tomato salad was amazing!  Slightly chilled, perfectly seasoned heirloom tomatoes with a nice balsamic...  YUM!  Perfect way to start the meal.  

Scallops were great - contrast btw the sweet, crispy corn topping was great and the delicately sweet, tender scallops and creamy mashed potato was great.  

Spaghetti was beyond expectation - I had read all the reviews on yelp and was like "right...  it's spaghetti..." - but somehow, the flavor of Isa's spaghetti is so deep...  Truffled spaghetti with tomato compote on al dente angel hair pasta...  Probably had tons of butter in it, but it was this amazing, deep, rich flavor.

The duck - the only disappointment of the meal (but maybe b/c everything else was so good).  Bf and I both agreed that we were let down by the duck (I think it was under-salted and bf said it was overall just "flavorless") - it's possible that if we ate the duck b/f other dishes, we'd like it better b/c flavorwise, it wasn't nearly as strong as the other dishes...  The entirety of the dish was disappointing though - duck was undersalted, came with undersalted jus that tasted slightly like blueberries...  Not a fan and will not order again.

We skipped out on desert b/c I wasn't feeling chocolate that night.  Grand total (meal + 1 beer and 4 glasses of wine total + tip) ~$170.  Def not an inexpensive place.  I really wanna come back Mony-Thurs for their prix fixe special (2 dishes for $25) b/c most of the things we ordered were on the prix fixe menu anyways.  Oh - and FYI - beer and wine only - yelp led me astray
author: Stephanie P.

description: unbelievable!!! i am very picky but wow amazing food amazing service! dean was an absolutely wonderful server courteous professional helpful!!domingo also absolutely wonderful really went out of his way to make visit wonderful !!! very classy!! my date loved it!i eat 3 star michellin and this has been wonderful food and service! bravo!!
author: Kourosh M.

description:
We had been wanting to try Isa out for awhile and Dine About Town presented an excellent opportunity to do so. We were definitely not disappointed. Highlights included the baked goat cheese, crab salad, the duck, flat iron steak (pleasant surprise having good steak at a reasonably priced French restaurant) and the creme brûlée. 

The service was also amazing. We weren't sure if the great service was because we were new or not but we'll take it.

Overall, great restaurant, and a nice option for the marina which was hurting for a nice French bistro.
author: Rob G.

description:
Been here many, many times, and it never disappoints.  Ask to sit in the back, their heated (when it's cold) tent area is open year round and creates a wonderful setting for a great meal.

Last night, I went with some girlfriends for the San Pelligrino prix fix menu.  I was impressed that Isa put some of their best dishes on it, as usually I've found restaurants will put their cheaper things on menus like that.  Our waiter was very friendly, and knowledgeable about the menu and wines without being overbearing. 

Between us, we had the spicy tuna tartare, butter lettuce salad, pototo-wrapped cod, and the duck.   All were melt-in-your-mouth delicious, perfectly seasoned and cooked.  I wanted to order a side of the truffled risotto, as I've had it before and it's amazing, but that would have been way too much food!  The desserts were to die for!  We tried one of each on the tasting menu, which was a flourless chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream, a vanilla creme brulee, and amaretto semifreddo.  

Highly recommended, I will certainly be back here!  Make a reservation, because they fill up quickly, especially on weekends.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
My BF and I tried to go to Bin 38 on Saturday night and it was packed! Since it was over an hour wait for a table, we decided to look to another to eat. We walked around and decided to eat at Isa. 

It's been over three years since I've eaten here and I remembered it being really good. Although everything was meant to be small plates, I felt like the portions were quite comparable to entree portion sizes. We started with the fuyu persimmon and apple arugula salad. It was a perfect salad for a Fall evening. The sweet and crunchy fruit went really well with the spicy arugula greens.

For our entrees, we shared the butter fish and chicken. The butter fish was wonderful. The fish and mushrooms were baked in parchment paper. All the flavors were trapped in the parchment pouch, so the fish was full of flavor. I highly recommend this dish if you like fish. The chicken was cooked under a brick, so it was very juicy and moist. It was served with a side of soft and smooth mashed potatoes. 

The dessert menu wasn't that impressive, so we just ordered the flour less chocolate cake with vanilla gelato. It was good, but nothing out from the ordinary.

The service and food were both great, so I would return if I'm in the area. I'm also glad to say that Isa was just as good as the last time I dined here.
author: Denise L.

description:
Amazing food.  Just the right portion sizes, priced reasonably also.  And the dishes were very innovative and flavorful.  They are also generous and quick to keep the bread basket full.  

The only drawback to this place was the hostess, who was very unfriendly.  She showed us to a table for two in the back patio area, which was located in the middle of a staircase.  So my friend and I asked if we could be seated at a table for 4 right next to our table.  The hostess looked at her in disgust and was like, you can't have that since there are only two of you.  I had noticed a nice tall table in the window in the front dining area, so I went back out and asked the hostess if we could take that table.  She said we could.  But when my friend and I went back out, we took our menus with us. And the hostess grabbed the menus away from us (like we should have known to leave them at the other table) and was like the menus are already on the table.  

Thankfully, our server was much nicer (we were contemplating walking out after our experience with the hostess).  He was very helpful in describing dishes and making recommendations for food and wine, how much to order, etc.
author: Ash T.

description:
Great little place in the marina...

Tables:  No booths, hard little chairs and small tables up front.  Not very comfortable at all.  I didn't go into the back - maybe better accommodations back there.

Tuna Tartare - Excellent.  Spicy with the smooth texture of avocado.  Plenty big enough for two.

Potato-wrapped sea bass - Amazing!  The potato was a little too salty, but the dish overall was great.  Perfectly cooked fish, fantastic presentation and interesting combination of flavors.

Risotto - Hell Yeah!  I try risotto everywhere.  I don't know why, hardly anyone can get it right.  The boyz at Isa have a PhD in Risottology!  Perfect texture.  Perfect Mushrooms.  Perfect Cheese.  

"Not bad meaning bad, but bad meaning good". - Run DMC

Best meal I've had in a long time.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Isa was the first "fancy" restaurant I had ever been to. I only came here because I was taking out a girl to dinner...and her name was Isabelle. I thought it was a cute idea at the time! 

Even though I only came here for the name, literally, the food was really good! It was $30 for the prix-fixe menu. I ordered the butterfish...and it was probably one of the smoothest ones I've had. They baked it in a paper bag...very interesting. My date (was it a date? I don't know!) had the chicken...because it came with mashed potatoes and she really likes potatoes. 

We sat in the back of the restaurant...which is actually outdoors but covered up like a tent. It was really nice...and it wasn't cold or anything. The waiter was really nice too. I'd probably come here again one day...regardless of the name of the girl.
author: Allan M.

description:
This place is SOOO CUTE!!  The outdoor garden with it's twinkling lights, warm candles, and white canopy....so dreamy and cute!  I love the heat lamps too...def made it more cozier on a cold night.

The food was good.  More like Asian tapas.  They offer a prefrixe menu also where you can order 2 dishes for $25.  Thing you should know is the plates don't all come out at once.  It comes out as it's done in the kitchen which is why they recommend eating it family style instead of waiting for everyone to get their dish.

We ordered the following:
benton corn potato soup - SO GOOD!!  some thought it too sweet but I devoured it.
goat cheese and tomato confit salad - pretty good.
grilled calamari - I actually didn't like this dish.  thought it too salty and chewy.  Others agreed.
halibut with capers and artichokes - good
butterfish with mushroom - better than the halibut.  Cooked well.
risotto with truffle oil - DELICIOUS.  Wished we had order more of it.
steak - didn't try this one.
Ceviche - I didn't try this either but others loved it

Overall, good food, GREAT atmosphere.  Will be back again.
author: C A.

description:
Been there two times within a two week time period.  First time visit left me salivating for more great food.  First visit I ordered oysters, foie gras and the two specials of the night (quail and truffle infused pasta).  With each bite of the foie gras with grilled white peaches and a lightly toasted slice of custardy brioche, it was a like a little culinary explosion in my mouth with each bite; it was that good.  Other than the oysters, the other dishes were good, but not thrilling.

2nd visit, I was craving the oysters and foie gras once again since peach season is ending very soon.  Additionally, I ordered the grilled calamari, crab salad, and the tuna tartare.  Everything was excellent and well executed.  I had a better experience the second time around.

Desserts are a little underwhelming - nothing too special.  First time around, we were stuffed and wanted something light, so we ordered mango in passion fruit soup.  It fit the bill, but  I have no desire to order it again.  Second time, we just passed on dessert.

Overall, great balance in flavour and fairly light fare.  Great service if seated in the dining room and average service at the bar, but there's not much of a wait for a seat and can make for a fun and spontaneous night out for fabulously executed food.

Order the seafood, pass on dessert and you'll have a great time!
author: Miss H.

description:
This place is strong.  I was with a group of 8 here the other night and was really impressed with the entire experience.  I generally like to hate on Marina joints because i wrongheadedly believe i'm cool and sf and indy, but i can't hate on Isa.  

If i had remembered to review it 2 weeks ago when i went I would have more to say but, hey, that's what happens when i hope to visit 100 new places this year and review to bookmark my project rather than a public service to y'all.  sorry.
author: Matt S.

description:
I have been waiting a long time to come here and I was not disappointed at all.  Had dinner with 2 other friends last night and we were seated in the front dining area.  They have a larger dining room in the back.  This would be a great date place.  We ordered several items to share.

Chilled skookum oysters on half shell-had an ocean taste to it....didn't like it at all.
Sweet fish ceviche-loved this one....it had mangos and tomatoes in it.
Spicy tuna tartare-creamy avocado on the bottom and the tuna....delish.
Seared grade A foie gras-very tasty...went well with the poached pear.
Halibut-tasty but a bit overcooked....loved the green beans tho.
Baked butterfish in paper-my favorite dish here.....melted in my mouth.
Maple leaf duck breast-also very tasty......and I liked the figs.
Veal sweetbread-not my cup of tea at all....definitely would not be getting this again.
Creme brulee-I liked and not too sweet. 

Definitely would be coming back again and now I know what not to order.  Downside.....i came with people who don't drink and they didn't have wine by the glass that is on the sweeter side.
author: Allison T.

description:
My BF and I celebrated our anniversary at Isa and we couldn't have chosen a more perfect place. We arrived maybe half an hour before our reservation and enjoyed some drinks at the bar during Happy Hour. Beer, wine, and soju specialty drinks are $4-5 until 7pm, which is awesome. The mojito and negroni were made with fresh ingredients and served up strong...delicious and a total win!

The back dining room is very cozy..I didn't expect this big white tent to be so nice but I was impressed. Service was top notch--water was always filled, bread was plentiful, and our dishes came out fairly quickly.

- Tomales Bay Pt Reyes Oysters- Good size and very fresh
- Seared scallops with butternut squash, sweet potatoes, spinach, bacon & truffle sauce- OHMYGOD guys. Scallops+bacon+truffle sauce=heaven. I've never tasted scallops cooked so well..ugh...must stop drooling. Portions were pretty hefty too, definitely filing. 
- Roasted rack of lamb with sautèed eggplant, zucchini, red peppers, nicoise olives & lamb jus- I'm not a big fan of lamb but this dish was great. Lots of flavor without the game taste, and the meat was cooked perfectly.
- Roaring Forties cheese plate- can't go wrong with some good cheese.
- Semifreddo all' amaretto with vanilla bean ice cream, biscotti, and amaretto- one of the best desserts I've had all year. The ice cream was icy, but a good kind of icy....and amaretto makes everything taste better, obviously. So good. 

PS. The Long Gamma wine is delicious.

I cannot stop thinking about this meal. Isa can do no wrong. I will DEFINITELY be coming back!
author: Stefi C.

description:
Alright, I'm giving it up, here's the secret for great service at Isa:

You have to give up the super-romantic patio seating and sit in the front room, near the bar and kitchen.  If you do, chances are, you will be served by Jonathan, who is funny, personable and a wine connoisseur, who will pair your meal perfectly.  It's definitely worth giving up a little ambiance to have him at your table.

Okay and one more tip: It's about sharing, do not, really, do not ,order for yourself only.  The way the food comes out of the kitchen, sharing makes all the difference, plus, you'll want more than a taste of every delicious thing that is placed on your table.
author: Amy A.

description:
*Update 6/15/2009*

Went there this Saturday for Dine About Town and am I speechless!!  Great food!  We've ordered what's on the Dine About Town menu plus their regular entrees.  

Let's start with the Dine About Town Menu first. 

First course:  
Spicy tuna crudo with toasted sesame, seaweed, avocado, nori & low sodium soy and it was delicious.  The tuna was really soft as well as melts in your mouth...it goes really well with the sauce and avocado.  

Second course: 
Halibut a la plancha with braised fennel, artichokes, capers, tomato confit & olives. Wow, the fish was really fresh, perfectly grilled and the vegetables were so sweet!!

Off the Dine About Town Menu we've ordered:
Foie Gras with Kamquat Sauce. One of THE best I've tasted!! They'd changed the sauce and it's even better...love it love it love it!

Lobster Broth. Although not as creamy as their Lobster Bisque, but it's still very very good.

Crab Salad. They've also updated the ingredients on this dish, and I like how they've put a little bit of mango in there.

Dessert:
Grapefruit Granite. Refreshing as usual. My friends had the Gelato with Expresso and it was just delightful. Also the flourless Chocolate Cake, YUM YUM!!

So the tab comes to a total of $72.00 per person and I think the money was VERY well spent. Service was excellent!! I truly believe if the food is this good, you don't mind spending even more than $72.00 per person!

I shall come back to this place again soon. Can't wait!
author: Irene K.

description:
My husband and I came here for Dine About Town.  From my experience, many restaurants serve poorer quality food during restaurant week, but this place was delicious!  I got the salmon carpaccio as an appetizer, the truffle risotto for my entree, and creme brulee for my dessert.  They were all sooo good...especially the truffle risotto.  

The ambience is very warm and romantic.  The front part of the restaurant is small and intimate, but when you walk to the back, it opens up into a spacious room with high ceilings and lights strewn around everywhere (it looks like a tent but it's actually indoors).  

I thought we got a great value during Dine About Town week.  Although the prices are more expensive during other times, I would definitely come back here again 'cuz the food is worth it!
author: B J.

description:
Impressed by the DAT menu I saw online, I persuaded my husband to give this restaurant a try. We came a hour earlier than our reservation time, but the owner was able to accomodate us in spite of this. We were surprised by the fact that she could do this, because the dining room was packed as far as we could tell. We didn't know that the restaurant had a super cute outdoor patio area as well.

Hubby and I decided to start off by ordering the salmon carpaccio and spicy tuna crudo. The fish, while prepared well, was lacking somewhat in freshness. I ordered the halibut and my hubby ordered the flat iron steak. Both of us agreed that the halibut was by far the better dish. The flat iron steak, while good, lacked "umph". 

Also, parking may be challenging, as it is the Marina area. Be prepared to circle for at least 30 minutes (unless the parking gods are with you).
author: Sandy Y.

description:
UPDATE: 3/15/08:

Isa has always been one of my standby favorites, but it has disappointed me the last two times I've been.

First disappointment: 
I was dining with some friends, and we ordered a couple of bottles of wine. When the server came to pour a glass for me, he completely missed my glass, pouring wine all over the table. Because we were all so shocked, we were speechless for a moment, and then of course we told him to stop (since he didn't seem to notice that he was pouring wine on to the table). He looks confused, apologies and tries to clean up the mess (luckily none of it got on anyone). After a little clean-up, he attempts his pour again...and repeats - pours wine on the table again. This time we were quicker about telling him to stop, but at this point, he has spilled about 1/3 of our bottle of wine all over the table. Again, he apologizes and tries to clean it up. The third try, he put the mouth of the wine bottle on to my glass so that it was touching and poured the wine. Embarrassingly, he did that for everyone else and for the rest of the night.

Mistakes happen. But that was huge. In addition to that, he didn't seem particularly apologetic, nor did he offer to open a new bottle of wine for us or comp us in any way for the bad service. When we told him we thought his behavior was unacceptable, he said he would bring us a free dessert. He didn't. 

You might think that after that experience, Isa would be on my banned list, but it wasn't; I still think the food is amazing and delicious and am willing to give them another chance.

-----------------------------------------------------

I've been here ages ago, but I don't remember it being as good as it was this last time...  The place bills itself as a small plates place but these plates weren't small at all!  I was surprised by the relatively big portions...and the great "value".  We had a great dinner with wine and cocktails...which only ended up being ~$50/person!  

We got the baked goat cheese, tuna tartare, potato wrapped sea bass, steak, lamb and truffled risotto.  Everything was delicious...  My favorites were the lamb and sea bass; the steak was the only dish that I thought was just average....but it was still good.  

The service was great.  I particularly appreciated the waiter's wine suggestion; we'd ordered a bottle of pinot grigio, and he suggested a bottle that he thought was better and $1 cheaper.  

We sat in the patio area in the back which was fabulous.  They have hung all of these little white lights around which makes the patio area so cute.  It made me feel like I was dining in a friend's backyard...

The only potential downer is that they don't have a liquor license, so it's just wine (and beer, I think...?) and soju cocktails....
author: Wendy L.

description:
Went here earlier this week for Dine about town, it was a group of 4 and we had reservations at 7. no problems getting seated; we sat in the back which it seems is their main dining area which is actually "outside" but they have some kind of roof over it. server was great and helpful. 

i started with the sashimi, then the steak, and then creme brulee for dessert. the sashimi was really good, but typical tartare style with the guac. but there was a LOT of it so i was feelin' pretty full already, especially 'cos they keep giving you more and more bread which is pretty good to begin with. the steak was decent, but my bf had the duck which was even better! my creme brulee was excellent too; it had a pretty thick sugary crust at the top, which is exactly how i like it.

the cons? i think there was some big party going on at the same time in that dining area and they were really loud. it was definitely hard to hear what people were saying in my group. also, it took a while to get our desserts...compared to the fact that we got our appetizer and entree quite quickly. 

but overall, definitely a decent place to check out!
author: Pauline S.

description:
Came here during "Dine About Town" was looking forward to trying to good french cuisine. The service sucked! We had the old white french guy, talk about having a stick up your butt. We waited forever to get anything, even to get the check. Anyway, on to the food.....

There were 4 of us and my one friend was being "Hitler" (LOL) and made us all try something different and share. 
They have a really good SALMON TARTARE served on top of guacamole, the DUNGENESS CRAB SALAD was sooooooo good and fresh. The one memorable item was the halibut on top of corn and green beans, very flavorful. The FLAT IRON STEAK with moutarde sauce was good but I could've gone without the mediocre potatoes. The duck was cooked perfectly but it was served with a hashbrown they got from Mcdonald's. The desserts were ok, the CREME BRULEE is definately the winner, smooth and not too sweet. The FLOURLESS CHOC. CAKE was made with a dark chocolate but wasn't too rich. The SEMIFREDDO AMERETTO  tasted ok but the texture was as if it had freezer burn. 

I would come here again, not when it's during Dine About Town and try something else on their everyday menu.
author: Diana L.

description:
Bring on the desserts!

As with every Dine About Town - we willingly opened up our wallets and threw down (well worth it for the prix-fixe menu)!  My girlfriends and I - always with similar palates had relatively the same thing.  Here's a run down of what we so hungrily devoured...

Appetizers:  You can't go wrong with the following two!  
Salmon carpaccio w/creme fraiche
Sushi grade tuna

Entree: I have to say - a lot of their food is saltier than need be, delicious but I drank a lot water!  
Duck breast w/bacon over a bed of spinach salad...I'm assuming this dish is heavy on the fat what with duck and bacon fat...mmmm
Grilled flat iron steak w/string beans and potatoes

Desserts:  This is where they EXCEL!
Vanilla Bean Ice Cream w/Biscotti and Expresso - perfect balance of sweet and bitterness...seriously SO good!!
Flourless cake w/vanilla bean icecream - good but nothing to rave about
Roaring Forties blue cheese - savory cheese was a good balance to all the sweets..
Grapefruit Granite - refreshing!  great way to end the meal...

Minus one star - service was off...our waiter barely said a word to us - we felt so ignored, the wait time between ordering our entree and dessert was forever long...

FYI: Parking is tough, try the other side of lombard...request to sit in the back (very quaint)...AND seriously order the vanilla bean ice cream with Espresso!!
author: Julie H.

description: Isa is a trendy little place with great food and drinks. Bring good company and go for some tapas and catch up with your friends.
author: Jessica L.

description:
5/5 SERVICE: timely and unobtrusive
4/5 AMBIANCE: back patio is charming with strung lights, but seats may be too close together for intimate conversation
3.5/5 FOOD:  tasty with good combinations, but not exceptional
2.5/5 VALUE: perhaps $17 is normal for a small plate in SF, but there are so many restaurants in SF that can give you the same/ better food at a better price.

OUR MEAL:
frog's leap sauvignon blanc:  crisp and fruity, an ok sb  $19 for half bottle

dungeness crab salad:  very nice and refreshing.  a generous dollop of crab meat on bed of spinach with light dressing made for a nice starter.  great contrast & texture with tart mango, sweet apple, and crunchy celery.

seared foie gras with huckleberry, port and brioche:  excellent.  foie gras was smooth and cooked perfectly, mild in flavor, well paired with sweet crispy brioche.

pasta special with truffle oil:  pasta had good texture, but nothing special regarding the sauce, and i could not even taste or smell the truffle oil.  decent, but i expected more.

seared duck breast with braised red cabbage, potato rosti, & kumquat:  my least favorite.  duck was chewy - i practically had to swallow the pieces whole.  i don't even remember eating the potato, and the kumquat was too sharp - it needed to be toned down with something else...

overall:  recommended with reservations.
author: Josie M.

description:
Went here with a large group, and it just wasn't great for a large party.  We were there for the Pellegrino Dine About (like Dine About Town).  It took us a while to get seated, and the service was just so-so.  Though we all ordered from the prix fixe menu, the food all arrived at different times, and it just didn't seem to be orchestrated properly.  At the end, they ran out of some of the desserts and had to make substitutions even though we ordered the desserts at the start of the meal!

If the food was really great, then I can overlook the misses in the service, but since it was just meh and forgettable, I can't give this place more than 3 stars.  There are too many good, reasonably-priced french places in the city for me to come back here.
author: Arlene M.

description:
Came here a couple of nights ago to celebrate a birthday and we definitely had mixed feelings about this place. The food was amazing. The service was questionable. The atmosphere had its ups and downs.

Thank goodness we had made reservations. The line was practically out the door (some w/ reservations even). The restaurant itself wasn't too big, but it was jam-packed and with only one hostess running around. The atmosphere was dim, nicely decorated, but very cramped. We got stuck at a table by a plant and somewhat in the middle of an isle. I thought that our waiter had a very cute-middle-aged-decent-kind-hearted-might-get-mugged-by-bad-guys look to him. So although my friends booed his service, my biased self gave him extra points compared to them. The table we got stuck at was extremely UNSPACIOUS and caused quite a bit of uncomfort. But I know how it is when people ask for a table change. People will be pissed, whether its the waiters or other staff. On top of that, they did have a s**tload of people waiting. So it was understandable that he couldn't give us that table. He did tell us in a nice tone. But I could understand why my friends were pissed. He told us that it was a GOOD table compared to many others already. Mistake. But on top of the extremely crowded spot we were stuck in, the bussers kept walking back and forth in between the tables next to us and they kept knocking down our bags, kicking our chairs etc. without any apologies. Our waters were refilled time and time again though. But, they did totally forget about our last entree, collected our dishes and handed us the dessert menu (the busser, and then the waiter). We had to remind them twice that we still had one more dish coming. Therefore, I had to knock down a star, despite the wonderful food. Oh yeah, and our server gave us the bill with the 18% gratuity added on there for "our convenience" he said. It would've looked a lot better if the gratuity part wasn't written in BY HAND. I let that slide once again because of the way he looked, but my friends were EFFIN furious! And since when was there gratuity for a party of 4?

Now for the food. It was recommended that we order one appetizer and entree per person, therefore leaving room for dessert. Family style was recommended as well. I'm glad we only ordered 3 appetizers, 4 entrees and 2 desserts, because we were just the perfect amount of full afterwards. The dishes aren't cheap, and the portions weren't big, but nothing on the menu was bad. Consider it a tasting menu.

Crab Salad - it was my favorite item of the whole night (and my friend's too). Large chunks of crab meat, and not with too many overwhelming spices. 
Spicy Tuna - this one was good too, but somehow I've just had better tuna dishes before.
Ceviche - I'm not positive of what fish was in this one, but it this dish was quite good. Better than the Spicy Tuna one.

Seared Scallops - my friend really liked this one, but I felt that the scallops were a tiny bit over-cooked. I like my seafood raw or close to raw. But the corn and mashed potatoes that came with it probably TIED IT UP with the CRAB SALAD if not BETTER! It was just soooooo good! It was freakin' delicious. I wish they had a side of that to order.
Butterfish - they said they could taste the "Chinese" in this one. I thought the butterfish was perfectly tender and cooked just right (better than the scallops, but not the corn and mashed potatoes).
Flat-Iron Steak - the steak was cooked to perfection and it was very juicy. Good steak indeed, but we could agree that its something we can have at many elsewheres.
Mushroom & Truffle Risotto - if there was a disappointment for the night, this one would've been it. There's no meat in this one, just mushrooms, expensive shaved tiny pieces of expensive mushrooms, and cheese. Lots and lots of provolone cheese. Cheese may be good to eat, but bad to smell. And we all felt that this dish was just too CHEESY. But it wasn't bad to eat, as I've mentioned previously.

Creme Brulee - amazing and not too sweet, but the hard sugar coat on top was a bit TOO HARD. I'd prefer the creme brulee over at PPQ anyday.
Flourless Chocolate Cake - the vanilla bean ice cream was good. The chocolate cake itself wasn't too sweet, which was good. But nothing too special.

Overall, the food was great. Knocked down a star for the service and crowdedness of the restaurant. BUT I did spot an extremely cute busser, and all the girls could only agree =P I would come back, but only if they guaranteed a better table.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Isa is a super romantic restaurant, and by romantic, I mean it's very dim inside. My friends and I had a hard time reading the menu and figuring out what to get, partly because of the lack of light, and partly because there were so many excellent choices. And when you are hungry, you can't think straight. Some of us wanted to order the whole menu, "but it's tapas so they must be small dishes!" The rest of us politely tried to persuade them otherwise. 

So, we all got the prix fixe. I had salmon tartar for appetizer and sable fish for entree. It was so much food we couldn't even order dessert. 

Salmon tartar was delicious possibly only because it had creme fraiche on it. I am very fond of creme fraiche and firmly believe it can make anything taste good. Like Creme fraiche ice cream at Bi Rite. You just can't go wrong. 

Fish was slightly bland for my taste. Very moist and juicy, but besides the flavors of mushrooms, i just needed more. 

Friends had steak, foie gras, calamari. They raved about all of them, but I have to point out that the calamari was so great! I love calamari that are not fried, but sauteed with some beans and become chewy, juicy goodness full of great texture. The calamari here was even better than the ones at Delfina. It'll be a must for me when I come back. 

Prix fixe were $25 a person, which is reasonable for the amount of food you get. I don't see why its cuisine isn't just "Californian." We didn't really get how it's "tapas," "French" or "Asian fusion." The only Asian thing we saw was the prosperity cat waving its little paw. 

Maybe it's a Marina thing: food isn't quite hip enough without the catch words like "tapas" or "Asian fusion." But, it doesn't matter what it's labelled at the end of the day as long as the food is good. And Isa has good food.
author: Candice B.

description:
The food here is consistently good, which in itself is impressive but even more so considering the variety of dishes.  In our case, for example, we had the potato wrapped sea bass, roasted rack of lamb, baby arugula salad, grilled flat iron steak,  and seared duck breast.  All of them reduced me to dreamy-eyed rapture.  

The wine I had deserves its own separate rave.  I had limited experience with white wine from Bordeaux but quickly came to love the Chateau Sainte-Marie.  It's a blend of Sauvignon Blanc, Semillon, and Muscadelle for an aromatic wine with a lasting finish.  This all goes to show, Isa knows how to treat a woman right.
author: M A N I K.

description: We had a last moment reservation for a group and the evening "just ok". It's a fairly noisy venue, and the tables are certainly squashed. It certainly could have been worse, but it could have been a lot better. Staff were pretty helpful, but the main thing that i dislike is the total lack of parking - it was so awkward to park that we actually missed our reservation by nearly 45 mins, despite leaving 20 mins for parking (with 3 separate cars)
author: Tim P.

description:
Came here for dine about town. Parking sucks, took forever to find a spot, but I guess I should be used to that since it is San Francisco. 

So, I got the spicy tuna which was ok. I feel like I tasted better. Portion was quite big, so I gave a lot to my bf to help me finish.

For entree, I order the duck breast. I did not like the duck at all. I barely even ate my meal. Luckily, I stuffed myself with the spicy tuna. 

I might come back in the future for another try.
author: Willa L.

description:
This place is fantastic!!  Everything on their menu sounds so amazingly good, so Isa's style of ordering many small plates to share is perfect.  I also enjoyed the atomoshere which is very modern and simple, and the staff is friendly as well.

I went with a group of 6 so we ordered about 10 different dishes to share.  My favorites were the Seared Dayboat Scallops, the Potato Wrapped Seabass, the Seared Foie Gras, and the Seared Duck Breast.  The scallops are seared to perfection and they are absolutely delish!  I was most impressed with the Potato Wrapped Seabass because of the unique presentation and how tender the seabass was.  

Overall a wondering dining experience.  Some of the plates are pretty small portioned, so if you go with a fairly large group, I recommend doubling up on the favorites.  Prices are quite reasonable for the quality that you get, and I would definitely go back again and again!
author: Mai S.

description:
Isa is a fine choice.  The garden area seating is great, and the food is very tasty. We even had an excellent bottle of wine without paying an arm and a leg.

The format, though, is not for every occasion. The small plates are, as our waiter counseled us, intended for family-style dining.  And it's recommended that you order two per person.  Sometimes it's not easy to settle on four dishes for two people to share, and selecting eight dishes for four might require help from a UN negotiating team.

We sampled a quail special, which I'd rate an A-/B+.  The tuna tartare was also good. The baked goat cheese and lamb were even better.  The selection of fish, chicken, meat, shellfish and vegetarian dishes was sufficiently broad to satisfy anyone.  And don't skip dessert. 

Overall, everything was quite good. Nothing was spectacular, but it's always nice to finish dinner without anything to complain about.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
Isa is great for trying a bunch of dishes and sharing with friends. Fun! While you are waiting for your table, try the lemon drop sake drink.  

I've been there are few times so the good things have outweighed the bad.  I was once annoyed when I had to wait 45 mins even with reservations or when they oversalted the food due to an idiotic SF Gate food critic, last name rhymes with Cower, who said that it wasn't salty enough.  Despite these bumps, some of the dishes are outstanding. 

Update!
I came back here tonight for a friend's birthday dinner.  we decided to get the prix fixe dinner.  If you order from there, the restaurant donates a small contribution to charity.  the sea bass crudo was so-ooooo goo-od - definite kick to it.  the heirloom tomatos were fresh, the prociutto was ok though i should have ordered the seared foie gras from the regular menu...amazing, amazing.

the entrees were the saffron paella (ok), the flat iron steak - ahhhhh, awesome green mustarde with a bordelaise sauce, and a tasty mushroom risotto.  the meals came with a bottle of sparkling or flat.  that was nice though i know san francisco is trying to go anti-bottled water due to pollution - oh well.

i really liked the amaretto semi-freddo (delish!), the creme brulee was good, the flourless chocolate was probably my least favorite.  

this time, we sat in the back - pretty area with a covered canopy and heat lamps.  cute place for date night!   the service was good until they really got busy for a wednesday night and it was snail mail slow...
i felt bad for the table next to me who waited and waited just to get an order for wine or food or even bread...

lesson learned, be more aggressive if you are short on time or patience and come early to beat the rush.

maybe i should give it a thumbs down so ya'll won't flock there...
author: Anh V.

description:
I've been here twice now. The first time, I really liked it. This second time, I fell in love. The grilled calamari was awesome and the hanger steak was fantastic. Certainly can't complain about any of the fish either. And butter lettuce salad with blue cheese... how can you not love that? 

The operation is set up for sharing. So the dishes are small and come out as they are ready. I think the key is to go with more people. The atmosphere is great for a date too, but if you can get more people there with you, you can also order more food. My second trip there was with a group of four, and it totally changed my perspective on the place.

Finally, having a good waiter never hurts either. Hats off to you, Norman.
author: Ben R.

description: This place doesn't disappoint.  The food and service are consistent.   The small sharing plate idea is good too.
author: Eric C.

description:
I'll probably have to write another review once I come back for dinner as I just went here for happy hour and some small bites, but everything was so well done.

The Negroni was perfectly mixed, it was perfectly balanced so as to be not too bitter, but still have that kick. The bread (which they kept bringing out) was delicious, as was the butter, and the wine I had (great 5$ happy hour specials on sojo and wine).

I split the salmon tartare, and everything was so perfectly done. I'm not a stickler for presentation and care more about taste, but you do have some expectation with french dining; and the tartare looked and tasted perfectly.

Love the back room with the heated lamps.

I'm excited to go back here for the 3-course prix fixe.
author: Mark A.

description: LOVE Isa! What a wonderful restaurant. Isa has a great happy hour with creative mixed drinks and a nice selection of wine. My favorite place to sit is at the bar and make conversation with the friendly bartenders (Jonathan!). Highly recommend the Sedna chardonnay and the truffle risotto - outstanding!!
author: Holly K.

description:
My girlfriend would probably give Isa 5 stars -- she can't stop talking about it. Her parents took us out to Isa after reading a review for it in the SF Zagat's guide. Four of us ate and were stuffed for around $150. The food here is served sort of "family style" in small plates. So everyone at the table shares (sorta like a traditional Chinese dinner). The potato wrapped seabass was incredible. Most of the food was, really. Their vanilla bean creme brulee was awesome too. I was not a fan of the duck breast or the potato & leek soup. 

As good as it was, I don't think it was worth ~$40/person pre-tip. I'm glad her parents paid! ;) Oh and if you like your umbrella, don't leave it in the umbrella bin. Apparently people just grab the best looking one on the way out - no matter if its theirs or not. I I expected more from a ritzy place.
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
Isa continues to be one of San Francisco's best choices for small plates fare. Slightly hidden on Steiner between Lombard and Chestnut, Isa continues to pack people in with a good combination of atmosphere, food, and service. Luke Sung, the head chef, has put together an interesting small plates menu that still stands out as rather unique. Like most small plates restaurants, the menu features a number of dishes that are "small" small plates (about appetizer sized) and "large" small plates (a large nibble for 2 people). The restaurant was redesigned in the last few years to create a more open dining experience.

The dishes on the menu offer a wide variety of options. There are some nice salads and a very interesting lobster broth that bears no resemblance to the usually cream-based lobster bisque you find in most restaurants. The strongest dishes on the menu are the seafood small plates, followed closely by the poultry dishes. I have been to Isa many times and generally find that you need about a total of 5 dishes for two normal adults. If you are out with a light eater, you might be able to get away with 4 dishes.

The service is generally quite good and the ambience is suitable for a nice early date (read 1st through 3rd date) or a night out with your significant other. Some of the tables in the main dining room feel a bit cramped, but the density of tables is a nice tradeoff when compared with the prospect of longer waits. Sitting at the bar is a fairly pleasant experience if you cannot get a table.

Cost: About $40 per person if you have 3 courses and a drink

Recommended dishes: Potato wrapped sea bass, the sea scallops, and fulton chicken are all excellent choices. Other good choices include the steak and the duck.

Advice: This is a great place to take a date. If you are planning ahead, ask to be seated on the patio in the rear as it has more ambience than the main dining room. The wine selection is relatively affordable and includes a few nice choices for the seasoned eye.
author: Charles H.

description:
Loved Isa.  It took us awhile to decide on what we wanted to eat since everything looked so good. But I knew (based on a suggestion) that we were having the potato wrapped seabass and the truffled rissoto.    I think we ate 7 plates?    Stand outs are those two mentioned above as well as the foie gras and the organic chicken.  The only thing we had that was a lil on the iffy side was the baked goat cheese.  That was a lil salty.    

Service was perfect for us.  We didn't want to be bothered so much.  Actually, when we finished our last course, the bus-person gave us clean dishes and silverware.  I looked at my friends and gave a "we still have more??" look.  And our server came up and told us that our chicken was coming.  I think they were getting ready to serve us another round of chicken, steak and rissoto.    If we weren't already stuffed, I think we would have had another go at it.  But alas... we settled for coffee.  

Would definately go back again.  Parking, as with any restaurant in the marina, is a crapshoot unless you pay for it in a parking lot.
author: Herb C.

description:
My first trip back in many years.  Mediocrity seems to be the prevailing norm in many supposed "tried and true favorites" in this town.

Was disappointed to find the small plate servings much larger than I expected, undermining the small plate experience which allows one to sample a few bites of a selection of dishes.  Soon realized we had ordered way too much food.

The spicy tuna tar tare was only marginally spicy, the dungeness crab salad was lacking in presentation and flavor, the foie gras was decent, but more than needed in terms of portion size.  

Scallops were served on an unimaginative bed of mashed potatoes.  Tasty but the mashed potatoes could have been replaced with something more creative.  The beets were, here again, lacking in presentation and distinctive flavor, just beets with goat cheese.  This I can do at home.  The potato wrapped fish was one of the best dishes we had.  It is apparently a specialty of the house.

My double espresso at the end of the evening was more like a regular cup of Peet's than espresso.  I suspect one of those pre-fab machines that does not require the expertise of a barrista.

Overall, some good dishes, but portions were too large and often sloppily composed.
author: Mimi G.

description:
Ah Isa... the restaurant you want to like but, once you've been burnt enough times by bad service, you're forced to write them off.  I did quite a long time ago.

Isa's an adorable little spot, especially if you sit on the back patio.  They have small plates, and most of them are very good (esp. the potato wrapped fish, I forget which one).

I've had bad service there on at least three separate occasions.  Most annoying are the "rules" which make no operational sense and piss off the customer.  Like - you have to order everything at once.  How many times have you been to a small plate restaurant and ordered a few things, planning to order more if you were still hungry.  Not an option at Isa (or at least when I was there).  I've had items forgotten on more than one occasion.  I've had downright rude service.

So, sorry Isa, you're out.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Essentially on a whim, i tried Isa the other night. It was fantastic. I like going to nicer restaurants, but it's pretty rare that I'll go to one and then already want to go again within the week. (however, that's probably not going to happen if my wallet has any say in the matter.) I tried 5 of their dishes, served in a tapas/family hybridized style, each of which ranged in quality from "that was really good" to "WOW! that was incredible".

Must-haves were the scallops and the veal thymus. I really want to go again (and soon) because there were a number of other things I wanted to try and I just wouldn't have room nor money for. The service was great - though it might have just been our waiter - but he was enough to really push the experience up from nice restaurant to a reasonable competitor of my area favorites.

if you haven't been, check it out. it's a bit noisy, and the people can be pushy and annoying, but it's a good meal to be had.
author: Bernie L.

description:
The wife and I had an early dinner here last Saturday night and found it to be a very good value with excellent service. A note on the service style, this is a takeoff on tapas in that they offer small plates that come out as they are ready as opposed in traditional courses.

We started with the baked Laura Chenel goat cheese with basil pesto. It was very flavorful and smoothness of the goat cheese and the basil pesto complimented each other nicely. We moved on to the scallops with corn, fava beans, cherry tomatoes, mashed potatoes with a truffle sauce. The scallops had a deep sear with a nice medium rare center. Of the few hundred times I have had scallops over the years these were the best prepared I have experienced. Next we experienced the truffle risotto with an assortment of mushrooms. While truffle risotto was something that I have wanted to try I am not a big mushroom fan. As such, you had the earthiness one wants/expects from truffles and mushrooms but it was a little much for my tastes. My wife on the other hand is a mushroom fan and loved the preparation. The final items we had was one of the specials offered that day. It was the braised short rib. The short rib was tender and the demi-glace provided a great source of flavor to compliment the risotto that was served with this dish.

Best single item was the corn that was served with the seared scallops. It was tremendously fresh and flavorful.

The facility is interesting. The inside is upscale and many of the tables appear to be good for an intimate dinner. The outside covered and heated patio is a bit more rustic and fairly loud. I would request a seat out here for larger groups or more festive meals.
author: Don V.

description: The food was great and the price was reasonable.  They only have a limited alcohol license, so I made do with these soju vodka drinks, which probably was for the best in the long run.  We ordered several dishes to share, which worked out well.   I would definitely recommend the goat cheese and the mussels, as well as the tuna tartare.  We did order lamb and were served beef instead, but it was delicious and because the error was the waiter's, they even took it off the bill, which was not necessary, but was very nice of them.  I would dine here again when visiting San Francisco.  Yes the back area was crowded, but it made for a fun vibe.
author: Jocelyn R.

description:
Oh YUMMY!  Can I have some more?  I can't believe that I just discovered this place. The food is just amazing. My personal favorites were the potato wrapped sea bass and the foie gras.  This is the type of place that makes a girl want to start dating just for the sake of eating out. Because no matter how bad the date is, the food was worth it.

EDIT:  I went back in January and it just wasn't the same as before.  I can't seem to pinpoint what exactly was missing but it just wasn't quite executed the same as before.  The food was still tastey but more salty and less flavorful.  It makes me sad to take away a star from them because they were one of my favorite places.  I'll try to visit again to see if I just went on a bad night.
author: Alice C.

description:
Originally posted on winodepot.com

Date: September 21, 2005
Location: 3324 Steiner Street, San Francisco
Corkage Fee: not sure
Price: $225 - party of three (including tax & tip)
Phone: 415.567.9588

ttepper, Beaune-2-Rock and I were attending the Realm Winery's 2003 release party next door at Nectar. After tasting some wonderful 2003 Realm release (another thread later), we decided to head next door for dinner.

This is a restaurant with small plates, everything is served family style for you to share. The waiter suggested 7 items for three people on average. We didn't listen to him and had six ordered, only to add on one more at the end, so he was 100% correct. 

Since this was a last minute thing, we didn't bring any wine with us, instead, we ordered a bottle of 2003 Tally Chardonnay off the list and ttepper also sucked down couple of beers.

The three fish course we ordered were done to perfection, temperature, flavor, presentation are all great. As with the scallops. 
I've been on a Heirloom tomato kick for the last year, so I make a point to order this when available at restaurant. Although it's a very simple dish, each restaurant generally have their own interpretation, and Isa's was wonderful.

The crab and lamb was probably the two weaker course we had, with that said, both were still above average. Perhaps these two did not intrigue me as much due to the lack of creativity. Do have to make another quick note here, the risotto that came with the lamb was very well done.

If you are even in the Marina District and have not been to this restaurant, please do give it a try. You won't be disappointed. 

Dungeness Crab Salad with celery, mango & fuji apple
~
Heirloom Tomato Salad with arugula & laura chenel goat cheese
~
Seared Yellowfin Tuna with cucumber, radish, peppers & tapanade
~
Seared Dayboat Scallops with baby artichokes, tomatoes, olives & basil
~
Halibut a la Plancha with beets, orange, champagne vinegar & cilantro
~
Potato Wrapped Seabass with brown butter, capers, lemon & parsley
~
Roasted Rack of Lamb with fava beans, pea risotto & natural jus
author: Powell Y.

description:
