Unpretentious, always yummy, and the small plates are actually big enough that i don't start to panic at the thought of sharing my  super rica roasted chicken with others.
author: Robyn C.

description:
Good place, good food, but I've had better in the city.  It's sorta tapas style--small dishes--too small for my taste.  However, the food is great and very flavorful.  We ordered steak (very good), stuffed cod (yummy), and tomato soup.  We also tried the heirloom tomato soup, but not so great---mine is better.

Atmosphere is noisy and it's super cramped--not good for large parties.  It was difficult to hold conversations across the table because it was so loud.  Wine menu is good, but they didn't have two different ones on the list.

I wouldn't go back if I had a choice.  Would rather try a new place elsewhere!
author: Mai T.

description:
I've frequented Isa's at least twice a year for the last, oh, four years and I have to say that today I was finally inspired to write a review.

But why, Sugar?

Honey, let me tell you, this was the first time that I received SUPERIOR table service. Sure the water and bread are free flowing and most of the staff is nice, but for some reason the people who take your order are meanies that like to roll their eyes when you don't order wine or order too much off of the menu. It's small plates people! I should be able to have as many as I want!

I can't remember the name of the young gentleman who serviced (tee hee) us tonight but he's white with a long-ish face and curly or wavy honey blond hair. Not my type, but a lovely boy. He was truly a sweetheart and a bit of a tip whore because he kept calling my 50-something mom "Miss."  She got a real kick out of that. 

The menu changes only slightly with the seasons which bothers me, but my mommy loves the old standbys. 

Here's what we always order when it's available:

Crab salad
Lobster broth
Something with scallops
Roast chicken
Pasta with truffle bits
Tomato salad
Prosciutto
Something with fish

The backyard seating is a beautiful experience with the soft lighting and greenery; however, it can get chilly and the outdoor heaters dry out your skin.

The only occasional disappointment is that some of their flavors are super strong. Like lots of olives "complementing" some fish. Lots of capers. Stuff like that.  Overly salty lobster broth (this happened twice).
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Exceptional place! I came here for my b-day dinner. Basically I looked at the website and was sold after seeing the picture of the carmelized scallops. I was a bit nervous since it was my first time trying it out for such a special occasion, but I was delightfully happy with the service, the food, the decor, and the waiter (David)!

All the plates are meant to share family style; the plates come small so they recommend ordering 2 plates/person. 

I recommend:
1) Carmelized Dayboat Scallops
2) Saffron Paella
3) Baked Butterfish

I also tried the lamb but it was too chewy. Since it was my first time, I'm hoping that was just a fluke! The service was phenomenal. It was raining that day and we sat in the patio. Water was seeping in from the outside crack of the tent. A waitress came by and took my coat so it wouldn't have the possibility of getting rain on it. The waiter was friendly even though he had many tables to wait on. For as busy as the restaurant was, the staff paid much attention to my table and was quick with refilling our drinks.

Great place!
author: Elaine T.

description:
We went here for my girlfriend's birthday and even though we had a reservation, we waited one hour!! The hostess was no where to be found and they kept making excuses for why our table wasn't ready. At one point the waitress told us to to go stand by our table to "intimidate" the group that was taking a long time to pay their check....who says that??!!! Once we finally sat down, they did bring us free appetizers for their apology. Our waiter was great, since it was an extremely busy night and this place is pretty tiny. 

However, the food was good. No complaints with the food, we enjoyed the goat cheese appetizer, butter lettuce salad, the braised lamb medallions. Overall the dinner was good, besides the whole fiasco with the waiting.
author: Meredith A.

description:
Was also there last night, and thought it was delish. Went with my dad (father/daughter every-other-tuesday-dinner), got there as soon as it opened, and was so happy with the turnout. 

Waiters came immediately, we had wine within 5 minutes (I had a white burgundy that was YUMMMMM) and a bread plate within 3. Our server asked how we'd like our meal to be paced (which more places should do), and we were off. The tuna ceviche was out of this world (made my dad trade me for my asparagus soup)...perfectly seasoned, not too citrusy, perfect crostini, the cilantro added just the right punch...I could go on and on.

The roast chicken was perfect. Crispy skin, herbs underneath it that made the entire chicken super-flavorful, and moist meat that fell off the bone.

One star off for playing jarring hip-hop that totally ruined the ambiance.
author: Annie B.

description:
No four stars because this place is overpriced, and kind of eh service - though admittedly the night we were there, they did have a HUGE private party at the restaurant that seemed to be occupying a lot of their servers' time.

The food tasted delicious! Flatiron steak & scallops were perfectly seasoned. Steak was medium rare, juicy and delicious. No complaints!
author: Latte Queen W.

description: Other reviewers have said a lot of what I have to say.  It's been awhile since I've been back to Isa.  Food is very good, though not outstanding, and service is friendly but slow.   We had a party of 8 and were seated in the heated patio, which I prefer, but we were really packed in like sardines, and it can get a bit warm (and those of us packed further in didn't even dream of trying to get out to excuse ourselves).  We ordered a variety - 15 dishes (combo of appetizers and entrees) for 8 people, and it was just the right amount of food ($55 each including tip).  We had the dungeness crab salad (very fresh with lots of chunky crab, mandarin oranges, avocado and lettuce), yellowfin tuna (was like a tuna tartare), butter lettuce salad (with pears and walnuts), goat cheese, Hudson Valley foie gras with figs and brioche (good sized portion, very good), the flatiron steak, duck breast, leek and potato soup, Maine lobster broth, etc.   I didn't like their Malbec, but the 2008 Carmenet Chardonnay was very good as was the River Run Cote d'Aromas.   Would come back - the oysters, hamachi special, potato wrapped seabass all sounded good  as well.  Remember to bring coins for the garage - parking is awful!
author: Vivian W.

description:
Wanted a long walk (from SOMA) and a cute restaurant with good food in the Marina and this place fit the bill. We were seated without a reservation shortly after arriving. Our server was a bit awkward at first (teensy bit rehearsed schpeel - how do I spell that?), but I warmed up to him and he was just so cute and eager to please. They suggest you order 2 dishes per person, but I think if you weren't extremely hungry you could get away with just 1. 

Lemon drop martini was delicious (I've gotten gun shy lately with icky sour mix ones) and our cabernet was good, even though we couldn't finish it. The bread smelled amazing, and the butter was good. For dinner, we had the baked goat cheese. It was good, but I could put goat cheese on top of tomatoes and basil myself and stick it in the oven. Our second appetizer was the sauteed prawns, which were also good and drenched in garlic. Yum. Then we had the Petrale sole with vegetables and more garlic. It was nicely browned and flaky and the light sauce was tasty. We followed this with the duck and, I believe, huckleberry sauce with a potato galette and red cabbage. The galette was okay, the duck was awesome (unless you don't like it mid-rare), and the cabbage was pretty good. The creme brulee was very "bruleed," but that's the way I like it, and the custard was less like custard and more like whipped cream, which is not the way I like it. 

The ambiance of the back room is great - romantic white string lights, barn like siding, something I'd love for an intimate wedding reception if I were having one. The tables were a little tightly packed, but it wasn't an issue.
author: Natasha D.

description:
Perhaps because it was Valentine's Day that everything seemed pretty perfect. The ambience, the food, the wine, the service - all good :). 

We got to Isa about half an hour before our reservation so we couldn't be seated right away. However there was space at bar where we got to enjoy a glass of red wine before our meal. Pink and red balloons filled the dimly lit space with it being more cute and romantic rather than cheesy. 

We were then seated later quickly and our server was pleasant in explaining their menu of sharing of the small plates. We each got to pick three from the prix fix menu which gave us a chance to sample a variety of dishes. Everything was absolutely scrumptious and beautifully presented. My favorites were definitely the hamachi, scallops, and duck - omg the duck, I've never had such juicy melt-in-your-mouth duck before!! 

Wish I had room to try their desserts but we were both pleasantly full and satisfied. For the restaurant to be so full, it didn't feel crowded or rushed. 

Sighhhhh. Can't wait to come back!!!
author: Sandy K.

description: One of the first restaurants we went to when we relocated to SF. My bf and I loved it. Great food, kind waiter, and nice patio/garden area!
author: Alyssa M.

description:
11 people, prix fix meal.  We purchased two bottles of wine. It came out to $65 a person with tax and tip.  

Although it was a good experience, and the waiter super nice, nothing wowed me about this place.  We had a pretty comprehensive dinner that consisted of Scallops, Foie Gras, Risotto, Duck, Lamb, and Steak.   Parking in the Marina is a beezy.  We probably will not come back, but glad to have tried it.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
Isa is a predominately French, family-style, small-plates restaurant with a fully weather-proof patio, an uncommon batch of middle aged, male servers, and fantastic food.  We ate there on Monday, February 1 and, arriving at 6, had no trouble getting a table, though the restaurant was filling when we left.
We were led past the open kitchen (noticed a shelf of celebrity cookbooks and bottles of Sriracha) onto the back patio which, despite feeling like a backyard deck with planters and strings of light, is fully covered, and replete with heat lamps and antique sconces.  Happy Hour doesn't end until 7 so we each enjoyed a $5 glass of wine (specialty Soju cocktails also available).  A 2-course selectable prix fixe is $24, 3-course is $28 and includes much of the main menu, including the daily special.  On the other hand, items on the menu range from $7-23, so I would advise  you to do the math, especially because everything is served family style.
Prince Edward Island Mussels: The mussels were something classic, almost common, done exceptionally.  The mussels were tender, almost like the bellies of raw oysters.  The steaming liquid was unusually rich, with a little tang of wine, and far surpassed the normal parsley and butter.  The grilled bread served with the mussels was in fact burned, overpowering and inedible, but the warm sourdough baguette already on the table was a nice substitute.
Baked Laura Chenel Goat Cheese: This dish didn't seem that exciting, but, like the mussels, was pleasantly surprising and unusual.  Served on tomato concasse (peeled, seeded and chopped...I learned something new today) with basil, pine nuts and olive oil, the baked cheese didn't have breading or crust.  Instead of being dolled up, the goat cheese remained a strong flavor with a delicate whipped texture.  It, too, went well with the warm bread and I plan to attempt to replicate it at home.  Being a small and light dish, I think it should have come before the mussels, instead of just a few minutes after.  The restaurant's philosophy of serving lightest to heaviest seemed to be offset by kitchen timing.
Daily Special: Grilled Hamachi:  Hamachi grilled to a slight char like a steak, served with olive tapenade, clams and calamari.  A little much, no?  And it was, especially after cheese and mussels.  But I cannot fault them for how I ordered and the dish was good.  I am not partial to fish, but it was really nice and pink on the inside, and the tapenade covering it was mild.  The calamari was unbelievably tender, really, like custard.  But what I really enjoyed were the clams.  Like the mussels, they were tender, and each had its own little pool of buttery jus.
Dutch Valley Veal Sweetbreads:  The last thing to come, and by far the heaviest, was the veal sweetbreads.  The varied, wild mushrooms were all good, but mostly overpowered by the really overwhelming scent of truffles.  The sweetbreads were tender, creamy, and, thankfully, were cut to small pieces that looked less like brain.  This is my second time having sweetbreads and I'm really just not all there  yet.  The potato was smooth and soaked up the delicious, rich mushroom broth that turned to a proteinous blob in my refrigerator overnight (a good thing, despite the image).  Unfortunately, the potato pancake was very dense and not crispy, and didn't help allay the weight of the rest of the dish.
They recommended that we order two dishes per person which was really too much (as exemplified by the sweetbreads I just had for breakfast.  mmm) as both the hamachi and the sweetbreads were more than generous entree portions.  As a duo that usually tempers our appetites by perhaps sharing an appetizer, four dishes made for a giant doggy bag of food that doesn't necessarily reheat well (potato pancake).  I also feel that the dishes would be better served as courses taken away at completion, rather than a conglomerate of dishes.  At one point, all four were on the table at the same time which, besides being cramped on a two person table, did not showcase the food well.  Lastly, we ate no vegetables.  Most of the menu items had a base of mashed potatoes or mushrooms, and I'm all for umami.  But next time, I'll make room for a salad.
Overall, the food was exceptional, the service attentive but not obsequious, and, the highest compliment I can give: I would take my parents here.

-Arrive before 7 for Happy Hour $5 drinks
-Double check the Prix Fixe menu for prices
-Grab a mint on your way out.  They are anise flavored and each cellophane wrapper says "Bye."
author: Laura S.

description:
Isa is a very good restaurant for its price. I have been there many times and have recommended my friends to go. We all like it. Every time I went there I got surprised by the dishes and the improvement of flavor. It's been the only place every time when i wanted to eat seared foie gras before it's prohibited in California. 
 I have tried the Grilled local calamari, Seared scallops, Potato wrapped Seabass, Roasted rack of lamb, Range chicken, Maple leaf farm duck breast, Grilled golden gate natural angus flat iron steak, braised pork. 
Each of them are good. My favorite is range Chicken and braised pork. They are great. It's flavorful but not too salty. And my least like is beef and seabass. The beef dish is not good but the texture is too hard. I Maybe it's the beef itself quality. And the seebass  I expected was soft and juicy but it was a little bit too dry and  hard, But the flavor is okay.

Anyways I will defilingly go again and recommend my friends to go.
author: Rouise L.

description:
Came here for D.A.T. with a group of friends. We had at least one of everything on the D.A.T. menu, except the flatiron steak. I liked all the appetizers and I'd get any of them again. Regarding entrees, I wouldn't order the halibut again. The duck was a little too salty, but otherwise outstanding. The risotto was too rich in my opinion. It was excellent for sharing, but I wouldn't be able to eat even a quarter of it on my own. I think the real stand-out was the chicken, because it was just so unexpectedly good. Regarding desserts, I personally prefer my creme brulees to be in more shallow ramekins and the top layer of carmelized sugar to be thinner. However, really, they were all very good, with my personal favorite being the granite. 

In terms of ambience, the bar area is very dimly lit, but it's completely different in the dining area. It's very cute - like you're sitting in an outdoor patio. Service was excellent! Our waiter obviously loves his job and where he works, which made the dining experience that much more pleasant.
author: Tammy L.

description: GREAT SERVICE, good shareable food. My family of 10 and I all loved it. The spicy ahi salad (not sure of the exact description) was especially fantastic!
author: Katelyn T.

description:
My family and I came here for my mom's birthday after a day of shopping in Union Square. Parking here is a nightmare, but my dad is historically lucky when it comes to parking spots, and we parked right in front of Isa and only paid 1 buck for 30 minutes since parking is free after 6:00 PM on Saturdays.

Our seating was at 5:30 PM (right at opening) so we were able to get 5 dollar happy hour soju cocktails including glasses of wine. The Number Seven with muddled blackberries, lemon, ginger, soju, and splash of champagne is excellent to start your meal off. Isa's menu comes family-style so order a few dishes for the table for everyone to try. On a side note: their bread is delicious. We had the following for 5 people:

Lobster broth
Heirloom tomato salad 
Seared foie gras
Argentinian sea bass
Seared sea scallops 
Sweetbreads
Mushroom risotto
Duck breast

Dessert: flourless chocolate cake, marscapone huckleberry trifle, creme brulee, affogato

The lobster broth was pretty flavorful, not heavy at all and came with big pieces of lobster tail meat. Good, but I wasn't wowed. The tomato salad was a great summer dish. The tomatoes were sweet balanced by the feta and basil and arugula. The foie pieces were huge and cooked perfectly, although the custard brioche and peaches were pretty much my favorite parts. The sea bass was kind of dry and flavorless although the potato crust was good. The sauce was a little too salty. Easily forgettable next to the scallops. Perfectly cooked with extremely fresh veggies. Very light. I could have probably eaten it for just my entree. Sweetbreads were flavorful and meaty, but nothing to especially rave about. The mushroom risotto was quite tasty. Cooked beautifully with lots of different kinds of mushrooms and salty, nutty parmesan shavings on top. I wouldn't have minded that as an indulgent entree to myself either. The last dish to come out was the duck and it was worth it. Moist duck with tangy huckleberry sauce with arugula and beets and cheese. You needed to eat them in a perfect bite to get the full amazing experience. Dessert was pleasant. The trifle was a great tangy mix of marscapone cheese, berries, and spiced apple/pears. A light ending to a really decadent meal. The chocolate cake was really fluffy but the gelato was the star of the desserts, especially in the affogato. 

Overall, Isa was a great, memorable meal with great service, although some entree misses in my opinion, but everything else was amazing. Cheap, well-made drinks during happy hour and great starter bread were huge pluses. I'd come back just for the foie, scallops, and risotto alone. 5 stars!
author: Vinh N.

description:
5 stars for ambiance- the tented area in the back felt like a private garden (well maybe not private).   
5 stars for food- I just kept ordering things because everything was so yummy!  Bill was high but worth it.   
5 stars for service- Go on a week night so you don't have to wait.  I hardly noticed the waiter so he must have been good.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
The food is delicious.  Isa only serves small bites (tapas).  The sea bass wrapped in potato skin is amazing.  Other dishes were great too.

Get a reservation with a seat in the garden even on a cold night.  it's covered and plenty of heaters.  It's very romantic back there.

I gave it 4 stars because I don't think small bites have to be expensive.  We didn't even order a bottle of wine...it was well over $130 for 2.
author: Julia H.

description:
This place is awesome.  The back patio is provides a fantastic ambience and I was very impressed by the food.  Went here with a huge group of like 16+ people - and had a blast just going sort of tapas style and drinking a lot of wine.  Think we ended up with a $1000+ tab though...must've been more wine than I thought :) 

The Foie Gras is mesmerizing.
author: Sam H.

description:
Overrated.

Despite having made a reservation on Opentable.com and having gotten there on time, we did not get seated for at least 20-30 minutes later, not to mention we had the meter going at one of the public lots in Marina (since parking in horrendous there).

While waiting, we were not warmly received, we were left just sitting there, the hostess did not offer to grab us some water or anything.

Finally, when we were seated, the table and chairs were TINY and I'm not a big girl.  Our waiter was a nice guy, recommended the mushroom risotto and what not.  The food came and was definitely very good, the potato wrapped sea bass and the chicken both lived up to their raves.  The mushroom risotto on the other hand, was not my cup of tea, my bf enjoyed it, but not so much myself.  The green apple martini smelled very good and looked very cool but I did not have any myself.

I wouldn't go back based on the lack of a warm greeting at the door.   The food was good but I'm sure available at another restaurant in the Bay.
author: Winnie L.

description:
I love Isa's.  They made my buddy 's visit for Taiwan so memorable to him.   He went to the restaurant slightly jet lag and came out so very happy.  I was determined to spoil him.  We order the Kir Royale Champagne to celebrate his arrival.  We had an absolutely delicious ahi tartare, follow with the some succulent dayboat scallops, which led us to the the tiger prawns cook to perfection.  Our "entrees" of the sea bass and the beef so perfectly done that it made my buddy grin ear to ear.   Watching his reaction to each bite and new sensation really made my day.   We finished off with light passion fruit and mango soup. Our server was impeccable and friendly.  

It really was a special night for the both of us and they made it special for him.   Thanks Isa's!
author: Chris C.

description:
Great food and great ambience -- the covered patio is lovely.  We had a group of about 8-10 people -- so this certainly is a spot that works for big groups...however, I'm deducting a star -- would've been four stars had it not been for the mediocre service.  The waiter we had gave us dirty looks for not ordering more wine...and we also end up over ordering since he claimed we would need a lot more food than planned... you gotta go family style here and some plates are smaller than others -- but no need to order 12 dishes for 8 people!

Get the sea bass....
author: Jennie L.

description:
145 reviews here, so I'll keep this brief. Since I've come San Francisco (end of July), I've been notorious for ordering the worst dishes out of my dinner guests. Either they are too salty, bland or just leave a sour taste in my mouth, but ISA was different...ISA was FABULOUS..for once I had people sampling out of my plate..

If you could go with one dish..Potato wrapped seabass, just divine!
author: Amruta G.

description:
Hubby and I walked in here on a whim after finding the Nectar Wine Lounge next door rather disappointing. It was around 6:45 p.m. on a Saturday night, so there weren't any tables available, but luckily there were still plenty of seats at the bar. We got there just in time though, because not even 15 minutes later there was standing room only!

The food here was really good. We ordered:

Baked goat cheese
Grilled asparagus 
Spanish seafood paella
Free range chicken with mashed potatoes
Garlic spinach
Foie gras with huckleberries and custard brioche

I think that's all of it. I may be forgettting something, but everything was really good. The foie gras in particular was very impressive. And that custard brioche thing was a little piece of heaven. I could eat a whole plate of those! 

Like I said, we sat at the bar, but the front restaurant area seemed small but in a cozy, comfortable way. In the back is this cool tented room with little white xmas lights and a lot more seating. IThat area had a lovely, romantic and slightly outdoorsy feel to it. 

My only pet peeve about this place was that the female bartender who was serving us had on a really tight black button down shirt and the middle button across her boobs was stretched open, so she was flashing the side of her boob and her bra. Um, hello? Invest in some fashion tape or a safety pin, for goodness sake -- or get a shirt that fits! That looked skanky and unprofessional. But...that's a minor peeve...

This was truly a goodie find. I definitely recommend it.
author: Christine P.

description:
Yum. 

This was on my list for a while and I had the pleasure of visiting it for dinner with my friend Brenna after work one day. We decided to go with their pre fixe menu so that we could try a variety of dishes. 

First off, their pre-fixe offers so many choices! It's like 3/4 of the regular menu!

We had the Baked Goat Cheese with Sun Dried Tomatoes and Basil and the Prosciutto and Melon Bruschetta to start. For our entrees, we ordered the Seafood Paella and the Mushroom Risotto. 

Our waitress was super nice, we spent two hours eating and gossiping about people at work, and all in all, it was a great experience. 

The food is really fresh, the flavors are great, and our conversation prompted us to start a monthly dinner club - the club name being the Amuse Bouche. :)
author: verna b.

description:
Went to Isa for the first time on Saturday night.
Made a reservation, and that seemed to be a necessity on a weekend night. The place was packed with what seemed to be people waiting for reservation no-shows. They are on OpenTable, so book before you go.

The restaurant had a great intimate, but not over-the-top fancy decor.
Service was great. Our server was able to answer all our questions about what the green stuff we just ate was.

Small plate menu is a great way to try lots of different tastes at one sitting. We were a party of 4, and we ordered 6 of the heavier dishes between us (none of the appetizer-sounding dishes at the top of the menu). We had the scallops, rissotto, foie-gras, duck, chicken, and ahi. Everything was amazing. Perfect amount of food, and great taste. Don't underestimate the chicken... amongst the other more "glamourous" sounding dishes, it seems to be a boring choice, but it was really excellent.

Wine list was big enough. The bottle our server suggested was excellent.

If you're looking for a small-plate restaurant, and a fun place for a small group, definately go to Isa!
author: David H.

description:
Small, intimate restaurant with a great wine selection.  I was in SF for work, so I didn't know the area to well.  I am so happy my friends took me here for dinner.

The food was amazing.  We had the risotto, lobster bisque, butterfish, and scallops.  it's set up tapas style, so you share with everyone.  Not only does this allow for more conversation, but it also keeps you from stuffing yourself.

It's a bit pricey, but I definitely think it's worth it.
author: angie c.

description:
I love this place!  I have been a customer since they have opened and am amazed with how consistent they are.  This is a great place to get 5 star food quality with 3 star prices!  I recently had their Dungeness Crag Salad  - loved it.  I also have to say that I enjoyed their bread and butter.  Warm and soft gooey rolls served with REAL lightly salted butter.  Now that's what I'm TALKIN' ABOUT!    

There menu is very diverse and there is something for everyone.
author: Caesar C.

description:
LOVE ISA! 

I've been to ISA a few times, I found it during one of my earlier visits to SF and every time I went back to NY I would not shut up about how much I love this restaurant.  Now that Iive in SF I want to eat here every night but am restraining myself, its a good thing I don't live closer to it!  Everything is great here, I have never had a bad experience.  The only issue for some may be the tight seating but everything else makes up for it.
author: sasha y.

description:
Eight of us enjoyed dinner at Isa. We sat in the back patio which was great. I can't honestly remember what everyone ordered but I do know there were no complaints. Some things that stood out were: 

1. Baked goat cheese
2. Dungeness crab salad 
3. Grilled honey spice calamari (these are not deep fried rings so if deep fried calamari with some mayo sauce is all you've had then you should try this dish)
4. Risotto
5. Dayboat scallops
6. Tuna tartare

Add a few deserts and some soju cocktails and presto! A delicious meal is born.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
3.5 stars

I was looking forward to trying a new place and decided Isa was the one after looking at the menu online.  We sat out on the patio which was covered - very cute with all the lights.  Our server was great - attentive and friendly.  We also played some hangman w/ the ladies sitting on the table next to us. haha

now the food. maybe I was just expecting too much? The appetizers were the best part of the meal.  The ceviche was really fresh and I really liked the baked goat cheese.  I thought it was great how they heated the basket of bread, making it warm and toasty.  The paella was good but I've had better.  The rice was slightly undercooked.  The halibut w/ the artichokes and olives was just ok.  The fish was slightly overcooked.  It just didn't wow me.  I was like "eh..."  Good selection of wine.  Creme Brulee wasn't that great.  The layer of sugar on top was too thick.  Almost broke my spoon trying to crack it (jk.. not that bad) - had to eat around the top crust or would have gotten an instant cavity!
author: Alice C.

description:
We stumbled upon Isa while roaming around the Marina looking for a cool place to eat without having to wait. I've seen Isa on Yelp and remembered it having decent reviews, so went in and had dinner. I ordered a really delicious (despite being a little salty) asparagus soup to start and the truffle spaghetti (recommended by our waiter). The truffle spaghetti was a nice surprise. The pasta is a lot tougher than usual and added a great texture. The truffle flavor and aroma was strong so the small portion turned out to be a perfect amount. I would absolutely recommend getting the truffle spaghetti if you like that truffle flavor. :)

Isa also has a cozy atmosphere and very cute patio in the back. Thumbs up.
author: Han C.

description:
One of the best places in San Francisco.  The Foie is amazing and the goat cheese divine.  The dishes are perfect sizes to order many and share with a larger group.  There isn't a single dish on the menu that I thought was not prepared perfectly.  The soft risotto is a must if you want to combine some great carbs with your meal.  

Service wise I've always found the wait staff attentive. I love this place.
author: Dan Y.

description:
Isa is definitely a great place for a group of 4 or less because of the tapas style dishes.  I came here with 6 people (5 of which are guys) and ordered 12 items on the menu (6 appetizers and 6 entrees) of which I thought my favorites were the foie gras, butterfish, flat iron steak, lamb shank and the ceviche.  

I thought the staff at Isa was really accommodating with our reservations as well.  I called 2 times to change my reservations and then again to let them know I would be late and each time they were able to change it for us.
author: Jen L.

description: Came here for Dine About Town.  It was so amazing!!!  For appetizers, we got the dungeness crab salad and the steamed Prince Edward mussels.  The crab salad was crispy, tart, and had a lot of crab.  There were so many flavorful mussels.  The seared scallops were perfection - just the right texture and flavor. Sadly, there was only four scallops.  We got the flat iron steak, which compared to all the other great food, was not as exciting.  For dessert, we ordered the semifreddo amaretto and the vanilla bean gelato.  By then, we were completely stuffed.  The desserts were good but I wish they had chocolate gelato.
author: Rose C.

description: I was here for DAT dinner two weeks ago.  The place was crowded.  When I walked by the kitchen, the cooks and chef all working very hard.  It was a small kitchen for the amount of guests they had that day, but the quality of food didn't suffer at all.  There were 4 of us that night, and we all ordered different appetizers, entrees and desserts.  So we tried quite a few different dishes, and everything was very good.  It's great that they didn't cut back on the portion nor quality even when they are running the DAT promotion.  Service was great as well.
author: Dee L.

description: Food is OUTSTANDING! Cute neighborhood location. Wasn't crazy about the "tent" atmosphere but didn't hate it either. Service was also excellent.
author: Amy H.

description:
Quality food served tapas style. Love it. I just love the idea of sharing small plates with a good group of friends. Everyone gets to try the food without being overly stuffed. We ordered several dishes here, but the ones that have forever been ingrained into my memory are the seared scallops, dungeness crab salad, foie gras, roasted chicken, and rack of lamb. The scallops and lamb were cooked to perfection. It's real easy to overcook these dishes, but they did it just right. The scallops come with asparagus, potato puree, and truffles. The dungeness crab salad is one of my favorites. It's fresh dungeness crab served with avocado, grapefruit, and mango in a tarragon dressing. The roasted chicken was so moist and full of flavor. I swear I could've ate that whole plate to myself. Lastly, the foie gras. Isa is rumored to serve some of the best foie gras in the city...I believe it. It's seared perfectly, and ours was accompanied with a poached pear. 

This is a great place for groups. Wonderful wine list as well as a great selection of cocktails. FYI: parking in this area sucks really bad so plan accordingly. Also, I have been here several times and each time I've had a reservation. Unfortunately each time I have came...I still had to wait for my table. It's not too long of a wait (~15 minutes), but still with a reservation...it would have been nice to be seated more promptly.
author: Maybelline C.

description: The food was delicious. The service was a bit slow, so we were there for about 3 hours for a 3 course meal. The place is small, but comfortable given the space. It's a little hidden, but definitely great food nonetheless. We went on a weeknight, so it wasn't super crowded and didn't see many people around the bar.
author: Clara T.

description: Wanted to love it more, but sadly, we didn't- mainly because we were so rushed.  We had seen this reviewed on Check Please Bay Area and tagged as one to try. Finally we got there, even a few minutes early- seated promptly- which was great -and we were seated in the front room which we had asked for; ok, so it was a great start.  Even better, our server explained that all dishes were cooked to order and family style and would be served when ready.  This gave me the picture of a leisurely meal, with some time between courses to sip wine, digest the previous dish and generally just enjoy our evening. Sadly, it was just the opposite.  I was afraid to put my fork down between bites because there was so much commotion around us and servers hovering so closely, I felt like I better speed it up.  We were in and out in less than an hour.  I'm sorry- I think that's a downright tragedy- when I go out to dinner, I want to relax and enjoy my meal- it should be an evening event.   I hate to sound like a European snob, but no restaurant in Italy or France would rush you out in an hour.  Your table is yours for the night.  Too bad American restaurants are more focused on turning the table for the next reservation rather than allowing diners to savor their food.  Too bad for Isa,as the food was tasty, but we'll never go back nor recommend.
author: Diane F.

description:
It was a warm evening out...and my friend and I decided to have dinner in the Marina.  We had reservations at 7:30pm on a Friday evening, and we didn't sit down until close to 8pm.  The lady didn't even say when we would be seated.

We ordered a bunch of stuff...  I would have to say...the Foie Gras was the best.  :)

The waiter we had wasn't so great.  We had to wave him down a few times.  We opted not to have dessert there...and went elsewhere.
author: Lise T.

description: What a gem of a place. Food is mostly a hit, but I have experienced a time or 2 that have been slightly off on some of their dishes. IE: they can over-dress or under the salad and portion size varies. Very casual environment and can get cramped loud, but they always manage to find you a seat. I am just very sad that CA has banned foie gras--as this place used to serve a very generous portion.
author: Alex A.

description:
Isa is my new favorite restaurant. I couldn't help but order seafood for every dish. The lobster broth was light but incredibly flavorful. I've never had grilled calamari that was so tender to the bite and not at all chewy. The seafood risotto was a beautiful balance of flavors, and not a single bite was overpowered by the flavor of another. 

The close-your-eyes-and-enjoy dish of the evening was the scallops. I have never, ever, ever had scallops so perfect. They weren't huge but the taste was. The buttery sauce glistened on the pearly flesh of the scallop and a sweet bite of salty bacon dressed the dish and the puff of potatoes that the scallops rested on. Just magical. 

My other raves were the waitstaff who were incredibly attentive, cycling through to take our finished plates, the covered patio with heat lamps, and the yummy chocolate cake with vanilla bean gelatto served with a spoon AND a fork. 

Don't be put off by he hostess who seems overstressed with an attitude, shes just the gatekeeper meant to ward off annoying tourists who you don't want at the table next to you anyway. Bon Appetite!
author: Melanie C.

description: This place is a gem! What a quaint and cozy establishment; it reminds me of a small town abode in Provence.  The service is impeccable (Taylor rocked our world!).  The shared plates are great to have on a date or with a group of friends...everyone enjoys having a little taste of everything!  We really enjoyed EVERYTHING we tried on the menu, but I highly recommend the Yellowtail Tuna, The Salmon Carpaccio, The Lobster Broth, & The Mascarpone with Strawberries! The vino verde is a perfect accompaniment. I plan to be back here as often as I can possibly afford it.
author: Brittany T.

description:
Highlights:
*yellowfin tuna
*seared scallops
*sea bass
*calamari
*truffle risotto 

Great service when requested.
author: around town e.

description: Great food. Ok service. Was with a big party and was able to sample a good portion of the dishes. The steak with wasabi sauce sounded intimidating but was outstanding. The  crab / avocado salad was also great. Didn't care for the elevated bar chairs for our group of 10 for a 3 hour meal but overall experience was good.
author: Cory L.

description:
My wife and I are inveterate zipcoders and seldom dine outside the Mission, and Isa is unlikely to change that.  We had a gift certificate courtesy of her parents, and that gave us the impetus to venture clear across the city for a pre-Valentine's dinner.

When we arrived, we were offered the table at the very front of the restaurant, which features side-by-side seating for two, which was nicely romantic, especially as the restaurant was sparsely occupied.  Our first concern was upon seeing the drinks list, which contained soju cocktails.  Not being a bar or restaurant owner, I don't know how hard or expensive it is to get a real liquor license, so I don't know if that's a factor in serving soju, and I imagine that it's more expensive to stock a full bar, but soju is not something I expect to see on the menu at an ostensibly nice restaurant.  Needless to say, we skipped the soju and started off with a couple glasses of bubbly.

Isa's novelty comes from the fact that it is a French restaurant in which the plates are served family-style.  In general, I'm not such a fan of shared plates, but the style works well when there are just two of us.  We started off with baked goat cheese and salmon tartare, both of which were quite good.  The salmon included egg, which was an unusual but not unpleasant taste sensation, and the goat cheese was served with pesto.  Both dishes were delicately flavored, with the goat cheese being more memorable.

With dinner, we opted for the rack of lamb and flatiron steak.  I believe the steak normally comes with roasted potatoes, but we opted to get it with broccoli with garlic and olive oil.  The broccoli and the lamb's accompanying dish, a mix of eggplant, red peppers, and olives in lamb jus, wound up stealing the show, since both were utterly delicious.  The lamb was rich and flavorful but perhaps a little too gamy, and the steak, while also tasty, arrived lukewarm and got cold too quickly as we tried every component of each dish.

We moved on to cheese and dessert, with the cheese being a substantial block of bleu, and the dessert being the semifreddo all' amaretto.  I would have preferred a milder cheese or perhaps a selection of two, since the sheer quantity of such a strong cheese was overwhelming.  It did set up a nice counterpoint to the sweetness of dessert, however.  The soju was a problem again at the end of the meal as I would have liked a glass of scotch or calvados, and even the dessert wines were fairly scant in selection.  We were not offered coffee or tea, which takes me to the service.

The restaurant was mostly uncrowded, with just a few other tables occupied at any point, and the service was appropriately attentive yet somehow distant.  Our waiter was polite but not gracious and seemed either to be unfamiliar with one of the wines we asked about or simply uninterested in providing details about it.  I can't complain, per se, but I was neither offended nor impressed, which is how most of the food made me feel as well.  I would probably not choose to go back of my own accord, but neither would I necessarily seek to dissuade others from going.
author: Bitter J.

description: Came here on a Monday night with three other girlfriends! Make sure you give yourself some time to find parking as parking is pretty hectic around the area! We made a reservation so we were seated promptly after arriving at Isa. The back patio is absolutely gorgeous! There is an option of sitting indoors or outdoors, but I felt that the indoor setting has a more romantic feel and the outdoor setting is good for gatherings. The ambience is awesome wherever you choose to get seated. I ordered the flat iron steak, which came with zucchini, polenta cake, moutarde verte and bordelaise sauce. I must say that the zucchini was DELICIOUS!..oh my goodness. Yeah, I am still dreaming about them. The steak had a very unique taste with the sauce, and it was very yummy as well. The servers were very attentive and friendly! Overall, I had a very pleasant experience and will be coming back.
author: J L.

description:
there were 5 of us.  the place and ambiance were ok and a bit random.  We were sitting in the extended room which was patio.  Was cold, but the heater was on and pretty warm. 

The waiter....he was so awesome, he explaint every detail about the food style, the setting and portion. The food comes in small quantity, and it's meant for sharing as well.  

Each of us ordered 2 dishes, I order the prex fix: started, main and dessert.
I ordered mussel and flat iron steak, the mussel was a big and the quantity is big for french restaurant.  The taste was unique with wine, tomatoes and onion.  The flat iron steak was ok since I do not like medium rare - I ordered medium. 
My husband ordered: grill calamari and lamb chop.  The calamari was fantantic with asian mix fusion taste. The portion is pretty big.  The lamb chop according to him was awesome and so tender.  I took a bit ( I do not like lamb) there is a after taste. 
1: lobster soup and seabass.  Soup was good, I can taste the seafood broth on it. Seabass a bit dry but tasty. 
2: asparagus soup and chicken.  Soup is unusual, my MIL loves it. It's so tasty but not too creamy.  Chicken is a bit dry but yummy 
3: Seared scallop and saffron Paella.  I have to say the scallop was perfectly cooked and prepared and mash potatoes was also incredible.  the saffron was a bit fishy. 
We have 4 dessert: flourless chocolate cake was the best. 
The bill come out $180 with tax not tips. 

Overall, all of us are so happy with the food and the price.
author: Naruto G.

description: I could kick myself for not going to this restaurant sooner.  I now know what I've been missing-a lot!  What a lovely restaurant, excellent food and attentive wait staff. With 2 other couples at our table, this allowed us to order at least 10 different dishes-all delighting our palates.  Happy hour lasts until 7pm each day which means you can order any soju drink or glass of wine for only $5-great deal!  As others have mentioned, the dungeness crab salad, foie gras, calamari and duck were the highlights of the evening.  Gotta go back...soon!
author: Al L.

description: Isa is always consistent.  Friendly service, reasonable prices, French ingredients but clearly an Asian approach.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Isa is a gorgeously romantic restaurant that exceeded all the wonderful things I had heard about it!

We were seated out on the charming patio swathed in a dark burgundy tent, and candles were twinkling everywhere we looked. Even though it was late October, heaters kept everyone comfortable so we  could shed out jackets promptly. 

The wine selection was fabulous, and we ordered the ceviche  which was amazing. The duck and fig plate was to die for, covered with an amazing sauce. Believe it or not, the real show stopper was the mushroom risotto! We all fought over the last few bites!

We finished our meal with the cheese plate and the flourless chocolate cake, washed down with a great Muscat. I won't soon forget our dinner here!
author: Kelly C.

description: This is a good place to go in the marina when you feel like having a nice meal with a group of friends.  Everything is quite good, but nothing is amazing. The prices are good for the type of food and they have some pretty good wine.
author: Jeff L.

description: GREAT restaurant! Delicious menu. Exciting seafood options! Must try in the Marina!
author: Rosheen A.

description:
Hate sharing . . . not the place for you then.  Isa comes alive when you can share everything on the menu, especially with friends as you need to be able to say, "I love that shrimp, can I have that last one?"  

Our server, John, was on the ball and was welcoming with his suggestions and playful personality.  We ate there with 6 people 2 who have eaten there before and 4 newbies (2, incl. me + 2 friends from NYC).  

The tuna tar tare appie had a little heat which was a nice surprise, the Kumamotos were sweet as expected, the shrimp were grilled to perfection, and the potatoe wrapped Sea Bass was moist on the inside and nice and crispy on the outside.  For desert, the creme 
brulee was standard and the torte had a nice hint of orange.  

All in all, excellent from both a food and service standpoint--I will definitely go back again.
author: Rick V.

description:
Service somewhat gruff.

Cheese & asparagus & salad: yummy.

Steak: excellent sauce but tough meat.

Wine: good list.
author: Des Esseintes I.

description:
On par with its Frenchy neighbor, 
Bistro Aix, down the street;
But a more upscale eatery,
boasting flavor magnifique.

Isa 
is the place
To get lucky 
with dates.
author: X E.

description:
If not for my most recent visit, this surely would have been a five-star review but the execution of some staple dishes, absolutely impeccable a few short months prior, was now somehow lacking.

The flat iron steak was just a bit overdone and a touch underseasoned, the foie gras conspicuously vanished from the day's menu, the lobster broth was a bit salty, and prices seemed to have increased by a few bucks.

If it sounds like I am splitting hairs, it is precisely because I am.  I still love Isa and it is near the top of a short list of fun, inexpensive, and delicious restaurants to visit with a small group of good friends.  Most of the dishes are very tasty and the portions are quite generous for the price, being somewhere between entree and appetizer portions in most restaurants (although closer to entree size).  The foie gras, tartare, and potato-crusted halibut are institutional dishes and the setting is very conducive to gregarious conversation.  I will surely be booking a table at Isa next time my friends and I want to have a fun dinner on a Friday night.
author: Yan G.

description:
I saw that Zagat gave Isa a food rating of 25.  After eating here myself, I'm kind of curious why.  Neither the food nor the menu were very inspiring.  Everything tasted pretty run of the mill for SF with no standouts.  The converted garden in the back with the tent was interesting as well.  When we first sat down, it was hot from the heat lamps, but those were turned off and later it became a bit drafty.  

We came b/c my friend saw somewhere that Mon-Thur there is a special deal of 2 plates for $21.95.  He must have read it wrong, b/c what they do have is a 2-course prix fixe for $24.95.  However, even that is misleading.  Most of the pairings you can do are the "lesser" items from the full menu, and when you choose, for example, the butterfish, you need to add $2, so effectively you *might* save 2 bux.  

What we had:

Crab salad - generous portion of crab, but the bed of avacado was something creative that didn't really work
Lobster bisque - watery
Butterfish - probably the best item, came wrapped in an interesting paper wrap which I'm not sure is edible, came bundled w/some enoki and other mushrooms
Rack of lamb - the Isa-style prep is to have them medium rare closer to rare.  Surprisingly not gamey, and fairly delicious
Scallops - these were really whatever
Foie Gras - is California outlawing it? The foie was excessively oily here

Service as a whole was pretty decent, the staff was pretty welcoming.  However, that just doesn't make up for the uninspiring food.  Nothing here would make me want to come back, especially not at the price point.
author: Jim W.

description:
I think the foir gras was great for their price... only $19 and the portion was good~~~ the scallop was very good as well~~~

But the seating is super pack~ If you are planning to take girls out as a romantic place.... this is not the place.. but it's definity a fun place to hang out with great food!
author: Devil c.

description:
We went here for dinner last night and it was spectacular. This was actually my 2nd visit but you have to sit out in the patio to really experience Isa- it's heated and super cute!

There were four of us so we each got a dish. The truffled risotto was to die for and the duck breast added to a perfect combo. 

I can't wait to have another good excuse to go!
author: Summer C.

description:
This past weekend we were in the city and had the pleasure of discovering Isa! As luck would have it there was space in the front of the restaurant to enjoy dinner. The restaurant is very small and intimate. The wait staff was so friendly and helpful. 
We ordered: 
Day Boat Scallops 
Risotto Truffle Sauce 
Brussels Sprouts 
Baked Goat Cheese 
Oysters on the 1/2 shell 
All were excellent. The wine was also an excellent find: Cali 351 2005 Cab. 
This place is worth the money the wait etc. I can't wait to dine here again.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
All in all it was a perfect evening. 
We called on a Saturday night and got a table for four just one hour later. The place was packed  and the audience ranged from twentysomethings to 80yrs+ connaisseurs - a great, cozy atmosphere. We got our table in the backyard and enjoyed sitting under a tent roof surrounded by dozens of fairy lights.
Service was A+. Fast, supportive, great tips as we asked for his recommendations, unobtrusive and the glasses were always filled. The wine, an excellent Syrah/Cab was just $28 - that's a bargain.
Then the food started, and it was incredible. The plates are rather small (definitely not too small) and "Isa" recommends two plates per person - sharing is strongly suggested. The prices per plate range from under $10 to a little above $20. We ordered lobster bouillabaisse, salmon carpaccio, yellowfin tuna, sauteéd wild prawns, duck breast with figs, truffle risotto, pan roasted chicken and grilled calamari. Oh boy, as soon as the food hit the table we all turned silent and our eyes turn heavenwards. Every single dish was outstanding. We enjoyed impeccable culinary skill. The truffle risotto with shitake mushrooms and tons of fresh parmesan had the most intense flavor one can imagine, the tuna and the salmon were uber-tender and the bouillabaisse had about 2 billion different choices of seafood. 
Everyone: Go there, book a table and enjoy excellent food.
Isa: Please keep everything as it is right now.
author: Felix H.

description:
Not what I expected!! I went in a small group of 5 for Mother's Day-this place definitely did not live up to the rating and I can't say that I will return. The corn soup was watery and had no flavor. The prawn soup in a lobster broth tasted and smelled both fishy and lacking in freshness. Appetizers were an improvement. The Yellowfin tuna and the goat cheese appetizer were delish! The oysters were pretty good as well. Other than that, nothing else was memorable including all dinner entrees. 
The killer was at the end dinner-although we ordered our meals at 6:15, at about 7:30 we were advised that the kitchen had completely run out of creme brulee for dessert. This could have been excused if at 8:00 we hadn't walked by and seen them still being fired for other guests in the back kitchen. When the manager was asked about this, she simply apologized and offered to have it on my next visit!! No thank you-I will not be coming back!
author: Maria B.

description:
I am by no means a "French Cuisine" expert, but I can say this was one of the best meals I've had in a long time. The service was very friendly and the menu had something for everyone. Some highlights for me include the risotto and the scallops (maybe the best I've ever had in my life).

I don't come to SF too many times each year, but I will definitely make it a point to come back to Isa!
author: John S.

description: An unexpected pleasure arriving at this buzzing restaurant - having been unceremoniously rejected by Parma next door, our party of 9 had a fantastic selection of plates, originally prepared, served attractively. Everyone in our party from the oldies to the teenagers, had a meal which they loved. Beef ribs and sea bass par excellence. Friendly service, an attentive waiter, sublime cocktails and a reasonable cost.  I'd recommend this place anytime.
author: D. A. E.

description:
the mussels, bread and prices are far better at delarosa!

ps- no sierra nevada here either. wtf?
author: MJ R.

description: Have been loving their food and been here a couple times. Although there's once they really disappointed me (the staff missed my order and we ended up waiting forever for the second course after we finished the first course) but they apologized and compensated my waiting with a free dessert.
author: Caryn W.

description: Truffle Risotto enough said.  Yum.  Really enjoyed our meal.  Lots of small plates to share that everyone loved.  Flat Iron Steak, Short Ribs, and the duck were amazing too.
author: B M.

description:
I wasn't there on a date, but the place was so romantic. Our waiter was the sweetest guy and super cute too! The chicken and steak were delicious, and we even got a free dessert to toast to new beginnings. It is by far my favorite restaurant in the Marina. And this is coming from a boy who eats a lot.

~A
author: Alex C.

description: One of my favorite restuarants in the city! Make sure you request the back patio and do not pass on the butterfish!
author: john b.

description:
Okay, there was good and there was not so great... I loved the foie gras. I had a plate just for myself! The seabass came out way overcooked, the sweetbread entree was meh, the scallops were were really good as well as the sauce, mash and corn it was sitting on. The calamari was excellent! They do not fry their calamari like the usual, which made it much more interesting and delicious!!! The skirt steak was so so... and the service was excellent. Although, I don't understand why they recommend two dishes per person. I went with group of 8 and each of us ordered 2 dishes, one small and one large. I was going to order one foie gras to share with a friend and since the waiter recommended 2 apps, we decided to order 2 foie gras. Their foie gras is the best thing I've tried there, but even for this, I've had better. But we could barely even touch our last dish, the sweetbreads. The dish was okay, nothing to write home about... 

Overall, a great place to hang out and have dinner with friends. The ambiance is excellent, very energetic and intimate at the same time. I would definitely come back here.
author: Bernice C.

description: "I'm sorry, I've no excuse" said the hostess, when at 8:40 we were still waiting to be sat for an 8pm reservation, having been repeatedly told it would be just 5 more minutes. My gut reaction was to head elsewhere or return to the much better wine bar (Nectar) next door, but we decided to give them a chance to put things right. A complimentary glass of red for the ludicrous wait (I saw another couple give up waiting and leave) was a good start. But we were sat 6 inches from the next table on one side, and barely a foot on the other. It felt cramped, the waiter was lackluster, the wine average, and the food - the whole reason we went - that only started arriving at 9:15, was largely bland and forgettable except for the potato wrapped sole. The only bright spot was the colorfully entertaining train wreck of a conversation happening next to us! Seriously, not worth the wait or the money.
author: Gavin B.

description: I came here for dinner with some friends and it was DELISH! They do have the best foie gras in town. We ordered a bunch of dishes family style. The lamb was amazing, very tasty! I definitely recommend trying a few appetizers here. Other dishes I thought were really good was the scallop dish, the duck breast, and the truffle risotto. We got a table in the back patio which is super cute, nice romantic and fun spot. I definitely would come back here again. Love it!
author: Susan L.

description:
My boyfriend and I were one of the many sappy couples who dined on Isa's expensive prix-fix for Valentine's day, but it was an absolutely phenomenal meal. Everything we chose was divine- it was clear this was not a place where you had to "order right" in order to enjoy your meal. Every course and every morsel was a hit. 

Our favorite was the flat iron steak that came at the end. It had a lot to prove considering it was paired with a green peppercorn glaze (since our favorite steak from Chez Maman also comes with a delicious green peppercorn sauce) but it was probably the best cooked, most delicious piece of steak I've ever hard. We'll definitely be back.
author: Allison S.

description:
Excellent food, very nicely priced for its calibre. Everything we had was delicious, and as a side bonus, our server had studied culinary chemistry - rawk on!

Heh heh... though this really didn't impact our meal, one thing that made the evening that much more fun was having arrived in a co-worker's hilariously behemothic monster truck. Yee haw - lookit them lil' Marinaites scurry out of the way!
author: Beverage Appreciato R.

description:
Isa's a great restaurant for any type of occasion.  I recommended my co-worker go there with his parents last week and he loved it.  I also just went last night with 3 of my girlfriends for dinner and they loved it.

Definitely try the goat cheese, it may look plain when it comes out but it is delicious! Especially with the warm toasted bread they kept replenishing for us. We loved everything we tried...the steak, the duck, the sea bass, calamari/shrimp dish and tuna tartare.  We had 7 dishes split between 4 of us and it was the perfect amount.

The only thing I was mediocre on was the scallops (not as exciting as the other entrees) and the desserts were just ok.  I will definitely go back again and will continue to recommend it to others!
author: Marcie L.

description:
French tapas . . .NICE!!! 
I'm no marina girl but this place - i'll be there. no hesitation. 
Spicy Tuna tartare - like butter.
Truffled Risotto - outstanding
but my heart belongs to 
Seared Fois Gras - Unbelieveable.  
So Money, So Yummy, So DAMN!
luv it.
author: M E.

description:
UPDATE: 
Isa saved us last weekend. Saturday night of fleet week, party of 8 with no reservation (who does that!?!?) Isa managed to somehow shift around to squeeze us in and provided great service..during prime dining hours on one of the busiest days of the year in the Marina. Amazing....

Great food, and an awesome atmoshpere on the back patio. We ordered 6 dishes between the three of us and they were all amazing. This would be a fantastic date spot!!!
author: Jess T.

description:
Eh.

The truffled risotto was nice, as was the beef, but overall, I have to give Isa an "Eh."

The small plate french seafood thing is novel, but really just a way to charge through the teeth for minuscule portions of mediocre food.  Service was unremarkable, which I guess is good.  I will say that we had a table of 7, and the service and food format made for easy sharing and a generally pleasant experience, which is hard to do with a table full of winos like us.  

I'm giving a begrudging 3 stars because I can't give 2.5.
author: matt h.

description:
While Isa may not be the best spot for a quiet, intimate dinner, it's a great place if you're looking for a more lively setting. (It'd be a great first date place, since the din in the dining area will fill in any empty spots in your conversation!)

We ordered the butterfish and the dayboat scallops (we were looking for a light meal). I thought it was a little strange that the other tables around us had gotten three or four orders before we got one order on our table, but we were pleased with our orders once we received them. The butterfish was light and melted in our mouths, and the scallops were perfect, with a firm texture and excellent seasoning. We topped it off with flourless chocolate cake and gelato, which definitely pleased the palate. It was light while still satisfying the sweet tooth.

All in all, a good dining experience, except for the food delay. Otherwise, service was professional if not personal.
author: C D.

description:
Interesting place...my buddy had a craving for prosciutto wrapped melon after reading a review mentioning it, but alas that was not to happen this time of year.  Hm actually that's on the menu on their website, so keep in mind that's not up to date.

The prix fixe menu seems like a great deal, but I stopped considering that once I saw the words "foie gras," so to the picking and choosing menu I went.  The foie was really just OK - overcooked, mostly.  Asparagus soup didn't thrill me, either - flavor and texture were a little thin. Flank steak was probably the best of the dishes we got.  And whatever our other guest had was completely unmemorable to me, or maybe it was the wine...

To me, the wine list is all over the place - Napa to Sonoma, over to Italy, back to Spain, and let's drop by France while we're nearby.  This is good and bad, in my opinion...the regional variety is nice, but personally I'd prefer a little more concentration.  The variety was just distracting.

My standards might be a little higher, but I wouldn't take a date here.  Friends, yes, but this place is not reading on the romantic scale.  Nice vibe in the garden.  The wait staff was attentive although a little stiff.

Will probably have to visit again to firm up my thoughts.
author: John K.

description:
This place is simply a gem.  There's an absolutely adorable faux-outdoor patio out back, complete with twinkling white lights.  The prix fixe menu during the week is a deal.  

My friend and I tried the truffled spaghetti(omg, don't miss this one!), the heirloom tomatoes(standard, but delicious just the same), the butterfish(yum), the butter lettuce and endive salad(so simple, yet they managed to sneak some extra deliciousness in there for us), and the scallops(holy shit you gotta try these!).

AND we washed it all down with a lovely bottle of pinot.  All of that for $70 a head including a great tip. Yeeeeeaaaaaahhhhh!
author: Shauna H.

description: I just need to say it again.  Isa is awesome.  Friendly service, a nice atmosphere, stellar food - possibly the best restaurant in Cow Hollow.
author: Bette K.

description:
My family and I had a great time tasting all the different dishes here.

We had crab salad, goat cheese, foie gras among others. All the food are well-prepared and each dish distinguishes itself differently.
author: Benedict C.

description:
this place is 100% allergy friendly for those who have wheat/gluten allergies.  Risotto and scallops were amazing....great martinis as well
GO FOR DINNER
author: alma h.

description: I am updating my review, because after the last review I wrote, I was contacted by the restaurant, because the price was a mistake. They are refunding the excess charges. I am so appreciative of their wonderful customer service and I think it speaks a lot about their business.
author: Nikki K.

description: This is not a traditional french restaurant. The food was good, but not great. The dungeness crab salad was very refreshing after a long day's work. The salmon carpaccio was pounded too thinly that it was overwhelmed by the capers. The halibut was overpowered by the sauce. I think it can be balanced out with something else on the side because the beets sure didn't help. Overall, I wanted to walk across the street to Izzy's and dive into the comforts of steak. But I stuck through this meal and left with an OK experience.
author: Wendy L.

description: It's really an 3.5 stars, but I guess the complimentary drinks made up for the other half. came here on a Thursday night with my cousin and brother for dinner. Our reservation was at 9pm and we arrived on time. didn't get seated until 9:30pm which didn't really bother me much since I had great companies plus complimentary drinks. Their menu is very limited and there wasn't much we could really choose from. Overall it was an decent dinner.
author: Connie T.

description: Been here in the past and loved it.  We would go here for special occasions.  However most recent experience was that our two fish dishes were floating in a bed of oil. Should have sent it back-my mistake but does not make for a great dining experience to have to send two dishes back.  Lots of great places to go in SF so will be trying other places.
author: L R.

description:
j'y suis allee uen fois, je ne me souviens plus tres bien si c'etait bon.
A re-tester.
author: armelle p.

description:
One word: Scallops, foie gras, mussels, crab salad, tuna salad, lamb, chicken, creme brulee, chocolate cake with ice cream. Ok, maybe not one word but all worth mentioning. In a nutshell, everything I ate- and I did eat all that- was outstanding. And no, I'm not a fatty, I just appreciate good food. If I had to pick only one item, it would have to be THE scallops. They were truly exceptional. 

Trust me, I was skeptical about how "great" this place was but it did not disappoint. The wine, too, was spectacular... We had the Alexander Valley Stuhlmuller cab (which was $59 on the menu but later found it at a local store for $36 - talk about a profit!).

The server was uber sweet and knowledgeable. Very pleasant; I liked him. The place itself was nice but nothing out of this world. We sat in the back faux-outside area which was kind of romantic. If i'd only been there with my significant other and not my boss and colleague.

Anyway, all in all a great experience. So good that we didn't even mind one bit when the lights went out and we had to eat in candlelight for 30 minutes. They ended up 'comping' us the desserts. Nice touch Isa.
author: Picky Nibblers G.

description:
Don't bother - go next door to Bistro Aix instead. 

Went to Isa with a group on Friday night and was super disappointed overall.  We're told to each order 2 things, and best if several people order the same thing, and please take a pen and pass the menu around and mark the number of each item we want to order.  Also told that things will be served to perfection, but when they're ready, so it's "forced family style". Excuse me? WTF? You're telling your customers how to order and how to eat to accommodate your kitchen?  That doesn't sound like a restaurant, that sounds like the soup nazi (but way less cool).

The waiter was super-enthusiastic in that insincere and unhelpful way.  Ask about the foie gras - "it's amazing", what about the paella? "amazing, everything is amazing from our 'french' chef."  To be fair, the food was not bad.  But not amazing. Come time for the group bill and, umm, we're told that we have to put it on no more than two cards.  Excuse me? Eventually he agreed to run several cards, but let's be honest - why do you want to be a pain in the ass to your customers?

SF has too many great restaurants for anyone to waste time here.  Move on - you'll be doing yourself a favor.
author: Ryan D.

description: This was my first experience with a prix fixe menu, and I was not disappointed.  Service was attentive, food was fabulous, and we were on the covered patio which was very romantica and cozy for date night.  Bring someone special.  Casual dress okay, but I felt good about my LBD and done-up-ness.
author: Emily F.

description: Dine About Town was awesome! My date and I thoroughly enjoyed our meals and they were very accommodating considering we were 40 minutes late for our reservation. The free glass of wine was a garnache and that was very enjoyable. For the food, we got the crab salad and the salmon carpaccio as our appetizers. For our entrees we ordered the duck and the seared scallops, and foie gras. The desserts we had were the creme brulee and the semifreddo. Everything was absolutely delicious but the stand-outs were the salmon carpaccio, scallops (truffle!!!), and foie gras. Dip the scallops in that truffle sauce and you will immediately have a foodgasm. The foie gras was really different from what i've had before, seared beautifully and it just melts in your mouth. It came with a grilled brioche toast, which gave it a very different and slightly crunchy texture. Personally I preferred to eat them separately, but it's a very unique combination. All in all it was a very delicious meal and I am sad that they are banning foie gras =[ but i cannot wait to go back and try their regular menu.
author: Grace C.

description:
Intimate setting and good service.  Back room is fun for bigger parties.  Everything done well.

They don't accept AMEX, hence i'm more reluctant to take clients there.
author: Jacob J.

description:
I'm super allergic to seafood. Super.  But when I caught a glimpse of my baby's scallops all caramelized and saucy, bathed in what seemed to be crushed black truffles, I just had to steal a bite.

Then I went into anaphylactic shock and died.  And it was worth it.  

Then they splashed some nettle soup in my face and I was shocked back to life with a nice departure from regular restaurant soups ... cream of this ... puree of that ... b-b-b-b-boring.  The nettle was subtle and unique and tasty.  

Oh man and then the steak. I had already died once but I could have died again. It was GOOD.  Like my baby said, it was the best well done steak she's ever had (snide but true).  Hecka butter or somethin all up on it.  

Our waiter was also courteous and expedient.  No complaints.

I would have given five stars but the front room was full of big dorks that were all staring at my beautiful girlfriend and if we weren't on a date I would have flat-lined all over them.
author: Jerkey J.

description:
When in doubt this is always my fall back place to go when on a date or wanting to impress out of towners with good food!  The scallops and seabass in parchment are by far my favorites.  I know I know I am not supposed to order sea bass because it is getting overfished etc.  but why would God make it taste so good if it is not meant to be eaten I ask?  Ponder that thought....

Aside from that the wine selection is good.  I usually roll in with a few bottles and sacrifice myself to the corkage fee gods, but way cheaper than doing bottles there.  Overall a must if you are looking for good spot to impress friends or loved ones in the marina.
author: Greg P.

description:
The food here is amazing and the service is quite good.  But you should make reservations if you want to sit in the backroom otherwise you will be sitting the relatively small front dining area.

I agree this is not a place for big groups but a party of four less would be ideal.  Not too crazy about the cocktails but that's just an afterthought in this case.

Definitely try the hamachi, paella, and the skirt steak.  Next time I want to try the dayboat scallops the sweetbreads.
author: Rene M.

description:
A pick from Bf among so many good restaurants in marina district and I was completely amazed by the great food it offered.

We were seated at the back/ patio with great atmosphere.  Our waiter was the only one with smiles in his team.  But service was actually very prompt and our food came fast.  We ordered the crab salad, asparagus soup, baked Butterfish in paper, truffle oil spaghetti for sharing. 

The asparagus soup was light and refreshing, thanks to the unknown herbs used.  Crab salad tasted fresh and the truffle spaghetti was light but with truffle oil fragrant.  Bf isn't a big fan for fish but he liked the butterfish with oyster and shitake mushroom.   These dishes built our confidence to try their dessert.  We did not pick the vanilla bean types as recommended but the semifreddo amaretto  It soon was included in our must-go-back dessert list.  Full of almond flavor and the ice cream was not too sweet but tasted wonderful.

Also they seemed to have a good selection of wine and almost every table got wine to accompany their dish

It should've been a 5-star choice.  But I was a little disappointed by tight seating space.  Tables were cramped and space was made to maximizing seating. Also the hostess was cold and not even attempted to accommodate any request or spare a smile.

We may not bring friends here if we want to enjoy private conversation.  But we may go back if we just would like to try their food and dessert again.
author: Ile F.

description:
I am a new yelper, so I don't feel like I can just throw out 5 stars but everything I ate was excellent.

My boyfriend wanted to check out Isa for his birthday (see Adam b. review with 5 stars). The "Asian fusion" category has me slightly stumped but loved all the small plates. Parking could have been a nightmare but we lucked out with a meter on the first go around. I suggest cabbing it...

We had late dinner reservations on a Tuesday and it didn't appear crowded walking into the front room where it was quiet with a dark, cozy ambience. We asked for seats in the back patio, where the loudness startled me at first. Once my ears adjusted and I could hear the waiter - I started to really dig the warm glow from strands of lights scattered about walls and the heat lamps throughout the covered patio.

The waiter arrived promptly and was very knowledgeable. We got our sparkling water right away...but then just sort of waited.  I started getting antsy and looking around. Bread arrived with soft butter. Can I just say how much I love soft butter that I can spread? [Still waiting]...the boyfriend said it was a cohesive team waiting on us, but I found it odd that the busboy was taking my order because I was making a "where the hell is my wine?" face. I used to work at a restaurant myself, so I understand being "in the weeds" but after what seemed like forever, I was surprised when we were still waiting on our bordeaux blanc.  Another waiter finally came over, brought it to us (aah refreshing) and magically our food started to crank out.

The plates were timed perfectly. The BEST ceviche I have ever had. They use a sweet fish that had me scraping the plate with bread to scoop up every last morsel. The dungeness crab cake was creamy and not overpowered by the avocado. We each had an oyster (didn't blow me away but I like the dipping sauce) followed by the corn and potato soup for two. I am a die-hard sushi fan so was skeptical to try cooked butterfish but it was AMAZING - steamed just right, similar to a nicely done sea bass, with of course, a rich butter flavor. But the um, scorched (parchment??) paper was a bit sore on the eyes for presentation.  The scallops were done nicely as well and we rounded out the night with dessert.  

Since there was a little confusion about who our waiter was, I ran into the first waiter, asking him to surprise the boyfriend with a candle in their best dessert. I sat back down, and the second waiter asked if we wanted dessert. My boyfriend ordered the amaretto semi-freddo and I just prayed to two waiters would realize what was going on. A few minutes later, waiter #1 showed up with a fabulous flourless cake and vanilla bean gelato and a candle, the other waiter followed up with the semi-freddo. The eisewine was complimentary for his birthday and delicate and fruity and YUMMY.

So I love dining out and I hate waiting for my food and especially my for drink. It wasn't the waiter's fault, it was busy (still surprised for a Tuesday?) - I just wish I knew that it was a team style service so I could have anticipated multi-waiters and not ordered two desserts. So 4 stars as the food was FANTASTIC, I just don't like to wait. But would definitely recommend - especially to a couple as the lighting was quite romantic :)
author: Amanda B.

description: I am in love with your 'wet' foie gras. Forget the pate, this is richness and yumminess on steroids. I've never had a non-pate FG, and I would come back for this.   Yumm... The special short ribs was yummy, the bread it comes with is delicious, I was so happy and stuffed at end of evening.
author: Giggly C.

description:
A friend of mine recommended this restaurant to me so for my husband's birthday I decided we will give it a try there. Indeed the food is as good as it gets! I shall say though their dessert are their weak points...
