Since we went on Monday, we decided to have the prix fix menu which is $29 per person and is only available Monday through Thursday. We ordered salmon Carpaccio and grilled calamari as our first courses. Both of them are delicious and we are so satisfied after each dish. 

For our 2nd courses, we first had the flat iron steak--it came with roasted zucchini and polenta cake. All of them are so well prepared that we love this dish. The zucchini is tender while very juicy. By the end of this dish, we were almost full even though none of the dish look a lot.  The our second order: the TRUFFLE RISOTTO came. It was the best risotto that I have ever had! It was very creamy and full of mushroom flavor that we could not stop eating it!! 

After these dishes, we ordered our dessert. But like I said, their dessert is their weak point. There were not too many options so we ordered Bucherondin De Chèvre and Grapefruit granite. The honey and walnut that came with the goat cheese is very good but both of us are not big fan of goat cheese--it is probably our mistake to order this one. The grapefruit granite is just regular shredded ice with grapefruit flavor. Given that both of us had a cold that night, we did not enjoy it too much. 

Overall, even though I am disappointed by their dessert (but I have not had a very satisfactory experience with any dessert in the restaurants in the city!) I am still giving them a five star as their food are indeed well made and the price came very sweet at $65 total (we also ordered a hot tea). 

We will definitely come back for their truffle risotto!
author: Jasmine C.

description: There's a really nice french waiter who upsold us on more entrees than we really needed. He was so polite that you couldn't say no but I'm glad he did. We got to try more dishes than we otherwise wouldn't. The potato wrapped sea bass wasn't on the menu but was the most delicious of all that we ordered.
author: Vien T.

description:
When I read on the menu that "two plates are suggested" I immediately thought of a VERY bad dining experience I had at this upscale restaurant in Las Vegas where we left hella hungry. 
That said, I was pleasantly pleased with the choices I made and it was actually fun trying everyone else's dishes along with mine. (but now that I look back on it, half the people I was sharing food with were sick. oh no).  
Anyways, I ordered the veal sweetbread and I really liked it. I still dont understand what this sweetbread is... but it came with pieces of veal mixed with lots of delicious mushrooms, mashed potatoes, and a hashbrown on top. The veal was really tender and I really felt like it melted in my mouth mmmmmm. (i love baby cow) Also I got this scallop dish served with asparagus which was quite tasty as well. The scallops had a lot of flavor, not bland like I'm used to them being.  I would recommend both of these dishes! 
I also really liked the flat iron steak (surprisingly juicy and well marinated) and this halibut special (cooked so it was half raw in the middle - yum!). My friend ordered the bouillabaisse and she seemed to like it ,but i'm not really a fan. I was not pleased with the duck breast though... it was too sweet with what it was served with (red cabbage and some other strange berry?) 
Anyways, the waiter forgot to put one of our orders in so he gave us free desserts and I was VERY pleased. Creme brulee, this grapefruit icy thing, and a hot brownie thing with vanilla ice cream. all of them were REALLY GOOD. 
Before 7 they have happy hour so their soju cocktails are $5 and glasses of wines are $5 as well. We ordered a bottle of sparkling wine for $25. The mojito cocktails my friends got were not very strong... so I did not approve =) 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was kinda cool - very dimly lit and intimate. They had another room that seemed to be brighter but I didn't get over there. It seems liek a good place to have both an intimate dinner as well as a place for larger groups (i went with a group of 8 people).
author: Tim B.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I had a very enjoyable and delicious meal at Isa.  But I must take off 1 star for the lack of liquor.   If I'm going out to a nice meal I must start it off with a martini... a REAL martini, not the fake soju crap they try to pawn on you.  Another star off for the lack of dessert options.  The only thing on the menu that interested me was the flourless chocolate cake which I've already had and it did not impress.

Okay..now on to the actual meal.   The foi gras is incredible and is a must have at Isa.  The tuna tartar dish that they have is also very good, but definitely not the best I've had.  The goat cheese made my fiance very happy.  He LOVES goat cheese and this really hit the spot.  I thought it was decent, but I always prefer a bleu cheese or a brie.  

We then split the duck breast with huckleberry sauce that was awesome!! Cooked perfectly and the huckleberry was amazing.  It was served with  a side of beet and goat cheese salad.  Unfortunately, neither of us are beet fans so we just picked at it. 

We also split the steak which was cooked a perfect medium rare.  Served with very crispy scalloped potatoes that were awesome.  Basically, there are better french restaurants out there, but for the price Isa is pretty awesome.

Also, we sat out on the back porch instead of inside this time.  Much better for carrying on a conversation and not feeling crowded.  However, it was really cold outside and the heat lamps just weren't cutting it for me.  I was slightly chilly throughout the entire meal.  (full disclosure: I'm one of those annoying girls that is ALWAYS cold). 

I'd come back if other people suggested Isa.  However, there are other French places in SF I need to try before coming back again.
author: Katie S.

description: Love Isa!! Sometimes I dream about their scallops... definitely MUST order!! I have been here twice now and the service has been impeccable. Great wines, small(er) plates that are still wonderfully delicious, and a romantic atmosphere - can't get much better for a date night!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Went here for a dinner. The food was extremely underwhelming.  The whole small plates concept is lost on them.  You can't simply chop up a tomato, throw some olive oil and cheese on top and charge $15 and call it a small plate.  Same goes for throwing pasta in a dish.  The only two dishes of any substance whatsoever were the risotto and prawns, steak was OK but nothing special.  How, at the end of the day could this place cost $60 per person with 1 cocktail each?

This is without a doubt the worst valued meal I have ever had.  The food was edible, but I'm not going to pay $60 for cafeteria food.  The complete attitude of the wait-staff and sad attempt at hipness does not win any stars either.  Accordingly...1 star.

Then again, if you're trying to seem cool and have more money than taste...this is the place for you.
author: James L.

description: Amazing food, great unpretentious ambiance.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Fidela B.

description:
Let me start off by sayin I was still bitter from last year's fiasco with my birthday dinner party at Limon (I'm glad their closed, I had no intention of ever going back) and I was worried what this experience would be.  

But there was nothing to be fearful of!  The restaurant has a very nice dimly lit ambiance and the backroom, which seems to be like the backyard patio area, was more open and had heaters.  I had planned out the menu with Kitty (coordinator at Isa) and we had agreed on how ever many plates to choose for my group of 10.  She was very attentive and accomodating in our emails back and forth as well as when we arrived.  Thank you Kitty!  

Also keep in mind that they suggest a family style type serving which I think worked out really good for our group.  Everyone got to try the food and hint: sitting in the middle is awesome since you don't have to share as much haha.  Each dish supposedly serves 3-4 people.  And for the amount of food we had, the price was fair.  You get what you pay for, and in this case, a little higher price gets you a great meal.

Onto the food, which I'm still picturing vividly in my head:
-Crab salad - MUST GET.  it may look simple, but crab meat is bountiful and its definitely a good starter
-Mussels - If you like mussels, this is a go getter as the sauce is also really good with the bread.
-Foie Gras - I was hesitant on getting too much of this, but it appears everyone enjoyed it with its tenderness and flavor.  Hudson Valley Foie gras, you are too good.  and Isa, great job on putting it with the poached pear sauce.  
-Scallop with Asparagus - Scallops were huge and moist.  the mashed mashed potatoes (yes its double mash because it was almost as if it was pureed) was nice and light
-Bouiillebaise - It was almost like a repeat of the mussels, but it had clam, fish, and squid...but I think the mussels were better
-Flat Iron Steak - tender with a nice creamy wasabi sauce
-Truffle risotto - nice and creamy with plenty of truffle flavor, helps get you full too.  hah
-Chocolate Cake with Vanilla Gelato - great great great
-Grapefruit Granite - It was ok, but at least it was something lighter
-Vanilla Creme Brulee - pretty tasty, but sort of heavy
-Ameretto - although this was the most hesitant one, it turned out to be really good.

And there you have it, the maginificant meal we had for my birthday.  Awesome stuff they got here.
author: Vincent K.

description: Came here on a Tuesday night with a friend and I thought we would have a quiet dinner since it was on a weekday. To my surprise, it got really busy within several minutes of sitting down. II never had foie gras before so I had the pleasure of trying it here with strawberries and rhubarb with biroche. I thought the strawberry paired with it was very interesting, but the thought of eating goose liver stopped me from enjoying it fully. So my friend ended up eating the rest. We then proceeded to the mussels and I was disappointed in the flavor of the mussels. It tasted like it was boiled with no taste at all. Our entrees were truffle risotto and scallops with orzo. Loved the scallops and the fresh vegetables in the dish. The truffle risotto was very overpowering. Way too much cheese. The flourless cake was a great dessert. However, the ambiance and setting of the restaurant is very causal romantic. Lit candles with a white tent for the back patio and heated lamps. I would definitely come back and try something else.
author: Aileen F.

description:
I didn't get this place at all.

First of all, the food is pretty good but this is NOT a french restaurant. A lot of the ingredients or preparations on the menu are things you'd never see in a French restaurant. It all became more clear when I saw that there were no French people running the place. 

WIth this said, the strangest part of the night was the service. Our waiter first talked to us for like 5 minutes. He explained this was family style. I looked around and saw the plates were huge. For 2 people, all you need is 2 plates. We didn't want to do family style but they would not bring all the food at once.  My girlfriend is vegetarian and received her plate 15 minutes before I got my meat, this ruined the meal. 

Also we picked this place because of the patio but, even if it was a hot night, the roof was put on and the feel of it was meh...

2 stars because the food was good.
author: Remi G.

description:
Hits: Foie Gras (_incredible_), Potato-wrapped Sea-bass, interesting and delicious wines, with wait staff that can recommend them

Misses: The hostess, Mushroom risotto (OK, but nothing special)

I thought the food of our dinner here was great, though not impeccable, with some definite strong points and weak points. (Nothing like Farallon or Masa's, which are much more consistent and impressive.) But, that's somewhat what you would expect with small plates, though these are some expensive small plates. The wine our waiter recommened, however, was one of the best matches I've had in some time, so kudos to him for that.

However, our experience was dampened by one of the rudest hostesses that I've seen in a long time. I made a reservation for the patio, and I mentioned this to her as she was seating my girlfriend and I. But then she seated us inside, and I asked again about the patio seating and mentioned that it was in my reservation, and she just kind of shook her head and gave me a dismissive look. Then, I saw her minutes later seat a number of parties in the patio. I saw other patrons who were getting upset with her during the course of the evening as well. 

That situation definitely put the evening off to a bad start, but the food was able to recover things a fair amount. Still, I don't think I would go back anytime soon, at the price/quality/service combination.
author: Kevin G.

description:
wonderful, romantic restaurant that has a great menu....and even better service.  seating can be a bit cramped, but that's ok if you like to ease drop on your neighbors conversations?
I will return next time I am in SF.
author: Heather J.

description:
ISA is not sooooo good. 

I'm not one of those dudes that needs a lot of love and attention at a restaurant. Give my food and the check in a reasonable amount of time, and have a few opinions about the food, and I'm happy. But the service last night at ISA was horrible.

My folks and I had a reservation for 9:00 p.m. We got there at 9:00 p.m., and the hostess said it would be five minutes. We waited 45 minutes, with perhaps one half-assed apology after 40 minutes. (And when you're waiting at ISA, there's virtually nowhere to stand where you're not in the way, and the bar area has all of four or five seats total.)

When we sat down, in a cool, chill way, I explained to the waiter that we had waited 45 minutes and that my folks had to stand the whole time, etc. The waiter, to this credit, was sympathetic, but that was it. I ordered a calamari to eat while we looked at the menu. Instead, a persimmon salad arrived. I sent it  back, explaining we didn't order it. The busboy looked confused, but he took the salad and returned to the kitchen. Then, the waiter arrived and explained that the kitchen had sent this out as a token of their thanks for our waiting.

One little salad that no one would have ordered anyway? And the waiter couldn't explain that himself when they brought it out?

Okay, so we ordered. Then, the waiter said that since that persimmon salad didn't work out, he would us comp a beer. One beer, like five bucks. Whatever. We ordered. The food was good, particularly the calamari. But the portions are small. We're talking 6 scallops on an entree plate. 

When the check came, they had put the persimmon salad on the bill. 

I could go on, but I think you're getting where I'm going with this.
author: Chris H.

description:
I've been to Isa just once.  It was exactly what we were looking for - great ambiance, shared plates and friendly service.  Our server was one of the happiest people I've ever encountered.  I heard someone at the table over tell him he wanted to squeeze him he was so nice.  Ahem. 

The food was mostly good but apparently the calamari wasn't great.  I don't eat seafood so I can't say more than that about it, but overall we were satisfied with what we ordered.   The chocolate cake was especially yummy.

I would go back again, even though its in the marina.
author: Miss M G.

description:
so i didn't love the "faux outdoor patio" because it was more faux than outdoor... But the food... and the service.... outstanding!  8 plates for 4 people was perfect, and since it was our first time there we had our waiter guide us to the most popular dishes.... all mentioned here... butterfish, scallops - wow.  We ordered the Flat iron steak twice - once it came medium, next on the rarer side of medium rare - still good though just not butterfish outstanding.

A great place to try 6 to 8 delicious dishes if you go with a couple of friends... you won't be disappointed.  And really great service... from waiter to busman to the bar keeper when we first walked in.
author: Rob R.

description:
The place is packed just right, to provide a warm and welcoming ambiance while receiving high quality service time.  The courtyard area provides a cozy surrounding, and the crowd is sophiscated.

The menu is exquisite and exciting.  Everything we tried was worth it.
author: Stacey F.

description:
I was lucky enough to visit Isa with about six people who were in the mood for food.  We ordered twelve dishes plus  appetizers and dessert, which seemed about right (yes, it does get expensive really fast...small plates are always deceiving).

EVERYTHING I had was melt in your mouth incredible.  I have never had scallops I liked...until Isa.  They were incredible.  So tender, dressed beautifully.  We had every meat imaginable, and all of it was perfectly (I mean it) prepared.  They let us sit there out back in the incredible ambiance for hours and enjoy all the amazing flavors.  I was in heaven.  

I also had some tasty sake cocktails.

I recommend: foie gras, scallops, flat iron steak, chocolate cake...actually, let's just say EVERYTHING.

I can't wait to go back.  Be prepared to spend because you should try everything.  I think it's worth it to eat cheap for a few weeks and then go crazy at Isa.  Absolutely heavenly.  I can say no more.  I'm all raved out.
author: Eliza L.

description:
Isa seems to have gotten better with age. The meal we had yesterday was close to perfect and the prices are very reasonable. Service was good too on a very busy night.

We had the tuna, goat cheese and butter lettuce salad as appetizers (3 different ones). All very tasty. Salad could have used a bit more dressing but that's my only quibble

I had the flatiron steak and tried some of my friends' risotto and lamb. All yummy

Dessert was the flourless chocolate cake - very well made.

Chef here knows what he's doing. Kudos. And keep it up!
author: Jay K.

description:
Parking is quite the task here and you'll have your panties in a bunch before you even step foot in this restaurant. Hopefully, you'll feel better once you enter because the ambiance in this restaurant is excellent; it's very cozy and intimate. 

Came here on a Friday evening so we didn't get to eat from their fixed price menu. They recommend 2 plates per person and everything is meant to be shared "family style" but don't expect Buca di Beppo portions. Each plate is perfect for sharing between 4-5 people and everyone gets a piece or so. Not entirely sure on how I feel about the prices. They seemed high for some of the items and portions that my group decided to order but they don't call it French for nothing. They screw you when you're in their country and still screw you when you're in your own. Lose-lose.

 Their "larger" (small) plates were about $18-$25 each while their "smaller plates" (even smaller) plates were about $10-$15. The bread may have been the winner here, as was the halibut. Everything else (scallops, salmon tartare, and shrimp especially) was just run of the mill average but the service was very good. 

5 girls eating, filled mostly on bread and having ordered no alcohol, had a bill that was about $165 with tip.

Edited:  I'm bringing down the star rating to 3 instead of a 4. Received a comment in response to my review from the chef/owner almost immediately (which he has since deleted) which really left a bad taste in my mouth as far as attitude goes. I appreciate that he checks Yelp out and reads feedback on the restaurant. A lot of people don't and that is probably what keeps them from their ultimate success in running a business or a restaurant for that matter. There's always an opportunity to improve and to use feedback to see how things are going. Instead, his comments made me uncomfortable. I was originally planning on bringing my husband to try the restaurant, but after having read the comment (and some below responding to other users) myself and a friend decided to not go back. The response was not professional or handled well in my opinion. With that said, I've been contacted by other owners and employees of establishments about my reviews and they have always been pleasant, regardless of what review I gave them.

Edited 5/9/2009: I'm glad you decided to change and re-word your previously rude comments. 

Anyway, my last thought is that price is subjective. It should be respected. If you call anything less than a 5 star rating "being stepped on" because users are voicing their honest opinions which you may not agree with, then Yelp is not the place for you.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The most helpful and patient bartender ever, a friendly server, and ever dish was better than the previous. A bit pricey, but absolutely worth it! I
author: Carly D.

description:
We came here because my friend read good reviews by reliable yelpers on this restaurant and we happened to be in the neighborhood last Saturday. 

It is on the pricey side. but every dish is really good, well worth its price-tag. Possibly the best seafood we've had in the bay area.

Our favorite dish was the Baked Butterfish Wrapped in Paper, runner up is Local Calamari.  Everything else are good too: crab salad, lobster broth, Arugula Salad, Duck Breast, Dayboat Scallops, Sauteed Brussel Sprouts, half a bottle of pinot grigio, and two Mojito.

There were four of us, and the total came to over 200 (i forgot the exact price).
Parking is difficult usually, we were early (5pm on a Saturday) and got lucky on Lombard. 

Definitely would like to come back.
author: Jean Z.

description:
cute lil place. my friend took me here for my bday. the food was really good. 
apps: got the raw oysters, and crab salad-they actually give u alot of crab meat. 
entree: the scallops were amazing and the mushroom risitto was so good. 
price was very reaonsable
a successful night!
author: Karen H.

description: One of the best restaurants I've ever eaten at.  Pricey but not not douchey, and totally worth it.  Go here with a bunch of people and get a little of everything.  Service was impeccable and the tent out back is magical.  The Foie Grais changed my perception on reality.
author: Mark W.

description:
I've gone to Isa a couple times now but I remember I wasn't too impressed the first time I went.  I revisited the restaurant recently for dinner and ordered a bunch of plates to share.  We ordered the following items:

- Salmon tartar w/creme fraiche, capers, lemon and more: lots of flavors but it worked well together.
- Tuna tartar: pretty tasty loaded with avocados and nori sprinkles.  Good.
- Lettuce salad: From what I remember, I thought this salad was quite good. It was served in a lettuce cup.
- Foie gras served with brioche and apricots: my fav dish of the night. Grilled and juicy just the way I like.
- Spaghetti: Was not bad but not memorable.
- Sweetbread with green beans and mashed potato: Something I wouldn't typically order but I thought it was pretty good especially since it was fried. 
- Roasted rack of lamb: Not too gamy which was good since I can't handle anything too gamy.  I thought the temperature and texture were very good.
- Duck breast w/a berry sauce and arugula, beets and goat cheese salad on the side: The duck was also prepared at a good temperature and texture and again not too gamy.  I really enjoyed the side salad!
- Creme brulee: Good but nothing special.
- Flourless chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream: absolutely delicious. Almost like a souffle with a gooey center, but fluffy cake...perfect combo w/the ice cream and not too sweet.  The only thing was that we had two orders of this dessert and one was not completely cooked so the entire dish was a bit gooey while the other was perfect.  When we mentioned it, the server was willing to bring out another order but we were all stuffed so we didn't get another.  They ended up giving us a glass of port which I thought was nice of them.

I'd say overall the service was pretty good.  The only thing that bothered me a bit was that the waiter was a little pushy when we were putting in our order.  But otherwise, I thought the service was fine.

Lastly, I really enjoy the ambiance of the restaurant.  It's definitely a cute, romantic little restaurant.
author: Jessica T.

description: If you ever go to Isa, ask to sit on the patio, its completely covered and heated and it's really nice out there. The food was delicious. Everything is small and sharable. They recommended getting a few different plates and then sharing, which is what we did. We each ordered the 3 course prix fix and shared our plates. It was the perfect amount. And their Soju Mojito was delicious! Definitely one of the great restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Guy S.

description: This place is perfect for a special occassion as the atmosphere is very intimate. If you're on a date and like the whole dim lighting and romantic setting then opt to stay inside. My bf and I were seated by the window and it was quite nice. The other time I came here I was with friends and stayed outside in the patio which is much more lively and bright-good for groups. Food was always good from beginning to end but what always stands out is the duck and desserts! They sometimes have different items on the menu so just go and try it out. Trust me, it's good! Staff was always attentive and friendly.
author: Neva R.

description: I came here for Restaurant Week and though the host service in the front was horrendous, I have to say the food was delicious! Normally on restaurant week, I try to go to more expensive places so that the promotion seems more worth it, so I normally wouldn't go to places like Isa that are cheaper than the restaurant week promotion. However, contrary to my initial beliefs, I found that most of the more expensive places tended to dull down their Restaurant Week menu and choose the cheapest ingredients (including Supper Club, Cortez, and Foreign Cinema) but Isa, coming from a different end of the price point, certainly did live up to the occasion. I was impressed with the delicious food from beginning to end! The tuna tartar and desserts were delicious!
author: Amy M.

description: Very, very good food. We got some tuna and salmon as appetizers. Tuna was served with some sesame oil and guacamole, and was truly awesome. As entrees we ordered iron steak and lamb: finished everything. Red wine was good: 2 bottles for 4 people went so easy. And chocolate cake was a great finale to our Saturday dinner. 5 stars.
author: Gladys D.

description:
really delish. good location. beautiful outdoor/indoor patio in the back, good waitstaff. 

came with some friends and the parentals. tapas style food. we ordered tons, including the dungenous crab salad, scallops, pork chop, lamb, duck, fettuccine, mussels, warm goat cheese, and some butter lettuce salad. it was ALL delicious. 

i've passed by here a few times and thought it looked kinda iffy, maybe not quite as nice as it wanted to be but i was really impressed. great dinner.
author: Georgia W.

description:
I've heard so much about this restaurant and i was totally impressed!  Ordered several dishes, you would have to since all dishes are very SMALL.  The seared foie gras and rack of lamb were done just right. 

The service was great and would definitely go again.

But Reservation is strongly RECOMMENDED!!!
author: Jenny C.

description:
I had heard good things about this place, but just didn't imagine how good it would be.

I made a reservation here for a girls night following a lovely spa day at SenSpa in the Presidio (making the most of the time while my friend's fiance was away in Vegas for his bachelor party). While the boys are still recuperating from their hangovers, we all continue to bask in the glow of our night out at Isa.

First, the service was great. We were seated right away and the waiter helped plan our meal - a series of small plates - from start to finish.  From the tuna tartare to scallops to pasta with truffles, each dish was more delicious than the last. All paired with a wonderful South African chenin blanc, of which we required several bottles. Yum!

It's not often that I'm out in the Marina, but will definitely go out of my way to come back to this restaurant.
author: Samantha R.

description:
Isa is a jewel of a place in the Marina.  The food here has never disappointed, and last night was no exception.  From the dayboat scallops to the duck, wild mushrooms, Laura Chenel goat cheese, and lamb, everything was excellent.  We even tried the raw oysters on the half shell with mignonette sauce (lovely) and the paella (superb!) both of which provided the robust flavors I expect from the kitchen.  The food is some of the best in the city!

So why am I giving it only three stars?  It's those heat lamps in the back that cause me the most dismay.  Every time I've been there my table is in constant competition with other tables over the heat.  The lamps get turned up high and we're roasting, so we ask to turn it way down.  Then before we know it, the heat gets jacked up again!  Perhaps its that table of Marina Muffys dressed for the clubs and showing off the 'girls', or the table behind us packed with Haight street expatriates in their thread-bare T-shirts (don't those tatoos keep them warm?).  Whatever the case, the battle of the heat lamps is always a distraction and clearly an annoyance for the wait-staff.  Hopefully, the folks at Isa will figure out how to resolve the climate conditions so everyone can be comfortable.
author: Ted R.

description:
I used to eat at this restaurant years ago and absolutely loved it. Fast forward 3 years later, the service was terrible! My friend and I sat at the bar (that was not busy) to get a drink before dinner. We were not even acknowledged. So, we moved to our table and it took almost 15 minutes for the waiter to appear. Once we ordered, we were completely rushed through our meal.

I still love the patio. The scallops were delicious. The rest of the food was only okay. Great wine menu.

Unless I have to have a beautiful patio in which to dine, I will not go back. Too many other fabulous SF restaurants with excellent service and food.  It is a bummer too b/c I used to love this place.
author: Beth D.

description:
I really enjoyed my dining experience here.  As it was DAT season, my friends and I gathered here for what ended up being part engagement celebration dinner, part congrats on getting a job dinner.  We got there a bit early, so we went to a bar around the corner for a drink, but first we wanted to drop off a few bottles of wine and bubbly to celebrate the occasion.  The hostess and wait staff was super helpful in getting things chilled and stashed until we returned for dinner.  

When we returned, we were seated quickly in the back patio.  The seating is a bit cramped, but the ambiance is definitely lively and energetic and having a conversation wasn't really an issue.  However, if you're looking for a quieter more intimate atmosphere, you may be served better with another place.

When our waiter arrived, it was like he was welcoming us into his home and just having us over for a nice dinner.  He took great care in explaining the philosophy of the restaurant, how people tend to order, which were the popular dishes and the specials.  He certainly made things sound fantastic and we basically bought it hook line and sinker.  Most of us that did order from the DAT menu also got something else in addition since he made everything sound quite appetizing.  From the DAT menu I chose the salmon carpaccio, the bouillabaisse and the blue cheese plate, and then on top of that I added the foie gras which was a steal.  

It was suggested that we share the plates tapas style, which we did, so I was able to taste A LOT of different dishes. The carpaccio was sweet and fresh tasting.  The bouillabaisse was far superior to the one I had only a few days before at a Peruvian place in the city.  This time, the seafood was cooked perfectly, the broth a beautiful balance of sweetness of the seafood and the brightness of tomatoes and acid.  It was a really well executed dish.  The foie gras was fantastic; a perfectly caramelized slab of buttery goodness.   The blackberry compote that paired with it balanced well with the richness of the foie gras.  I also was able to taste a roasted prawn dish, as well as some of the best mussels that I've ever eaten.  The mussels were perfectly cooked and the white wine butter sauce it was served with was simply divine.  I could have drowned in that sauce and been perfectly content.  The desserts were also very well done.  Overall my meal there was just superb and the service excellent.  It's pretty safe to assume that I'll be returning here again.
author: Gary L.

description: Isa, I celebrated my bday here last april. Since my group was a big reservation I called ahead.  Host was super nice. They recommended to pre-order the menu since my party was over 10 people. I went ahead and complied. It was very easy to set up. Dinner time came and we got seated promptly. Food that we ordered was excellent. We had a variety of selection from the menu. Just one less star because of the wait time between dishes, seemed kinda long. Other than that I had a great time.
author: Mark J.

description: good food, nice decoration but waiter was rushing... even without asking, brought our check!
author: Neda M.

description: My favourite restaurant in the city.....Love it!!!! I've been there so many times. Sometimes I wanna try a new restaurant, but always tempted to go to Isa. Foie Gras, Lobster Broth, Scallops, Lamb chops are so good that I almost order the same thing, or just change 1 or 2 items. Sometimes the side dishes are surprising and so tasty!!!
author: Winnie H.

description: My hubby and I really enjoyed our dinner at Isa. The complimentary bread and butter is so yummy, we ate 3 baskets full! I ordered the halibut which was pretty good except I think it would have tasted better if they added a side of either rice or potatoes to the dish. I'm not a fan of beets or radish and this is what the fish was dressed with. My husband ordered the pan roasted chicken which comes with mashed potatoes. He loved it. The white corn and potato soup was to die for. Creme brulee for dessert was really good too. I want to go back one day and try other items on the menu.
author: Afroze B.

description: One word: delicious.  I've been here 3 times, and the food is always awesome.   I love how you can even book big tables here.  I recently booked a dinner for 15 people and everything from changing the number of people to the food service was flawless.   Even with 15 people, Isa didn't even make us do a pre-fix menu which most SF restaurants require with parties of 10+.   We pretty much ordered everything on the menu, and everything was fantastic.  The service was always prompt, always having our wine glasses full.  HIGHLY recommended for a special occasion!
author: Christina C.

description: The grade A foie gras with rhubarb was magically delicious.  The grilled calamari was also amazing.  Almost 5 stars because of these items.  Our fish were also perfectly cooked and excellent.  If you're on a date, probably want to avoid the semi-outdoors back area, as it can get rather loud with groups.  The inside was very comfortable though.
author: Duke K.

description:
We had reservations at a restaurant this past Saturday (11/20) but luckily their power went out and we were forced to find an alternate. As we trekked through the rain-soaked streets of the Marina I stopped to ask a well-dressed couple for a recommendation. They pointed us to Isa and I am so glad they did. We walked in at 7:45, ordered a round of drinks from the bar and before we could go for round two a table on the rear patio was ready for us. 

The bar drinks are wonderfully different, not your standard fare. For dinner we split a few plates as is recommended. Started with the oysters, always delicious; then moved on to the heirloom salad which was their special. The tomatoes were fresh and delicious and the compliment of arugula and basil made it very refreshing. We then moved on to the potato wrapped seabass which was amazing. The compliment of the salty potato wrap and the light fluffy flavor of the fish were outstanding (my fav dish by far). We ended with the lamb which was very good, but in my opinon the seabass dwarfs its flavor. For dessert we ordered creme brulee which was average as I like to taste a bit more vanilla and custard, however not sub-par by any means. Cost is reasonable (we spent just under $100 for 4 plates and 2 drinks) and the service was very good. All in all a great choice for dining in SF and we will definitely return on our next visit.
author: Nick A.

description: We ate here for my birthday dinner last month and were very impressed. Isa also carries my boyfriend's wine :) so we had been wanting to check it out. The idea here is to share a variety of different plates. If you want to order only two entrees, have them come at the exact same time, and aren't into trying new things - don't go here. You'll get annoyed. And are probably an annoying person to boot. We ordered a wide variety of things including sweetbreads, the crab salad, mussels in a tomato-based broth, the flat iron steak, and a delicious chocolate flourless dessert. They came out as they were ready which was fine...the server did try to course them so we weren't overwhelmed with table space since it was just the two of us at a two-person table. The restaurant got busy with their dinner rush QUICK but it wasn't too noisy or crowded, even though every table was filled. Incredible service and a fun atmosphere. Definitely recommend!
author: Courtney K.

description: Last night my friend and I went to Isa for dinner before hitting Circa for a girls night out.  We had the Yellow Fin Tuna and Calamari appetizers and Scallops and Mushroom Risotto entree.  The Yellow Fin Tuna was really yummy.  The Calamari was grilled with beans, it was okay, perhaps an acquired taste.   The Scallops were served with garlic mashed potatoes and asparagus with truffle oil.  That was my favorite dish of the night, it made me want to learn how to sear scallops.  The Mushroom risotto was ordinary.  We sat in the back which was very cozy and homely.  The atmosphere was very relaxing.
author: Connie L.

description:
thanks to the ladies for organizing a nice, mellow evening this weekend...got to take in this lovely date spot in one of my fav neighborhoods (psyche!)

best way to avoid prix-dinner stress(especially when you are running on hawaiian time) is parking in the lot on pierce, which is good for like 2 and a half hours and won't set you back too much as it is metered.

we jumped into isa and was welcomed to super-sexiness of a soft-lit bar area, kinda reminded me of firefly...walked to the back and found the first of two bathrooms to the left-OH GAWD!!!  damn commutes from the southbay!!! (other one is on the right, before you enter the patio area).

found jen and euge in a table on the upper corner and was welcomed with a nice bottle of..ahem (what is called again??) yeah and it was tasty.

we all ordered an appetizer and entree with a few more apps on top of that.  obviously we all walked out of there like a bunch of fat bastards..oh back to the food.  
* seared foie gras  
* spicy tuna crudo  
* basil scallops  
* miyagi oysters
* seafood risotto
* flat iron steak 
* leek soup
* truffle risotto 
* rack of lamb
* bacon brussel sprouts.  

everything was lovely, but the standouts that had me daydreaming about dinner later at nihon were the prawns (on the seafood plate), the brussel sprouts and that lip-smaking foie gras with custard brioche..OOOOOO  MY!!!!!!!!!!!!

this is definitely the kind of experience to share with friends and props to mgmt on the staff, everyone was super-professional, courteous and one question...is a heavy accent a must to be hired here??!  hahaah..all jokes aside, highly recommend.
author: omar b.

description: Incredible atmosphere. If you want the bistro ambience, dine in the front room. There is a darling table for two that faces the street and is quite private. If you want an al fresco effect, go to the back room. The food is exceptional. Servers a bit overwhelmed at times. But the food is so good that a bit of slow service can be overlooked. I would echo what other reviewers have mentioned about large parties squeezing out couples or foursomes who are having more intimate dining. The management needs to be a bit more attentive to how they seat people. Maybe even give up some seating so that people have more space between tables. I was there with a party of 11 and it was like a tsunami of sound and movement had descended on the poor couple seated next to our group. Felt bad for them.
author: La Gata M.

description: I recommend sitting out in the patio for a cute/romantic dinner. Service was really great, waitress was really sweet...Went on a weeknight and still had to wait about 30 min with a reservation fyi
author: Ami Y.

description: Well prepared and well served.  Great ambiance, and the food is creative and oh so tasty.  The pri-fix menu is a steal and they have an exceptional little wine list. Isa hits that perfect little sweet spot between comfort and elegance.
author: Jeff C.

description: Thank you "Dine About Town" for leading my friends and I to this place! I was impressed with the flavors of all the courses and felt more than satisfied for the $34.95 prix fixe pricing. The duck breast, served with bacon, spinach, and currants was cooked perfectly and was delicious. The deal sealer for this restaurant was the flourless chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream. Hands down, one of the best desserts I've ever had in my life! The dark chocolate cake (almost a souffle) was flavored with a hint of citrus and was a slice of pure heaven! It was light, fluffy and melted in your mouth on contact. I'd come back over and over again for this gem of a dessert!
author: Christina N.

description:
came here for dat.

it was amazing.

had the salmon carpaccio: the salmon was buttery.  the crostini were perfectly crispy. the lemon flavor added a perfect amount of citrus to cut the rich flavor of the fish. it was amazing. some of the best salmon i have ever eaten.

also had the dungeness crab salad: also delicious. the crab was sweet yet had a little brine to it. the avocado provided a perfect amount of fatty creamy goodness and the intermittent bites of apple provided a great texture change to the course.

all in all 2 of the best appetizers i have eaten in a while.

for the mains:

duck breast: i am a huge fan of duck. i think that it is a perfect amalgamation of gamey, fatty, crispy and juicy. isa did this duck proud. and btw the huckleberry was the best DUCK SAUCE everrrr (barbra streisand...)

flat iron steak: cooked a perfect rare/medium rare that allowed the steak juice to mingle with the bordelaise and provide a delicious soppy goodness for the polenta cake (which btw was quite amazing). the zucchini aside from being cut in a peculiar manner was quite good.

the mains did not disappoint and they were nice large portions given the less expensive dat menu.

for the desserts (they were out of the semifreddo, which made me quite sad)

vanilla bean gelato with biscotti: nice. tasty. meh

flourless chocolate cake with espresso gelato: this was a delicious dessert. i am not a huge dessert person but this was really good. the cake was moist and had a rich yet not overpoweringly chocolate taste. i dug it and it was a great end to a great meal.

the ambiance was great as well: dark but not dungeon-like. cozy and cute. nice mood lighting.

the service was top notch. friendly, knowledgeable, courteous (they accidentally brought us a scallop dish and were more than apologetic in taking it back). he also changed our table candle when he noticed that it was running on fumes. never had to ask for more water or to try to refill our champagne flutes. (side note: had a real good price for the roederer estate l'ermitage brut 2002. srsly its nice to go to a fine dining establishment and not have to pay a 200% mark up to have a nice bottle to sip on during dinner).

the only real problem that i had with isa is that when i asked our server to order a cab he told us to walk to the corner and we would find one without any problem. hmmmm.... well if i wanted to do that i would have done it. however, it was cold outside and i would have preferred to wait in the warmth of the restaurant for a cab. BUT. i am always one to find a silver lining: the cabbie that we ended up getting was by far the most hilarious cabbie i have ever met. he srsly made me laugh the whole ride home. so i cannot, in good faith, take off a star because it worked out quite well.

i would love to come back to isa. it was one of the best meals i have had in sf.
author: Jason B.

description:
San Francisco is noted for great restaurants, and this one really stands out.  On a recent visit with my daughter, we had a superb meal on their great back patio, with a waiter (Dean) who made it so much fun.
We had a tuna appetizer that was fabulous, then shared a lamb entree and sea bass, both perfectly prepared, so fresh and bursting with distinctive flavors.  We still managed to find room for a chocolate dessert that made it sooo worth the calories.  This restaurant is the first place I'll go to when I get back to SF...what a discovery!
author: Pat P.

description:
We went to Isa for the first time recently. I was looking forward to dinner because I had heard good reviews. What a disappointment. The food was good, but nothing blew me away. What gives this restaurant a two star rating from me was the service - it was abysmal. Their idea of serving food family style seems to mean that the kitchen can send out dishes whenever. When our first course came out, three of us got our food and the fourth person, who ordered soup, got his about 10 minutes later. His main course arrived when he was about 1/2 done with his soup. Two more main courses arrived about 15 minutes later, with the final one arriving about 25 minutes after the first.

The final straw came when one of our party went to the restroom and a waitress took his chair and moved it to another table. We took that as a sign to leave - and not go back.
author: Natalie T.

description:
I'm new to San Francisco and I was looking for a nice place to take my girlfriend for her birthday dinner. I decided on Isa because of the great Yelp reviews.

We sat in the patio (covered and heated) and the service was fantastic. We had the Potato Sea Bass and the Organic Chicken as our main courses. The Sea Bass was the winner hands down. The Lobster Broth was very good, but unfortunately the prawns in the broth were a little over done (the only fault with the entire meal, and may have been my fault because I let them sit in the broth while I ate and they were probably still cooking). 

Also, unless you feel like paying 5.75 for bottled water, go with tap and lemons, or skip the water completely.

The bonus - during the online reservation I left comments about the birthday, and the comments did not go unread! Desert came with a candle (the trick-kind you can't blow out =o)
author: Ben L.

description:
My girlfriend and I just got back from a dinner here - her friend from Canada was in town and we wanted to show him a place in her hood. 

The night took a turn for the "different" when we walked in and saw a ghost town of a restaurant. But for some reason, the only table available to us was right by the door. Interesting.

We were greeted by the server, who quickly brought the menus, then decided to take a mini vacation in the back of the restaurant while he left us with rounds of bread. 

We finally got his attention, and ordered the appetizers. The calamari was delicious and the goat cheese plate was equally as good. We quickly followed this up with our main plates, while we had the waiter available. We ordered: The chicken, duck, lamb and paella. The waiter then disappeared and waited a good 40 minutes before bringing us our dishes. When we asked him if our food was almost ready, he quickly brushed us off and said "well, food takes awhile to cook, but I guess I could ask the Chef." Wow. Thank you for the wise words! The dishes were overall good, but not great. The duck and the lamb were the tables favorites.

Overall, the food is decent, the atmosphere is your typical marina restaurant (after it's prime), but the service....oh the service....If I was able to provide a rating for the food and the service individually, the food would get 2.5/3 and the service .5, maybe 1 star (I am feeling more generous now that I was able to settle my stomach with dessert, from elsewhere).
author: SandJ C.

description: Came here back in June on a friend's dime, and the food was pretty good (not just because I didn't pay...)!  I had to try the foie gras because my previous foie gras experience was pretty disappointing, and I'm happy to report that Isa apparently does foie gras right because I thought it was delicious!  I had duck breast as my main, and while it was nicely cooked and super flavorful, it was also a little too salty.  The outdoor seating area in the back was super cute.  Our server was the older Asian gentleman previously described by others, and I thought it was entertaining to see how many different adjectives he could use to describe all of the food on the menu.  "The excellent duck!"  "The superb scallops!"  My friends thought it was a little annoying, but I'm glad he seems to enjoy his job.
author: Mousputin S.

description:
Everything was going great until the end... 

We were finishing up our dinner and the server came by to ask if we wanted a last round of drinks which we willingly obliged. The check was dropped with the last round and the manager opened the book 4 times in 10 minutes to not so subtly hint that they wanted us out. The fifth time she came back we still had half of a drink each and I asked her if there was a problem. She advised that someone else was waiting for our table and she would give us a free round of drinks next time we cam back if we would leave. 

It's too bad because the food was good and the atmosphere was energetic. Needless to say, I won't be heading back to get my free round of drinks and be asked to leave after I take the first sip.
author: sarah h.

description:
The first time I came to Isa was thanks to Yelp (which happens quite a bit for me). My friend and I had just picked up some cupcakes at Kara's in the Marina and wanted to grab dinner. We thought tapas would be fun and a quick search on Yelp for a tapas restaurant on the Blackberry turned up Isa. 

The restaurant is very small and intimate when you walk in, with only a few tables in sight. They have a covered patio in the back with more tables and it's very cute. We proceeded to order a Tomales Bay Miyagi Oyster on the Half Shell each, Maine Lobster Broth, Spicy Local Tuna Crudo, Seared Foie Gras, and Baked Fish. (We were hungry, OK? Besides, the waiter recommended that we order 2 plates per person.) We started with the oyster, which was seasoned with citrus vinegar and topped with tobiko. It was good but not too unique. The lobster broth was very light and flavorful, but I wasn't necessarily impressed until the foie gras came out. It was one of the best piece of foie gras I've had - tender, juicy, seared to perfection. And to top that off, the brioche that accompanied it was crispy and delicious, almost better than the foie gras itself (hard to imagine!) The rest of the meal went by in a blur (the tuna and the fish were both good but not memorable) because all I could think about was the foie gras. Hmmm, let me take a moment to reminisce about the foie gras again... OK, I'm back. When the waiter came by to ask if we wanted any desserts, we said, "Can you bring us another order of foie gras?" 

I've been back to Isa many more times since and have tried many things on their menu. My favorite - can you guess? - the foie gras of course! I've also discovered other dishes that are really good, such as the Seared Dayboat Scallops, which comes with a creamy potato puree topped with a truffle infused sauce. Yum! Isa is a great place to bring out-of-town guests and it has consistently helped me impress visitors (even folks from NYC who are normally really picky!)
author: Elizabeth L.

description: I rarely write reviews online but this is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco so I will take a moment. The food is excellent, and the staff are friendly and courteous.  The interior has a nice ambiance, I especially enjoy the heated outdoor area.  I highly recommend Isa.
author: Evan B.

description: Great atmosphere, delicious food and a very friendly wait staff. I went to eat there for a friend's birthday party and had a wonderful time! I can't wait to go again. The truffle risotto was especially amazing!
author: Kristin M.

description: I hadnt been to Isa in years. On my latest visit, I was pleasantly reminded of how much I love the place. I love the small neighborhood restaurant feel (especially cause its in my neighborhood). My fav item on the menu is still the seared foie gras. I had the sweet breads as well on this visit and it did not disappoint. I love this place.
author: Alden H.

description:
five years ago, this would have been a five star review.  i've had many dinners and parties here.  over the years, the food has seriously gone downhill and dining here a few nights ago was a total let down.  

i've ordered almost everything on the menu so i decided to go with a few DISHES I HAVE NOT TRIED BEFORE:  the CEVICHE dish that looked and smell refreshing, which our server highly recommended, was nothing to write home about.  the PAELLA was way buttery and mushy.  the beef was dry and potatoes overcooked.  the CALAMARI had a super weird taste to it.  the lobster bisque soup was probably the only dish that was decent, but ordinary still.    

one star for the delightful server and friendly staff, and another for the back room ambiance but deducted a star because there was a piece of hair in our ceviche.  

what on earth has happened to this place?  and to think i used to love this restaurant and recommended this restaurant to everyone for french tapas!

warning:  
DO NOT have french food before a bachelorette party, your stomache will hate you  :)
author: Paulina C.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in Sf. Even after I moved to Chicago temporarily this was the only place I wanted to come when I visited. My favorites are the goat cheese appetizer and the asparagus, but I have never eaten anything here I didn't like, and their menu changes frequently so I'm always trying something new. I do try to avoid the truffle risotto, it's gotten a little too truffle-y recently. Great atmostphere (sit out back on the heated patio), great staff, I love this place!
author: Kelly L.

description: The food is truly top-notch. Every dish we ordered was a surprise of flavors and quality. Though the desserts were forgettable. Despite the menu's claim that the dishes are shareable small plates, the portions are actually quite large, and the presentation not always accommodating to sharing. So if you order traditionally (appetizer plus entrée for yourself) you won't go wrong. The covered patio in the back is great for groups (and couples too), but be prepared for lots of noise. The acoustics are horrible and everyone just ends up trying to yell louder than the table next to them.
author: Gary P.

description: I have been to Isa for several times and recommended many of my friends to go to Isa. But recently I had a really bad experience, I came to Isa with my family and friends to celebrate my graduation. We ordered 7 glasses of wine and when the waiter served the wine. He spilled the wine and two of my family's clothes got really wet. The waiter just said sorry and we still have to pay 18% of the gratuity. I feel disappointed about that.
author: yunpei t.

description:
As the scene of an eagerly anticipated reunion dinner, Isa would've had to try super hard to spoil my mood.  $1 oysters and a $17 glass of wine on special for $10 are not mood spoilers.  Some may say they might even enhance ones mood.
Warm, tangy goat cheese with tomatoes, pine nuts and basil smooshed onto soft baguette; also not a mood spoiler.
Rich and buttery butterfish with mushrooms and truffle cooked in parchment paper; not a spoiler.
Kick ass, cooked to perfection scallops with a little dollop of mash and tender asparagus; certainly not a spoiler.
Bowl licking good vanilla bean creme brulee; come on now, what could creme brulee spoil?
Not only did Isa's food and staff not even bother trying to spoil my mood; they worked hard to enhance it.  I think we were forgotten about for a while in the beginning after a ridiculously warm reception, but we got over it, especially when the food started coming out.
I can't tell you how much we spent since SOMEONE stole the check while I was in the bathroom (to ensure follow up dinner dates I imagine), but I have a feeling it was a hefty sum.  Yes, the food was amazing, but it's sharable small plates and you're almost paying full entree sized prices.  If you're looking for mass quantities of food for low prices; this is not your place.  If you're in the mood to drop cash for a reasonable amount of food to share; this is your place.  We left completely happy and satisfied, but not overly stuffed.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Isa is my favorite restaurant. I have been there about 5-6 times and each time it has been amazing. By far the 1st restaurant in the city I recommend. 

There is a great variety of food, and you can even have it tapas style. The flavors are wonderful and the lobster broth is wonderful! 

Great date night, or nice place to go with a couple friends!!!!!!
author: Heather B.

description:
I came for DAT with a party of 6 which really enhanced the experience because we got to share all the different dishes with each other. 
For the appetizer, we got the salmon carpaccio, calamari, mussels, crab salad, and yellow fin tartare (these last 2 weren't on the DAT list). Everything was awesome especially the tartare. 
For the main course, I got the bouillabaisse which was ok but the steak, scallops, braised ribs, and risotto were all very good. 
We were all stuffed by dessert. The semifreddo was a little disappointing so that's why I had knock off one star. The dessert list could be better.
author: Olivia H.

description:
"Oh great." I thought as I first glanced through the Evite, "Another overpriced big-group dinner in an 'Asian Fusion' restaurant with price tags that would put me in the poorhouse."  

Tainted from horrific experiences at Butterfly and, more recently, The Slanted Door, where expectations were sky high and reality were down in the gutter, I was skeptical about Isa.  What's more - it is Friday night and my old self is normally already pooped after a brutal week at work, AND it is in the swanky Marina district, which has got to be the farthest point from the highway in San Francisco.  

But I did not want to disappoint the birthday girl.  

And I'm glad I went - The reality could not be further from the truth.  

The ambiance were just great - the back of the restaurant was a tented little backyard with enough heating to stave off the famous San Francisco evening chill, our server was quite possibly the best one I've ever encountered in a large group dining - and certainly unlike the snooty server with attitude problem at Slanted Door, or the generally incompetent one at Butterfly.

And for a mere $52 per person (vs $75 at the Slanted Door and Butterfly), we had one of the most amazing prix fixe family-style menu ever - there has to be about 12 different dishes, the presentation of each could not have been more perfectly timed.  While my memory is a bit hazy, the few that I could recall were the foie gras with white peaches and custard brioche, roasted rack of lamb, seared duck breast, flatiron steak, baked paper-wrapped butterfish and shiitake mushroom risotto.  

Now if only Marina District Parking God could be more generous to me, I could see myself visiting this restaurant more often.
author: Ange L.

description:
4.5 stars, almost perfect.
tuna crudo plate - good
dungeness crab salad - great
seared foie gras - great
dayboat scallops -good
baked butterfish in paper - great
saffron paella - no
roasted mushrooms - ok
potato wrapped seabass - N/A
(minimalist review)
btw, prix fixe went up to 24.95
author: Rob C.

description:
The Yelp Supper Club was a hit tonight - thanks Serena Y. for making all the effort to organize. And thanks to all the guests for their lovely company!
Now - let's talk Isa.  First, though, I have to clarify my rating logic here.  Isa is a solid 3.5 to me.  If anyone should read my other reviews, sometimes I mark 4 stars for a 3.5 review, sometimes 3.  I choose based on what the current overall rating is. 
There were some good dishes tonite - the potato wrapped bass was innovative and tasty, the thin-thin potato shell edges having turned crisp on baking while the bass remained moist.  The spicy tuna tartare - it was good as well, but it wasn't at all spicy. The lamb and flatiron steak were both well prepared, but not particularly unique.  Then there were some oddly plain dishes - vegetable medley?? Todd E. hit the mark when he said 'anytime you see medley it's not a good thing'.  We are at the peak of tomato season right now, and tonite's heirloom tomato salad, just didn't seem all that. Perhaps the dressing was too overwhelming? I dunno. And they burned the creme brulee. For shame. FOR SHAME!
The vegetable small plates started at $8-11, the seafood items~$13-17, the richer poultry/meats were in the upwards of $18. None were more than a soup plate's capacity.  
The staff were all pleasant and accomodating of our large-ish party - all thumbs up to them. 
For such prices, though, I left wishing there was just a bit more going on with their food.
author: CINDY K.

description: I second (third, fourth, whatever!) the potato-wrapped halibut - SO GOOD!  Try it if you haven't - that alone is worth the trip there.
author: Joyce L.

description: Everything was right with my dining experience at Isa. We got a cozy and private table in the corner with excellent wines and dishes. I recommend the crab salad and lamb rack plus icecream and flourless chocolate cake for dessert.
author: quan n.

description: My husband and I dined here last night and we were satisfied with our meals. We sat in the back, which was good because on our way out, the front area was very cramped. The back is more spacious, but it's not the prettiest space. The food was good though. We had the salmon and butter lettuce salad to start. Nothing mind blowing, but good. For our entrees we had the scallops and spaghetti. I enjoyed the scallops and the sauce it came in. My husband, who isn't a fan of brussels sprouts actually liked the ones this plate came with. The spaghetti was just ok. Truffles are definitely in season because they seemed to throw it generously on most of our plates. I've usually seen truffles shaved and served sparingly but it was quite the opposite here.
author: Yelp O.

description: I always have had a great meal here and if you get a chance to dine on the back patio I would recommend it. Great ambiance. An excellent choice for French cuisine.
author: Brian R.

description:
i came here for dinner last night in a group of 5, so we were able to try a lot of dishes.  service here is pretty prompt, so they bring out the dishes soon after you order.

i tried the grilled calamari, dungeness crab salad w/ avocado and mango, shrimp w/ grilled artichokes, day boat scallops w/ asparagus and potato puree, truffled pasta, and the side of mushrooms.  all of it was delicious, and i really liked the mushrooms and crab salad.  my friends also got the baked goat cheese, fois gras, and flat iron steak, but i didn't try those.  

for dessert, we shared the warm chocolate cake and the creme brulee, which were both good.

service here is pretty good, and since the tables here are really small, the servers cleared our tables pretty quickly.
author: Helen T.

description: Took a group here last night, including a dear friend in from out of town... we got a table in the back patio with the heat lamps and the little white lights.  So great!  There were 5 of us and we vowed to avoid repeat selections so we were able to sample more than half the menu.  Everything we had was truly delicious, really fantastic flavors.  My faves had to be the baked goat cheese (which was honestly to die for), the scallops (in particular the mashed potatoes that came with), and the lamb.  And our waiter was adorable.  I didn't quite catch it, but he did say something about their liquor license which made it so the drinks contained less alcohol than normal... I stuck with kir royales accordingly.  All in all, a perfect choice for the evening.  Highly recommend.
author: Kristin D.

description: I may have to drag more haters to the Marina...  Absolutely wonderful ambiance, food and service at a reasonable cost.  Sharing plates among seven allowed us to sample the baked goat cheese, calamari, heirloom tomatoes, halibut, butterfish, truffle spaghetti, flat iron steak and scallops.  It was all fresh and delicious.  We topped it off with the cheese plate and farmer's market fruit.  The covered back patio was effectively heated and pleasant on this foggy, cold night.
author: Esther R.

description: I loved it here. The ambience is delightful, especially if you sit in the patio area. We had salmon carpaccio(YUM!!), duck(YUM!!) spaghetti with truffle oil, and dessert. I will definitely come back to this spot again. One of my new favorite places. Great for dates :-)
author: Lady L.

description:
Although I don't quite remember what we ate, I do remember that almost all, if not all, the selections were great. I also remember the server to be very knowledgable and made great recommendations (also told us not to order anymore because we would not be able to finish it, which is always a plus).

One thing that I was not particularly fond of was the back patio/backyard like setup. It kind of felt like we were all camping and dining under a big tent or something - I could even see the flora and fauna creeping up the side of the 'walls'. Others may enjoy it but that's just not my thing...

I'll still give it 4 stars though, although it should be more like 3.75 stars or something.
author: Ken L.

description: I really enjoyed the calamari, and I'm not usually a fan of calamari that hasn't tasted breadcrumbs and a deep fryer.  This was also my first taste of butterfish, oh where have you been all my life?  Probably swimming in a buttery pond in heaven somewhere.  They have a nice wine list but only five cocktails, all with soju.  The flour-less chocolate cake was okay but not great.  I enjoyed the atmosphere but thought the tables were too close together, although it's always fun eavesdropping.
author: Derek G.

description: I'm bumping my previous 4 start rating up to 5 stars after a fantastic recent dinner. My date ordered the pan roasted chicken. Typically, I don't order chicken as a main course when I go out to dinner, but this is an exceptional dish. And simple(ly) perfect mashed potatoes. You won't be disappointed! Everything else was delish. And the service, as always, was excellent.
author: Susan S.

description: The food here is consistently great, the wine list is good,  and the staff is friendly.  What more can I say?
author: Sonia A.

description: They do their thing well. It's excellent food at a reasonable price point, the exact sort of good but not pretentious place that's findable here but nearly impossible to find in, say, NYC. Probably my only quibble is that the pacing was a bit fast relative to the price point--they had us in and out in about 1 hr 10. Overall, while I'm a Mission guy in general, I'll definitely be back.
author: Peter B.

description: The food is AMAZING full of flavor and freshness!! very cozy place for a special occasion. The patio is heated. We always get the hamachi for appetizer even when its not on the menu, its soo tasty, for entree the seared scallops or the range chicken is yummy, both come w/this creamy mashed potatoes that melt in your mouth when you take a bite, (the best mashed potato i ever had) the chicken is full of flavor and juicy as well.  Lets not forget the creme brulee, so creamy and you can really  taste the vanilla. Every dish is made to perfection and you can tell they use fresh seafood and produce on their dishes because nothing taste frozen.
author: Alicia P.

description: So I went and tried this place for the first time after my girlfriend repeatedly mentioned how much she liked it. Turned out she was right. Small plates, family style....so if you are one of those who doesn't like to share, be forewarned. Had a really good Maine lobster broth with tiger prawns and tarragon, followed by a saffron paella, that isn't like Andalucia, but definitely held its own. Good service, heat lamps, good date spot.
author: Sam S.

description: I'm not a big fan of the Marina night life, but Isa was pretty solid. I got the chicken, which admittedly wasn't as stellar as I was hoping. However, I tried a bit of some of the other dishes & they all fell somewhere between solid & amazing.
author: Pete J.

description: Very interesting. The Foie Gras and Sweetbreads were definitely the highlights. The wine and champagne were decent. The salmon crudo, asparagus soup, lamb, and steak were all pretty good. I'd definitely go back, but maybe with a smaller group...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I went again on a Monday evening, and the food was not as good and came out cold!  The service also was not great.  I was soo disapointed, my second visit greatly paled in comparison!
author: Olivia C.

description:
I have mixed feelings when it comes to tapas. Sure, its a fun idea and allows you to really sample the menu, but I'm a very selfish eater. I know what I order is going to be good and I don't want to share. Luckily, at Isa, everything is so good that you don't have to be concerned about coming with a non foodie and having your meal ruined by their below par selection.
The scallops were my favorite but to my dismay, they took those with the potatoe puree off the menu and replaced them with another scallop dish that had an edamame bok choy thing going on or something. Didn't sound nearly as appealing. 
The al dente spagetti with truffles, fresh tomatoes, and basil is amazing! It doesn't sound all that exciting but they really load the truffles on this thing. So good.
The big surprise of the night on our last visit was the special, which was sweet breads! When do you ever see these babies on a menu... (practically never if that wasnt clear). Personally I don't trust sweet breads unless its my grandma thats making them at home, so I passed, but my friend braved it and was thoroughly impressed. Great sign of a quality restaurant if they can pull that off.
Appetizers - oysters, goat cheese, lobster broth - all solid.
The back patio makes for an amazing date setting, so romantic (if you're into that sort of thing).

The only beef I have with the place is that if you aren't sitting in the back patio, and get stuck in the front, the place can get incredibly cramped and stuffy. And they seem like they overbook reservations pretty frequently. So even if you have rez's for 8:30, don't come starving, because theres a good chance you won't be seated till 9.
author: Taylor E.

description: For a nice night in SF, the patio was comfortable and very cozy (the tables were practically touching).  I initially liked the French tapas idea but it seemed a little contrived and a lot overpriced. Food wasn't too dazzling either, though the duck was pretty tasty. I'd probably go back for drinks, but skip out on the "dinner".
author: Brittany L.

description: I came to Isa last Tuesday had mixed feelings. Don't get me wrong, the food was excellent but had to deduct 1 star due to their service. We had reservations for two and they seated us in a tiny table right by the stairs in the back of the restaurant. It was fine at the time since no other tables were available. A few minute after we sat, the larger table of 2 next to us left. We asked to be switched and they declined as they were prepping the table for another party. Well, that party didn't like that table and they were able to switch. Not a good experience - the tip given was reflected due to this experience. Overall, I would come here again for the food.
author: Jen T.

description: Small plates - yes please. Their roast chicken is to die for - order it with the risotto and you are on your way to a fantastic time. The goat cheese spread is also nice and be sure to have the creme brulee - it is some of the best I have had. They have perfected the warm crisp top without compromising the cool custard inside. Be leery of the popular mojito however - it is not made with rum - rather with soju - I'd stick to the wine menu!
author: CarOline C.

description: Went here for the Dine about Town event. We went early and avoided the rush. The parking is tough in this area but the perseverance was worth it. The staff was friendly, helpful and attentive. The food was absolutely delicious. We had the mussels (tender and tasty), crab salad (good amount of real crab), flat iron steak there's a very light wasabi-tasting sauce on top that I liked but if you don't like wasabi be forewarned), scallops, creme brulee and grapefruit granite (a harder form of sorbet). The portions did not seem huge but I wasn't hungry after the meal. The bonus, a free glass of wine with dinner.
author: Randy C.

description: Amazing place. The room in the back is the perfect place for a date, the food is spot on, (would absolutely recommend the foie gras, risotto and ribs), and the service is great. As the last people to leave the place, the waiter was kind enough to put on some music (not normally on during service) and let us stay as long as we wanted - a rarity for places to be so accomodating. After a quick dance we were left with hgh fives and cheers from the kitchen staff - couldnt ask for more than that really.
author: Ben W.

description: I was invited by a very charming guy for our first date here. My date ordered "seared foie gra" for appetizers and it comes with vanilla custard brioche. It's one of my favorite dish...and the price here is unbeatable for French cuisine lover!
author: Mimi K.

description: This French restaurant offers you standard plates such as foie gras, risotto (truffle risotto might I add) and duck breast which are sure to be crowd pleasers. Both their wines by the glass and bottles are reasonably priced, and the heated seating area in the back filled with lights makes for an intimate atmosphere. This is a great place to go on a date, take relatives or have a celebration.
author: Courtney C.

description: I love this place! One of the best French/Asian restaurants for its price. My boyfriend took me here on our first date over a year ago and I never forgot the experience. The restaurant wasn't too busy since we went really late on a Wednesday night. The staffs were very attentive and warm; coming back to check on us a few times after our dinner was served. There are three dishes I always order at a French restaurant... Duck, Lamb, and Foie Gras. All three were delicious. Some restaurants serve the pate foie gras, but not Isa. They seared their foie gras to perfection! I went back another time for a Bday dinner and had almost a whole plate to myself b/c the others didn't like foie gras. More for me! Their butterfish, mushroom risotto, dayboat Scallops are also a must try. I think I've had almost every item on the menu...must come back to finish off the rest! :)
author: Kim D.

description: I've been going to Isa for over five years.  I've moved away, come back, visited, moved back - and the food has always been consistent, yummy, and fabulous.  The patio in the back is the best part about the restaurant, it has this surreal, fantasy-land quality about it - and the crowd?  There's always a great mix of dates, family, friends, random ppl, tourists.  Young, fun and reasonably priced.  They get knocked for the service, but hey, what can you expect?  It's run by Chinese ppl, you're not paying for Gary Danko, and it's a small place.  You deal.  Though I did lose my favorite denim jacket there one time, and they refused to admit that it was their fault.  I've forgiven the restaurant - that's how great it is.  But not that server, trust me - I gave him hell for it.
author: Samantha W.

description:
I've been hearing about Isa's great food and enchanting outdoor patio for years so I thought it was about time to visit. We went at 7:30pm on a Saturday, and the place was a madhouse. We were seated on the patio but immediately decided we couldn't bare to sit out there - crowded, HOT (heat lamps everywhere) and two tables with screaming children. I know the children were not fault of the restaurant, but you should be aware that the patio is the furthest thing from enchanting - in this case it was unbearable. And you should be aware that Isa is apparently a place that people think is appropriate for infants (and think it's fine to have them screaming at the table). 
My BF wanted to leave immediately but I convinced him to eat at a teeny spot at the side bar. The food was generally very good (they sure love parsley, which I dislike immensely, but otherwise it was tasty), but the scene was just too chaotic. Part of the problem was my expectation for a refined, romantic experience - not at all the case. Would be a good spot for a loud, group dinner (bring your megaphone). The wine list extremely low priced - I was a little worried about the quality but to their credit it was fine. Service was impressive considering the tight quarters and crowds in the bar area.
author: Ellen H.

description:
We came here with no knowledge of Isa, only what other Yelpers' expressed. I must say I was a little taken aback when we were sat in the patio. The patio didn't really look like a patio and it was empty when we got there; however, shortly after I got used to it I really liked our spot. Our waiter was really friendly and knew everything about the menu, he even commended us on our selections. 
We started with the heirloom tomato salad, grilled asparagus and the salmon carpaccio. All were great but my favorite that I will surely order again was the heirloom tomato salad. 
Our entrees were amazing. Since they encourage a family style, sharing of entrees we ordered several. The specials of the night were halibut and short rib, both of which were amazing! We also ordered the duck and the spaghetti. The duck received rave reviews from our table too! 
I was impressed with all of the food and the service was really great, not overly attentive but not too standoffish. 
I urge you to try it if you haven't- what a treat nestled between so many other restaurants on Steiner!
author: Janell D.

description: I always like restaurants that have the small dish menu. Our party of 3 ordered 4 plates to share and they were all very good. Nice ambiance and a comfortable setting.
author: Stephanie C.
