description: Isa has absolutely awesome food.  Probably my favorite restaurant that does not fall squarely into an ethnic category (which is not to say that Isa's food doesn't have various ethnic influences).  Small plates.  Relatively upscale.
author: Russel S.

description: Came in on a Saturday night as walk-in.  We got a seat at the bar, in front of the kitchen.  Love the small plates, great way to try out a variety of dishes.  We started out with hamachi, then on to foie gras.  Next up was the day boat scallops, then a special that night, short ribs.  Everything was well prepared.  Since we sat in front of the kitchen, it was fun seeing all the activity.  Jonathan, our server, provided great recommendations for both plate selections and wine.
author: Steve L.

description:
More like 2.5 stars. ahh, I had really really wanted to like this place more. I had walked by soo many times and was excited to try their $28 pre fixe. The setting is adorable. I liked the little tent area in the back. 
The food was very good. Family style, sharing of everything, even with the pre fixes which is interesting. The veggies were fresh, the chicken was delicious and juicy, the tomato salad and asparagus were awesome.
But...the service. Ahhh, it left much to be desired. Getting water, getting refills of water = huge challenge. We had to race down our server half the time. At one point the lady bought over one of our dishes and we asked if we asked her about the serving sizes and if we could add one more tomato or bring dishes out with 5 of items instead of 4 (there were 5 of us) and she snapped at us and told us we could cut it ourselves. The servers were rushed so they would just throw down plates meaning half the serving utensils were sitting in sauce before we even touched them.
Would I come back? For the food...yes. Given the service...no. And service is huge in my book. There are just too many places in the city that have amazing food and great service to have to compromise.
author: shadi m.

description:
Absolutely LOVED this place!  It helped that I was in great company but the food was phenomenal.  Service was just right.  We all left feeling like pigs and super full but ready to eat more if they'd bring it!  We had: Yellow tail, salmon, scallops, zucchini, flat iron steak, potato and leek soup, oysters, tomato salad, gosh something else that came with goat cheese but I can't remember what for the life of me (obviously it wasn't my favorite dish~).  I can't personally attest to the yellow tail, oysters and salmon since I'm not a fish person, but everything else was to die for.  Everything tasted like it had been cooked in butter and oh it was so good!  
We sat outside in the tented area and it's a bit noisy but not overpowering.  You can have your own conversations and be in your own world, but it's not dead silent when you're busy shoveling the food in your face~  The inside dining area looked a little more romantic, very dark and cozy.  Small bar in the front when you walk in.
author: Katie W.

description: I happened to get placed in the backyard area which doesn't even feel like your outside.  Great service and recommended a perfect amount of food for the 4 of us.  Everything was tasty, except for the goat cheese dish.  I now know that I don't like cheeses that taste like ass.  Well can't blame this place for that.  Thumbs up and seems like cool place to impress on a 1st date.
author: Jason A.

description: We generally don't eat out too much anymore, but over the years, we have gone to Isa many times.  We went back there recently and had another wonderful experience.  A wine selection was offered, but not pushed.  The waiter gave us plenty of time to order, but was always close by when we needed him.  We ordered appetizers, and main course, and desserts.  All we perfectly prepared and brought in a timely fashion.  without rush or delay.   The restaurant was busy, but not chaotic.  It was romantic, but not isolated or silent (it was actually kind of loud, but in a fun way).  We were properly greeted, seated at exactly our reservation time, and sent out afterwards with a friendly goodbye.  Another great dining experience.
author: Ken B.

description: I am so disappointed Yelpers!!! I was looking for a great date night restaurant and Yelp steered me here with glowing reviews. We both decided after the meal that we would have thought it was an okay meal if the bill was $25, not $85. The server told us the best dish was the potato wrapped fish so we were very excited about that. We also ordered the chicken. The potato wrapped fish was bland and just not delicious- sadly this was supposed to be what they are known for. The chicken was too salty and not very tasty either. The ambiance is nothing like the previous yelpers want you to believe- it was a very loud mediocre patio. I'm wondering in this place paid for reviews because my experience was so far from what I expected.
author: Leeroy B.

description: Isa continues to deliver outstanding food with polished service.  My wife and I ventured there on Valentine's Day, surely one of the most hellish nights for a restaurant, and while the place was packed, we were well taken care of on all counts.  The potato crusted sea bass has been on the menu for two years or longer, but is still a knockout dish.  Six not-so-small plates between the two of us, along with flourless chocolate cake & a cheese plate for dessert, and not a bite that disappointed.  Service on this most challenging of nights couldn't have been better if we'd been dining there alone.
author: Hugh B.

description: I love love love this place! Especially the patio.  We sat in the back, had an INCREDIBLE waitress and she even hooked us up with a little extra dessert wine... we like freebies! (hope I didn't get her fired for writing this)  Anyway, truffle Risotto- to die for.  Not a bad thing on the menu and not an unhappy customer in my party.  I make it a regular spot to take friends who are visiting... of course it's a toss up between Bistro Yoffi and Isa... Isa wonderful restaurant.
author: Carrie U.

description: I'd like to give it a better review.  And perhaps it's worth more than 3 stars.   The owner/chef is very nice, but even in its early, Michael-Bauer-having-a-fit-because-he-liked-it-so-much-days, it didn't kill me.  It's pleasant, it's good, but it's nothing like Lawrence Jossel in his early days at Chez Nous.  I have a friend who has hosted several dinners here (my winemaker friend), and it is always very pleasant.  But nothing killer.
author: Laurel B.

description: I went for the second time with a big group of friends and that's two great trips. We shared a lot of different plates and everything was good. The foie gras was delicious as was everything else. Our waiter was also really attentive and funny. I can't wait to go back.
author: Jonathan G.

description: We have eaten at Isa over 50 times since they opened.  The food quality and service has steadily gone downhill.  We have supported their business since the opening, however, tonight was the last time.  The service was painfully slow, the food marginal at best.  The staff and owner(s) seemed completely overwhelmed and unable to handle the diners.  The last straw was waiting an unusually long time for our dessert, just to be served RAW cake batter.  Wake up Isa, you're run could be over very soon.
author: kathleen g.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco.  Everything on the menu is delicious. I've always had great service. The atmosphere is relaxed but luxurious. Romantic and great for dates, but equally nice for groups of friends.
author: Leigh M.

description: Excellent food.  Excellent ambiance.  Excellent service=a rather boring review. (sorry)
author: Lauren S.

description:
yum. yum. yum. 

isa impressed on all counts. we sat in the rear courtyard which was very warm and cozy thanks to a tented ceiling and heat lamps. strung with white lights, the tent glowed and made everyone look better. the tables were close together, but we still felt we could focus on our conversation. 

the food was perfect, i went to yelp first and based on reviews decided that i had to order the tuna tartar and the seabass, which i did. both were excellent. i won't go into them since others already reviewd those. we also had the steak, which was cooked to perfection, and was very tender and juicy. it came with a lovely herb butter and some yummy reduction sauce. we also had very nice butter lettuce salad, with blue cheese and pecans and pears. very good. 

our waitress was super nice and very attentive and was happy to fix her error when she accidentally charged us for the prix fixe menu. 

we will definitely go back.
author: rachel p.

description: Isa is a wonderful gem in the Marina.  It has all of my favorite dishes including the truffle risotto, foie gras, and seared scallops. Yummy :)  The only dish I wasn't too fond of was the lobster broth.  I thought it would have been a nice touch if they actually put some pieces of lobster into the soup to make it more like a bisque.  I guess I just won't order that next time. A definite recommendation
author: Marilyn W.

description: Great ambience and delicious small plates! Suitable for family style sharing! Wonderful Marina restaurant!
author: Yan M.

description: This is such a great little restaurant.  Warm and cozy with some fantastic dishes.  The dayboat scallops were tasty and done perfectly ...I hate when it's not quite cooked through enough and wiggly inside.  Unfortunately I wasn't too enamored w/ the flat iron steak which was really greasy -- like it was seared in too much oil plus rather bland but the thick fingerling potatoes that came w/ it were SO good -- crispy/crunchy on the outside and soft inside.  Thankfully the potato wrapped seabass more than made up for the steak's shortcomings.  There's a thinly sliced potato wrapped around the fish which was cooked perfectly and so tasty -- the flavors of the sauce went so well with it and made me wish I ordered two b/c I was fighting over the last bits w/ my bf.  I'd return again and again for the seabass alone.  Service was great... perfectly timed and friendly.
author: Jeannie C.

description: Isa is one of the first restaurants I fell in love with in SF. The concept is great, the service has been flawless each time, and of course, the food is phenomenal. We usually end up getting two each of our favorite plates - the baked laura chenel goat cheese with sundried tomatoes and pine nuts (yum!!), the mushroom risotto, the sushi, and some semifreddo to wind down. Everything is fresha nd delicious.
author: Purnima M.

description: It's loud in here, but it was a cute, quaint place in a great location.  My friend and I ordered the crab salad, butterfish, chicken and creme brule.  Ok, so the chicken and creme brule was really nothing special, but the crab salad and butterfish were excellent.  I've never had fish literally melt in my mouth before and the fruit with the avocado with the dungeness crab was super super good.  Service was ok, but that crab and fish garnered this place 4 stars from me!
author: Jennifer N.

description: LOVED this restaurant. It is french style small plate so order lots of things and share them with your dining companion...yes I said companion. It is somewhat expensive but the food quality is superior. I had this seared chicken the skin was so crunchy and so good and the potatoes were delicious. Dessert was so great...i enjoyed every part of the meal. I hate that the restaurant is located in the city because I hate driving or even taking the BART there. It's not worth dealing with people on BART, unless I have something/one to keep me occupied, but it is definitely worth the drive.
author: Courtney R.

description:
Last night my boyfriend and I ate here to celebrate New Years Day. The place was packed and understaffed but Jonathan, one of the staff members who wasn't even a waiter just jumped in ready to help and took our order. That's good service. He continued to attend us for the rest of the night. He was very friendly and even offered me a taste of a different wine on the house. Every time I leave Isa i leave feeling content and with warm feelings towards this place. 

About the food: I love the Truffle Risotto, Lamb chops, goat cheese, yellow fin tuna, the steak, and the swordfish. Desserts are delicious. Try the Semifreddo all' amaretto. It's a delicious almond cookie mixed in with a lighter ice cream. yum!
author: cin d.

description: Absolute best in the Marina.  Wonderful service, great food, very warm atmosphere.  Small plates designed to share.  Make sure to ask for outside seating.
author: Nellie L.

description: So, I'm not a seafood eater but of course have several friends who are.  This review is only for the non-seafood dishes.....deeelish.  Had the asparagus soup, creamy goodness.  The zuchinni was fab and the chicken and steak were wonderful.  Topped off with a fantastic creme brulee and lots of great wine, who could ask for more?  The only reason this is a 4 is because they asked our party (who had just forked over $600+) to clear the table.  The service up till then was great.
author: Nichole H.

description: Best local restaurant in the marina - bar none. Always consistently good, m wife and I keep coming back to this place as often as we can. Their scallops with potato puree, their pasta with tomato sauce and their spaghetti with truffles are simply divine. Their seabass in parchment is one of their best dishes (it's super light). They have a small wine list, but the wines are offered virtually at cost or tiny markup. So besides having one of the best neighborhood cuisines, it's also one of the best values in SF. Our favorite table is the one by the window and in the far corner.
author: Aydin S.

description:
food here is very tasty. the prices are also very reasonable for the amount  and quality of food you get here.  if you sit in the back, the restaurant is also very intimate and romantic. the front of the restaurant really didn't seem like somewhere i would want to eat.  the scallops and duck here were the best dishes i tried.  

since the place and kitchen is small, they can't bring out the food at the same time so you get dishes one at a time, creating the shared tapas style.  the service is very minimal and lacking, but at the time there was only a few servers for the entire place.  if that is the reason the prices are decent, then i don't mind, but they forgot to bring out one of our main dishes and we had to wait an extra 20-30 for it.  luckily i was having a good time that night.
author: Molly C.

description: I am editing my review to reflect the positive experience I had with the owner.  When I went to Isa, I enjoyed the food but was not pleased with my server. I posted my review and the very next morning the owner had replied and apologized for my experience.  She wanted to talk to me about what happened so that she could take action to rectify the situation. I am hugely impressed that she is so actively involved and cares so much about customer service.  Now, I will definitely try Isa again.
author: Stefani S.

description: I absolutely adore this restaurant!  The ambiance on the back patio is enchanting and makes me feel worlds away from the busy streets of San Francisco. The menu offers a perfect variety of delicious small plate options which are so fun to share.  The wine list gives plenty of good choices!  I get so excited every time my boyfriend and I make a reservation... when we leave Isa, we are already looking forward to returning again!!
author: Andrea C.

description:
Isa is simply magical.  The ambiance is beautiful- intimate, romantic, and unique.  The food never misses and the menu is long enough to satisfy nearly all food types.

My personal favs:  fall menu tuna tar tar, winter menu salmon crudo (amazing lemon sauce and avocado contributes to the perfectly creamy meets salty and sweet consistency), the butterfish (baked in parchment with mushrooms, will melt in your mouth), and the fall scallops (with edamame and light sauce--  the winter scallops with brussels sprouts and bacon are also delicious, although definitely heavier).

My fiance loves the PEI mussels and the summer heirloom tomatoes are to DIE for (in fact we are copying the recipe for our wedding's first course.)

Make sure to reserve your table in the back patio, covered, decorated with white lights, and heated with space heaters.

After Chez Nous closed (which still is devastating more than a year later), Isa is the only tapas restaurant that measures up.  Enjoy!
author: Casey M.

description: Went there a few months ago because it claimed to be "French". When I first looked at the menu, I realized it is not authentic at all. I asked the waiter if the ownership had changed. He answered yes, but the whole staff were still there.  The food and menu had a lot of "italian". I though if I want Italian, I would go to an Italian place, not a "French" one. Also, the waiter claimed the food were good portion to share in family style. We had 8 people in the party, so it turned out everyone got only a tiny bit. I was not too impressed with the taste of the food either. I probably wont go back again.
author: Kar K.

description: Isa, Isa..I had high expectation on this restaurant but it turned out  to be mediacre. Maybe I didn't make a reservation and went on a lark. I skipped the appertizers went straight for the main course. The food took longer time to prepare. Anyway, I do want to give them credits on their service. Good service but nothing special beyond that. Maybe I need a date to go with not a friend.
author: Michael K.

description:
This is my favorite french restaurant, I love their food.

Scallop, cook just right, and very good favor.
Rack of Lamb, always very tender, and juicy.
Raw oysters, very tasty and fresh.

Love going here for special occassion.  The price is reasonable too.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Delicious.  Delicious.  Did I mention, delicious?  

We went to Isa on Tuesday of this week to celebrate a friend's promotion and we were not disappointed.  I have to admit, however, after reading some reviews on opentable.com, I was a bit nervous about our dining experience; the timing of the dishes kept coming up as a concern.

The experience starts with the location of Isa.  It is located in the Chestnut/Fillmore area and I was reminded of how much of a gem this area is.  Tuesday night was the 2nd night of the heatwave so it was a gorgeous night.  

We were taken care of by Dean, a lovely, lovely man, and he walked us through the optimal dining experience by basically explaining their vision and offering his assistance in choosing our dishes.  We agreed to choose 2 dishes p/person, making that 8 dishes total.  The first half of the menu is what you would consider lighter, appetizer fare, and the second half of the menu are the heavier dishes.  Their vision: that each dish is shared and that each dish is served after finishing the previous dish.  

What we ordered: 

First half of the menu: Spicy Tuna Tartare (recommended), Dungeness Crab Salad (recommended; the grapefruit paired well with the crab salad), Seared Grade A Foie Gras (didn't try), and a Seafood Ceviche (forgive me as I've forgotten what fish was used in the ceviche)(highly recommended if you like ceviche).

Second half of the menu: Baked Butterfish in Paper (highly recommended. fish melted in your mouth.  flavors worked well together), Caramelized Dayboat Scallops, King trumpet, Morel & Shiitake Mushroom Risotto (recommended), and a Seafood Risotto (highly recommended).

Really, everything we ordered was delicious.  

Their wine list included areas such as California, Italy, Oregon, South Africa, New Zealand, and Spain!  I appreciate that the wine menu was inclusive of different areas/countries, and that it wasn't an overwhelming list of choices.

The timing of the dishes was... impeccable.  At one point, we had 3 of our lighter fare on the table and it was after our 4th dish that the next 4 dishes, the heavier fare, came after the previous was finished.  I was impressed.  Once our table was cleared of a dish, the next one came within a minute or two, and it arrived piping hot so it was obvious to us that it hadn't been sitting around.  I still am impressed.  And may I just say that I appreciate their vision, although I know it isn't for everyone, and I agree with Dean's sentiments that bringing one dish out at a time really encourages you, and allows you the rare opportunity to enjoy, savor and appreciate the food/dish for what it is.  You take your time because there is only one dish on the table.  You are more prone to talk about it's flavors and what your thoughts are as you work your way through the dish.  You are less prone to eating at a fast pace.    

Dining at Isa is such an experience that speaks beyond eating out, I think it talks to life, in general.  It sort of reminds you to slow down sometimes, as cliche as it sounds, regardless of your daily grind.  It reminds you that food is nourishing, and that eating should be a positive experience for all involved. 

So I raise my glass to Luke Sung for his vision and execution; I really do feel the commitment, hardwork, and love.  I also raise my glass to Dean, and his support staff, for taking such good care of us, and for making it an unforgettable night.

I will DEFINITELY be returning to try the other half of the menu!
author: Desiree V.

description: I loved this resturant! The back patio is fantastic and a great place to go on a date. everything we ordered was excellent. our waiter was very knowledgeable and offered great recommendations from the food to the wine. overall it was a great dinning experience. i would recommend the heirloom tomatoes, the scallops, the potato wrapped seabass and the risotto. all were absolutly excellent. i can not wait to eat here again!
author: Jenifer B.

description: Isa is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  Very consistent, flavorful small plates and good service.  It's classy and cozy at the same time.  Sit out in the back patio if you can.
author: Mitzi C.

description: I went here with some good family friends and I thought it was pretty good.  I love tapas, small plates, sharesies, etc. because you get to try so many more things.  I don't remember everything we ordered but I remember the scallops were done just right and the butterfish was phenomenal.  The service was great as well.
author: Katie M.

description: What happened??  This used to be one my favorite restaurants in the city.   We sat at the bar and ordered some oysters, the tuna tartare and the potato/corn soup.    All were meh.   The most dissapointing part of the experience was the service.   Did somebody's dog die?    The lazy attitude of the bartender was inexcusable.   I'll try this place again in a few years.  Hopefully they'll still be around.
author: Fred X.

description: Great food and friendly service. I love taking people visiting from out of town here. Isa suggests ordering tapas making it ideal it ideal for groups. I think in my few visits I've tasted about 2/5 of dishes and have like everything. Defiantly worth a visit.
author: Charlie C.

description: i hardly ever post reviews, unless i'm truly very satisfied or truly touched by a certain business.. so i was thinking of making a reservation for a relatively big party for my bday and i was calling around very last minute to see which restaurants would accommodate.. i've been to isa a couple times already and remembered how much i loved the food, ambiance, and services.. so after calling and leaving my name with isa, the owner reached out to me and was incredibly nice and provided great customer service.. if you're looking for an amazing dining experience, put isa on your list!! i promise it won't disappoint!!
author: maki i.

description: I enjoyed the ambiance and our waiter was very friendly.  He accidentally spilled my wine, but made up for it by topping off each of our glasses.  I thought the sea bass was a little overcooked, but I enjoyed the other dishes very much -- tuna tartare, foie gras, roast chicken, and the truffled risotto, all very good.  Will have to return for the desserts.  I chose this restaurant, thanks to Yelp!
author: Yasmine G.

description:
food was really good...i guess the one star downgrade was because it's coooooold in the back...brrrrrrrr!  maybe a couple more of those heaters?  maybe that's a ploy to get you drink more until you're numb or at least order some soup?  well, it's 2008, and i'm sure you all can figure something out.  it's SF for chrissssakes!  it's gonna be cold...trust me!

the lobster broth was good...maybe a tad bit salty, but good.  my dining companion liked the hamachi.  risotto was cheezy and tasty.  dayboat scallops were good....i mean if you're gonna add bacon, how am i going to resist that?  my favorite was the chicken though...the skin was crispy, they must have also rubbed some herbs under the skin or they bred some chickens that are naturally coated with herbs beneath their skin...

overall, a very satisfying meal....
author: Miss P.

description: I finally returned to Isa this week  . . . and I am so glad I did!  I remembered liking it in the past, but forgot just how great it is!  My dinner there really couldn't have been any better!
author: Rachel T.

description: We ate here for my birthday dinner and what a wonderful present to me (and my friends) (and our tastebuds)!  We did small plates and seriously ordered 3/4 of the menu.  Everything, EVERYTHING was delicious.  I recommend the pate, the scallops, the butterfish!!!!  Nothing is to be skipped, except possibly the outdoor seating if you're highly sensitive to extreme temperatures (heating lamp is too hot, not being near it is too cold).  Hopefully, you can withstand the weather bc sitting al fresco with the Christmas lights and sheer tented roof is truly a treat.
author: La A.

description:
Every single thing I wanted to order kept running out. Hey can I get item 1? Nope, sold out. How about item 2? yeah we're out of that too. Jesus Christ I know food is expensive since the world is coming to an end, but stop telling me that you have all this great looking food if I can't eat it.

Aside from that, the food I did get to eat (which wasn't very much) was pretty good. I really had the urge to beat everyone in this restaurant up immediately after walking in the door, probably because I hate the Marina with a passion. Place is expensive for what you get.

Worth going to once, I suppose.
author: Alexis C.

description: way too few waiters, very squished tables, fish too salty,  but other than that it was good.
author: Barbara W.

description: the service was fabulous, food was behind delicious and the restaurant manager was soooooooooooo friendly! love love love this place. highly recommend it! we went there for the dine about town and had crab salad, mussels and salmon for appetizers... all very tasty! for main course, we had duck breasts (the best i have ever had and everyone should try this), halibut and scallop. for dessert, grapefruit shaved ice, vanilla bean gelato and creme brulee. definitely worth the 2 hr drive (traffic was bad in SF).
author: Jennifer H.

description: Love this place!  Sitting outside under the twinkle-lit tent, dining on great small plates (the calamari is to die for) and sipping fantastic wine -- this place can't be better!  Make reservations as it gets packed and can have a wait beyond one hour on the weekends.
author: Katie P.

description:
Went to Isa on a Tuesday night...and it was packed...now that's a sign of a good restaurant....the staff was friendly ,the hostess was able to squish us in even though we were over a half hour late for our reservation, (the waiter was nice but overly shy and not so helpful in the wine selection process)... everything on the menu looked good...my favorites were the oysters (great sauce), Potato wrapped sea bass, the risotto and the pea shoots. The special of the day was a little disappointing.... but overall great food, ambiance (love the outdoor patio and heat lamps =) !) and service...
they have a prixe fixe menu on the weekdays: 2 courses for $19.95 which wouldn't be bad for a yummy affordable weekday dinner out!
author: Joy Y.

description: The Marina always sets me up for false expectations.  The crowd at this busy Steiner Street eatery was much older than I'd expected for a Saturday night, but the back tented dining room was quaint, charming and more lively.  The service was pretty good (minus a somewhat dingy hostess) and the small plate menu wasn't lacking--though they were out of several popular items by the time we got seated at 9:05 (with reservations at 8:30).  We got the last butter lettuce salad, but it was worth it, having begged for whatever portions they had left. The seabass is a must, as is the goat cheese appetizer. The most unique dish was the.  The wine list was also quite impressive.
author: Jojo W.

description: My friends and I came to this restaurant to celebrate my B-day.  I thought the food was excellent!  We were able to do share plates and everyone all walked away with full stomachs.  The price was actually pretty good too...for 13 people we were able to walk away with a good bill!  Seared Grade A Foie Gras, Roasted Lamb Tenderloin and Maple Leaf Duck Breast were all yummlicious!
author: JenJen W.

description: I am a huge fan of this place. The outdoor patio is a must. I loved everything we ordered...especially the warm goat cheese, sea bass and shrimp. The service was excellent.
author: A D.

description:
online the food looks great, and atmosphere fun- this is where I part ways with the online, versus reality.  

My girlfriend and I were excited to be able to get a reservation for two at 8:30 when we called a few hours before on a Friday.  We arrived right after two other couples and were seated at a tiny table for two , in a tight squeeze right between the other couples.  It was like we were having a triple date with people we didn't know, or want to talk to.  It was awkward how much of everyone's conversation we over heard (the couple to my right was arguing about how much they were going to spend per head at their upcoming wedding... they left early wrapping up untouched food and left a half bottle of $50 wine!).  To my girlfriend's right was a woman who was loud and annoying b/c she spoke so loud over the din of the room.

OK, so the waiter was French or something and carried a bit of an attitude for no reason,   I wanted the foie gras and my girlfriend inquired about the wine pairing that was suggested on the menu for her first drink.  The waiter said that was a dessert wine, as though she was supposed to know that... Well why is a dessert wine paired with an appetizer! A-Hole! 
(sorry)
As she went to look for something else to drink, he was pretty unhelpful with the wine list.  He ended up suggesting something she didn't like- and I got stuck with it.

FOOD:  The asparagus soup was really good, light and with a citrus zest in the undertones.  The foie gras was AMAZING!  the brioche and accompanying white peaches made for one of the better foie gras dishes we have tried.  I ordered the the butterfish which was baked with  shitaki mushrooms- it was light, flavorful and also quite good.  Nothing fancy, but a simply, flavor-filled dish that was light.  My girlfriend ordered the duck.  At first bite it was the sauce overwhelmed the flavor of the duck, but in a really good way.  But as the sauce dissipated  you could taste that the duck was slightly over cooked and it left a gammie taste.  Dessert was creme Brulee- nothing special at all, rather flat and cold as ice in the center- booooo.

IN THE END:
when all was said and done, the food was good enough, but nothing like what I expected.  The atmosphere was too loud, i felt a bit like a sardine in a nosy room with no music.  The check didn't bother me, but I was ready to go once the dessert was half done.  I would go back to give it another try, but no time soon- too many other places to try!
author: Don D.

description:
french bread with unsalted butter was an endless loaf, and fresh out of their ovens. gets all that saliva flowing like a flooded river

arugula salad was ok. it comes in a nice stack like gardeners sometimes make with grass on their brown canvas bags.  i should have tried the butter lettuce but didnt feel like salad at the time

calamari-personally i like calamari to be breaded, that way it doesnt look like what i see when i dive. these were babies, and they came with beans and some others stuff, these were so good and would recommend you skip unless you really like squid. also we got their asparagus special which had the same beans so maybe thats why it wasnt as good

the asparagus spears were very well done, and nice and fat. the sauce stuff it came in went very well with it.

the potato wrapped seabass with brown sugar sauce was awesomness as barney stinson would say. make sure to get this, as apparently it was on hiatus for like 5 years??? at least it comes wrapped warm in a potato blanket.

the flat iron steak with the mustard sauce and potatoes was pretty good too, the cut of meat was superb and was as soft as a filet maybe softer! the round little slices of potatoes were also equally excellent

the chicken, i forgot what it was called had some sauce on the inside of the skin and was moist and juicy and perfectly flavored. it came with mashed potatoes

halibut was also well done. whatever seasoning they used i wish i had in my own kitchen for when i cook it because it was perfect. this came with zucchini and something else on the side.

all this was sufficient for 6 people.

this restaurants staff is the epitome of service. esp guy, with the salt/pepper shoulder length hair

will definitely come back
author: Porkers T.

description: Service is great, ambiance is perfect. If you are offered a seat in the back porch, take it it's so cozy. I would come back here just for the truffle risotto and the asparagus. The rocky jr. range chicken is good too but the vanilla gelato was totally frozen and the biscotti hard has rocks. We were so full on our meal though that we didn't mind the mediocre dessert. Again, I'd go back just for the truffle risotto.
author: S K.

description: My favorite restaruant in the Chestnut St. area.  I was first a fan of Lux before I ever went to Isa.  Then when Lux closed, I decided to give it a shot being it's run by the same people.  Was not disappointed and have now been numerous times!  I recommend the spicy tuna tartare, potato wrapped sea bass, truffled risotto, and the halibut when they have it.
author: Tom E.

description: Please go here.  You will NOT regret it.  I loved everything we ordered. YUM!!!!!!!!
author: Aileen D.

description: There are currently 128 reviews for Isa (soon, one more)...and the average score is 4.5 stars.  There is a very good reason for the stellar rating.  You can read all 128 reviews if you'd like...or simply go and find out how good it is for yourself!
author: Allison K.

description:
5 for the night we had.

just sit at jackie's (aka non-squeaky betty boop isotope)  "magic" table, which ends in a shower of free muscato, and you will understand. 

i will tell you it's on the patio, but only the force will get you there. had an awesome weekend vibe for a wednesday night.
author: Chelsea B.

description: "Good vegetarian selection but not really good on meats. OK."
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Well, I guess everything good that can be said about this place has already been said.  The only bad part is it's hard to get a reservation if you're a last minute slacker like me.
author: Ricky S.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed our dinner here last night. The $5 cocktails/wine before 7 pm (everyday) was a nice surprise; we ordered both the Riesling and the soju mojito and both were excellent. We ordered the dungeness crab salad, but I don't know if the grapefruit complemented the seafood flavor very well. The salmon carpaccio was refreshingly tasty. We also split the asparagus soup which was smooth and delicious with just a hint of mint (?).  For entrees, we ordered the halibut, which was a little more raw in the center than we'd like, but it had a nice sear topped with perfectly cooked  and seasoned green beans and  sweet fresh corn. I decided to order the pan seared chicken, which had a  nice layer of herbs stuffed under a succulent crispy skin. I like white meat, so I expected the breast to be a little dry, however the pan sauce it comes with definitely compensated, as did the ultra creamy mashed potatoes. We ended by splitting the flourless chocolate cake with gelato--not as dense and rich as others I've tried; not bad, just  reminded me more of a very airy souffle, actually.  

Attentive service, sleek ambiance, unpretentious crowd of all ages, good value.
author: Jen S.

description: This place is great its always packed, the food is top notch very well done.  The dungeness crab salad is simple yet done very well with the grapefruit, apple and crabmeat at the same time it's very fresh.  The Foie gras was also very nice wish it had more bread that came with it because of the richness of the it.  Rack of lamb also was juicy, flavorful.  The flourless chocolate cake was also fluffy and a good way to finish off a great meal.
author: Stevezee C.

description: The food was good but not worthy of five stars. I particularly enjoyed the mussels, scallops, tartare, and potato wrapped sea bass. We got a bottle of the Rioja which wasn't bad especially for the price. Isa was full but not packed and we were seated as soon as we walked in. The outside patio at Isa was cozy and relaxing.
author: Deepak J.

description: i threw a birthday party here and they were amazing. excellent food, service and special attention for the birthday boy! i love this place!!
author: Annie W.

description: Small plates, big taste, tres hip. French tapas meets California meets the Marina - egggcellent menu. Sheik deco inside, but sit out back if you can, esp. at night. Heat lamps, tree lights, a smattering of foliage here and there...escape from the city, if only for a moment. Nice place to take your time. And definitely commit to a full bottle of wine - it will help when the bill comes. A great date spot.
author: Christopher S.

description:
A friend recommended we try Isa since we were staying close-by at Hotel Del Sol.  
We had a 9pm reservation, but arrived a good hour early- 
They were very busy, but managed to seat us by 830pm.
Between the 3 of us, we ordered 5 dishes, and they were all delicious.
Service was excellent. We brought our own wine, but they have a very nice wine selection too.
We will definitely go back!
author: Farah R.

description:
my review is kind of mixed:

Food was really good in French standard, but the atmosphere i rather loud and not so intimate, in French standards.

Our waiter was not so attentive nor friendly but other people we dealt with that night definitely were.

Apart from that the restaurant serves food family style which is interesting  and one must remember that parking is rather difficult to find in the area.

So I would call it a ok/good French fusion place.
author: Laurent C.

description:
+ Great food, 
+ Great wine list
+ Excellent service and nice people.
+ I really like the back patio covered with a tent
+ I will be back!
author: Hal B.

description:
My good friend brought me here for a birthday dinner.  The place is small and cozy.  When asked how much we should order for 2 people, they suggested that we should order 2 plates per person.  All the food portion was small, but it was enough for both of us.  We ordered:

1) Half dozen of oysters - Good, but very small
2) Crab Salad - Love the mango in there, but it was only OK.
3) Lobster soup - Love love love it!  it was sooooo good that we asked for bread refills 3 times!  
4)  Halibut special - The corn made this dish yummy!
5) Scallop Special - Scallops were not huge (like we thought it was).  There was only 4 scallops and 4 asparagus.  it was good, but a small dish.  
6) Mojito - Love this drink here!  It was small, but it was only $5 due to happy hour.  
7) Riesling Wine - Wine was pretty good and also $5 due to happy hour.  

Overall, I would go back for the lobster soup and mojito!
author: Linda H.

description: The foie gras was definitely the highlight of my meal - the texture was amazing and the poached bartlett pear was a nice complement.  Also tried the steamed mussels, seared Dayboat scallops, crushed truffle risotto, and the vanilla creme brulee - all very good choices.  There's a lot to try here, so I will be back.
author: Mark K.

description: Excellent small plates with very few misses. The outdoor seating is certainly great when the weather is great but can also be good in lousy weather so always consider it. Isa is also behind the newer Lux which is several blocks away on Chestnut. Grab a glass of wine at Nectar while you wait.
author: Patrick B.

description: I found Nirvana in Isa! I found parking on a Friday night three doors down from Isa so how could I pass up the opportunity to try out this place? I had read a review about their veal sweetbreads and because these are so difficult to find prepared properly I had to give them a try. The parking spot was an omen of good things to come.  I started out with the crab, avocado and grapefruit salad which was a star in it's own right and then was completely swept off my feet by the sweetbreads!  These were the best I have eaten anywhere and will be an excuse for more visits to this marvelous restaurant. Raul was a great waiter, offering input and suggestions as required without being overbearing or condescending. I will recommend Isa to anyone I think would appreciate fine cuisine.
author: Diane S.

description:
4.5 

great food, great service, too loud!!

everything was good, even down to side veggies I would never think to order, like plain corn.  Bursts in your mouth and perfectly sweet! 

careful, it's good. you'll end up ordering too much and wanting to puke!
author: Hannah W.

description:
Excellent food and service.

But dammmn, watch out for the other patrons!  My girlfriends and I got in a war about the heat lamp with the male counterpart of the couple next to us.  After turning it up and down a few times, he declared he had jurisdiction over the lamp because "I'm spending more money than you guys are tonight."  

The waiter came to break up the fight that ensued and gave us a free dessert after the other couple left to soothe wounds.  

Good times.
author: S. H.

description: ya i should probably give it 5 stars....When i go here I gorge myself on foie gras and sweetbreads... not to mention the 2-3 bottles of wine. I think i hold the record of ordering 3 fois grass orders in one sitting. whatever...If i am going to eat the liver of a stuffed goose...i can enjoy the thymus, pancreas of the some calf.
author: J B.

description: absolutely horrific service.  food was decent/average, not overwhelming.  had reservations for a table for a party of 4 for a nice table.  we got stuffed in the bar area which was noisy and cramped.  waiter passed us up multiple times when we tried to order. very arrogant and rude staff.  not worth the price of admission. nobody seems to care.  must be nice to have so much business you can treat your customers so poorly.  apparently under new management who reaked of insincerity.  many other restaurants in town offering better food, better service, and at a more reasonable price.  will never go back.
author: peter k.

description: The Lobster broth is the best soup I ever had!!!  The food is very delicious at Isa!  Though small plactes. but very authentic, and fusion.  The atmosphere is also good for little gathering.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I decided to go to Isa last minute with some friends for SF Dine about Town.  I rarely ever hang out in the Marina so I figured it was about time I checked it out.  

We (a party of 4) were seated promptly for our 7:30 reservation.  Our waiter was very attentive and kept the water and bread refilled.  

Each of us ordered off of the special Dine about Town menu.  I chose the tuna and avocado tartar and the maple leaf duck breast.  For dessert, I had the creme brulee.  Each dish was well done and smelled delicious.  The one dish that smelled even better than mine was the seared scallops with asparagus and truffle mash potatoes.  Other dishes that didn't disappoint were the lobster Bouillabaisse and the goat cheese dish.  However, I heard that the flank steak was cut a little too think, which made it tough to chew and the sauce was too salty.

The total with tax and tip came out to about $46 per person.  Pricey, but at least it was tasty.  There is nothing worse than paying a lot and getting nothing for my bucks.  It makes me mad.
author: Michelle Y.

description: This place was wonderful on so many levels. A friend had wanted to celebrate his birthday in this restaurant, and we didn't realize how much of a treat we are all in for. The staff is super professional, especially the waiter that suggested how we should approach the menu. The meal itself was on the expensive side, however, worth every penny. We had a group of 10 people and had shared our plates family style so we got to try out all the different dishes. Delicious!!!! The ambiance in the back of the restaurant was admired by the entire group. I would definitely patronize this restaurant again at some point in the future. Enjoy!
author: Adiv S.

description: Excellent food.  Friendly and attentive staff.  All our items were cooked and served perfectly: Yellowfin tuna, Smooth Corn soup, Potato wrapped Seabass, Roasted rack of lamb.  For desert, we had the Vanilla bean crème brulée which was the best crème brulée we have ever had.  Make reservations and try to get the patio.
author: Jeff G.

description: This is my second time to Isa and I enjoyed my second time as much as my first time!   Smaller portions, meant for sharing, but food is FANTASTIC!  Must try the tuna crudo, the scallops, the steak, the lamb, the gulf prawns, and the mussels.   I didnt try the oysters, but I heard they were good as well.  Salad was just ok--I think the arugula was better than the endive and pear salad.  This is a must try!!!  You wont' be disappointed!
author: Liana W.

description: I have only been in charge of one bachelorette party - (luckily!) and decided to kick off the festivities at Isa. They were very accommodating, friendly and attentive. We had a great time and devoured the food! I have been here many times and always have a great experience. The patio is charming and wonderful for a first or any number date. I would highly recommend.
author: Megan M.

description:
I would give the food a 5-start rating, but service, atmosphere and the inability to talk, because it was so loud  really dampened the experience.

The seating was cramped and we felt rushed into finishing one dish before the next showed up. No water service and constantly changing waiters made it a bit impersonal. 

We ordered the special - prawns with truffle sauce, short ribs and duck after our salad starters: butter and tomato salads. All dishes were delicious and made you crave for more...more...more. Short ribs were our favorites!

We finished up with Creme Brule and Vanilla bean gelato. The gelato was nothing to write about. Creme Brule was great though.
author: Inka t.

description: Wonderful food, personal attention from the owners and a cozy atmosphere.    I prefer the back "outside" patio (it barely seems like it is outside) to the front section of the restaurant.  Be sure to try the hangar beef.
author: lisa g.

description:
the fred segal font drew us in...and the outdoor patio with little lights and trees and heat lamps charmed us to stay.

we had a birthday and an engagement announcement to celebrate - and Isa was perfect.  made us feel like we were in some sweet european restuarant (didn't hurt that our waiter had an accent).

and then the flavorfest began. for three women, our waiter suggested 7 share plates (but we think 5 would've been perfect).  we had the heirloom tomato salad - and these were the best tomatos to enter my mouth.  then the halibut - with an explosion of deep red beets, oranges and champagne.  divinely colorful and delish.  then the steak (my least fave - but still yummy).  then the chicken with an herbed crust w/ mashed potatoes.  how did they get so much flavor in there???  fabulous!!  then we had the mixed veggie medly (fine) and the pasta (i can't recall the name - but though it looked totally unassuming - it was so good that even though we were already full and forgot we had even ordered it....we devoured every last tasty bite).

oh how i adored this entire experience!!  what i'm wondering:  is friday to soon to go again???
author: Kate F.

description: Great small plates place in the Marina....was here with a girlfriend, and between the two of us we were able to sample (and share) 7-8 dishes without feeling like little piglets. The foie gras was amazing. The back patio was nice and pleasantly warm with the heat lamps. Our server was also quite pleasant and made some good recommendations for wines by the glass to accompany our food. Will definitely return.
author: Suepattra M.

description: I honestly haven't dined here in a while and I don't know why cause I really like this place. I have never sat outside but inside it's has a nice, dim, romantic atmosphere. Service has always been good. The one thing that really stands out is the leak & potato soup. You definitely have to try it!
author: Diane M.

description: Had dinner the second time with my girlfriend to celebrate "the day" before Valentines day. The foie gras is still very good and consistent. I am usually not a fan of internal organs, but I didn't know seared foie gras would taste this good. For entree I had the veal sweetbread, which I mistakened it for the veal meat so I had unrealistic expectation about its taste. I would recommend sitting at the back of the restaurant for a more cozy atmosphere, and get dinner here on a weekday for a better bargain with the fix price menu.
author: Chuck W.

description: Appetizers were good.  Main courses were just okay.  I'd definitely come back here but I would only get appetizers.
author: Andrew K.

description:
We used to live down the street from here and went once for dinner, had great food, and never went back. For the life of me I couldn't tell you why, as we went back to places where we weren't wild about the food. I'm thinking it's because it's not casual enough to be a neighborhood regular but maybe not nice enough to feel like a special date night? Not really sure!
Anyway went Friday night. We couldn't think of anywhere to go, they had availability on Opentable, so I looked up their menu and it sounded appealing. From when we got there it was a bit of a nightmare. We had thought, we'll get there a little early and check in for our reso - if they have room for us we'll sit down early and if not we'll have a drink at the bar or at a nearby wine bar. It was PACKED, and with people that were a bit rude and annoying - the kind that shove you without saying "excuse me" and that try to cram up next to you at the hostess stand to make sure they get to talk to you next - it won't get them seated any earlier!!! At least we managed to squeeze up to the bar and get a glass of wine. The hostess was so swamped she spoke to us in three- or four-word phrases. "You have a reservation?" Exits. "We'll seat you." Walks away. We realize that time she meant for us to follow.
The experience didn't improve all that much with the waiter - he asked if we wanted sparkling water, which we did, but he brought flat. He let us know that our appetizers and entrees wouldn't come at the same time, their kitchen is small so things come out when they're ready - which I understand for a group but seems odd for 2 people?
But. The food was awesome. I was so happy with my meal - the lobster broth and the crispy skin chicken, amazing. And my husband loved his warm goat cheese starter and steak. The menu also seemed to have something for everyone - a lot of the choices sounded appealing to me - a salmon tartare, a baked Butterfish entree, those I definitely want to try on future visits. And if you'd been out drinking the vibe in there might be kind of fun. And the back patio looked awesome.
I think we'll definitely be back this time, if only for that chicken - but now I'm kind of thinking maybe the service was why we didn't come back the first time. Something about the experience must have left a bad taste in our mouths that we just don't remember. But I don't think we'll let it stop us this time. As long as you know what you're walking into, the food is fantastic. Oh - and with how close the tables are together - if you like listening in on other people's conversations, this is your spot! :-)
author: Sarah R.

description: What a cute little place!  Love the back covered patio - very good ambience.... I was here for a work dinner, but it was fun anyway!!!  We didn't really do the sharing thing because a lot of people orderd off the Prix Fix, and well, because a lot of the dishes didn't seem like they really lended themselves to sharing.  So I got to be selfish!!!  I started with the Dungeness Crab Salad - it was really really good, with mango, grapefruit and arugula.  Then I had the baked butterfish, it was also very good, maybe a little mild for my taste.  Then the creme brulee for dessert - yum!  It was a great meal in a fun, non-pretentious setting.  I'll be back!
author: A B.

description: So I don't understand why they only had 1 very frazzled woman working the front of the house on a very busy Saturday night. It's a pet peeve when I don't get seated within 15 minutes of my reservation. Especially when I'm starving. But the amazing food and great service (once we were seated) made up for it. I really enjoyed the ambiance of the back patio area. My friends and I agreed that it felt like a wedding reception. The chicken, halibut and goat cheese were especially memorable. Great for groups and good times.
author: Kristen D.

description: This is a cute lil restaurant with pretty good food right in the Marina.  To start the Cab Franc that I started with was quite nice albeit a bit cold.  Then once we sat down we saw how great the service was.  Really attentive and ready to give their opinion on the dishes.  Highlights of the night were a "divine" risotto, the crispy chicken and the duck!  Also the Bonny Doon (I believe that's what it was called) was a great to cap off dessert!
author: Swarup B.

description:
This place in the Marina is a great find. 
Food-There was four of us and even though they say the menu should be 2/person, you can definitely do 1.5/person and its more than enough. We go the scallops (3.5 stars) grilled calamari (5 stars) really delicious with interesting spices like star anise, dungenes crab salad (4.5) amazing flavors and best crab I've had in a long time, sweet bread-my husband loved this, but i can't really take a plate full of it, and heirloom salad (3 stars). Overall what makes the restaurant great are it's ingredients. Everything was fresh, delicious, and inventive. Wine list was amazing, so many wines under $50! 
Decor- 3 stars 
Service- 3.5 stars 
Definitely a place I will revisit. Good for groups, dates, or a casual/upscale dinner.
author: Setita E.

description:
Great pre-fixe menu! $24 pp for a 2 course meal! Can't beat that!

We ordered the mussels and the goat cheese (which is awesome spread on their bread!) for appetizers. We shared the sole and risotto for the entree! The risotto rocked! I thought the sole was missing something.

Also good to know...they have $5 glasses of wine and soju cocktails until 7:00 PM. What a bargain!

Would definitely go back!
author: Pam W.

description: Very basic seasoning with sloppy presentation and sub-par ambiance. The only attractive concept about the restaurant is that the plates are designed to be shared between everyone at the table and thus ideal for a friendly gathering... other than that the dishes were not creative at all, and many of the items (especially deserts) are not even made in-house.
author: Alex A.

description: One of the best in Marina. Love the medium size dish meant for sharing. Everything i have tried there turned out to be really good! Don't miss the seabass, foie gras, and the duck. I am sure there are a lot other good ones, but i have always sticked with the couple of my favorites! Any recommendations?
author: Angela H.

description: Great food.  There aren't a whole lot of restaurants out there that I would prefer to go again, but this is definitely on my list.  Small plates allow you to try a variety of delicious dishes.  The ambience is also quaint and nice.
author: Clarence K.

description: Went to Isa for the third time last weekend and was a little disappointed.  The foie gras was still amazing, but everything else just seemed okay compared to the last two times I went.  I'd recommend the chicken too, but the chocolate cake was worth skipping.  Hope I just went on an off night!
author: l c.

description: Isa is absolutely delightful!  I like to think of it as a french tapas place.  The quality of the food is so fresh and tasty; and the prices are low!  You definitely have to have a reservation, or you'll be waiting an hour and half or so.  Parking is scarce.  All and all, a great place to eat, for a first date, or hanging out with friends.
author: Mai A.

description: Very yummy.  Leans towards the pricey side, but perfect for celebrating a momentous occasion....or for just a splurge of a night out.   They have a patio out back that is covered in cold weather - the heat lamps keep it pretty warm.  The spicy tuna tartare was excellent, as well as the seared scallops - melt in your mouth.
author: Angela T.

description: You can't go wrong with a dinner at Isa's -- perfect for a romantic evening (request a table in the back patio area).  Try the free range chicken: it's surprisingly delicious.  The dungeness crab salad was extremely tasty.  I hear there is an early bird pre fixe menu before 7pm?  I'm totally there!
author: Lisa C.

description: Too much to choose from on the menu. Everything looked good. We started with their tuna tartare served on top of a bed of avocado and pine nuts, then moved to the potato crusted sea bass, and garlic pea shoots, then were served the foie gras with a brioche and white peaches. This combination was more dessert like than typical foie gras due to the sweetness of the brioche and the peaches. Wanted to try the duck, lamb and the nightly special, quail. If you can get a table on the covered patio. Can't wait to go back and try the other small plates. The plates come out in the order they are listed on the menu which isn't segregated aside from the few appetizers. Didn't have room for dessert but the passion fruit soup with mango would probably be really refreshing on a summer night.
author: Rob H.

description: Food was excellent but it was a little too noisy inside. Maybe the outdoor patio is better. I like the small dishes because you can try just about everything on the menu with just a party of four. 5 sexy stars for service! Our waiter was extremely attentive and gave us great recommendations.
author: Susan L.

description: Isa gets a pretty good rating in my book.  The food was varied - some interesting options, but I'll be honest when I say that it didn't WOW me.  A number of typical small plates, bursting with flavor, and a couple with a glimer of creativity.  The thing that knocked this up from 3 stars to 4 was the service.  Our server was funny, attentive, and very nice.  Overall - a good experience, a 15-20 minute wait on our reservation with no appology rubbed me the wrong way, but the service had me smiling by the time I left.
author: Jared F.

description:
At 4:30 on a Saturday (a holiday weekend, no less), my sister and I decided that she should treat O. and me to a special dinner that night. Jumping at the opportunity to partake in great dining at another's expense, I cracked open my laptop and got to searching for a place that would be special yet marginally affordable. I came across Isa, a French-Contemporary restaurant that welcomed us.
Inside the restaurant, one is greeted with sounds of conversation, hues of red, and warm, delicious aromas. To my sister and me, anyway-- O.'s disdain for anything from the sea got him apprehensive about the place, as there was a faint smell of fish going around (their halibut is popular, is the only way I could ease my thoughts). That unpleasant tidbit aside, the atmosphere is vibrant and congenial but at the same time sophisticated. We were seated immediately after checking in, which was impressive given that we had come in fifteen minutes past the time I had reserved.
Once seated, our waiter, who was personable and consummately attentive, placed our menus on the table and got our drinks started. He explained to us how Isa serves up their entrees family-style. We took this to mean that the portions would be large and beamed at the pleasant surprise.
Once seated, I was disappointed to find an utter lack of the potato-wrapped halibut promised as Isa's specialty on its website, which was what I had used to lure my sister to this place. Discouraged but optimistic, we ordered the halibut nonetheless, with capers, artichokes, and zucchini. We also tried the spaghetti with crushed black truffles in a basil-tomato broth ($13.50) and the mushroom risotto ($15.50), and for the appetizers an heirloom tomato salad ($8.50) and leek and corn soup ($6 for one; $8.50 for two. Isa was kind enough to split the soups three ways).
We had the privilege of sitting by  the kitchen, which divides the front portion of the restaurant (where we were) from the back (more formal, but we were looking for casual), where we could see the finishing touches put on all of the plates. The kitchen seemed to operate smoothly throughout the night, evidenced by the rate at which the food came to our table. Before and in between dishes, our basket was refilled with delicious, piping-hot bread (not sourdough!).
First came the soup. The sweetness and robustness of corn was fully captured and the fragrance from the leek brightened this wonderful dish. However, this brought up the one theme that played consistently throughout the night: a lack of salt in the dishes, a caveat that may perhaps be unnecessary to most who don't like as much of it, but I was alarmed at how seriously this soup was lacking in sodium. As part of the decor Isa puts out a small wooden dipping bowl filled with sea salt at every table. I dressed my soup with much of it and sprinkled a smidge onto the heirloom tomato salad, which would have been spectacular even without the extra touch of salt. They were the sweetest tomatoes I had ever tasted, enhanced by the balsamic and offset by the tangy feta and peppery arugula.
Remembering our waiter's claim that everything was served family-style, we stopped for a minute to look at the tiny plate before us. But the heady aroma of the basil soon took over, and we were able to ignore the size of the dish to rather just enjoy its flavors.
I think the spaghetti, aside from the tomatoes, was my favorite. The pasta was perfectly al dente, something that I can never achieve myself (I always tend to go under). The truffles were not applied too liberally so as to be obnoxious, and I had never had them served any other way than shaved, which was an interesting experience. The basil tomato broth at the bottom was light and fragrant, salted and thickened slightly by parmigiano reggiano. A heavenly combination, and surprisingly the plate turned out to hold more than we had originally thought.
O. winced and ate the last of the spaghetti as slowly as he could as my sister and I devoured the fish. It was cooked to perfect consistency, with a lovely, crisp crust, but I felt that, again, it was underseasoned and perhaps too fishy. Artichokes were soft and the capers were nice little balls of salty punch, but the zucchini, being undersalted, did little to enhance the dish.
The risotto was the most disappointing. It came goopy with bits of mushroom, which ranks at the top of my favorite foods. I could not, however, enjoy this dish. We expected a parmigiano garnish but the cheese was far too pungent to be so; it was probably pecorino. The extreme sharpness of the cheese against the blank slate of  the risotto was not a winning combination.
Despite what I said about the risotto and the fact that the food is undersalted, I loved Isa! The ambiance is spectacular; the service was truly exceptional; and the food, despite the lack of salt, packs in a flavorful punch. Just make sure to put the little wooden bowl to good use.
author: Nuri K.

description: Had the chicken here. It was really good. I also enjoyed sitting outside, it had a nice vibe to it.
author: Steve C.

description: Pleasant tented patio, share plates of thoughtful but simple California French. Veal sweetbreads superb.
author: chris o.

description: Everything here was tasty. Not really the type of place you come to fill an empty stomach, but as such, the prices are pretty reasonable which in turn allows you to taste a greater range of dishes. The back patio/tent is nice. I'd come here again.
author: Cristofer P.

description: Went here with a friend visiting from out of town and we had a great experience. Service was very attentive, didn't have problems getting a table on a Tuesday night, and would recommend the outdoor seating for ambience. Food was tasty and the bill wasn't unreasonable given we ordered 5 dishes and 2 desserts. Went with a friend, but definitely think it gets extra points as a date place as my friend was particularly fond of the 'cute little plates'.  :)
author: Allen S.

description: The food was "average'.. the atmosphere was a bit loud... we ended up (3 people) in this table made for two right by the window.  Problem was that it was very crammed.. and so tight in there we could hear our own voices echo.  The sea bass was so-so, it was borderline over cooked.  The fries we had were too stringy (if they could be called fries at all).  I was so uncomfortable in my seat, I could not focus on the food much.. and even then it was okay.  Parking was a bit of a pain.. but then again, it's the Marina.  Three stars overall.
author: Nancy H.

description: Probably my new favorite restaurant in the city!  We're big Chez Nous fans, but Isa is like Chez Nous with the food, service and decor turned up a notch (and better bread -- warm baguettes). Interesting, delicious, reasonably priced tapas-style dishes served family-style -- not really a place for hearty eaters, but the portions were perfect for the two of us (we ordered two dishes each, plus dessert). We loved the oysters, the sea bass wrapped in potato and we love love loved the fois gras. The service was fabulous; we plan to come back frequently!
author: Jan C.

description: Went here with a couple of my girlfriends and was plesantly surprised.  We were seated in the back of the restaurant, where the semi-outdoors feel was very romantic.  Their drinks menu was confined to wine and soju cocktails.  All the tapas dishes we ordered were very well prepared and enjoyable.  My only complaint that night was the service.  Our waitress that night started off a little condesending, but got better as the night went on, which was good because w had to wait a long time between plates.  I think we filled up more on bread than anything else that night.  Very cute date place, hoping my next experience will be a little better.
author: Chris Y.

description: Screw going to A16 with a rude hostess and annoying scene.  I did, and ended up at Isa for a comfortable yet sweet meal.  The back area has heat lamps as it is actually an outdoor deck (covered) but you wouldnt really know it.  Positioned as more family style sharing, the dishes are rich with flavor.  Foie gras was excellent.   Sauces with the dishes are very good.  Get a side of fresh sauteed spinach.   I would pass on the syrah (a bit too round for me), but the zinfindel was bigger and better.  Isa seems like it is a lesser known place since it doesn't have the "scene", and that is worth appreciating.
author: Ross W.

description:
I've been coming  here on and off over the years and have always enjoyed this place.  I come to satisfy my craving for foie gras without having to spend $$$ at a really fancy restaurant.  I like to come with several friends as you get to try more options.  This was the first time I sat inside - kind of bummed me out - the experience at Isa is all about sitting in the back room.  This time, us 3 girls had the:
-seabass crudo - fish was cut a lil thicker than usual carpaccio - providing a nice texture
-butter lettuce salad with bacon and bleu cheese - mmm,lots 'o bacon-one of the few things that  can get me to eat a salad
-foie gras with brioche - CAPITAL YUM!  though i always eat the peaches separately - i'm not much into sweets with my savory
-butterfish with truffles - truffles so aromatic and trumpet mushrroms so flavorful
-seafood paella - lots of seafood, not so much rice
-maple leaf duck breast - really good port sauce
-potato wrapped halibut - good texture with the crisp potato and saltiness of the capers
I really like this place - but the host could be a lttle warmer...last time i was there with a party of 12 and she wouldn't seat us until we ALL arrived- I think when a group of 10 has already shown up, it warrants getting seated rather than having us the wait area...
author: Amina B.

description:
really, it gets 3.75 stars, but the atmosphere threw me off too much.  My girlfriend and I walked in just after leaving frantic work days.  Isa missed the mark on taking you out of your daily routine.  The interior is not too inspired.  You dont really know where to stand or where the restaurant begins.  We were seated a little too close to the tables next to us.  The back room was bright and a little too DIY.  The Server, frenchy, was a little impatient and uninformative.  Like we shouldn't bother him with questions.  Oh, maybe the translation for server in french is...served?  nope, thats not what babelfish says.
The key:  they still get 4.5 stars for the food.
the little gem salad was flavorful, not overdressed. 
the corn and potato soup was not so heavy and had a nice contrast of flavors.  
the butterfish in paper was fantastic, with black truffles, chanterrelles and green beans. mm mmm good.  i think i give 4.5 stars for anything with black truffles.
the flank steak-fantastic- was well seasoned, the sauce was scrum-diddely-umptous. but the zucchini and potato on the plate were fairly bleh. not even blah, just bleh. shorter, less remarkable.  
they glaring disappointment was the flourless  chocolate cake, which sure seemed to have flour in it.  it was not too dense, and dried out.  \
now i see why m bauer took it off the top 100.  get some more courteous servers and an interior remodel from cass calder smith or whoever does the osha outposts, and you're back in it Mr Sung.  
O, and $92 for 4 small plates, 1 dessert, and 2 glasses of wine.  I'll take myth and coco500 a second time.
author: Christian W.

description: Isa is very good overall, but it has its flaws.  The carmelized dayboat scallops are to die for, but many dishes are merely pretty good.  The flat iron steak is also ridiculously delicious, though I felt like the specific preparation and level of quality is something I have had at other places.  Service is quite good, but certainly not on the level of a fine dining establishment.  I also felt the plates came out too quickly, as though they were trying to rush us so they could open up the table.  The price is definitely decent for the quality level.
author: Jes H.

description: This place is THE BEST!  We loved it the first time so we decided to take our parents. (There were 7 of us on a Monday night).  There is nothing bad to say: our server was so friendly and gave great suggestions on the food and wine. They know their stuff but do not act pretentious.  The timing of the dishes was perfect too -- the kitchen knows what they're doing!  It's a little bit pricey and the food is pretty rich, but worth it for a treat once in a while or a special occasion.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Amy H.

description: I came here with my girlfriend for her birthday...and we had an amazing night.  We arrived early for our reservation and they accommodated us no problem.  Then they took us out to their beautiful patio (which of course was heated).  We sat down and the service was pretty good, and the fixed menu full of delicious choices.   We shared our 4 tapas and were more than satisfied.   I highly recommend this place to anyone looking to try something new.
author: Daniel L.

description: Isa is a fabulous date restaurant! It's candle-lit, cozy, on a really pretty street, and all of the dishes are designed for sharing. Everything we had was fabulous, from the warm goat cheese, through the foie gras (I know, sorry Mr. Goose, your torture and eventual murder were most unfortunate but tasty!), and finally the truffle and mushroom risotto. We were pretty stuffed at that point, so I'm calling Isa a "medium plates" restaurant, and definitely giving it two thumbs up!
author: Will A.

description: Been here many many times..nothing had changed...exceptional mussels ,great food and good desserts BUT terrible parking!!
author: anny g.

description: Simply amazing. Had the salmon carpaccio, goat cheese, butter lettuce salad, sea bass, and fungi risotto. The Lodi syrah was a great accompaniment. Great date spot, or just for friends, can't wait to come back!!!
author: navid s.

description:
This place is really good. The portions are small but I didn't even care! The duck is so delicious.

I removed 1 star  because we were kept waiting for over an hour WITH reservations. apparently the party before us just wasn't leaving--- they had paid the check but still sat around to chit-chat and the waiters there did not want to tell them to leave. somehow, i think the situation should have been handled better than to keep us waiting for so long. In the end, they just led us to the table with the group before us still sitting there and said loudly, "here is your table" --- luckily, they got the picture and left, but we were SUPER hungry by then. 

i think they may have compensated us with an extra dessert or something for our wait. perhaps that's why my memory of this place is so pleasant!
author: chrissie s.

description:
maybe it's because it was valentine's day and they had only the prixe fix menu, but it was kind of hit-or-miss. salmon tartare was good but nothing memorable. crab salad was delicious.. except we found little bits of shell in it. goat cheese was excellent, as well as foie gras. but the real issue was the rack of lamb-- the waiter asked if medium rare was ok, but brought us a bloody piece that was still cold in the middle. only the edges were cooked. otherwise, the lamb was completely raw. i didn't want to make a scene and there was plenty of other food, so it was not sent back. we also had the truffled risotto: while the flavors were very good, the rice was undercooked and the grains were a little crunchy in the middle still.

overall they seemed to be in a hurry that night to get people on their way (maybe to free up tables?). they brought us dishes a little too fast. i would have liked to savor each course, but the next one would arrive when we were halfway through the previous. i didn't mind that too much except that it seemed a similar rushed attitude was taken in the preparation of the food-- undercooked, somewhat careless. i'd really like to try isa again on some other night.
author: Dana D.

description: Solid offerings. Potato wrapped seabass was tasty and not overcooked. The ribs were a good texture but not that flavorful. I prefer interesting sauces over textures.
author: Aiko S.

description: My friend and I stumbled upon Isa after a day of window shopping; it was the perfect place to end up.  She had a huge chicken dish and I ordered the mushroom risotto -- both were exceptionally delicious.  They cooked the risotto perfectly: creamy and soft but firm.  A solid cocktail menu (we had our usual mojito and lemon drop martini).  We enjoyed sitting at the bar, and we'll be back with a group to try more!
author: Anna R.

description: You know, I'm a pretty big sucker for trendy restaurants. I'm especially forgiving for a trendy restaurant with wonderful service. On first impression, this restaurant was not only not as trendy and cute as mamacita or bin 38 next door but extremely pretentious. However, things picked up nicely - we rapidly got drinks while we waited for our reservation, we were seated at an adorable table, and the entire wait staff was attentive. Food is meant to be shared and I suppose you could call it tapas-style. 4 dishes for a dinner for 2 is perfect. I strongly recommend the seared scallops with butternut squash, sweet potatoes, spinach, and bacon. BACON! who doesn't love a little bacon? The potato wrapped seabass was fantastic and the truffle risotto was served hot and mouth-watering. But be forewarned, the rack of lamb is NOT good. There's good lamb that has the appropriate amount of herbs and spices to cover up that gamey smell and then there's lamb that tastes WAY too much like lamb. Good thing creme brulee fixes everything. Creme brulee and a very large mojito....So overall, I'd say Isa was 3.5 stars and decent for a Saturday night dinner, but I bet the happy hour during the week could make it 4 stars.
author: Alisa A.

description:
Came here last night with a friend.  I noticed that a lot of the other reviews mentioned that parking was difficult, but we were able to snag a space less than 1/2 block away.  Is it just me, or has been parking been plentiful in SF lately?  I remember coming to SF for dinner on a Fri or Sat night and pulling into the first space you saw even if it was 8 blocks away because that might be the ONLY space you'll get.  But I digress.

My friend has been to Isa a few times and asked that we be seated in the back patio.  The back patio was really cute - very informal ambiance.  We were seated right under one of the heat lamps and it was HOT.  we asked the waiter to turn it down and he did so right away.

We ordered 5 dishes to share - mussels (divine), goat cheese, foie gras, scallops, and the risotto.  All of the food was delicious and we were stuffed.  The servers were very attentive, stopping by to check on us numerous times without being intrusive.

All in all, great good, great company, great service.  What more could you want from a meal?
author: Ling L.

description: Pleasantly surprised. Unfortunately I have to be in the Marina District to enjoy this restaurant.  But I have to say it's worth it. There are no surprises on this menu. It's pretty much got one of everything on any crowd-pleasing menu: the seared dayboat scallops, the flank steaks, the mushroom risotto, the tuna tartare, etc. But it was all real tasty. We had a waiter who was a spectacular salesmen and we were a little put-off that he sold us on a couple of sides of dauphenoise potatoes when one of the dishes came with the same thing.
